HEADLINE: New Mitsubishi U.S Plant

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala., April 18
<RE>Dow Jones

 BODY:
The Mitsubishi Materials Corporation of Japan will build a $130 million plant in Mobile, Ala., to make polysilicon, a material used to manufacture computer chips. Mitsubishi, a leading maker of metals and ceramics, said that the plant would supply primarily the United States market. The factory is expected to be completed in October 1997 and will eventually employ 150 workers.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Why the Allied Victory Was Not a Sure Thing

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

WHY THE ALLIES WON
By Richard Overy
Illustrated. 396 pages. W. W. Norton. $29.95.
 The Allies won World War II because, compared with the Germans, the Japanese and the Italians, they were bigger economically, they had more people and their cause was just. Indeed, looked at from the perspective of the past half-century, the combined power of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union inevitably had to prevail in World War II, even if the sacrifice, the cost and the time spent in doing so had to be enormous.
According to Richard Overy, it is true that greater size and greater population were indispensable elements in the Allied victory. But Mr. Overy, whose "Why the Allies Won" is a clear-sighted and very interesting explanation of the reasons for the victory, forcefully denies that there was anything inevitable about it. 
 Mr. Overy, a professor of modern history at King's College, London, and the author of several previous books on World War II, takes nothing for granted as he examines the question of victory from the ground up. Large powers have been defeated by smaller ones, he notes, even by technologically far less advanced ones (Vietnam over the United States, for example). Countries have fought multi-front wars and been victorious over adversaries that faaed enemies on one front only. And even in the case of World War II, the margin of victory was, Mr. Overy argues, precariously slender.
In showing why and how matters went as they did, Mr. Overy has written a learned, multifaceted piece of military history. With straightforward prose and an obvious command of the facts, he lays out the vast and complicated story of what the Soviet writer Ilya Ehrenberg aptly called "deep war," war that involved every aspect of the societies that fought it.
Some of Mr. Overy's conclusions are unsurprising: that the Soviet victories at Stalingrad and Kursk were the major turning points in the war, for example. But Mr. Overy also takes issue with some commonly accepted views: that the bombing of Germany was an ineffective element in the Allied victory, for example. Mr. Overy contends that it was a crucial element, because it caused the downing of numerous German planes and most of Germany's best pilots, which was essential in giving the Allies air supremacy for the Normandy landings.
Mr. Overy devotes separate chapters to each of the main theaters of the war, from the struggle for control of the oceans to what Mr. Overy calls "the moral contest," the advantage brought to the Allies by the moral defensibility of their struggle. ("In every theater of the war," Mr. Overy writes, "the language of liberation and resistance was directed against the Axis.") But Mr. Overy's starting point is the nearly forgotten fact that early on in the conflict, after the first huge and stunning victories of both the Germans and the Japanese, the odds seemed to favor the Axis.
"On the face of things," he writes, "no rational man in early 1942 would have guessed at the eventual outcome of the war." The Germans had needed only a few short weeks to smash Poland and France, and they seemed to be making short work of the far larger Russia. Japan had bombed Pearl Harbor, occupied half of China and taken all of the British, French and American possessions in Southeast Asia. In this sense, Mr. Overy says, "Allied victory represented a remarkable reversal of fortune."
The most conventional of Mr. Overy's explanations concerns the war in the Pacific, where he recounts once again the often-told tale of the American naval victory at the Battle of Midway. The lesson, given overwhelming Japanese superiority in the number of warships, has to do with superior technology and tactics. In the Atlantic, victory involved finding a way to defeat German U-boats, which were sinking supply vessels faster than they could be built. Here, the key had to do with the development of accurate radar and of very long-range aircraft equipped with it.
Two essential factors made the landings in France in 1944 successful, Mr. Overy says. One was Allied supremacy in the air. The other was deception, the creation of a decoy landing force in England that effectively kept the 20 divisions of the German 15th Army, commanded by the legendary Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, out of the battle. Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery, the Bpitish commander of the Normandy landings, told a subordinate that his "forces could well have been defeated, for all the Allies' advantages, if Rommel had been able to mount strong assaults from midday against forces still in a confused state on the beaches."
Mr. Overy uncovers some parodoxes, not the least of them that the Germans and the Japanese lost the war in part because of the very strength of their early victories. The Axis powers felt that they already had the correct formula, Mr. Overy argues, and they were therefore much less prone to alter their technology or their tactics as the situation changed. The Allies, by contrast, including even Stalin, understood that they had to correct many weaknesses. How, for example, did the Germans so quickly lose the overwhelming superiority they had in waging mechanized warfare? "The answer lay in imitation of German practice," Mr. Overy contends. "Given the extraordinary success of German arms, the Allied learning curve had to be short."
Among the most interesting of many interesting passages in "Why the Allies Won" are those examining the roles of the senior leaders. Hitler's early victories gave him a sense of infallibility that led him to try to manage the war from afar, often with disastrous consequences for the German armies. Stalin, contrary to the popular image of him, was more adaptable in this sense. He was a ruthless dictator who tried to command military action in the early phases of the war. But even though he bullied his subordinates so that "the threat of punishment or death hung over every mistake," Stalin learned to listen to his best commanders, most notably Georgi Zhukov.
"The victories at Stalingrad and Kursk were designed by military leaders, not by Stalin, who played a smaller role as the war went on," Mr. Overy writes. Hitler's role, by contrast, grew; and that, as Mr. Overy describes it, was an under appreciated element in his defeat.

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief Seeks World Bank Funds

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin appealed to Congress today for funds for the World Bank and other international financial institutions, saying United States participation in the lending agencies was at a crossroads.
He told lawmakers that United States credibility and leverage at the agencies had already been severely hurt by Republican-led cuts in contributions last year, at a time when Japan and Europe are aggressively trying to increase their influence. 
 In testimony to a House Appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Rubin said the Clinton Administration was trying to do more with less when it came to those institutions, but needed the help of Congress to achieve that.
The Administration is seeking Congressional backing for just under $1.48 billion for the multilateral lending agencies and debt reduction programs in the year starting Oct. 1.
But the proposal faces tough going with Republicans in Congress amid continuing efforts to cut the budget deficit.
Speaking to reporters on Wednesday ahead of his planned testimony, Mr. Rubin rejected suggestions for cuts in economic aid to Israel and Egypt to pay for United States contributions to the international financial institutions.
He said the money would help the United States press ahead with its efforts to reform the lending agencies.

HEADLINE: Stripped of Themes, Yeltsin Wraps Himself in Flag

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 18

 BODY:
In his embattled bid for re-election, President Boris N. Yeltsin has raised the red flag. Literally.
Bowing to the growing nationalism and nostalgia for Soviet power fueling the Russian presidential elections, Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree this week restoring the red banner, embossed with a gold star instead of the Communist hammer and sickle, as a national emblem. 
 From now on, a Soviet-style flag will be unfurled alongside the Russian tricolor at patriotic ceremonies -- a symbol of Russia's deep ambivalence over its post-Communist identity.
President Clinton arrived in Russia today for a summit meeting that was planned in part to bolster Mr. Yeltsin's prestige before the elections, and he will be tiptoeing through a radically changed political landscape.
Resentment and suspicion of the West, particularly the United States, have never been higher since the cold war ended. Mr. Yeltsin's main challenger, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, is seeking to reach beyond orthodox party members and capture the nationalist vote by reviving a common enemy. Mr. Zyuganov calls it "a planetary regime of political, economic and military dictatorship of the West, headed by the U.S.A."
In his meetings with Mr. Clinton and other leaders of industrialized nations gathering in Moscow for a meeting on nuclear issues, Mr. Yeltsin will use all the pomp he can muster to suggest to Russian voters that he is greeting them as the head of a still great power, and not as a needy supplicant turning to the West for political and financial support.
On the campaign trail, Mr. Yeltsin is not beating the nationalist movement, he is joining it. After Communists won the parliamentary elections in December, his Cabinet was purged of all advisers viewed as "Westernizers." His new Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, complains repeatedly that Russia has been too supine. Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Zyuganov are both courting the Russian Orthodox Church.
As he campaigns across the country, Mr. Yeltsin is competing for the same voters who are flirting with his Communist and nationalist opponents, promising to restore part of the social safety net that was torn when Communism collapsed and seeking to wrap himself in symbols, not of democracy, but of Russia's imperial past.
The presidential regiment, the honor guard that once goose-stepped in front of Lenin's tomb, now serves in the Kremlin. Last month its elite soldiers, selected for their Slavic blond looks and six-foot stature, were refitted with pre-revolutionary dress uniforms. Heavy on gold braid and peacock colors, the uniforms were designed by the Bolshoi Theater's costume designers and are meant to evoke the martial splendor of imperial Russia.
The West is now an obsessive topic in Russian politics, much in the way American candidates were once defined by their attitude toward Communism. Politicians of all stripes talk about the "specialness" of Russia, of its intrinsic incompatibility with Western models of democracy.
Figures as disparate as Mr. Zyuganov and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn use "sobornost" to describe the Russian condition. The word loosely translates as "spiritual unity" and connotes a collectivist mentality far removed from the individualism that drives people in the West.
It is a loaded phrase, conjuring the centuries-old battle between Westernizers and Slavophiles. That struggle still raged under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President, whose policy of perestroika divided liberal Westernizers within his circle from the hard-liners. In political discourse, if not always in practice, the Slavophiles have won.
Irreconcilable differences remain between Communists and nationalists. Many nationalists will never forgive the Bolsheviks for their original sin -- killing the Czar. Mr. Solzhenitsyn recently called for an international tribunal to try the Communist Party for crimes against humanity. He suggested Nuremberg as a site.
But Mr. Zyuganov, who in 1991 recognized the need to replace the bankrupt ideology of Communism, has won the endorsement of many nationalist groups.
He exploits Russians' shock over the loss of empire, their anxiety about economic and spiritual decline, the invasion of American pop culture. His campaign speeches are buttressed not by Marxist-Leninist dogma, but alarms about a Western conspiracy to enslave the Slavic spirit.
And such sentiments, expressed more sedately, can be found at every level of Russian society. "There is now a shameful policy of concession to the West in our country," said Aleksei Petrov, 25, a journalism student at Moscow State University. "Russia should lead a policy of revival -- its economy, military and all sides of life. I am very much against democracy." He said he planned to vote for Mr. Yeltsin.
American political analysts and politicians, who like many Russians view Mr. Yeltsin as the lesser evil, express bafflement that there is no stronger democratic alternative. The liberal economist Grigory A. Yavlinsky is feted in the West as Russia's brightest prospect. He is running, but his chances of becoming one of the two candidates who advance to the second round are dim.
"Democrats like Yavlinsky have as much chance today of getting elected in Russia as Gus Hall had of becoming President of the United States," said Leonid Dobrokhotov, a former Gorbachev adviser who now teaches Russian history at Richmond College in Virginia.
Once a liberal reformer within the Communist Party, he now supports Mr. Zyuganov. "We Soviets understood this, why can't Americans understand the political reality here?" he said.
Anti-Western sentiment, fanned by the likes of Mr. Zyuganov and the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, is proving fertile ground.
Campaigning in Krasnodar on Tuesday, Mr. Yeltsin was booed when he tried to defend his economic reform policies. "The most difficult period is over," Mr. Yeltsin told an angry, jeering crowd of workers and veterans. "Those three or four years have passed, and we survived. I don't want you to lose hope."
But mainly, his is a message not of hope, but appeasement -- promising to raise pensions and wages to offset the inequities of the free-market system.
Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms are increasingly viewed as an ill-fitting import, imposed by Western governments and the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, and not even with good intentions.
In a poll of 3,850 Russians that was sponsored by the Brookings Institution in Washington and conducted last December, 60 percent of the people interviewed said they believed that "the West is pursuing the goal of weakening Russia with its economic advice."
Such views can be found not only among elderly pensioners, but also among ambitious entrepreneurs.
"This Western assault, all these economic loans and business ventures, I think they are bad," said Lyudmila Chelnokova, 38, a former construction engineer in the town of Sergiyev Posad, who is now attending law school in the hopes of starting her own business. "We Russians have to develop ourselves, our own way."
The domination of Russian television by Mexican soap operas and knockoff game shows is a universal lament. Yet Russian nationalism is creeping onto Russian screens.
The Moscow Channel, which reaches 35 million viewers, features the weekly program "Russki Dom" ("Russian House"), a homespun talk show that showcases the Russian Orthodox faith and old Russian traditions. The show's creator, Aleksandr N. Krutov, a former member of the Soviet Parliament, described Russia as a "flowering meadow." He said: "Under democracy, they tried to turn Russia into an internationalist, cosmopolitan English lawn. It's not in our souls."
Russia's largest network, the state-controlled company ORT, which blatantly favors Mr. Yeltsin's candidacy, is also seeking to co-opt the nationalist movement. Last month ORT began broadcasting a new show by Aleksandr G. Nevzorov, a celebrity television journalist turned Member of Parliament who is known for his nationalist views.
His old show was banned after he supported the 1993 parliamentary insurrection against Mr. Yeltsin. His new program, "Dni" ("Days"), is veined with attacks on the West. In last week's episode, he asserted that organized crime leaders lobbied to make Russia a part of the European Union.
Many ordinary Russians seem more depressed than angry about their loss of status.
"I think it's something that Clinton even agreed to meet Yeltsin, that they haven't turned their backs on us," Lidiya K. Mogusheva, 45, a receptionist at a hairdressing salon in Sergiyev Posad, said mournfully. "We've become a third-world country -- nobody looks at us with respect any more. Why should they?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many Russians are nostalgic for their country's lost empire. The honor guard that once goose-stepped in front of Lenin'a tomb now serves in the Kremlin, refitted with bright uniforms meant to evoke past splendors. (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In an Amazon Cave, Light Is Shed on Early Americans

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
Digging in a cave near the Amazon River in Brazil, archeologists have found stone weapons, rock paintings and other traces of what may have been one of the earliest human cultures in the Americas. The discovery could revise thinking -- and stir more controversy -- about the lives and migrations of the first Americans.
The excavations yielded evidence that the ancient Americans who regularly camped in the cave led lives distinct from the big-game hunters who roamed the plains and hills of western North America at the same time, about 11,000 years ago. These Amazonian people lived off the fruits and nuts and small game of the tropical forest and took fish and turtles from the river. 
 Their paintings on the cave walls are thought to be the earliest reliably dated examples of art yet found in the Americas. The earliest European cave paintings are believed to be more than 30,000 years old.
The findings, being reported today in the journal Science, challenge the widely held assumption, based on knowledge of an ancient group of North Americans called the Clovis people, that the earliest Americans were primarily specialized big-game hunters who lived in open, temperate country and could not have sustained a culture in the humid tropics, where large animals were scarce. They had supposedly migrated across the Bering Straits from Asia in pursuit of mammoths and mastodons, settled in North America and then moved into South America, still a hunting society and living mainly in the highlands. These hunters were presumed to be the forerunners of all subsequent cultures in South America.
But a team of archeologists led by Dr. Anna C. Roosevelt of the Field Museum in Chicago and the University of Illinois reported radiocarbon dates of material in the Brazilian cave showing that early paleo-Indians there were contemporaries of the Clovis people with a distinctive foraging economy and different styles of stone weapons. These foragers used the cave as a campsite from 11,200 to 10,000 years ago, the scientists estimated.
The research seemed to confirm earlier evidence that the spread of paleo-Indians through the Americas was more complex than current theories would explain. It also seemed to lend weight to Dr. Roosevelt's thesis, based on two decades of excavations in Amazonia, that the tropical lowlands were not necessarily a barrier to early human cultures and that, indeed, substantial societies were living in Amazonia as early as or earlier than in the Andes.
In the Science article, Dr. Roosevelt and her colleagues wrote: "The existence of a distinct cultural tradition contemporary with the Clovis tradition, but more than 5,000 miles to the south, does not fit the notion that the North American big-game hunters were the sole source of migration into South America. Clovis is evidently just one of several regional traditions. Clearly, paleo-Indians were able to adapt to a broad range of habitats."
Other archeologists said the findings indicated that parts of South America might have been occupied by a wave of migrating people who crossed from Siberia before the people associated with the Clovis culture. Several recent discoveries provide tantalizing hints that people may have been in America several thousand years before the Clovis culture, though none of them has yet been established beyond dispute.
Dr. C. Vance Haynes, an archeologist at the University of Arizona who specializes in the Clovis culture, conceded the possibility.
"It wouldn't surprise me that somebody was here before the Clovis people," he said.
Dr. John Rick, an anthropologist at Stanford University, said the evidence produced by Dr. Roosevelt "left no room for doubt that this is an old site of hunter-gatherer occupation." He said the date of 11,000 years for materials found in cave sediments appeared to be well-founded.
But Dr. Rick cautioned that it might be premature to derive broad interpretations about the nature and timing of early American cultures on the basis of a single site, particularly one that he said had only a relatively small sample of tools on which to make cultural inferences. The findings "open the door but don't tell you exactly what's on the other side of the door," he said.
Some archeologists, notably Clovis specialists, expressed reservations over the dating of the Amazon materials, saying that a more conservative averaging of the radiocarbon results would yield a more reliable date of 10,500 years ago, which might preserve the Clovis primacy and could have given the Clovis people time to move south, modifying their weaponry and diet as they went.
Dr. Roosevelt argued that such averaging would obscure the time of a site's earliest occupation and also distinctions between artifacts and seeds found at slightly different levels of the excavated sediments.
Dr. Roosevelt made the discoveries at Caverna da Pedra Pintada, Cave of the Painted Rock, near Monte Alegre, a town on the north bank of the Amazon between Manaus and Belem. The excavations occurred in 1991 and 1992, but laboratory analysis of the thousands of artifacts and other campsite remains, as well as the radiocarbon testing delayed publication of the results. Several independent dating tests were conducted on charred seeds and wood found in sediments associated with stone spear points and other artifacts.
One of the most striking discoveries at the site was the presence of stone projectile points of a triangular shape. This set them apart from the Clovis style of fluted points, which have often been uncovered in North America at kill sites also bearing many large animal bones. Archeologists said it was not clear whether the Amazonian points were used as knives, spears, darts or harpoons. But the litter of stone flakes indicated that people using the cave spent much of their time making or repairing their stone weapons.
The other important discovery, Dr. Roosevelt said, was the presence of such a variety of food remains. These included the charred seeds and nuts of tropical trees and other plants, but no plant remains associated with temperate habitats. Being charred in ancient fires helped preserve them. Other remains included shells of mollusks, bones of fish, birds, turtles and land animals and scraps of meals. "This culture didn't emphasize big-game hunting," Dr. Roosevelt said. "The charred food remains we found point instead to broad-spectrum foraging."
Dr. Betty J. Meggers, an archeologist at the Smithsonian Institution who has frequently differed with Dr. Roosevelt on interpretations of early Amazonian cultures, said that she was convinced that the Amazonian environment was much less tropical 11,000 years ago, with more open, dry land. In that case, she said, there could have been such scattered foraging cultures, but it would not disprove her hypothesis that significant human cultures could not have been supported in the Amazon basin because the climate was too harsh and resources scarce.
Dr. Roosevelt, on the other hand, thinks the people of the Monte Alegre cave show that "early human evolution was not severely limited in humid tropical environments as compared with others." Indeed, she views them as the beginning of a "dynamic trajectory" of cultural evolution along the Amazon, leading in time to fishing villages, then to horticulturists who adopted and used pottery as early as 8,000 years ago.

HEADLINE: Profit Data Help Lift Stock Prices

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose narrowly yesterday, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index set a high for the 12th time this year.
"Today's stock market actions were strongly influenced by recent earnings reports," said John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president of Advest Inc. "Stocks and bonds have effectively decoupled over the last two months and this was more of the same." 
 As evidence of that decoupling, the bond market fell, after a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia gave indications that demand for manufacturers' products was strong and that the economy was gaining momentum. The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 8/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, increased to 6.83 percent, from 6.81 percent on Wednesday.
The Nasdaq index, which had established the previous record of 1,124.92 on Tuesday, jumped 15.43 points, or 1.38 percent, to 1,136.30. Other major market indicators did not gain as much, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 1.81 points, or 0.03 percent, to 5,551.74, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 2, or 0.31 percent, to 643.61.
Advances topped declines on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,300 to 1,007. Big Board volume amounted to 415.2 million shares, compared with 465.2 million shares Wednesday.
Another record was also set by the Dow Jones transportation average, which rose 19.98 points, to 2,221.06. The previous high of 2,206.68 was achieved on April 4.
Among the gainers in the Dow transportations were Union Pacific, up 2 3/8, to 70 1/8; Burlington Northern, up 2, to 84 1/2; UAL, the holding company for United Airlines, up 1 7/8, to 222, and AMR, the holding company for American Airlines, up 1/2, to 93 3/8.
Gillette jumped 3 1/8, to 52, after increasing first-quarter profits by 17 percent, raising its dividend and announcing a stock buyback program. Raychem surged 5 3/4, to 73 1/4, after its fiscal third-quarter earnings more than tripled those for the period a year ago. And McDonnell Douglas vaulted 2 3/4, to 90 5/8, after reporting surprisingly strong first-quarter net income.
Good profit reports from drug companies helped to stimulate the pharmaceutical sector. Eli Lilly closed at 58 7/8, up 2 3/8; Pfizer ended at 68 3/4, up 1/8, and Bristol-Myers finished at 82, up 7/8.
Computer stocks rebounded from Wednesday's retreat. Motorola rose 2 5/8, to 60 1/88, and Hewlett-Packard added 1 1/2, to 99 7/8. I.B.M., which plunged a whopping 10 1/4 the previous session, increased 1/4, to 105 1/2. The Morgan Stanley high-technology index had a gain of more than 2 percent, to 326.
On the other hand, oil stocks slid amid rumors of an agreement between Iraq and the United Nations over Iraqi oil sales. Exxon declined 1 5/8, to 81 7/8; Royal Dutch tumbled 2 7/8, to 42, and Mobil fell 2 3/8, to 112 5/8.
Traders rotated out of some beverage issues. Coca-Cola closed at 79 1/2, down 5/8, and Adolph Coors closed at 17 7/8, down 7/8.
Tobacco stocks also dropped as concern over litigation continued. Philip Morris fell 1/2, to 89 1/4, and RJR Nabisco declined 1/4, to 29 3/4.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Sooner Than Expected, Germans Cut Key Rates

 BODY:
The central bank of Germany, faced with a stagnant national economy, unexpectedly cut official interest rates half a percentage point yesterday.
The move is expected to help the German economy, which appears to have contracted for a second consecutive quarter. And because Germany has Europe's largest economy, a rebound there could be expected to flow into neighboring countries. 
 Although many economists had expected the influential central bank, the Bundesbank, to lower interest rates at some point this year, few thought it would act so soon. The rate cut caught the financial markets off guard, and the dollar initially rose against the German mark. But by the end of the afternoon in New York, the dollar stood below its levels of Wednesday.
The Bundesbank lowered the benchmark discount rate to 2.5 percent from 3 percent, matching a record low after the stock market collapse in the autumn of 1987. The discount rate, which is charged on loans by the central bank to commercial banks, sets a floor under German money market rates. It also effectively dictates interest-rate levels elsewhere in Europe.
The bank also cut a second important measure, the Lombard rate, to 4.5 percent from 5 percent. The Lombard rate is charged on emergency loans the central bank makes to commercial banks and acts as a ceiling on money market rates.
The Bundesbank last lowered the discount and Lombard rates in mid-December.
In reducing the rates yesterday, it said it was confident that inflation would remain under control.
The bank left unchanged a third widely tracked interest gauge, the securities repurchase rate. Better known as the repo rate, that is what banks pay for short-term borrowing in the money market. The Bundesbank, which controls the repo rate by adjusting the money market's liquidity, said it would keep it at 3.3 percent for the next two weeks so as to leave its monetary-policy options open. That, plus comments by the central bank's president, raised the possibility of a further reduction.
On the heels of the Bundesbank's move, interest rates were cut yesterday in Austria, Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands, as well.
"Because Germany is weaker than the rest of Europe, and is setting the base rate for the rest of Europe, this is more stimulative than the other countries may need," said Steve Englander, a European economist at Smith Barney in Paris, to Bloomberg Business News. Still, he added, "This is very bullish for Europe."
Interest-rate reductions in a country tend to weaken that country's currency by reducing the yields available on investments there. The Bundesbank's announcement did cause the mark to fall initially, though the dollar later turned lower.
Traders attributed the dollar's afternoon retreat to a view among some in the currency markets that the rate cut would be the last the Bundesbank would make -- despite the indications from the central bank to the contrary. And they said that the dollar had lost value against the Japanese yen yesterday because traders believed that Japan's central bank might soon move to raise interest rates there.
"The timing of the Bundesbank cut was a surprise," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But the talk is widespread that this is the last rate cut. The rise in commodity prices we have seen has to be an inflation concern in Germany. What the central bank did yesterday was a political concession, one the Bundesbank is not likely to do again."
The dollar rose as high as 1.5120 marks, a 14-month high, before retreating. In New York, it settled at 1.5015 marks, down from 1.5060 on Wednesday. The dollar was quoted at 106.65 yen, down from 108.20 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5185 from $1.5095.
But the dollar gained against the Canadian dollar, after Canada's central bank cut interest rates there by one-quarter of a percentage point. The Canadian dollar fell to 73.35 United States cents from 73.72 cents.
The German bank, always alert for signs that inflation may be accelerating, is known for its great caution in cutting interest rates. In a report issued yesterday before its rate announcement, the bank said that the broad measure of Germany's money supply rose at an annual rate of 12.2 percent in the first three months of the year, slower than the 12.8 percent pace in the first two months. It also said that the current annual rate exaggerated actual monetary growth.
The Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, said at a news conference that inflation pressures were relatively tame. Addressing the possibility of a further easing of interest rates, he said that the bank would "wait and see."
"We aren't talking about an end," Mr. Tietmeyer continued. "We will see whether there is further room."
The rate reduction came against a backdrop of continued stagnation in Germany. The Economics Ministry said in a report yesterday that the economy probably shrank in the first quarter. It cited unusually cold weather and the lack of a pickup in consumer spending.
The economy, as measured by the gross domestic product, shrank four-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1995 from the previous quarter. It has been hurt by the strong mark, which makes Germany's exports less competitive, and high labor costs.

HEADLINE: Group Asserts U.S. Workers Are Better Off Than Thought

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Injecting its voice into the debate over economic insecurity, a lobbying group representing the nation's manufacturers issued an analysis today that it said rebutted "the conventional wisdom that wage stagnation and job loss represent reality for American workers."
The National Association of Manufacturers said in its report that there were valid reasons why workers might feel uneasy about the future, reciting what has now become a familiar list to employees of almost any company: global competition, the fast pace of technological change, demands on the labor force to continually upgrade its skills and the bigger bite taken out of paychecks by taxes. 
 But it said problems with measurements of inflation had caused Government statistics to report that average wages had stagnated when they had actually improved somewhat. Once distortions created by overestimating inflation are taken into account, the group argued, wages have risen by 15 percent since 1979. And the report said that the economy was creating jobs far faster than corporate downsizing was wiping them out. Unemployment has stayed under 6 percent for more than a year and a half.
"There is one overriding, fundamental truth about the U.S. economy," the study said. "It has created millions of new jobs over the last 25 years -- 8.4 million since 1992 -- and at the same time it has raised average compensation for a rapidly growing work force. Other industrialized countries in recent decades have done one or the other; none, aside from the United States, can claim to have done both."
The study did not generate or analyze new data, but was an attempt by the manufacturers' group to shift the focus from what it said were misleading or incomplete accounts of an issue that has taken center stage both in politics and in economic policy debates.
The report's conclusions also reflected a broader belief on the part of corporate executives that they are unfairly being blamed for the plight of workers when the executives' success in helping industry become more efficient and competitive has restored the United States to a position of pre-eminent economic strength.
"Much of what is said about the plight of workers is inflammatory, demagogic, or flat out wrong," said Jerry Jasinowski, the association's president.
Many news organizations, including The New York Times, have reported in recent months on the anxieties of workers who fear for their jobs, worry that living standards are slipping and feel they are working harder and harder to keep up.
Those sentiments have also been seized upon by politicians. In his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan railed against what he called the greed of corporate executives and their lack of concern for their workers. President Clinton has been touting companies that treat their employees well as part of a White House effort to address feelings of disenfranchisement among the middle class.
In Congress, Democrats including Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico have offered plans to give tax breaks to companies that offer better wages, benefits and training to workers. Congress is edging closer to raising the minimum wage, despite the arguments of many economists that such a move might discourage companies from hiring additional workers.
Next week, the White House's Council on Economic Advisers plans to release its own study of the downsizing phenomenon -- one expected to bolster the Administration's argument that while workers have undergone a wrenching change, the job displacements have not been worse than other recent periods in America's economic history.
"What we want to show is that the new jobs being created are good jobs -- better paying, more stable than people think," one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers said this week. "On the other hand, we're concerned that the layoffs that people have experienced recently may be more permanent than in past periods, and that's something we'll have to address in the campaign."
For Mr. Clinton, the divergence between the figures showing strong job growth and the economic insecurity felt by voters poses a tricky political quandary: he clearly wants to take credit for the country's strong economic performance without seeming oblivious to the pain and anxiety felt by many workers.
"Obviously there is extraordinary anxiety -- let me say high anxiety -- among many workers," the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said the other day. "No one is trying to ignore that."
Instead, Mr. Clinton's re-election team is trying to cast the President as the man who helped spur growth, and who now is focused on Government and private-sector programs, including portable health insurance and retirement savings systems, to aid those caught up in the wheels of the national economic transition.
The manufacturers' group, in its report, said the two main causes of worker anxiety were slow economic growth and high taxes. A typical family in 1955 paid about 20 percent of its income in state and Federal taxes, but now pays about 37 percent, an added burden of $9,000 for the median two-income family, according to the report.
The report made several recommendations, starting with increasing the economic growth rate, in part by reducing taxes. It said that companies should use more incentive-based compensation and stock ownership plans for workers. It also called for less government regulation of business and a vaguely defined "new employment relationship" under which employees would commit themselves to keep learning new skills and companies would keep lines of communication open and help workers achieve their goals.

HEADLINE: Elusive Salinas Turns Up in New York

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 18

 BODY:
He was supposed to be in Cuba, or Canada, or Costa Rica, or a resort on Paradise Island, or a walled compound in central Mexico.
For more than a year, reporters have chased yachts, climbed mountains, cased apartment buildings and flown halfway round the world to try to find him, but former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has been hard to find. 
 Until Wednesday. The former President showed up in New York wearing a navy blue trench coat and an impish smile to attend the annual meeting of the Dow Jones & Company, where he is a director.
Mr. Salinas, whose whereabouts have been a mystery since he was hounded out of Mexico last year by political opponents and public outrage, told a Mexican reporter, "I live in Ireland with my family." An article in The Sunday Times of London last weekend reported the same thing.
When asked about reports of his global ramblings, Mr. Salinas reportedly smiled and said, "You know how reporters are."
Mr. Salinas arrived about 20 minutes late for the meeting at the 43d floor of the World Trade Center in New York City. He officially began his two-year term on the Dow Jones board last April.
Company officials would not say how often he attended meetings but the proxy statement given to shareholders noted that he had taken part in just over half of the board and committee meetings held in the last year.
He works on the membership and audit committees and, according to the statement, does not own any shares of Dow Jones.
People who attended the meeting said that Mr. Salinas looked slightly thinner and that the little bit of hair he has left has turned grayer. Mr. Salinas, who just turned 48, completed his six-year term as one of Mexico's most popular presidents in December 1994. But just weeks after he left office, the seemingly strong economy he built collapsed, setting off an avalanche of criticism.
Since then, he and his family have been accused of everything from theft to murder. No charges have officially been brought against Mr. Salinas himself, but most Mexicans consider him a symbol of official corruption.
Most of Mr. Salinas's political allies in Mexico have abandoned him and the few who continue to support him face troubles of their own. Socrates Rizzo Garcia, the Governor of Mr. Salinas's home state, Nuevo Leon, across the border from Texas, resigned today under a cloud of suspicion and speculation.
There are no official charges against Mr. Rizzo. But during the last year, drugs, violence and political infighting have become increasing problems in Nuevo Leon.

HEADLINE: Boat People Embark on Sad Voyage Home

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUANTAN, Malaysia, April 18

 BODY:
 Sullen and defeated, 317 Vietnamese boat people shuffled down a gangplank into the hold of a Malaysian Navy landing craft this morning, the first to be sent back home by ship as refugee camps in Southeast Asia begin to close down for good.
Some sobbed. Most were silent. A few whispered "We don't want to go" and, "They are forcing us." One man holding a small child stared intently at a reporter and muttered, "Malaysia United Nations are animals." 
 For these failed migrants it was the end of a journey across the same South China Sea, begun in the hope of a new life in the West but leading only to half a decade in a crowded refugee camp.
It also signaled the approaching end of the era of Vietnamese refugees that began on helicopters in the tumult of the Communist takeover of Saigon in 1975, then grew to a flood of hundreds of thousands of desperate boat people, many of whom lost their lives to storms and pirates.
More than a million Vietnamese refugees succeeded in reaching the United States. Even as today's shipload began its 40-hour journey to the Vietnamese port of Vung Tau, successful Vietnamese-Americans were flying back to visit or do business, with dollars in their pockets.
As the unwilling returnees approached the gangplank one by one this morning, Malaysian police officers searched their purses and pockets, removing any items, as one official said, with which they might "hurt themselves or others."
The officers removed not only belts and combs and pencils but watches, keys and nail clippers, bobby pins, mascara brushes, bracelets, rings and rosaries, and they pulled barrettes from the hair of children.
The morning's operation -- quick, efficient and uneventful -- was a clear success. Earlier forced returns by air from Hong Kong have sometimes been chaotic, with refugees wailing and officers carrying them bodily aboard the aircraft.
Here in Malaysia, the prospect of a forced return has touched off two riots in the last six months in the Sungai Besi camp in the capital city of Kuala Lumpur. In the last of these, on Jan. 18, one Vietnamese was killed and 24 people, including seven police officers, were hurt.
Rear Adm. Yaacob Daud, director of Malaysia's task force on illegal immigrants, was clearly relieved as the last Vietnamese walked down the gangplank today.
"This is what we have wanted all along," he said. "This shows it can be done peacefully."
A decisive factor, he said, was the announcement last month by the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees that it would stop financing the camps in Southeast Asia as of June 30. "That was a clear message to the people still in the camps that they have no more choice but to go home," he said.
The Vietnamese in the Sungai Besi camp had clearly given up their struggle as they were marched single file before dawn today to board busses for the five-hour ride to this small port city on the Malaysian east coast.
A refugee named Le Binh Xinh, who had been here since 1989, said, "We do not want to go but they are making us go." Asked how they were being forced, he raised his palms and gestured at the rows of riot police officers that surrounded him, carrying heavy batons and wearing red, visored helmets bearing the word "Polis."
Monitors from the United Nations refugee agency looked on uncomfortably as observers. They have spent the last two decades assisting Vietnamese refugees but have agreed now to step aside. Almost all the 35,000 Vietnamese remaining in Southeast Asia's camps have been judged to be "economic migrants" rather than genuine refugees fleeing persecution and deserving of protection.
A United Nations observer at Sungai Besi camp this morning said she was satisfied with the conduct of the operation, but she declined to give her name.
Admiral Yaacob said 3,128 Vietnamese remain in two camps in Malaysia. Of these, about 1,500 have agreed to sign voluntary return forms, allowing them to take the quicker and more comfortable flight home by aircraft.
The others have so far refused to volunteer, after their years of struggle, and are opting for the more arduous and humiliating journey in the hold of the Sri Inderapura, a 7,000-ton landing craft that was bought last year from the United States, where it was known as the Spartanburg County.
Admiral Yaacob said he hoped that the forced return today would help persuade more of the Vietnamese to return voluntarily. Already, he said, today's total was reduced from more than 500 when many of the holdouts chose instead to volunteer.
Shortly after the departure of the 317 involuntary returnees from the Sungai Besi camp this morning, 216 volunteers were bused to the airport, where they were to board an Air Vietnam flight for Ho Chi Minh City.
One of these volunteers, Vu Long, 23, acted as a sort of trusty this morning, helping carry out the involuntary departure before his own trip to the airport.
"I must go back; I have no choice," he said. "I came here looking for my future and I wasted seven years. Now I must go home and start again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Malaysia's forced return of 317 Vietnamese refugees began early yesterday in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, where they waited for buses to Kuantan. There, naval vessels took them back to a "home" they had escaped. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Rivalry Between East and West Grows In New Media

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The new-media business may be a fledgling industry, but it has already generated a big-time fight for bragging rights that pits New York against the West Coast.
The heated debate was precipitated by a study of the new-media industry in New York released on Monday. The study, conducted by Coopers & Lybrand, found that companies making sites on the Internet's World Wide Web, multimedia software, computer games and other new-media products supported 71,500 workers in 4,200 companies in the metropolitan New York region. 
 New-media jobs, the study found, had doubled over the last three years, and gross revenues reached $3.8 billion, although once transactions among themselves were eliminated, the final figure was about $1 billion.
On the West Coast these figures were greeted with derision.
"That New York study galvanized people here like you wouldn't believe," said Rohit Shukla, executive director of the Los Angeles Regional Technology Alliance, a corporate and government partnership.
"There may be a thriving new media business in New York," Mr. Shukla said, "but no matter what they are doing in New York, it isn't generating those kind of revenues and jobs."
Mr. Shukla, using a different methodology and definition of new-media technologies, places New York behind both San Francisco and Los Angeles.
A study done by the Bay Area Multimedia Partnership, a corporate and government group, estimated last year that new media industry in the nine-county region around San Francisco had more than 2,200 companies employing 62,000 people.
Measuring employment and job creation in any new industry is tricky because such jobs do not fit neatly into the standard industrial classifications of the Federal Government's official employment counter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Most new-media jobs, economists say, would probably be included in the Government's business services category, which saw a rise of 30,000 in the last three years, to 260,000 from 230,000, in New York City and adjacent counties in New York State, noted David Hensley, a regional economist at Salomon Brothers.
In New York City, the nearest comparable area in Coopers & Lybrand study, 17,000 new-media jobs were created over the last three years. "The net job growth is possible, but it would mean new media accounted for much of the growth in the entire business services category," Mr. Hensley said.
"Measuring this kind of amorphously defined industry is difficult for anyone, but the results of the New York study don't make sense to me," said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow for public policy at Pepperdine University in Malibu, Calif.
Andrew Zimmerman, a partner at Coopers & Lybrand, said: "I feel that within a reasonable margin of error, the survey numbers are accurate," but he admitted that measuring employment in new media involved judgment calls.
"We did extrapolate from a sample, but we made every effort to avoid double-counting that might exaggerate the numbers," Mr. Zimmerman said. Coopers & Lybrand followed up the data generated by market research and government data with telephone interviews and some face-to-face interviews.
The New York survey was paid for by the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency, and commissioned by the New York New Media Association, a trade group.
One explanation for the bicoastal dispute, said Brian Horey, president of the trade association, is that westerners "are looking at this from the prism of CD-ROM and PC software." New York lags in those areas, he said, but is dominated by legions of small firms designing and supporting Web sites for larger companies. He estimates that companies working on the Web account for more than half of the new media employment in New York.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Still Plagued By Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower for a third consecutive session yesterday, retreating from early gains, as inflation worries revived following a stronger-than-expected regional manufacturing survey.
"We're still within the grasp of a bear market in bonds," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a money management firm in Washington. 
 Bond prices rose in early trading, bolstered in part by a cut in German interest rates that helped the dollar. But bonds fell sharply after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that its index of general business activity jumped to 17.3 in April, from minus 0.1 in March. Analysts had been expecting a reading of 2.8.
"The overall reading was higher than expected," said Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of Government bond trading at Cowen & Company. "I think it really knocked the wind out of the bond market's sales after starting the New York session with a firm tone."
The price of the 30-year bond fell as much as 14/32 of a percentage point after the Philadelphia Fed report. It ended down 8/32 , to 89 16/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to6.83 percent, from 6.81 percent on Wednesday.
While the Philadelphia Fed report contained indications that inflation remained moderate, the bond market seized on the signs of sharp growth. The business activity index is at its highest in in more than six months. And surveyed companies reported increases in both new orders and shipments this month.
Mr. Carpenter of ASB Capital Mangement noted that the market ignored the second consecutive monthly contraction of employment seen in the report. "Collectively these two months worth of data cast doubt on the strong February employment report we had," he said, "and even the validity of the more moderate March data."
And many analysts note that the Philadelphia Fed's index number is often volatile, with wide swings from month to month. Some suspect that the sharp rise this month reflected a bounce-back from the General Motors strike that shut an Ohio assembly plant in March.
Another economic report was largely in line with expectations. The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits for the first time rose by 10,000 last week, to 360,000. Analysts said the underlying trend remained consistent with a noninflationary pace of job growth.
Another source of investor concern remains new supply as the market prepares for next week's Treasury auctions of $18.75 billion in new two-year notes and $12.5 billion in five-year notes.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6 percent; the yield on the five-year issue was 6.37 percent. Both were up a about three-hundredths of a percentage point from the previous day, as dealers sought to reach a yield level that would attract the most buyers.
Despite the slump in recent days, Mr. Carpenter, for one, remains optimistic. "I still think that we are no more than a quarter away from a substantial rally in bonds," he said. "By year-end, the long bond yield will be closer to 6 percent than to 7 percent. I remain optimistic that the current level of both long- and short-term rates are certainly high enough to suffocate or strangle the developing second-quarter spurt in economic growth."

HEADLINE: Researchers Link Income Disparity to Higher Rates of Death

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Poor people have long been known to have more medical problems than affluent people of the same age, but a new study suggests that greater inequality in the distribution of income contributes to higher overall mortality rates and deaths from heart disease, cancer and homicide.
The study, undertaken by three faculty members of the Harvard School of Public Health and being published on Friday in the British Medical Journal, suggests that reducing such inequality may reduce mortality rates. Data from the Census Bureau show that income inequality in the United States has increased in recent years. 
 The study found that for treatable conditions like tuberculosis, pneumonia and high blood pressure, mortality rates were higher in states where the income gap was wider.
"The size of the gap between the wealthy and less well-off, as distinct from the absolute standard of living enjoyed by the poor, appears to be related to mortality," says the article, written by Dr. Bruce P. Kennedy, Dr. Ichiro Kawachi and Dr. Deborah B. Prothrow-Stith.
Why this may be true is not clear. "It is possible that income distribution is a proxy for other social indicators, such as the degree of investment in human capital," the researchers say. "Communities that tolerate large degrees of income inequality may be the same ones which tend to under-invest in social goods such as public education or accessible health care."
In an interview today, Dr. Kennedy said, "We found that mortality was strongly related to inequality in the distribution of income, but not to the median income or per capita income of a state."
A separate study in the same issue of the journal, by researchers at the California Department of Health Services, reaches similar conclusions. They found high levels of income inequality and high death rates in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Kentucky and New York. Conversely, they found comparatively low levels of income inequality and low death rates in New Hampshire, Utah, Wisconsin, Iowa and Hawaii. By both measures, New Jersey and Connecticut were in the middle.
The principal researcher in the California group, Dr. George A. Kaplan, said in an interview: "What we found is that as income inequality goes up, as the wealthy receive a greater share of total income, death rates also go up. The states that had the highest levels of income inequality in 1980 had poorer mortality trends from 1980 to 1990, compared with states that had more equal income distribution."
In addition, he said, "We found that income inequality increases death rates at all ages, from infant mortality to deaths in the elderly."
Dr. Kaplan and his colleagues reported that "income inequality increased in all states except Alaska from 1980 to 1990." Over the decade, they said, mortality declined in all states, but those with greater income inequality showed smaller declines.
The California team suggested that decisions about economic policy could affect mortality levels, for better or worse. So, they conclude, "it would be prudent to consider health effects, and the costs associated with them, when evaluating the impact of economic policies."
Dr. Kaplan, an epidemiologist, said, "People might assume that states with higher income inequality have more poor people, and we know that poor people have higher death rates." But he added: "The evidence in these two studies suggests that the increased death rates in those states are not due simply to their having more poor people. Income inequality seems to be increasing mortality rates among nonpoor people as well, and we are investigating that possibility."
Dr. Kaplan suggested that "income inequality affects all segments of the population because it affects rates of violence and disability, as well as public spending on police protection, education, welfare and health care."

HEADLINE: A Season of Opening Days;
Companies Make New Issues a Big Event on Wall St.

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Down on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, a lot of high-priced talent is just standing around in the frenzy. Henry B. Schacht, the chairman of Lucent Technologies, is part of the crowd, and so are Richard A. Grasso, the exchange chairman, and President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro of Italy, who is at the exchange to give a speech. Messengers push through the gawkers to deliver buy or sell orders to Michael La Branche, the specialist at Post 7-N.
Lucent is going public, a spinoff of AT&T. And even those who are not trying to buy shares in the $3 billion deal, the largest initial public offering in American history, want to witness it. 
 Most excited of all, perhaps, is Nellie Perkins, who works the second shift at a Lucent plant in Oklahoma City. She has never before set foot in New York City, let alone on the floor of the Big Board, but on this particular day, April 4, Lucent has flown her in to buy the first 500 shares.
Finally, at 10:44 A.M., 74 minutes after the opening bell, Mr. La Branche matches orders and bundles them into one trade. Ms. Perkins, whose purchase is part of the package, announces the inaugural transaction: "15,887,800 Lucent shares to trade at 31 7/8." Cameras click. There are smiles, hugs, even tears in the Lucent crowd.
In one variation or another, that scene has been repeated hundreds of times in the last year, as companies increasingly make going public into an event, hoping to stand out in the crowd. And what a crowd it is. If current trends hold up, April will be the hottest month ever for raising money in new issues.
Wall Street's roaring bull is allowing a throng of companies to tap the market for money. But as a few recent sharp declines suggest, the market's strength -- based in part on a five-year-old economic expansion -- will not last forever. At some point, investors will undoubtedly have their fill of these newly minted companies, and the window for new stock issues will close. That prospect is making the current rush to the starting gate all the more jammed.
New York, as the capital of capitalism, makes it all happen. Wall Street orchestrates, and lives off, these stock offering deals, through which shares in private companies are made available for sale to the public for the first time.
The blockbuster fees generated by mergers and acquisitions get more attention because the deals are bigger. But securities firms typically collect 7 percent of the value of a stock offering, compared with 1 percent of a merger, said Richard J. Peterson, an analyst at the Securities Data Company. Only once in the last dozen years, 1989, have merger fees surpassed stock offering fees, which already exceed $700 million this year. Lucent rained $117.6 million on Wall Street.
From the pockets of investment bankers, that money gets sprinkled around. Some wends its way to printers, hotel and restaurant workers, chauffeurs and even unemployed actors on some recent occasions. The money shows up in everything from a generous tip to the shoe-shiners downtown to box seats at the Metropolitan Opera. And a lot goes, too, into Park Avenue co-ops and summer homes in the Hamptons.
In a trend likely to fatten the bonanza, some recent stock offerings are being celebrated in ways that go beyond the traditional exclusive breakfasts and dinners for executives and investment bankers. Now companies are using the occasion to create a public image, to foster esprit de corps among employees and to spread the action around -- as well as to forge an identity with Wall Street brokers and traders.
Along with the ubiquitous Lucite-block gewgaws for deal makers, companies like Lucent, which makes telecommunications equipment, are handing out baseball caps at the exchange. Revlon brought the models Claudia Schiffer and Cindy Crawford to spice up its debut in February. It also put their photos on the traditional giveaway lapel pins, instantly turning what are normally throwaways into hot items.
Cartoon character appearances -- like Spiderman for Marvel Comics and Mr. Peanut for Nabisco -- are becoming so common that last fall the Boston Beer Company did not just bring an actor playing Samuel Adams, the namesake of its label, but re-enacted the Boston Tea Party, sort of, on Broad Street.
Boston Beer deployed employees and actors on a ship-shaped float. Dressed in colonial garb, they dumped cases of imported beer into the street "to dramatize the declaration of beer independence," C. James Koch, the chief executive, said.
These antics are spreading as the number of new issues soars. Ever since the bull market that began in the early 1980's got its second wind in 1991, private companies with great ambitions and a need for capital have been running to investment bankers. They size up the company's prospects with investors and determine the price the shares may fetch.
Lately, investors have been snapping up virtually every company on offer. Companies with a link to the Internet, no matter how tenuous, are the stars, commanding prices in the ionosphere. When one of them -- Yahoo -- went public last Friday, it soared from an offering price of $13 to $43 and closed at $33.
But restaurants, makers of luxury goods, retailers and manufacturers are feasting on the market's plenty, too -- even some that have failed before. On Wednesday, for example, Donna Karan International, the fashion house that found little interest in a stock offering in 1993, said it would try again later this year.
So far in 1996, 198 companies have sold $12.6 billion worth of new stock, more than double the money raised in the corresponding period in 1995, according to Securities Data. The pace so far this year is running ahead of 1993, when a record $34 billion was raised.
The numbers add up to good news for the economy, simply because initial public offerings fuel dreams. By allowing companies to raise money, usually to pursue growth and invest in new ideas, they help drive innovation, technological advances and productivity gains.
For a long time, Wall Street has kept mum on how new stock offerings actually happen, partly in fear of running afoul of Federal regulations that forbid anyone involved to hype a stock, partly out of reluctance to demystify the process.
But the move to make the offerings into events is changing that. Although each stock offering is different, there are certain traditions and rituals. When a company goes public on the New York Stock Exchange, its chief executive normally rings the opening bell. He usually makes the first trade, too, though some companies delegate the tasks.
Most companies, however, go public on Nasdaq, an electronic market that has no trading floor. So the scene takes place on the trading floor of the lead investment firm. A banker there balances the initial buy and sell orders, while the company's executives watch and then head out for a lunch.
With so many deals, some on the trading floors take a jaundiced view of the hoopla. "We want them to get out of here so we can get back to business," said one investment banker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "This is a big important event in their life, and they're fascinated. But we want to declare victory and get on with it."
Some people with long memories or a sense of history also find much of the hoopla a bit hard to countenance. Robert Sobel, a business historian at Hofstra University, pointed out that as recently as 40 years ago, common stocks were considered too speculative for the average person.
It was not even until 1984 that the New York Stock Exchange began to trade in new issues. By then, the business was too big to ignore.
Today, the issues that go public on the Big Board generate the most folderol. The day typically begins with breakfast in the private dining rooms of the exchange's high-ceilinged Luncheon Club. Lucent had to give a lunch, thanks to the long-scheduled breakfast appearance by President Scalfaro of Italy.
Whether it is breakfast or lunch, the two chairmen -- of the exchange and the company -- bring gifts. Mr. Grasso gave Mr. Schacht the traditional bronze medallion depicting a bull and a bear. Mr. Schacht handed over what he called "the obligatory hat that goes with the obligatory T-shirt and a sweater," all bearing Lucent's red logo.
As the culmination of weeks or months of work, those involved in stock issues are glad it is over. The so-called dog-and-pony shows, a routine of speeches, videos and slides that executives make to countless potential investors, end the night before opening day.
Big issues like Lucent generate so much attention that three teams traversed the country for 11 days, three or four cities a day, on the roadshows. More than 400 people packed the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel for the biggest.
Luckily for Lucent's weary executives, Morgan Stanley, the lead investment banker, cut the schedule short. With demand for the stock high and the market looking volatile, the bankers decided to go on April 4, rather than later in the month.
The night before, they huddled with executives from AT&T, which was spinning off Lucent as part of its plan to split into three companies, to agree on the offering price of $27. The deal signed, "everyone drank champagne," one participant said.
Mr. Schacht and the rest of the roadshow teams were still calling on customers. They did not return to the area until 10 or 11 P.M.
The next day, the big suspense was the price at which Lucent would open trading. Investment bankers consider the job well done if the stock begins trading at 5 to 20 percent above the offering price. Lucent fell within the range at $31.875, without going too high. "They'd be disappointed if it ended up at $36," a veteran said. Too much money would have been left on the table.
For Carleton S. Fiorina, an executive vice president at Lucent, the process was "exhausting and chaotic, but also exhilarating." Ms. Fiorina, who piloted Lucent's efforts to go public, added, "I feel like I've given birth here, literally."

HEADLINE: GUNMEN IN EGYPT KILL 18 IN ATTACK AT TOURIST HOTEL

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 18

 BODY:
Gunmen with automatic rifles and pistols opened fire early today on Greek tourists outside their hotel, killing 18 people and wounding at least 17 others in the most violent attack on foreigners since tourists became targets here in 1992.
Hours after the 7 A.M. attack, no group had claimed responsibility, nor did the Government officially accuse any party. 
 But senior Egyptian officials said they suspected cells of the Islamic Group, fundamentalist Muslims who have waged a violent four-year-old campaign to undermine Egypt's secular Government. Their former spiritual leader, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, is serving a life sentence in the United States for involvement in plots to bomb several New York City landmarks.
In a statement from prison made public this week, the Sheik called on his followers to avenge him, saying he was being treated shabbily, prevented from praying when he wants and subjected to frequent strip searches.
Witnesses to the shootings today said three men dressed in black jackets shouting the familiar Muslim refrain "God is great!" jumped from a taxi van to spray bullets at the tourists. Most of them were elderly Greeks on a pilgrimage, lining up at the palm-framed Europa hotel for a bus tour.
The firing, aimed both at the bus and inside the hotel lobby, lasted about three minutes, then the gunmen packed into the van and a fourth man, armed with a pistol, drove them away, the witnesses said.
The attack ended a hiatus in a terror campaign in Cairo, a metropolis of 13 million people, and will almost surely usher in a new crackdown on the fundamentalists by the Egyptian Government.
Recent roundups of the militants had restored enough confidence in the capital that Egyptian security forces had visibly relaxed their watch here in the last year, for example, by allowing unarmed guards to provide hotel security.
Grigorious Mafoutis, 65, had come to see the Orthodox Christian tourist sites and was waiting in the hotel's lobby to board a tour bus when the shooting began. "When I saw people screaming and running, I threw myself on the floor," he said. "I never suspected it could happen here."
Most of the dead and wounded were Greek visitors who had just arrived in Cairo from Israel on Wednesday after having celebrated Orthodox Easter there on Sunday.
The group operator, Mistakidis Tours of Athens, said the 88 Greek visitors had gone to Israel to visit churches and other religious sites.
At the hotel, 10 miles or so from the Pyramids, the killers left behind a scene of mayhem, with the dead and wounded lying on the ground among small pools of blood, abandoned shoes and smashed bottles of mineral water.
The dead included 14 women and 3 men, all Greek, and an Egyptian parking attendant.
Interior Ministry officials said the killings were part of the four-year-old campaign by militant Islamic groups to punish the Government by casting doubts on its stability and setting back the economy.
There was no evidence to link the slayings to Israeli attacks on Lebanon over the last week.
"The victims were Greeks from a country very friendly to Egypt and the aim was us -- the police, the security forces and the Government," a senior Egyptian official said tonight in a telephone interview.
Ahmed Hassan, one of the hotel's security guards, said he felt helpless in face of the attackers. "We are not armed," he said. "Even if we were, what would a gun have done to stop these automatic weapons. All I could do was to shout at the group to 'lay down, lay down.' "
Mr. Hassan said one attacker had a moustache and another was bald. He said both appeared to be in their 20's and were dressed casually.
Greek and Egyptian planes were reportedly sent to Cairo to take home the bodies of the dead and the wounded and the shocked survivors.
 In the last three years, the Egyptian police had largely succeeded in driving the Islamic militants out of major cities, reducing attacks to a few infrequent incidents in remote areas of southern Egypt.
The latest assaults were largely concentrated on the unarmed and unguarded minority of 10 million Christians who are landlords and farmers in many southern villages.
The attack this morning was evidently intended to deal a blow to Egypt's tourist industry, which had only recently recovered fully from the assaults on tourists that began in 1992.
The Government announced a week ago that 3.1 million visitors came to Egypt in 1995, the highest figure ever recorded. Officials had hoped to increase tourism revenues to $4 billion this season, which ends in June, from $3 billion a year earlier.
Today's attack, however, is bound to seriously dampen the momentum of tourist travel here.
Since 1992, 920 people have been killed in political violence, mostly Egyptian Christians, Government officials and police personnel, but also scores of Islamic militants. The Government campaign to crush the terrorism put an estimated 26,000 armed militants in jail, dozens of whom have been sentenced to death.
It is virtually certain that the crackdown on fundamentalists, even those of seemingly peaceful disposition will now go into higher gear, Government officials here said tonight.
The Islamic Group has repeatedly advised foreigners to avoid visiting Egypt, but its primary aim is believed to be to sabotage the fragile Egyptian economy in hopes of nudging President Hosni Mubarak's secular Government away from its Westward leanings toward an Islamic Government.
While these attacks have little chance of bringing down the Government, which is held up securely by the two pillars of support that brace all Egyptian regimes -- the army and security forces -- they do present a potent instrument of blackmail.
This is especially the case because the violence has the tacit support of some senior members of Egypt's religious establishment and of the Muslim Brotherhood, a militant political and social network that was established in the 1930's and that has spawned many of the militants who are doing the shooting today.
In a rare gesture, made perhaps in anticipation of a crackdown, the Muslim Brotherhood, which is officially banned but whose social activities have so far been tolerated by the Government, condemned the attack today, calling it "a disgrace to humanity."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Relaying Warning To Libya

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Deep inside a mountain, Libya is building the world's largest underground poison gas plant. Short of a bombing raid, which the United States is preparing for if it comes to that, the Clinton Administration is doing everything it can to deliver a message to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: Stop while you have the chance.
Those are some of the realities that make Libya and its chemical weapons program a major security issue and a critical military and diplomatic planning operation for the U.S. And these are four others: 
 1. Any debate inside the Government about whether the U.S. should use military power if needed to prevent the plan from going into operation is over. The conclusion is that Libya wants the plant as a shortcut to Mideast power. The colonel would become the quartermaster of poison gas and mustard gas weapons for terrorist groups and such countries as Iran and North Korea. Then the spread of chemical weapons would make them, like land mines, a military plague beyond effective containment -- but with mass loss of life.
2. Using European products, Asian go-betweens and Iranian money, Libya built the plant so deep into the mountain that the U.S. does not now have acceptable military weapons to destroy it. Unhappily, the U.S. did not fully comprehend what was going on until it became impossible to knock the plant out with acceptable weapons already in the arsenal.
3. Bombing by large nuclear weapons is not acceptable. The danger of drifting radioactive fallout is so terrifying that it has been ruled out.
But as a last resort, the use of a "small" nuclear weapon that could penetrate the mountain and destroy the plant without exterior fallout has not been dismissed. The U.S. expects to have such a weapon by 1997 -- a year before the plant might go into operation.
4. More likely would be a non-nuclear bomb that after penetration of the mountain would detonate another, spreading fire. The twin bomb would not destroy the plant. But it would put it out of operation long enough to give the colonel a choice: Shut the place down or invite more raids.
So far, in two tests at White Sands, N.M., the fuse of the second bomb did not work. Research and testing go on.
Meanwhile Washington is trying to stop Colonel Qaddafi from completing the plant, at Tarhunah, without the U.S. having to take military action. By the time Washington discovered the full extent of the plant in 1992, a couple of years after work began, it was three underground stories high, thousands of square feet large, a network of caverns connected by two-way truck-wide lanes.
For about three years the counter-operation was secret -- an effort to break Libyan foreign supply lines. Huge earthmovers and drills were sold by Europeans to middlemen in Asian countries, bomb-shelter blueprints may have come from Russia, and "dual-use" chemicals arrived from around the world -- "peaceful" in themselves but part of the first stage of making poison gases.
Washington believes it broke enough supply-line connections to slow the Libyans down, but not enough to stop them.
Now the U.S. has gone public with warnings it will not allow the plant to go into operation. Defense Secretary William Perry, intelligence chief John Deutch and Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have delivered them. The U.S. is trying to build a coalition of Arab and European leaders to persuade Libya to stop, or at least support America politically if military action is needed. (There's some talk of economic "inducements," but a Marshall plan for Libya would not make Americans cheer.)
That's the American double track -- avoid attack on the plant if possible, but prepare for it unless construction ends. Washington wants the colonel to know all that.
I think that's why I was able to gather much of the material for this column, after I wrote my first on the danger of the plant on Feb. 27. If so, I am glad to be part of the warning to Libya.
I also think I was encouraged to believe next year is the cutoff point of U.S. patience. But the U.S. officials I dealt with are extremely sophisticated. Could it be, colonel, that an attack might come earlier so you better stop now? No guarantees on American timing go with this column's conveyed message.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
The Minimum Wage: A Portrait

BYLINE: By David E. Rosenbaum 

 BODY:
Advocates of legislation to raise the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over the next two years, mostly Democrats, argue that it would provide a critical lift for low-wage workers. Opponents, mostly Republicans, say that the increase would lead to a loss of jobs and that the benefits would primarily be enjoyed by teen-agers and others who do not really need the raise. Economists disagree over which position is right. Both sides offer data to bolster their position. Unless otherwise indicated, the source of the figures here is the Labor Department.
