HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise by 10,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The number of new claims for jobless benefits rose by 10,000 last week -- the first increase in three weeks.
The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 360,000, up from a revised 350,000 a week earlier. 
 Claims last rose in the week that ended on March 23, when they shot up by 47,000, to 433,000, reflecting the effects of a strike that virtually closed down the General Motors Corporation. Employees at many of the auto maker's suppliers were also affected. After the strike, claims dropped by 27,000 during the week ended March 30, to 406,000, and by 56,000 the following week.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims fell by 6,500, to 387,250, the lowest since 383,500 in the period ended on March 23.

HEADLINE: Senate Defeats Dole Revision To Health Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
The Senate cleared the way tonight for passage of legislation that would make health insurance more accessible, narrowly defeating an amendment by Senator Bob Dole that opponents charged would have killed the bill.
Before adjourning close to midnight, the Senate disposed of all other amendments to the measure and scheduled a vote on final passage, which is assured, for Tuesday. 
 The bill would make it easier for workers to obtain health insurance coverage if they changed jobs. Mr. Dole sought to add to it tax incentives encouraging medical savings accounts, in which individuals would put aside money to pay for health care costs not covered by high-deductible insurance policies that holders of those accounts would be required to buy.
But the Dole amendment was rejected on a vote of 52 to 46, with 5 defecting Republicans joining all 47 Democrats.
Democrats had said President Clinton would veto the bill if the Dole provision was included, fearing that it would appeal to the rich and the healthy, who would benefit from lower-cost, higher-deductible insurance, and raise costs for the poor and the sick, who would not. And the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, made clear that Democrats would use the issue in the Presidential election campaign, saying of the amendment, "If this passes, health insurance reform once again is dead, and Bob Dole will have killed it."
Mr. Dole, the majority leader and presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, said the provision would enable someone to "tailor his or her own health care to his or her own needs." He said he would press for the amendment in the conference committee that will reconcile the Senate bill with one passed by the House, which includes the provision.
The larger bill was hailed by both parties as offering the kind of incremental health care improvements that Congress can manage after the demise of the Clinton universal-coverage plan in 1994. Mr. Dole said the bill's modest steps forward were the only sensible alternative to "President Clinton's insistence that turning the American health care system over to the Federal Government was the only solution."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who has urged sweeping health care legislation since 1970 and is a chief sponsor of the current bill, said: "The legislation is not comprehensive health reform. It will not solve all the problems in the current system. But it is a constructive step forward -- a step that will help millions of Americans."
The bill's other chief sponsor, Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Republican who is Mr. Dole's fellow Kansan in the Senate, and who opposed his amendment, said, "This legislation isn't exciting, but then again good government often isn't."
The bill would require insurance companies to cover workers who moved from one employer offering health insurance to another. If the new employer did not offer insurance, then the insurance company would be required to provide individual coverage, a provision that would also apply to workers who lost their jobs with insurance-offering employers.
That provision was hailed by Mrs. Kassebaum as a boon to 25 million Americans who, she said, now fear changing jobs because of insurance restrictions.
The bill would also prohibit insurers from denying coverage for a specific existing medical condition for more than 12 months.
And, under an amendment offered by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and adopted by the Senate tonight, health insurance plans would be required to deal with mental illness the same way they deal with physical ailments, providing the same maximums for hospital stays, office visits or lifetime spending limits for both. The House bill has no such provision.
Further, Mr. Dole did succeed in adding to the bill a provision that would allow self-employed people to deduct 80 percent of their health insurance premiums on their income tax returns. Under current law, they can deduct only 30 percent; the House bill, passed in March, would allow deducting 50 percent.
Another major difference between the two versions is that the House measure would impose severe limits on medical malpractice suits. The Senate bill has no such provision.
But the crucial issue for the House-Senate conference is sure to be the incentive for medical savings accounts, a proposal that would allow holders of those accounts to contribute to them in pretax dollars and also enjoy tax-deferred growth of the accounts' earnings. The idea has been pushed hard on Republicans by a marketer of such accounts, the Golden Rule Insurance Company, a major contributor to the party. The concept also fascinates Speaker Newt Gingrich, although he said on March 28 that he would not insist on it "if the President sends up a veto signal."
Mrs. Kassebaum and Mr. Kennedy made clear all day long that they would oppose any amendments, even those they personally favored, that lacked overwhelming support. One apparent ally of theirs, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, said this morning, "I would rather pass legislation that actually becomes law, even if it is not as far-reaching and perfect as I would like it to be, than to make a political statement with legislation that ends up in the scrap heap of unfinished business."
But later, when Mr. Dole went all out for his amendment, Senator Simpson voted with him. Another vocal opponent of amending the bill, Senator Bill Frist, a Tennessee Republican, sat uncomfortably through almost every minute of the roll-call as one side and then the other lobbied him. He finally voted with Mr. Dole.
Yet another Republican, Senator William S. Cohen of Maine, first voted against Mr. Dole and then switched to side with him.
In the end, though, Mrs. Kassebaum was joined by four other Republicans in opposing the amendment: Senators Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, Slade Gorton of Washington and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon. Two Republicans were absent, and, after stretching the 20 minutes that it normally takes for a roll-call to 35 minutes, Mr. Dole acknowledged defeat, at least for today, and let the voting end.
Throughout the day, there was an alternating between politics and substance. Politics dominated.
After the vote on the Dole amendment, Vice President Al Gore, who had sat in the Senate president's chair to break a tie if he had to, stepped outside the chamber and assailed the proposal. He called it an attack on Medicare, the health program for the elderly, which the amendment did not address.
One Republican after another said the larger bill showed the error of Mr. Clinton's 1994 plan. Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, for example, said the bill demonstrated that "improvements in health insurance can be made without a massive government takeover."
The partisanship had time to thrive because except for the medical savings accounts, there was little disagreement on substance.
Senator Kennedy said the bill was needed because "those who have insurance deserve the security of knowing that their coverage cannot be canceled, especially when they need it most."
And Mr. Dole said that "passage of this bill will not only improve our health care system, it could very well restore the faith of the American public that the work of Congress is not just a series of political stalemates."

* Guarantees that most people in health plans sponsored by employers would be able to obtain health insurance after switching or losing their jobs without being denied coverage because of existing medical problems.
 
* Guarantees coverage for many people leaving an employer-sponsored plan, but does not set Federal limits on the premiums, leaving regulation to the states.
 
* Assists employers and individuals in forming private, voluntary coalitions to purchase health insurance.
 
* Generally requires insurers to offer group health plans to all employers in markets where they operate.
 
* Forbids employer-sponsored health plans to deny coverage or charge higher premiums to individual employees because of their health problems.
 
* Gradually increases the tax deduction for health insurance purchased by the self-employed to 80 percent from 30 percent.
 
* Provides new tax breaks for people who spend money on nursing home care or buy insurance to cover the cost of long-term care.
 
* Allows accelerated tax-free payments of life insurance benefits to the terminally ill. (pg. A26)

Microsoft Profit Rises 42%, Topping Analysts' Forecasts
Microsoft reported a 42 percent earnings rise to $562 million, beating analyst estimates and belying reports of a slump in the personal computer industry.
Its shares soared $3.0625 before the announcement, to $109, but traders then backed off, sending the stock down to $107 in after-hours trading. [Page D3.]
 
Tainted-Blood Settlement Offer
Four makers of blood-clotting products that infected thousands of hemophiliacs with the virus that causes AIDS plan to offer $600 million to resolve suits against them. [D2.]
 
Agency Approves Loral Merger
The F.T.C. approved the $9.1 billion merger of Lockheed Martin and Loral after the companies agreed to certain restrictions on how they will operate. The approval came hours after the Pentagon endorsed the deal, saying it would have little impact on its ability to buy weapons from competing sources. The merger is expected to take place Monday. [D3.]
 
Wrangling Over a Bell Merger
Bell Atlantic is pushing to value Nynex shares at a discount to market value, bankers say, as the two companies continue wrangling over merger terms. Indebted Nynex has reason to wrap things up quickly, to get back to the capital market. Market Place. [D8.]
McDonnell Earnings Up 25%
McDonnell Douglas earnings jumped 25 percent, to $198 million, with impressive performances by all three segments. Some analysts raised their estimates for 1996. [D3.]
 
Gains at American Express
American Express profits increased 12 percent, to $396 million, despite surging loan losses on its credit and charge cards. [D8.]
 
NBC Lifts G.E. Profits
General Electric earnings rose 11 percent, to $1.52 billion, benefiting from strong gains at its NBC and plastics units. [D17.]
 
Stocks Move Higher
Stock prices rose narrowly, on good earnings, and the technology-laden Nasdaq index set a high. The Dow Jones industrials inched up 1.81 points, to 5,551.74. [D9.]
 
Signs of a stronger economy dampened the credit markets. The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 8/32 in price. [D18.]
 
Health Insurance
Bill Advances
The Senate cleared the way for legislation making health insurance more accessible to workers who change jobs. The Senate defeated an amendment by Senator Bob Dole that would have threatened a veto. [A1.]
 
Sears Profit Rises 22%
Sears, Roebuck's earnings from continuing operations rose 21.8 percent, to $151 million, benefiting from strong Easter sales. [D4.]
 
Drug Makers Have Strong Quarter
More drug companies posted higher earnings, setting off triggering a stock rally in the sector. [D18.]
 
Disney Drops a Times Sq. Venture
Walt Disney dropped plans to run time-share condominiums at a hotel to be built in New York on 42d Street. [B6.]
 
A Minimum Wage Portrait
The minimum wage, now at $4.25 an hour, is far below its historical norms, after adjustment for inflation. [A26.]
 
In New Media, East vs. West
The fledgling new media industry is generating a big-time coast-to-coast fight for bragging rights. Westerners scoff at a study, conducted by Coopers & Lybrand, that found 71,500 workers in 4,200 companies in the New York area working in new media. [D4.]
 
Japanese Make Arrest in Debt Crisis
Japanese authorities arrested a property magnate in an apparent move to begin pinning responsibility for the nation's debt crisis. His companies cannot repay $2.2 billion. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Expect Gas Prices To Keep Going Up

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As evidenced by recent Business Day articles (April 11 and 17), consumers are facing steadily increasing gasoline prices as a result of rapidly increasing demand. This textbook supply-and-demand relationship is being worsened by omissions and commissions perpetrated in Washington that are letting energy demand soar and pushing prices up. 
 For example, we expect legislation that was enacted last year to increase the national speed limit to result in heightened demand of seven million gallons a day, costing more than $3 billion annually and increasing oil imports by 10 percent.
A new proposal to vitiate the executive branch's ability to raise Federal fuel-economy standards will, in our view, cut down the nation's most successful oil-demand reduction effort. These standards have already saved the typical buyer of a new car an average of $3,300 at the gas pump over the life of the car and lessened the country's oil demand by three million barrels a day.
Congress has refused full financing of a research effort between the Federal Government and automakers that is intended to triple fuel efficiency performance. Meantime, the Federal budget for operating assistance for mass transit was hit: the President proposed a 37 percent cut and Congress approved a 50 percent cut.
In the past year, Congress has cut the Administration's request for energy efficiency and alternative energy sources by one-third, leading to delays in bringing about new technologies and applications that will help lessen demand for gasoline, heating oil and other fossil fuels.
As long as demand for gasoline and other finite energy sources keeps going up faster than supplies, price increases for drivers will stay in the fast lane.
 
DAVID M. NEMTZOW
Washington, April 17, 1996
 
President, Alliance to Save Energy

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Piracy Grows in Mexico, U.S. Companies Shout Foul

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
Luis is proud of his work, and he backs it up with a personal guarantee. From his stall in a teeming Mexico City market, Luis peddles the latest in pirated videotapes of American movies. Recently his prize item was Walt Disney's "Toy Story," which is not even out on video yet in the United States.
"I taped it myself," Luis assured a hesitant customer. "If there's any problem, bring it back and I'll make you a better one." 
 After losing an estimated $485 million annually to Mexican pirates in recent years, American music, film and software industries have set off alarm bells about the rapidly growing business of illegal entrepreneurs like Luis, who, like other vendors, would not identify himself further. Industry leaders complain that Mexico has grossly failed to enforce its own laws protecting intellectual property, violating the tough copyright standards of the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement.
Piracy in Mexico is a major trade issue in the making that the Clinton Administration is not eager to confront right now. Since the free trade agreement remains a prickly subject for many Americans, President Clinton's advisers hope to keep Mexico out of the public debate during the campaign. In contrast to its high-profile clash with China over piracy, the Administration discusses the problem with Mexico in low-key closed-door meetings.
Mexican officials acknowledge that President Ernesto Zedillo is not keen to come down hard on a trade, even an illicit one, that is sustaining thousands of poor Mexicans through an economic depression.
"Mexico has become one of the biggest pirate markets in the world," the International Intellectual Property Alliance said in a recent report to the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor. The Washington-based Alliance, which includes American film, music and business software companies, called Mexico's enforcement record "abysmal" and sent a 10-point emergency reform plan to President Zedillo, threatening to file a formal trade complaint if there was no change over the summer.
William H. Gates, the chairman and chief executive of the Microsoft Corporation, told President Zedillo of his worries about piracy in a private meeting in Mexico City earlier this year. According to the Business Software Alliance, the industry association based in Washington, four-fifths of all business software programs now used in Mexico are unlicensed copies.
Mr. Zedillo responded to the pressure by reviving a high-level committee on piracy that went dormant after meeting once in 1993. Also, Mexican and American trade officials agreed to meet monthly to monitor the issue. An American trade official familiar with the meetings said the Mexicans pledged to put new controls in place, and the American official described them as "very cooperative."
The heart of the problem is in Tepito, a tough Mexico City neighborhood that is home to one of the world's biggest bazaars for pirated videos, music cassettes and software. The crowded labyrinth where hundreds of yelling vendors hawk their wares is just a few blocks away from the offices of the top Mexican prosecutor in charge of stopping the pirates and right around the corner from the national headquarters of the police who are supposed to hunt them down.
In the alleyways of Tepito there is no sign of a crackdown. In dozens of open-air stalls, commerce is thriving.
Music cassettes are a favorite product of Tepito vendors because they are easy and cheap to copy. Tapes of the Beatles are selling strongly, especially a collection of their classics labeled "Golden of Memories," apparently by a pirate with less than perfect English. On a tape of Madonna's "Something to Remember," in the spot where the Warner Music label should be, a service-minded counterfeiter stamped a message in Spanish: "Thank you for your patronage." The tapes sold for 5 pesos, or 67 cents each.
In his booth with a sheet of pink plastic for a roof, another youthful merchant named Alfonso offered his own catalogue of cassettes that can be made to order in an hour, among them a Gloria Estefan medley.
Gabriel Abaroa, a Mexican executive who is president of the Recording Industry Federation of Latin America, said a recent census showed that pirates sold about 66 million cassettes, for a total of more than $90 million, in the Tepito market last year. By comparison, the entire legal music industry in all of Mexico sold only 30 million cassettes.
A whole section of Tepito's sprawl is occupied by video copiers. The Oscar-winning film "Braveheart," which has been out on video for only a month in the United States (mainly for rental, since it sells for about $100), is available for purchase here for 20 pesos, or $2.70. But let the buyer beware, because quality is uneven. One tape of "Toy Story," the computer-animated children's film, was sloppily recorded over the action movie "Mortal Kombat." Bloody scenes emerged suddenly from the happy Disney cartoons.
"We felt that Nafta signaled a level of maturity in Mexico that meant that business conditions would improve," said Tim Kuik, anti-piracy director of the Motion Picture Association of America Inc., by telephone from Los Angeles. "Instead, the level of legitimate distribution was greatly reduced. We began to lose terrain we had already gained."
The problem for the Clinton Administration is different in Mexico from what it is in China, where the Government encourages and protects huge pirate industries that cost American companies $1.8 billion last year. (These losses are calculated partly from wholesale prices, partly from actual pirate prices.)
In Mexico, the Government has tolerated the explosion of a business that trade officials say supports a handful of large pirates and thousands of small sellers making subsistence livings.
The criminal fight against piracy is in the hands of an energetic but novice 26-year-old prosecutor, Ernesto Soriano Valdez, who has a staff of just 15 agents to cover the whole country. When Mr. Soriano took over the post in October 1995 he conducted an aggressive series of raids, but this year the raids have fallen off. Out of hundreds of cases brought before the anti-piracy prosecutor's office since 1994, only six pirates have been convicted, and none have served substantial jail terms.
Mr. Soriano said he was hampered by Mexican laws. "Our legislation is very benevolent with this type of crime," he said. Pirates are immediately released on bail as low as a few dollars and face fines of less than $150.
And that is when the pirates are actually caught. Mireille Gotsis, a Microsoft corporate counsel who heads the Latin America committee for the software group, said that in four separate cases, evidence seized in police raids -- computers, diskettes, office records -- vanished from police warehouses before the cases reached court. In several other cases word of impending raids leaked out of the prosecutor's office, giving pirates time to pack up and flee.
So after several years of frustration, the Business Software Alliance decided to settle directly with pirates for damages where it could, Ms. Gotsis said .
The settlements infuriated Mr. Soriano, who accused the companies of "obtaining juicy profits through economic deals." His office, he said, has different goals.
"We are not that interested in helping them recover their losses," Mr. Soriano said. "Our interest is in punishing criminals, not correcting economic damage."
Industry executives argue that Mr. Soriano's operation needs to grow and change its tactics to signal that piracy is no longer tolerated. "There will never be a frightened pirate until one of them goes to jail," Mr. Aboroa, the music executive, said.
But Mr. Soriano said the Government had decided to catch pirates in highway roadblocks and clandestine factory raids, but not to go after Tepito.
"There will be no more frontal attacks in these street markets," Mr. Soriano said. "There is a risk of generating a social conflict."

HEADLINE: Columbia Defeats the P.C. Separatists

BYLINE: By Chris Glaros; Chris Glaros is president of the Columbia College Student Council.

 BODY:
Some of my fellow students at Columbia staged a two-week protest this month to try to force the university to establish an ethnic studies department. Such a department would be wrong. Twenty-two students were arrested after more than 150 occupied Low Library, the main administrative building. About 100 blocked the central classroom building for four days to protest the school's "hegemonic and white supremacist" curriculum.
While I admire such activism and dedication, these tactics only disrupted the education for which we pay so much. Many students disagreed, not only with the means used but with the ends demanded. 
 An ethnic studies department would divide the curriculum along racial lines, implying that the study of whites and nonwhites should be segregated. This is not only an academic issue. It is a national issue that lies at the core of the American challenge: how to build one nation from many peoples and preserve democracy for all.
I chose Columbia because it is one of the country's most diverse institutions of higher education. Its students represent nearly every race, ethnicity and conceivable social and economic background. More and more, it is becoming a microcosm of the nation.
The university is struggling to diversify its curriculum while creating a strong campus community based on common bonds. But as the protest showed, our common bonds are increasingly ignored as we become more diverse. Though the university has made tremendous progress, the ethnic studies issue indicates that it still has far to go.
Should we insure that cultures and traditions that have been excluded from the curriculum are embraced and taught? Of course. But do we need a separate department to focus only on the ethnicities of nonwhites? No. Separatism isolates and marginalizes not only academic disciplines but students, too.
It is necessary to study all ethnicities. Native Americans and Americans of African, Asian and Latino descent have given their blood, sweat and tears in the development of this nation. But so have Americans of European descent. I am tired of people celebrating difference to the neglect of commonality. This includes politicians who make careers of ethnic divisiveness.
In an age of declining political discourse, of an "us versus them" mentality, we must work together to elevate the national dialogue. Tactics of division and polarization must be rejected everywhere.
In saying no to an ethnic studies department, Columbia has shown great leadership in taking a road less traveled: It refused to become another haven of political correctness. It has shown commitment to individuality, pluralism and community -- ideals we must all embrace, now more than ever.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Here's a Stadium Plan That Will Work

BYLINE: By Meyer S. Frucher; Meyer S. Frucher is an executive vice president of Olympia & York and a former president of Battery Park City.

 BODY:
Faced with shrinking revenues and cuts in services, New York City has to find ways to grow. Done a little differently, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposal to build a ball park over the Long Island Rail Road yards in the West 30's offers this chance -- without dislocating residents or businesses.
In fact, it's a mistake to cast such a proposal as a sports project. The goal should not be simply to create a stadium but to develop an engine of growth that can create jobs and revenues for years to come. 
 My suggestion: Build a single-purpose stadium on the site -- between 30th and 33d Streets, next to the West Side highway -- and make it the center of a master plan to revitalize the moribund area around the rail yards. At the same time, transform the stadium in the Bronx into two new schools and playing fields.
The dreary neighborhood around the L.I.R.R. storage yard has confounded planners' attempts at development for 50 years. This area is primarily a warehouse district for a port that no longer exists. It is not much of a home or a workplace, nor is it a magnet for investment or tourism. (Under a reorganization settlement, my employer, Olympia & York, is shedding property in this district at a substantial loss, after 10 years of trying, and failing, to develop the parcel.)
A ball park over the rail yards could spur the city to improve transportation into the area and speed up construction of the esplanade and park that are planned, but not yet financed under the scaled-down Westway project.
The storage yard district is already near a mass transportation hub. The port for ferries to and from New Jersey is across the street from the site. And it would be easy and relatively inexpensive to create a subway shuttle, using L.I.R.R. tracks, from Penn Station.
The shuttle could emerge at 11th Avenue and 33d Street at a station that would serve the new stadium, the nearby Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the planned park and esplanade and any commercial enterprises that might spring up.
To discourage driving to the games, parking would be limited to existing spaces in the area, with minimal new parking for stadium employees and boxholders. About one-third of Yankee fans drive to the games in the Bronx. A West Side stadium would likely increase the number of Manhattan dwellers who go to games, and, with more convenient mass transit, decrease the percentage of fans who drive.
The overall plan -- upgraded transportation, the ball park, the waterfront development, changes in zoning to spur economic renewal-- could be put under the auspices of a single development authority like the Battery Park City Authority.
How to finance this master plan?
* Make the new stadium and waterfront area a so-called tax-increment district, where the increased taxes that result from a growth in property values pay for the structural improvements that helped create that growth. Once those costs are paid, however, the taxes would go into the city's general revenues.
* Insist that the ball park itself -- which would cost $250 million to $300 million -- be built with private money. Private developers, after all, get tax breaks for such investments. (It does not make sense to build a stadium that would serve other teams or other uses. The returns would not be worth the added cost.) Would the Yankee organization be willing to spend this money or find others to do it? I believe it behooves them to stay in New York. They'll make a lot of money here.
* Pay for the $100 million deck covering the L.I.R.R. yard (this would be the floor of the stadium) by selling the right to name the stadium. This may shock traditionalists, but there may be no other way to keep spending down.
The stadium plan could be a winner for the Bronx as well.
In part because of lack of space, no new high school has been built in the Bronx since 1973, and the borough needs to make room for 14,000 more high school students. Two new high schools could be built in Yankee Stadium in the space occupied by the left field and right field stands. And by building the schools under the mezzanine using the stadium's outside walls, the existing playing field and some 35,000 seats could be used for sports and athletics.
The goal in planning a new stadium should not be to keep the Yankees in New York. It should be to keep New York growing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
News of German Economic Woes Helps Propel the Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday, strengthening on a new report of German economic malaise and uncertainty over the outcome of high-level meetings of finance ministers this weekend in Washington.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5120 German marks from 1.5015 marks on Thursday. The dollar traded at 107.36 yen, up from 106.65 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5140 from $1.5185. 
 The advance largely erased the dollar's losses the day before, which came despite a half-point cut in interest rates by Germany's central bank, aimed at stimulating the largest economy in Europe.
German rate reductions have tended to weaken the mark against the dollar and other important currencies, but the degree of Thursday's decrease, if not the timing, had been widely expected, so it had already been factored into foreign exchange rates.
Currency traders said the dollar advanced against the mark yesterday after a monthly report from the Ifo Institute for Economic Research, a prominent group in Munich, Germany, showed a sharp drop in business confidence in March.
The report compounded fears that Germany could be sliding into a recession and aroused speculation that the Bundesbank might have to follow up the latest rate reduction with another cut soon.
Traders reasoned that Germany's central bank had little choice in the matter because the German Government could not increase spending to stimulate the economy. Doing so would raise Germany's deficit and risk violating terms of the European Union pact aimed at monetary union by the end of the century.
"The German economy is weak, and there has to be some mechanism German authorities have that can counteract that," said Seth Cohen, director of foreign-exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company. "It means more of the brunt of stimulating the economy is falling on the Bundesbank's shoulders."
Other traders attributed some of the dollar's strength yesterday to speculation about a finance ministers meeting this weekend by the Group of Seven major industrial nations in Washington.
Some traders speculated that Japan would be asked by the other six nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and the United States -- not to raise interest rates because that would put pressure on them to do likewise.
"The market will be a little bit interested to see if there's pressure on Japan to keep rates low," said Bob Near, a vice president at the Bank of New York. "That would help the dollar."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Brighter, But the Cheering Isn't by Leaders

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 19

 BODY:
The Mexican stock exchange hit record highs four days this week, interest rates dropped to their lowest point in seven months, and the once-wobbly peso traded at its strongest level since January.
But because the Mexican economy is still so fragile after last year's peso crisis, even the Government's top officials were reluctant to express much optimism. 
 "The possibility of a collapse has completely disappeared," was the less-than-triumphant declaration of President Ernesto Zedillo as he opened the annual meeting of the Mexican stock exchange convention on Monday. He referred specifically to the dangerously weak banking sector, but in many ways the remark captured feelings about the economy as a whole.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz has also been restrained. He addressed Mexico's stock market leaders on Tuesday and said that while the Government's tough recovery plan was working, "most of the population hasn't yet seen any improvement in their lives."
The reticence of the Government to crow about an economic recovery stems in part from its disastrous record last year in which just about every official projection turned out to be wrong. It is difficult for officials to declare an end to the worst recession in 63 years when domestic consumption is anemic, many families are burdened with unpayable debts and prices for gasoline, milk and even tortillas continue to rise.
For the recovery to be real, Mr. Zedillo said, Mexico will have to perform the trick of increasing both domestic savings and domestic consumption. That will take time for the economy to heal more and for the Government to establish the private pension funds that it hopes will increase the paltry rate of domestic savings.
Nonetheless, market analysts in the United States have seized on the rash of positive indicators. "The recovery has begun," is the headline of a typical report on Mexico, this one by HSBC James Capel, a research company in New York.
"What you have now is a situation where people have to be making the assumption that a strong peso is compatible with economic growth," said Felix Boni, director of Mexico research for James Capel. "If that's true, then the market's a buy."
Even analysts who normally are cautious about predicting Mexico's ability to bounce back now sound downright exuberant. "The Mexican bolsa is blowing away everyone in the hemisphere," said Michael M. Churchill, assistant director of global research at Polyconomics Inc., a market research firm in New Jersey, speaking of the stock exchange.
"The thing driving the rally is December peso futures," Mr. Churchill said. He was referring to contracts to buy pesos on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which in the last month have strengthened from 9.5 to the dollar for December delivery to 8.86 currently. In New York foreign exchange trading today, it took 7.3850 pesos to buy a dollar. As the peso gains value against the dollar, the trend improves the earnings of many Mexican companies.
Even with the reserve exercised by Mexican officials this week, it is clear that they have tried to reshape expectations. For example, President Zedillo pointed out that the bolsa index had more than doubled since it hit a low of less than 1,500 last year.
The market exchange closed today at a record high of 3,284. In just the last week, the exchange has gained 3.45 percent, and since the beginning of the year, it has rallied 18 percent.
Mr. Zedillo also made headlines when he said on Monday that the economy would expand by 5 percent in the second quarter of this year. But he was using as a base the dismal second quarter of 1995, in which the economy contracted 10.5 percent.
The head of Mexico's central bank, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, delivered what was taken as good news on inflation, projecting that in April prices would rise 2.8 percent, even though substantial wage increases and price increases took effect on April 1. In subsequent months, prices will jump less than 2 percent, Mr. Mancera said, for total inflation of 20.5 percent by the end of the year. If that holds true, and many private economists think the estimate is too low, it would drive up company earnings and stimulate domestic buying.
Mexican business leaders have harshly criticized Mr. Mancera, saying he has strangled the recovery by keeping an iron grip on the monetary supply in order to bring down inflation. But he made it clear that he did not intend to change his policy.
He did leave open the possibility, however, of someday abandoning the floating exchange rate that has been in effect since the peso was devalued in December 1994.
"We have a floating exchange rate, and I do not see the possibility or the advantage of changing it in the forseeable future," Mr. Mancera said. "I want to underline the term foreseeable, because in these areas it is not easy, nor proper, to establish dogmas."
Government figures showed unemployment dropping to 6 percent, but the figures are unreliable. Industrial production is improving and Mexican exports totaled $7.5 billion in March, the highest level ever.

HEADLINE: Tiff Over Intellectual Property;
Should Columbia Own Fruit of Economist's Labor?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Did Columbia University convince Geoffrey H. Moore, a world-renowned pioneer in business cycle forecasting, to sign over the rights to his life's work, then callously evict him from his office? Or did the university walk the last mile with Dr. Moore, an 82-year-old economist, absorbing his deficits for a decade and arranging for a wealthy alumnus to underwrite his money-losing research center before cutting off his paycheck?
Just who has the better claim to the high moral ground in this embarrassingly public dispute between the Ivy League university and an icon of economics remains murky. 
 What is clear, though, is that Columbia's problem is linked to the widely pursued effort these days by universities to profit from the intellectual output of their professors. Columbia, for example, expects to earn nearly $50 million from intellectual property this year, most of it from licensing biotechnology and other scientific endeavors.
The tangled tale of Dr. Moore and his institute is a study in what can go wrong when a university goes out of its way to provide a home for research unrelated to the interests of its regular teaching faculty.
Dr. Moore was in the vanguard of economists -- a group that included the former Federal Reserve chairman Arthur Burns -- to search for statistics that would explain past recessions and predict future ones. Their approach to analyzing ups and downs of the economy, begun under the auspices of the National Bureau of Economic Research in the 1940's, has achieved commercial success in the business world. Indeed, Stephen McNees, a consultant to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, notes that "it won the war for popular acceptance over formal econometric modeling in forecasting business cycle turning points."
Dr. Moore, who continued the development of his predictive indexes at his own center, garnered clients like Chase Manhattan Bank, Business Week magazine, and the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Publication of the Government-sponsored index of leading indicators, a dozen measures derived from Dr. Moore's work and used by many to forecast economic activity six months to a year down the road, has often had as much impact on markets as Government reports on inflation or employment.
And for decades, the pronouncement by Dr. Moore that the economy had entered a recession has been regarded as the closest thing around to a certification from Mount Olympus. "His work is without peer," says Hank Hatch, the head of EMG Advisors, a money management company in Fairfield, Conn.
But this approach to business cycle research went out of fashion long ago among academics. They favor the use of more complex models designed to answer the same questions. Though Dr. Moore's place in the economist's pantheon is assured and forecasting is making a bit of a comeback in some quarters -- he was named the American Economic Association's "distinguished fellow" for 1995 -- his welcome at the ivory tower has at times been strained.
In 1983 Dr. Moore was forced to find a new host for his Center for International Business Cycle Research when Rutgers University chose not to underwrite his deficits. The Columbia Business School was then approached by some of Dr. Moore's friends.
The association seemed a natural since Columbia's economics department had once been home to Arthur Burns. And while the business school was prepared to supply seed money, the university administration apparently gambled that with the prestige of the Columbia connection the center would quickly become self-sufficient through the sale of forecasting services. "All research institutes are expected to pay their own way," Michael Crow, Columbia's vice provost, said.
Revenues from the sale of Dr. Moore's indicators did increase, perhaps in part because of his coup in predicting the 1990-91 recession before other forecasters. But according to Mr. Crow, they were never large enough to cover the center's annual budget, which had ballooned to as much as $600,000. By 1993, the cumulative deficit exceeded $1 million, and the university ran out of patience.
Giulio Pontecorvo, a professor at the business school, rode to the rescue. As a member of the center's board of faculty advisers he had earlier raised private donations for the center. And he persuaded one former "angel," Edward Armaly, a Lebanese-born British investment banker who had earned a Ph.D. from the Columbia Business School, to underwrite what was expected to be a long-term solution to the center's financing problem.
Under the December 1993 deal, Dr. Moore assigned to Columbia the rights to the dozens of economic indexes he developed. In turn, the university licensed this intellectual property for 15 years to the Foundation for International Business and Economic Research, a company registered in the Cayman Islands that was controlled by Mr. Armaly. Columbia received $150,000, plus 5 percent of future royalties. In a separate contract the foundation, known as Fiber, agreed to pay at least $150,000 a year for five years to Columbia to support continuing research at the center.
The foundation demonstrated its determination to create a viable business by luring Victor Zarnowitz, a well-known researcher in business cycles, out of retirement to help Dr. Moore oversee the work. The center's work was marketed to bond traders on Wall Street.
But within months of the new union there was friction between the center's staff and Richard Pantel, a new manager brought in by Mr. Armaly. Some of the center's staff members were transferred to work at the foundation, while others were dismissed. And last year, to the university's dismay, Fiber failed to come up with the minimum research budget it had guaranteed for the center.
"We have been negotiating in good faith with the university," Mr. Pantel responded, "but the research must have commercial applications."
Given its policy that research centers should be self-sufficient, Columbia was unwilling to reassume the center's obligations. It finally threw in the towel last month. "I am sorry to have to inform you that, due to the loss of funding for CIBCR, I am forced to put you on leave without salary," the Business School dean, Meyer Feldberg, wrote to Dr. Moore.
Even before the cutoff, Dr. Moore and several of his colleagues moved to set up a rival to Fiber called the Economic Cycle Research Institute. "I think an amicable resolution is still possible," explains Dr. Moore, who says he still wants to re-establish ties to Columbia that makes future operations self-financing.
Lakshman Achuthan, who is serving as the new institute's business manager, notes that its first newsletter will be published next week. "We hope to regain the rights to sell Dr. Moore's indexes," he says, "but we'll go forward either way."
Where you sit determines where you stand on whether Columbia has an obligation to sustain the center. Mr. Crow, the vice provost, dismisses the idea that the university should treat Dr. Moore more generously than other scientists with research appointments. Moreover, he notes that the fees that Columbia received from licensing Dr. Moore's research amounted to a fraction of the center's debt and less than one-half of 1 percent of Columbia's total income from royalties on faculty research.
But Mr. Achuthan insists that the university has played hardball, exploiting the unworldliness of the aging researcher in convincing him to sign over the fruits of decades of labor without explicitly assuring future financing. "The man has been prohibited from using his life's work," he argues.
Moreover, Mr. Achuthan insists that the center's debt to Columbia is much smaller than the university contends. "When the deal was done with Fiber," he says, "the university was made whole financially."
The root of the problem, it now seems clear, was in grafting a research operation onto an economics faculty with which it had so little in common. The isolation left Dr. Moore and his colleagues with few allies within the university who had a stake in raising funds. And it almost guaranteed that the university would be faced with the problem of phasing out the operation once Dr. Moore left the scene.
How could it have happened, then? "Big universities are complicated places," laments Philip Cagan, a recently retired professor of economics at Columbia. "Nobody knows what anybody else is doing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Smaller Stocks Rise, As Dow Average Falls 16.26
Smaller issues took the leadership role in a mixed stock market. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 1,138.70, establishing its third new record of the week. And the American Stock Exchange market value index climbed 2.80 points, to 585.88, marking its fourth consecutive record and its 18th high this year. 
 But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.26 points, to 5,535.48, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased just 1.46 points, to 645.07. A series of computer-assisted sell orders and the simultaneous expiration of options on stocks and on stock indexes fed the market's gyrations. [Page 37.]
 
Open short positions reached a record level for the third consecutive month on the New York Stock Exchange, showing expectations of declines ahead. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest was at its highest level since its peak in October 1994. [35.]
 
 
Archer-Daniels Settlement in Doubt
A Federal judge cast doubt on the proposed $45 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing Archer-Daniels Midland and three competitors of price-fixing, saying Archer's $25 million share may be too low. United States District Judge Milton Shadur ordered attorneys for both sides to revise court filings to indicate the settlement reserve. [34.]
 
Westinghouse Considers 2 Stocks
Westinghouse Electric, the nation's biggest broadcaster since acquiring CBS in November, said that it was weighing the idea of separate stocks for its broadcasting and industrial operations. Westinghouse also said it would take a charge of $813 million, or $1.85 a share, to sell its environmental services businesses, close a Florida plant and adopt accounting changes. [34.]
 
Ascent to Acquire Spectravision
Ascent Entertainment Group agreed to acquire the assets of Spectravision, a rival company in pay-per-view television, which has been operating under bankruptcy-law protection, in exchange for canceling $600 million in debt. [35.]
 
Freer Use of Nicotine Patches
Smokers should be able to buy two brands of nicotine patches without a prescription, a panel recommended to the F.D.A. Over-the-counter sales of the nicotine gum Nicorette started this week. [9.]
 
Mexicans Pirate U.S. Software
Mexican piracy of American music, film and software is a major trade issue in the making that the Clinton Administration is not eager to confront right now. But after losing an estimated $485 million annually to Mexican pirates in recent years, American audiovisual industries have set off alarm bells about illegal entrepreneurs who violate both Mexican laws and the tough copyright standards of the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement. [1.]
 
U.S. and China Hold Talks
Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, opened talks in the Hague in an effort to resolve disputes over trade and software piracy -- for which Washington has threatened $2 billion in retaliatory sanctions -- among other issues. [5.]
 
Treasury Securities Rally in Price
Prices of Treasury securities turned higher, ending a three-day slump, sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.78 percent, from 6.83 percent on Thursday. One reason was overseas buying in the wake of Thursday's interest rate cut by the Bundesbank, which led to cuts throughout Europe. [43.]
 
The dollar rallied, responding to a new report of German economic malaise and uncertainty over the outcome of high-level meetings of finance ministers this weekend in Washington. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.5120 German marks from 1.5015 marks on Thursday and to 107.36 yen, from 106.65 yen. [36.]
 
Wheat futures prices jumped 7.5 cents to $6.08 a bushel in Chicago as wet soil conditions in the northern Plains delayed spring plantings. Copper and crude oil contracts rose. [36.]
 
Foreign Policy Snags Company
A Georgia concern is caught in the middle of a confrontation involving American policy toward North Korea. NAC International, the company, performs nuclear cleanup and is based in Newt Gingrich's district. Washington needs to spend $4.1 million to complete the project, but an Indiana Republican, Representative John T. Myers, is balking. [11.]

HEADLINE: Small Stocks Lift Nasdaq; Dow Declines 16.26 Points

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Smaller issues took the leadership role yesterday in a mixed stock market.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 1,138.70, establishing its third new record this week. And the American Stock Exchange market value index climbed 2.80 points, to 585.88, marking its fourth consecutive record and its 18th high this year. 
 But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.26 points, to 5,535.48, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased just 1.46 points, to 645.07. These market actions were spurred by a series of computer-assisted sell orders and the simultaneous expiration of options on individual stocks and options on stock indexes.
"The market is shifting into the smaller-to-mid-size companies that have underperformed the Dow and the top 50 stocks in the S.& P.," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist of Legg Mason. "Small-cap stocks were relatively more attractive than the bigger guys."
Advancing issues outpaced decliners on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,390 to 915. Turnover on the Big Board was 422.4 million shares, compared with 415.2 million shares on Thursday.
Bond yields moved lower, and analysts forecast that inflation would remain under control. The yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 6.78 percent from 6.83 percent Thursday.
Software stocks were higher yesterday, starting with Microsoft, the country's largest software company, which reported a better-than-expected 42 percent profit increase after the close of the market on Thursday. Microsoft gained 3/4, to 109 3/4; Pure Software vaulted 4 3/4, to 41, and Shiva Corporation added 9 1/2, to 108.
The report also lent strength to computer makers. Compaq gained 7/8, to 41 7/8, and Digital Equipment rose 1 5/8, to 54 3/8, in active trading on the Big Board. On Nasdaq, Dell Computer rose 1/8, to 41 1/4. But I.B.M., which has been battered this week after issuing a cautious outlook in an otherwise strong earnings report, struggled again, losing 1/8, to 105 3/8.
Drug issues continued to show strength in reaction to good first-quarter results. For instance, Eli Lilly closed at 60 3/4, up 1 7/8, and Pfizer closed at 70, up 1 1/4.
Regional telephone companies also finished in positive ground. Reports that merger plans were close to being resolved helped push Bell Atlantic up 2 1/2, to 65, and Nynex up 1/4, to 53. Bell South, which was upgraded by Cowan & Company, advanced 1, to 39 1/8.
In contrast, the two giant soft drink stocks, Coca-Cola and Pepsico, retreated amid concern that a strengthening dollar would negatively affect their international operations. Coke slipped 3/4, to 78 3/4, and Pepsi gave up 3/8, to 61.
Tobacco companies, which also have major operations outside the United States, declined on dampened prospects for foreign earnings growth. Philip Morris closed at 88 1/8, off 1 1/8, and RJR Nabisco closed at 29 5/8, off 1/8.
Paper issues were weak, and analysts cited profit-taking. International Paper fell 1 1/8, to 39 1/2; Georgia-Pacific dropped 7/8, to 73, and Boise Cascade eased 1/8, to 45 1/8.
Kimberly-Clark fell 1, to 69 7/8, after saying that it would sell its remaining shares in Midwest Express Airlines. EMC Corporation slumped 1 3/4, to 18 1/2, after Merrill Lynch lowered its earnings estimate for 1996. Zycad, which said that it expected to report a first-quarter loss, dropped 15/16 , to 51/16 . And Alternative Resources fell 11/16 , to 33 1/2, on slightly lower-than-expected first-quarter revenue.
Two widely-touted initial public offerings began trading yesterday, and their prices spurted. Planet Hollywood soared 8 7/8, to 26 7/8, and was the most actively-traded stock during the session. Compuserve jumped 3, to 33, and was the second most actively traded stock for the day.
The New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq Stock Market observed a moment of silence at 10:02 A.M. to remember the victims of the bombing last year in Oklahoma City.
Tokyo's Nikkei stock average rose 71.34 points, or 0.33 percent, to close at 21,883.84, yesterday.

HEADLINE: 90's Revival: Positive Power of Thinking

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Few legends haunt the imagination of New Yorkers of a certain intellectual or literary bent more than tales of the circles, salons and other highbrow hobnobbings that were once a feature of city life.
It has become de rigueur in some quarters to dismiss the possibility that anything these days could measure up, to opine wearily that such circles have vanished and that intellectual life is heading that way, too. 
 Yet throughout New York City, people are consciously (sometimes self-consciously) resuscitating the tradition, flocking together in a ritual that can simultaneously stimulate the mind, the heart and the gut.
One high-powered set -- including Susan Sontag, Denis Donoghue, Robert Silvers and others -- convenes weekly over sandwiches, designer water and wine in plastic cups to ponder such topics as the relativity of truth.
A coterie of conservative writers and editors pushing 40 (Yale, the Manhattan Institute, The Wall Street Journal) organized a salon that went on to spawn a book of essays on politics and culture written by salon regulars.
A loose circle of young magazine writers gravitates on weekends to a couple of houses in Garrison and Cold Spring, N.Y., an area some of them have taken to calling Bloomsbury-on-Hudson. ("It's a joke! It's a joke!")
In a loft above Dragon Auto Repair on the fringe of Hell's Kitchen, in East Village apartments, salons have been serving up everything from discourse on beauty and evil to quiche and literary gossip.
And in a bar called Mare Chiaro on Mulberry Street in Little Italy every Friday night, a 33-year-old editor on the staff of The Paris Review convenes a roomful of young fiction writers, screenwriters, editors and publishing-industry types.
"I started to pull friends together out of a kind of quaint notion that New York, at its best, is like a series of small towns," the editor, James Linville, said. "It's a series of circles, of overlapping circles."
One evening recently, George Plimpton stopped by and found the place packed. "I was deeply impressed," Mr. Plimpton, who edits The Paris Review, said. "It was like Elaine's in the old days."
New York City is still, in many ways, a city of circles (especially if the term is liberally defined). The circles are formal, informal, calculated, impulsive. They range from purposeful to purposeless.
One group of writers with interests in boxing, policing and politics meets regularly at Supreme Macaroni Co. in Chelsea for what Jack Newfield, one of the organizers, calls "pasta, pugilism and rap sheets."
At the on-line salon Echo, a six-year-long discussion of the work of Thomas Pynchon is still in progress. On the Upper West Side, a writer only half-jokes that his rotisserie baseball association has become his intellectual circle.
 
Freelance Thinking: A Lost Way of Life
But these days are not the old days, Mare Chiaro notwithstanding. Many people agree that intellectual and literary life is not what it was in earlier decades, when the Algonquin Round Table and later the Partisan Review crowd indelibly defined two types of New York circle.
Gone are the fierce ideological struggles that galvanized earlier generations. Gone is a culture, an economy, a way of life that made it easier back then to subsist in New York City as a freelance thinker.
Universities have swallowed up many intellectuals, scattering them across the country. Intellectual life has become increasingly balkanized, people say, with its many duchies circumscribed by politics and specialization.
The publishing industry, too, has absorbed many among the intellectually inclined into its expanding embrace. They now devote themselves, critics complain, to work that has strayed far from the realm of ideas in pursuit of topicality and profit.
"I never hear people talk about ideas," said Jim Holt, a writer who does commentary on American culture for the BBC. "The only people who talk about ideas at book parties and cocktail parties always turn out to be interns."
"They're the only ones who haven't been jaded by the volume of gossip and the incredible velocity with which it moves," he added. "It tends to drive anything related to ideas out of conversational currency."
Social changes, too, have made it difficult to follow the old patterns. Work seems to have intensified, socializing to have declined. With intellectual life more cosmopolitan, some circles survive primarily by telephone or on line.
"With a culture more compartmentalized, work more competitive, insecurity more rampant," said Katrina vanden Heuvel, editor of The Nation, "I think you're not finding spontaneous croppings of social, cultural, intellectual exchange in the way you did."

A 'Talk Tank' Of Intellectuals
Yet on a recent Friday in a house in Greenwich Village, dozens of big thinkers turned out for the weekly lunch of the New York Institute for the Humanities, the city's best-known gathering of card-carrying intellectuals.
There was Anne Hollander, president of the PEN American Center, talking with Ms. Sontag, the novelist and critic, whose son, David Rieff, the journalist, was sharing a table with Louis Menand, the critic, and Richard Howard, the poet. There was Joanne Akalaitis, the director, next to Jonathan Schell, the author, next to Mitchell Cohen, co-editor of Dissent.
"Usually Robert Silvers comes last and eats nothing but grapes and sits in the back taking mysterious and copious notes," said Jocelyn Carlson Baltzell, the institute's assistant director. Mr. Silvers is co-editor of The New York Review of Books.
Ms. Baltzell likes to call the institute a "talk tank." Started in 1977 to promote intellectual cross-fertilization, it has become what some members describe as an intellectual lunch club. There is food and a talk, usually by someone smart working on a new book. Then there is a discussion, ranging in tone from respectful to what one member called "nail the speaker."
One subgroup within the institute has become something of a circle itself -- a group of writers, mostly in their 40's, some of whom have set out to carry on the tradition of the earlier New York intellectuals.
The group includes Mr. Menand, Paul Berman, Katha Pollitt, Andrew Delbanco and others inside and outside the institute whose hallmark has become the kind of critical essay they publish in magazines like The New Republic and The New Yorker.
If no great cause unifies them, the group is seen as loosely allied by friendship, age and a suspicion of academic intellectual discourse. They bump into one another mostly in the pages of magazines but also occasionally over lunch, at the institute or at events like a recent conference at Princeton University celebrating the centenary of Edmund Wilson's birth.
Ten to 15 years behind that group is another circle of writers and editors, mostly in their early 30's -- politically contrarian and skeptical about ideology. They include Jacob Weisberg, national political columnist for New York magazine; Michael Lewis, who wrote "Liar's Poker," and a half-dozen other friends associated with magazines like The New Republic, The New Yorker and Lingua Franca.
Mr. Lewis and Mr. Weisberg, who lived in the same building in Washington when they worked for The New Republic, have each bought houses, one in Cold Spring and the other in Garrison, where they spend weekends. Mr. Weisberg holed up there last summer and wrote his book "In Defense of Government," which is due out this month. Mr. Lewis rattles off a roster of writers whom he has "dragged up" to stay in his gray-shingled house.
"He proselytizes," Mr. Weisberg said of Mr. Lewis. "His fantasy is to turn this into a writers' paradise."
One of Mr. Lewis's pastimes there is hiking, he said. He can be found from time to time on Breakneck Ridge in the company of Philip Weiss, the journalist and novelist, who is also an inhabitant of Cold Spring.
Another circle, more tightly bound by a sense of ideological mission, is composed of conservative writers and editors with ties to The Wall Street Journal, the Manhattan Institute and various conservative magazines.
Some of them, like Richard Brookhiser and Walter Olson, met at Yale in the 1970's. Lisa Schiffren met Mr. Olson in Washington, where she wrote Vice President Dan Quayle's Murphy Brown speech. David Frum worked on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, which he describes as a "switching point" through which conservatives meet. In the late 1980's, they and a few others coalesced as a group.
For a while, they passed continually in and out of a brownstone in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where Mr. Olson and Steve Pippin held small dinner parties several times a month and garden parties timed to the roses. After one such party, Terry Teach out, a music critic, who had been reading about salons, invited a dozen friends to a meeting at a Chinese restaurant near the Empire State Building. They agreed to organize a conservative salon.
 
The Vile Body In a Town House
They named it The Vile Body. (They had all read Evelyn Waugh.) Until several years ago, it met monthly in a town house on the Upper East Side occupied by the Manhattan Institute. "It looked like a cocktail party," Mr. Teachout recalled. "The difference was, it was a cocktail party of like-minded people." In 1990, the group produced a book, "Beyond the Boom: New Voices on American Life, Culture and Politics."
But salons and circles are not necessarily easy to sustain. Mr. Teach out said he became too busy to continue managing The Vile Body. Since it folded in the early 90's, success and age have gnawed at the circle.
Mr. Olson and Mr. Pippin moved to Wilton, Conn., where they still entertain their friends, but less often. Others in the group married, had children, moved away. These days, the group contents itself with regular phone calls and occasional shared meals.
There is a natural history to such groups, Mr. Teachout said. "They're not permanent undertakings. They fulfill a function at a certain point in the trajectories of the lives of the people who take part."
Other recent salons have met with related difficulties.
Sam Pratt, the 27-year-old founder of a zine called Ersatz that devotes entire issues to things like bumper stickers and hair, organized a salon of sorts in the early 90's in his loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. When he moved to the Dragon Auto Repair building on West 37th Street, he tried to continue. But he finally gave up, out of what he describes as "pure exhaustion, wear and tear."
Liesl Schillinger, a 29-year-old freelance writer and fact checker for The New Yorker, has held a salon in her East Village apartment since mid-1994. But Ms. Schillinger, too, says she is calling it quits, in deference to a downstairs neighbor. "I wish that my house was bigger and my floors were thicker," she said glumly.

Reading Together, Staying Together
But at least one group seems to have defied Mr. Teachout's principle of the impermanence of circles. The Proust group, as it is called, first convened in 1971 with the intention of reading all of Proust. It is currently celebrating its 25th year, having polished off Proust long ago.
The idea began with Ashton Hawkins, now executive vice president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Robert MacDonald, a publisher of golf books, who had known each other as undergraduates at Harvard in the late 50's.
Mr. Hawkins had remembered a professor's admonition that students who had not read all of Proust by graduation could take no comfort when the Harvard president welcomed them into "the company of educated men and women."
So Mr. Hawkins, Mr. MacDonald and a third Harvard friend gathered a dozen acquaintances they considered intellectually compatible and started meeting for dinner on Sunday evenings once a month during the academic year.
They enjoyed Proust so much, they decided to move on to others. They went through Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Balzac, Flaubert, Stendhal, Mann, Faulkner, Austen, Trollope. Twenty years out, the group read Proust again.
For a quarter-century, the membership has remained relatively stable at about a dozen. A few people divorced and left. Last summer, two members died within three weeks of each other.
"As we've grown older and people have gotten sick and died or divorced," said Mr. MacDonald, who turns 60 this month, "we've all become close friends. More and more, you begin to look forward to not just reading the book but the little dinner and the group."
"In a sense, this is the longest commitment to a single group that most of the people in the group have ever made. It's an oasis, and a somewhat intellectual oasis, in this loud culture of ours, which most of us are now beginning to drift away from.
"I think it fulfils a need in all of us, perhaps in different ways, that we're not fully aware of. E. M. Forster always talked about being able to connect. This is a way to connect."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1333 words

HEADLINE: Dole, Citing 'Crisis' in the Courts, Attacks Appointments by Clinton

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole said today that President Clinton's judicial appointments had caused a "crisis" in the courts and in a move eagerly sought by conservatives, he promised to expel the American Bar Association from the judicial screening process.
Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, has voted for 182 of Mr. Clinton's 185 appointees to the Federal bench and for both of his nominees to the Supreme Court, although he said today that he gave that support "out of deference to a President's constitutional prerogative." Nonetheless, Mr. Dole warned that Mr. Clinton's re-election would undermine the judiciary with "an all-star team of liberal leniency." 
 In a speech on the judiciary at a meeting here of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, Mr. Dole said re-electing Mr. Clinton, who has already appointed nearly 25 percent of all sitting Federal judges, "could lock in liberal judicial activism for the next generation, and the social landscape could dramatically change."
"More Federal intrusion in the lives of average Americans," he said. "More centralized power in Washington. Less freedom of religious expression. More rights for criminals. And more arrogant disregard of the rights of law-abiding citizens."
Clinton Administration officials immediately threw cold water on Mr. Dole's charges, saying that the President's appointees were hardly more liberal than those appointed by President Bush. They said Mr. Dole, by opposing the ban on assault weapons, was soft of crime and was trying to divert attention from his party's capitulation to the National Rifle Association.
"The A.B.A. is a totally phoney issue," said Jack Quinn, the White House counsel. "The real issue here is that, No. 1, the President has appointed moderate, mainstream judges. That's why Bob Dole voted for 98 percent of them. No. 2, Senator Dole's tired, worn-out complaint is just a smokescreen for what has been an abysmal, embarrassing record on crime. It was Bill Clinton who fought to put 100,000 cops on the street, to get cop-killer bullets off the street, for the Brady handgun bill and to ban assault weapons."
But Mr. Dole said the judiciary was, in part, responsible for crime. "If we're looking for root causes of the crime explosion," he said, "this is clearly one of them: I'm speaking of the crisis in our courts, the crisis in our legal system, and the crisis of confidence this is causing in America." His chief remedy, he said, would be to shut out the "narrowly partisan and ideologically liberal" American Bar Association from its semi-official role in the screening process, something favored but never permanently accomplished by Presidents Ronald Reagan or George Bush. (Attorney General Dick Thornburgh briefly suspended the practice but later reinstated it).
In its place, Mr. Dole said he would appoint a panel of police, prosecutors, crime victims, legal scholars and others to review appointments.
Mr. Dole's campaign advisers described today's speech as "the start of framing this election vis-a-vis Clinton," and said they planned future speeches on other topics, including the economy and values.
But in the Dole campaign's vigorous promotion of this contentious issue and the Administration's equally energetic response -- including a pre-emptive strike by the Vice President on Thursday -- today's speech marked a new, more tactical phase of the Presidential campaign.
The matter of the American Bar Association seemed a particularly obscure for a Presidential campaign.
Since 1955, successive Administrations have allowed the A.B.A. a special role in independently evaluating judicial nominees. But conservatives have loathed the process since 1987, when four of the 15 members of the association's screening committee rated Judge Robert Bork "unqualified" and helped doom his nomination to the Supreme Court.
William E. Leuchtenburg, visiting professor of legal history at Duke University Law School, said in an interview that both Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon had made judicial appointments issues in their Presidential campaigns, but he doubted they had influenced many voters' decisions.
Mr. Leuchtenburg said he was struck that Mr. Dole would call Mr. Clinton's appointments liberal, since "what most people say is how moderate they have been. He has not taken advantage of his tenure as President to offset the decidedly ideological appointments that Reagan and Bush made in the 1980s."
But Dole officials treated the speech as a major event. They held a background briefing for reporters and released an advance text and fact sheets, a far more assertive approach than the Dole campaign customarily makes with the media.
They said that over the next five days, squads of Republican officials, including Senators, Governors and state attorneys general, would be echoing Mr. Dole's comments. The first statements clogging newsroom fax machines this afternoon came from some of those who have been angling to be Mr. Dole's Vice Presidential running mate.
Dole aides said they wanted to signal that they were running "a very aggressive, issue-oriented campaign" that included their own interpretation, or "political spin," apparently something they felt has been lacking as their candidate trails Mr. Clinton in the run-up to the November election -- by as much as 18 points in the latest national poll by The Los Angeles Times.
In fact the Administration has been anticipating this attack for weeks. President Clinton himself upbraided one of his own appointees, Judge Harold Baer of New York, who had thrown out evidence in a drug case and said he could understand why people in one neighborhood would flee the police.
Mr. Dole called for Judge Baer's impeachment. The judge recently reversed himself.
At the same time, the well-oiled Clinton machine, known for its rapid response to criticism, even had Vice President Al Gore try to pre-empt Mr. Dole's speech the day before. On Thursday, Mr. Gore spoke to the same group, where he noted that more of Mr. Clinton's judicial appointees had received the highest rating from the American Bar Association than the appointees of any of the three previous Presidents. Moreover, he said, 40 percent of them served as criminal prosecutors.
In addition, the Democratic National Committee today launched a new television commercial that paints Mr. Clinton as tough on crime and Mr. Dole as soft.
Dole aides said today that Mr. Gore's speech was a sign that the Dole campaign had succeeded in hitting a nerve. "I didn't hear Gore yesterday defend any of these liberal judges that we've been talking about," said one Dole official.
Indeed, after Mr. Dole singled out four Clinton appointees today as particularly irresponsible, even though he voted for two of them, Clinton officials did not rush to their defense. The judges named by Mr. Dole were Judge Baer, Leonie Brinkema in Virginia, Rosemary Barkett in Florida, and H. Lee Sarokin in New Jersey.
"We're not going to get into a tit for tat," said George Stephanopoulos, an adviser to the President. "For every Clinton judge they can pull out, we can pull out a Reagan or Bush judge who might have a similar isolated decision."
Unlike Patrick J. Buchanan, who has called judges "little dictators in black robes," Mr. Dole did not call for term limits for judges.
The Bar Association defended its role in rating judicial nominees. "The American Bar Assocition's standing committee has done a very important service for the American people since the Eisenhower Administration, using first-rate lawyers to evaluate potential nominees for the Federal bench," said Roberta Cooper Ramo, the president.
Ms. Ramo said that the committee evaluates potential judges on the basis of their reputation for integrity, ability to write clearly, judicial temperament and their experience and understanding of the law. "None of these things have to do with ideology," she said. "The A.B.A. isn't a political organization in any way."
