HEADLINE: Study Says Babies in Child Care Keep Secure Bonds to Mothers

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
The most far-reaching and comprehensive study to date has found that using day-care centers or baby sitters does not affect infants' trust in their mothers.
The results, announced yesterday at a conference in Providence, R.I., run counter to several previous studies that seemed to show that infants in child care were slightly more likely to have an insecure relationship with their mothers than those whose mothers stayed at home with them. 
 The earlier research had alarmed some experts and parents because other studies had indicated that troubled bonds between infants and mothers could signal emotional and behavioral problems later.
The new study sought to address one of the most emotionally charged issues in society today: Does a mother put her child at risk by working outside the home? It reported that the sense of trust felt by 15-month-old children in their mothers was not affected by whether or not the children were in day care, by how many hours they spent there, by the age they entered day care, by the quality or type of care or by how many times care arrangements were changed. Instead, what affected that trust was a mother's sensitivity and responsiveness to her child.
"Part of what elicited this study was real worries that child care in and of itself was unhealthy," said Dr. Deborah Lowe Vandell, one of the 25 researchers on the project, which was sponsored by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, part of the National Institutes of Health. "I think that is the wrong analysis. One message from the study is that if the quality of the interaction with the mother is sensitive, then the child is likely to develop a secure relationship with her. I'm sure that will be reassuring to many mothers and families."
But the researchers cautioned that the study found some aspects of child care appeared to pose risks for certain vulnerable children. When a mother does not handle her child sensitively, the likelihood of a troubled mother-child bond can be increased by child care that is of poor quality, changes several times or extends more than 10 hours a week.
The ongoing study, which brought together researchers who have often clashed about the risks of child care, has been following more than 1,300 families nationwide since 1991. Compared with previous studies, this one includes more diverse families and more types of child care. It has observed children at home as well as in child care and laboratories and will follow children from birth through 7 years of age.
Researchers emphasize that many questions remain unanswered, and they must await later stages of the project to see if the links described yesterday last. Children who look secure now could be insecure later. What seem to be risks of child care now could prove unimportant as children grow, or new risks could surface.
The scientists plan to publish next research examining children's bonds to their mothers at 3 years old, and their cognitive and language development, physical development, health, behavior and relationships with peers.
In a result that intrigued several researchers who said they were still not entirely sure how to interpret it, the study also found that more time in child care was linked to some risks for boys but that less time was potentially risky for girls. Boys who were in child care for more than 30 hours a week were slightly more likely to have an insecure relationship with their mothers, while girls were more likely to have an insecure bond if they were in child care less than 10 hours a week.
While this finding was statistically significant, it was weaker than the other results and researchers cautioned against overreacting to it.
Previous studies of older children have found that child care can have some ill effects for boys, particularly middle-class boys, and that girls of working mothers tended to be more independent and focused on achievement.
Dr. Jay Belsky, one of the researchers, said it was possible that "separation might prove stressful for boys, but girls who are home with mothers extensively may become almost too close and enmeshed."
The study offered researchers in the often-acrimonious world of social science a chance to test competing ideas. Psychologists have long disagreed over how important and lasting are the effects of the mother-child bond, known as "attachment," that this study measures..
The scientists measured attachment by watching children's reactions when their mothers returned after brief separations. Children who sought comfort from their mothers were judged to be secure. Researchers also evaluated mothers by videotaping them with their children and grading the mothers' sensitivity according to accepted criteria.
While many researchers say the quality of a child's first relationship sets the tone for all future ones, others say that impact has been exaggerated. Usually, the first relationship is with the mother, which is why this study and others measure that bond.
This study confirms researchers' belief that a mother's sensitive care is crucial in forging a secure attachment, said Dr. Cathryn L. Booth, one of the researchers. But some researchers, as well as some popular baby experts and pediatricians, have argued that working during the first year of a child's life would be harmful, either because long hours spent away from a child would interfere with the mother's ability to be sensitive or because a baby would experience a mother's absence as a devastating abandonment and feel unable to count on her. Although the earlier studies seemed to offer some support for that argument, this more comprehensive study questions that assumption, Dr. Booth said.
The study offered further evidence of what experts have been telling parents for years: smaller groups of children, more adults per child and more sensitive caregivers spell higher-quality child care, defined as environments in which children are stimulated and get adequate attention. Child-care centers were ranked lowest in quality; care by fathers or relatives or in the home by a caregiver were ranked the highest.
Because researchers were able to follow children from birth, they were also able to figure out what influenced parents' choices for child care. Children who were in better-quality care had more stimulating home environments and mothers who were more likely to believe that working put children at risk. At the same time, children who were most securely attached had mothers who were better off economically and who appeared to be more sensitive and were more likely to believe that day care could be harmful.
Dr. Belsky, who ignited a firestorm in 1986 when he became one of the first researchers to raise questions about the potential risks of day care, suggested that while the study offered reassurance to working parents, it also indicated that some guilt might be productive.
"It may be that some guilt and anxiety keeps you alert, vigilant and able to monitor the quality of care," Dr. Belsky said. "Being cavalier about the effects of work turns out to be risky."
The study departed in several other ways from previous ones. By the time the children studied were a year old, 80 percent of them had been in child care for at least a few hours a week, a higher percentage than previous surveys have found. And the overall quality of child care, the researchers observed, was better than the usually dismal picture revealed by several recent studies.
Dr. Sarah Friedman, the study's coordinator at the institute, said that researchers were not sure why, but one explanation might be that previous studies had focused on child-care centers, which were found to provide the lowest-quality care in this study.

VINDICATION FOR DAY CARE

WOMEN AND THE ELECTIONS

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: With G.O.P. Congress the Issue, 'Gender Gap' Is Growing Wider

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, recognized the magnitude of her party's problems with women when she received a telephone call from her 34-year-old daughter in Colorado.
"She said, 'Mother, there are these TV ads out here and they make you Republicans look like you're taking food out of the mouths of little babies. Are you?' " 
 The Congresswoman assured her that the party was not, but found it ominous that she had to defend the Republican Congress to her own Republican daughter.
The gender gap, the tendency of women to lean Democratic while men tilt Republican, has become a gender chasm in recent months. And many political analysts believe that it has a lot to do with women's perceptions of the 104th Congress, particularly the fear that the revolution led by Speaker Newt Gingrich tried to go too far.
"Women are still bigger believers in government," said Andrew Kohut, of the Pew Center for People and the Press, a Washington research group. "Women are stronger environmentalists, more critical of business and less critical of government. This drives their party preferences and their attitudes toward the Congressional agenda."
The gender gap has been a recurrent feature of American politics since President Ronald Reagan stirred the hearts of men, but not as many women, in 1980. What makes it so striking at the moment, many pollsters say, is its size and its potential to affect not only the race for the White House, but also the battle for control of the House.
The most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll shows some stark differences between the sexes: Women disapproved of Mr. Gingrich's job performance by a 2-to-1 ratio, while men disapproved far more narrowly. When asked how they would vote if the Congressional elections were held today, women went for the Democrats by a 16-point margin, while men backed the Republicans by a 10-point margin.
Women are also much more likely to identify themselves as Democrats: 40 percent did so, compared with 30 percent of the men. This Democratic advantage rises with age; it does not exist among 18- to 29-year-old women and rises to an 18-point margin among women 65 and older.
Even the women who identify themselves as independents have much greater Democratic tendencies: 49 percent of these women said they would vote Democratic in this year's House races, compared with 31 percent of the men who said they were independents. This survey of 1,257 adults was conducted March 31 to April 2 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Several polls in recent days have found similar gaps, raising Democratic hopes that women can do for them what the "angry white men" did for the Republicans in their 1994 Congressional sweep.
Republicans counter that the flip side of the gender gap is their superior strength among men, and they note that they have prevailed over their vulnerabilities with women many times in the past.
"People were worried about the gender gap in the early 1980's," said Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, "but as it turned out Ronald Reagan carried 56 percent of the women's vote in 1984."
Given the time, Congressional Republicans say, they can make their case to women: The Contract With America to lower taxes, reduce Government and balance the budget will reap rich rewards for average American families.
Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island, the highest-ranking woman in the House Republican leadership, said: "We were trying to do so much that we didn't have time to communicate, to tailor our message. That clearly opened a door of vulnerability, but it's eminently undoable."
As for Mr. Gingrich's unpopularity, Ms. Molinari said, "Maybe I'm too close to Newt to see it, but I think he's one of the more politically sensitive people we have in our party when it comes to women and the women's vote."
Ms. Roukema is urging her party to put issues like health insurance and child-support enforcement at the top of the Congressional agenda.
For their part, Democratic strategists are consumed with turning a polling phenomenon into actual votes. If they can galvanize women to turn out in 1996, and if women's current Democratic predilections hold, they could turn the tide in many districts. (In 1994, women accounted for 51 percent of the vote, a drop from 1992, when they accounted for 54 percent. The most recent Times/ CBS News poll showed that 53 percent of the registered voters were women and 47 percent men.)
Even Democratic strategists acknowledge that those are two very big if's. A report for Emily's List, a group devoted to electing women to office, said last week, "While 1994's drop-off women could have a substantial impact on 1996, they must still be considered uncertain voters." Many women who voted in 1992 but not in 1994 are young, with high school degrees or less, and have annual incomes under $30,000.
Appealing to the women's vote is considered a far more subtle art than it was 15 years ago, when a narrowly focused set of "women's issues," like abortion, was often considered enough. Analysts are careful to note that women are obviously not monolithic, but say some general trends are evident.
For example, surveys show that economic security is front and center for them; the Times/CBS poll showed that while 62 percent of the men rated the economy as "fairly good," only 45 percent of the women did; half of the women rated it as "fairly bad" or "very bad."
"Most of my concerns have nothing to do with politics or government," said Patricia Lewin of Wisconsin, 46, in a follow-up interview to the Times/CBS poll. "It's the way society is going, the downsizing by corporations."
Economic anxiety is particularly high among older women, many analysts say. Women over 65 and those just over a decade younger are particularly susceptible to Democratic attacks on the Republican plan to restructure Medicare, and to Democratic promises, like Mr. Clinton's last week, to safeguard pension programs.
"Median income for women 65 and older is about $8,500 a year," said Ann Lewis, a chief strategist for the Clinton campaign. "That's why when women hear talk about cutting back on the entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security, they feel the icy grip of fear."
Some studies suggest that neither party has fully capitalized on women's economic concerns. Some Republicans acknowledge that their party's focus on balancing the budget, which has dominated the debate in Washington for the past year, has fallen flat with many women.
Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, said of women, "We haven't been successful in conveying what we're trying to do in Congress: the cause and effect between downsizing Government and improving their future and their childrens' future."
But several analysts suggest that women may be suspicious of attempts to "downsize Government," in part because of their greater concern for safety-net programs like Medicare, and in part because they simply believe that government should do more to help families.
"Men are more likely to say Government is too involved and should leave more to the individual and business," said Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster who addressed a forum last week in New York sponsored by Ladies Home Journal and the League of Women Voters. "Women, on the other hand, are more likely to want to see a more activist government."
But until the Democrats come up with a stronger economic message, some analysts suggest, much of the women's vote will remain volatile; Congressional Democrats are expected to begin laying out their economic platform in the next few weeks. The volatility is especially true with many of the younger, high-school educated women who sat out the 1994 election.
At the same time, the Democrats hope to make inroads with suburban and professional women who might ordinarily lean Republican on economic grounds, but are turned off by the party's social agenda over issues like abortion.
Stan Greenberg, a Democratic pollster, said, "You have a large group of suburban women, professional women, better educated women, who are just uncomfortable with the Republican Party right now."
Ms. DiVall says that Republicans have numerous opportunities for appealing to different groups of women, including mothers who are not in the work force, white women who consider themselves independents, and evangelicals. She also noted that it is still early in this election year -- but not too early, she added, for Republicans to start dealing with their problem with women.
 
A Margin of Decision
Women play a crucial role in President Clinton's lead over Senator Bob Dole, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.
In a two-way race, men divide evenly between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, 45 percent to 45 percent. But women break for Mr. Clinton, 52 percent against 34 percent for Mr. Dole. This gender gap began to emerge last fall and widened through the winter. It is not simply because more women are Democrats; Mr. Clinton has a similar edge among women who describe themselves as independents.
Republican strategists note that such gender gaps are a staple of American politics and can be overcome in the course of a campaign. At a similar point in 1988, for example, men favored George Bush over Michael S. Dukakis by 51 percent to 41 percent while women were for Mr. Dukakis by an 8-point margin. In the election that fall, Mr. Bush carried the votes of men -- and, albeit by a narrower majority -- women as well.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
For the Draft Picks, Mother's Day Is Early

BYLINE: By Thomas George 

 BODY:
Draft day is for the fans. Especially the New York fans. They come to the Theater at the Garden and they cheer, they boo, they wear green and they wear blue.
Draft day is for the teams. They make selections, cross their fingers, prepare to dish out millions and hope that their pick will stick. That a Super Bowl victory will be the eventual reward. 
 Draft day is certainly for the nation's universities. They want their players selected high. That way, they can boast in their football brochures about how their program produces pro stars. That way, they can more effectively recruit the future first-rounders fresh from high school.
And, of course, draft day is for the draftees. A dream, a miracle, a harvest of so much taxing physical and mental work.
But draft day is mainly for mothers. Did you see them yesterday? They were beaming, each one. So proud. So much the story behind the 6-foot-4-inch giant that just made it to the top. So frequently the single parent, or the sacrificing one, or, simply, the best friend.
Take Simeon Rice's mom, Evelyn.
She and her husband used to take their two sons and four daughters on trips across America in the family camper. Family trips, where the family bond grew. They traveled to Niagara Falls. They viewed the monuments in D.C. They even came to New York, back in '85, when Rice was barely a teen.
Rice remembers that, the trip to the Statue of Liberty, and now this return visit, one that changed his life forever as the third pick of the draft.
He is an Arizona Cardinal now.
"On Jan. 11 last year, I sat down with my mom," Rice said. "It was her birthday, and it was the last day to declare for the draft. I looked her in the eye and I promised her that I was going to stay in school, get my degree and not enter the draft early. I didn't even get her a gift that day. But now, she's got her gift. I got the degree, I got drafted today and now I will have the money to buy her more gifts than she could ever want."
Alex Molden, the draft's elite cornerback, was raised by his mother, Cassandra. "We are extremely close," Molden said. "She was a single parent who raised us in Colorado Springs and never made more than $10,000 a year. We relied on food stamps."
No more of that, ever. Molden was the 11th pick in the draft, to the New Orleans Saints. Selected that high, his signing bonus, alone, will be more than $1 million.
Keyshawn Johnson's mother, Vivian Jessie, said that she taught her son how to play football. He loved baseball as a kid, she said, but she swayed him toward football and tossed him his first few passes and taught him how to catch them. Quite a start. And his draft finish? Tops, to the Jets, the No. 1 selection.
Tim Biakabutuka's mother, Marceline Misenga, was here in New York for the first time, in from @ontreal. Through Velly Janvier, a French translator, she said that she had prayed since Biakabutuka was born in Zaire 22 years ago that she would be blessed through him. He was the eighth pick, and will play for the Carolina Panthers.
"I am prou' of him -- he has done well in football," she said. "But I have other children who are trying to achieve their goals. Their goals might not be as glamorous, but I am as proud of them."
Spoken like a true mom.
The Regan Upshaw story is inspiring, too. His mother, Rosalyn Morgan-Upshaw, is a principal at Pittsburg High School, which is 35 miles east of Oakland. His father, Charles, is the chief executive assistant to the vice chancellor and provost at the University of California in Berkeley. His grandmother owns a master's degree in education, an aunt one in special education, one uncle a doctorate in finance from Columbia and another is a doctor from Harvard.
Upshaw, drafted by Tampa Bay in the first round, earned his degree in economics from Cal.
Mrs. Morgan-Upshaw said her son was a rambunctious youth, "a tiger, the epitome of an idle mind being the devil's workshop." She said through sixth grade that he and his sister, Kirsten, grew up in luxury, in upscale homes and schools in Hillsborough, Calif., where their peers drove to class in Porsches and BMW's.
"He needed to be out of that, out of the city, period, because I felt that in an urban setting that his safety would be in jeopardy," she said. "So, when we decided to move permanently to one side of the Bay or the other, we chose Pittsburg. It's country. That's how Regan got so fast, by chasing cows up the hill. It was a place where some kids walked to school two or three miles away and the others rode the bus. In the city, even without doing anything, he would have been at risk. With his personality, he would have been in more jeopardy."
Draft day is a day for mothers.

HEADLINE: Ethanol's Value Wins Bipartisan Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the president of the trade association representing 45,000 workers in 53 ethanol plants across the country, I take issue with your April 16 front-page article on Senator Bob Dole's support for ethanol subsidies.
You state that "for years, Government studies have questioned ethanol's value," and cite a 1986 Department of Agriculture report as evidence. But that report has since been repudiated by the agency, and more recent studies have promoted the economic and energy benefits of the ethanol incentive program. 
 For example, a 1995 Department of Agriculture study concluded that the ethanol program increases net farm income more than $700 million annually. Another 1995 study determined that "the production of ethanol yields 25 percent more energy than is used in growing the corn, harvesting it and distilling it into ethanol."
With regard to the environmental effects of ethanol, you cite only a Congressional Budget Office report, which was neither intended nor able to provide policy guidance on air quality issues. Ethanol adds oxygen to gasoline, which reduces exhaust emissions of ozone-forming carbon monoxide. Because ethanol adds octane to gasoline, it also reduces the use of toxic, petroleum-derived octane.
The support for ethanol is bipartisan. The reason is that public policy makers have gained an appreciation for its benefits.
 
ERIC VAUGHN
Washington, April 16, 1996
 
Pres., Renewable Fuels Assn.

HEADLINE: Woe if Chinese Turn Energy Gluttons Like Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Thomas L. Friedman's "Gardening With Beijing" (column, April 17): It seems that President Clinton is aware of the environmental dangers of a modernized China. If a billion Chinese become as energy-profligate as the average American, the world's finite energy reserves will decrease at a more frightening rate than they do now, and the products of their consumption will poison the atmosphere. 
 There is a corollary to this idea that Mr. Friedman bypasses. Our leaders on the right and the left invoke "growth" as the solution to our economic difficulties. However, a significant aspect of growth is the sale of manufactured goods abroad that consume energy. The solution to one of our pressing problems thus has a depressing downside. If the free-market gurus have a way out of this dilemma, I would like to know what it is.
 
CHARLES R. COWLEY
Ann Arbor, Mich., April 17, 1996

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Club Fed

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis 

 BODY:
THERE ARE A LOT of different ways to read the draft of a new report on the inner workings of the Federal Reserve System released last month by two Democratic Senators, Harry Reid of Nevada and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota. But it appears that most people have read it supine, just before falling asleep. Here we have the first real attempt to investigate the most important economic force in government, and the chief response the Senators are getting is . . . boredom.
"It's an area of disinterest," Senator Reid acknowledges. "The vast majority of Americans have no concept of what effect the Fed has on their lives." 
 The Fed has always had an odd relationship to the citizenry, precisely because it is so boring -- shrewdly boring. In theory, the Fed is answerable to you and me through both Congress and the President. If we don't like what the Fed chairman is doing, we can send a message to Congress, which can grill up the chairman and eat him for lunch. If that doesn't work, we can send a message to the President, who can decline to reappoint the chairman, thus forcing him into a high-paying job on Wall Street.
But practice in this case is very different from theory. For instance, despite constant prodding, Congress has failed to get answers from the Fed to a lot of very interesting questions: What became of the billions of dollars the Fed has wired into Mexico before presidential elections in the last two decades? How much money has the Fed lost propping up the dollar? How does the Fed decide to change interest rates?
The end result of the Fed's distance from the democracy is raw economic power. Its power is only enhanced by the Fed's equally ambiguous relationship to the markets. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is a lifelong disciple of Ayn Rand and a passionate advocate of free markets. He has said and written many times that free markets are not only uniquely efficient but also uniquely moral. The Federal Reserve itself is run in part by private bankers who have a deep attachment to market outcomes.
But much of what the Fed does constitutes blatant market interference. When the dollar falls or rises against foreign currencies, for instance, the Fed spends a lot of taxpayer money buying or selling dollars, to offset natural market forces. And these distortions are tiny compared with those created whenever the Fed decides to expand or contract the money supply, thereby lowering or raising interest rates.
To the extent that power over the economy resides in the hands of any one person, it resides in the hands not of the President or the chairman of AT&T but of Alan Greenspan. Greenspan gets to decide how many dollars to print. That wouldn't be so bad if at the end of each week he explained his actions in plain English and subjected them to an honest public evaluation -- if, say, he walked out onto his portico and declared, "I decided not to lower interest rates today because the price of oil just went up, and though I have no real idea what that price bump means, I fear that it might cause inflation."
But he doesn't. He keeps it all bottled up inside him, and leaves the rest of us to wonder nervously whether he'll pursue his vendetta against inflation past the point of all reason. He has never fully explained why he has done what he has done. His rare public statements are famously indecipherable; indeed, the Fed's most recent vice chairman, Alan Blinder, resigned after nearly two years of trying to get Greenspan to recognize English as the official language.
Now we have this new report, which purports to drag the Fed, with Greenspan, back into our noisy democracy. In spite of the drum roll that preceded it ("Reid, Dorgan to Unveil Groundbreaking Report on Fed Excess," the news release blared), the document contains only a handful of minor revelations: that the Federal Reserve's costs have outpaced inflation, that Fed employment rose slightly at the same time overall Government employment fell slightly and that over the last 79 years the Fed has squirreled away a $3.7 billion "surplus account" the purpose of which it can't really explain, since it has never had to draw on the account and it makes huge profits each year. All of this is worth knowing, but none of it will have any effect on the world, except, possibly, to create the illusion that the Fed has finally come clean.
It hasn't. The General Accounting Office, which did the dirty work, wasn't asked to audit the Fed's books and wasn't permitted to audit the results of the Fed's market interventions. In other words, it was forced to take the Fed's word on all the numbers. This left the investigators little to do but search for meaning in the most quotidian details of Fed life.
Lunch, for example. On page 88 we read: "Two [Federal Reserve] Banks reimbursed travelers for meals based on a schedule which divides the day into four quarters while another Bank used a more narrowly defined schedule which aligned with typical meal times. . . . As a result of these policy differences the total meal reimbursement for a three-day trip to the Board of Governors in Washington, D.C., could range from $76 to $105."
We also learn that 120 people inside the Fed earn more than Greenspan, who was paid $133,600 in 1994; that the Fed springs for Greenspan's car and driver and that the Fed dental plan is the best in town. The Pentagon Papers this is not.
To my mind, the report's most telling new fact is that the Fed -- that is, the taxpayer -- has paid to install in Greenspan's home a $2,500 alarm system. Senator Reid claims to be outraged at this expenditure and others like it. But the truth is that $2,500 is a bargain. Kamikaze pilots are flying planes into the back end of the White House; snipers are firing Chinese semiautomatic rifles into the front. Meanwhile, the only protection the man with real power feels he needs is a $2,500 beeper. Greenspan has no bodyguards, no sniffer dogs, no snipers, no electrified fence. If the world were ever to wake up, he'd need an army.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

SECTION: Section 6; Page 39; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1891 words

HEADLINE: Europe's Reborn Right

BYLINE: By Mark Hunter; Mark Hunter lives in France and is working on a book about the National Front. He has previously written an About Men column for the Magazine, "Vive la Difference."

 BODY:
A PAGE OF HISTORY HAS TURNED: FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE World War II a wave of aggressively nationalist, extreme-right parties have swept into municipal, regional, national and European parliament offices from the English Channel to the edge of the former Soviet empire. When they won a few scattered elections in the mid-1980's, they were taken for a passing phenomenon. But in election after election, this hard right -- which calls the traditional right "soft" -- is proving its power to survive and grow, pushing its roots deeper and deeper.
Between January and the end of March, Germany's Republikaners climbed from 2 percent in pre-election polls to 9 percent of the final vote in the state of Baden-Wurttemberg. Last year three French cities elected National Front mayors, while in Belgium the Vlaams Blok won nearly 27 percent of the vote in Antwerp. In Italy, which goes to the polls today, the National Alliance and the Northern League are serious contenders for power. And the Austrian Freedom Party has maintained its potent influence in Vienna, despite a scandal when its leader, Jorg Haider, held a rally with Nazi SS veterans. 
 The parties are hard to define: they are like snowballs rolling downhill, constantly adding layers. They are clearly populist outsiders, troops of angry men guided by charismatic figures, something like the American movements of George Wallace and David Duke. Just as clearly, their ranks include racists, anti-Semites and even former Nazis. At a National Front lunch in central France I was seated beside a trooper of the Charlemagne SS, and over dinner in Paris a "friendly" French journalist loudly denounced "Jew America, nigger America, Jewish-nigger America."
In truth, though, the vast majority of the parties' new recruits, including their candidates, are closer to the American Republican right wing than to Hitler. Aping Newt Gingrich, the Front calls its antibureaucracy platform a "Contract for France With the French," and one of their cadres told me, "I read Pat Buchanan's program, and it's practically the same as ours." That doesn't make them democratic -- it is appalling to watch a Front mayor cut off debate on crucial city policies -- but neither does it make them all fascists.
In their own eyes they have been building toward this moment for centuries. A radically antidemocratic right was born in Europe with the French Revolution, which defined the stakes of the battle -- the conflict of liberty, equality and fraternity with authority, tradition and elitism. But after the catastrophe of Nazism it took several decades for a new generation of radical-right cadres to emerge across Europe.
Their ideologies define a safe but narrow path: they condemn the "excesses" and errors of fascism while refusing to denounce those who claimed to fight Communism or to see in Hitler's conquests a chance for national renewal. When accused of racism or xenophobia, they reply that they do not hate other peoples but are simply defending their own. Like Louis Farrakhan, whom they cite approvingly, they believe that different races and ethnicities cannot mix without losing their cultures and identities.
The hard right still appeals to its traditional electorate -- the petite bourgeoisie of shopkeepers allied with ambitious professionals, military officers and embittered aristocrats. The Vlaams Blok, the Republikaners and the Northern League draw electoral strength from both upper and lower classes. The ranks of the National Front bristle with anti-abortion Catholics, doctors, lawyers and veterans of the Algerian war. Yet the hard right's drive for power is fueled by the working class. In Vienna, polls show a Freedom Party approval rating of more than 30 percent among unskilled and skilled workers and artisans; across France, the National Front holds 30 percent of these voters, more than any other party. The Communists once controlled this electorate but lost their grip on it even before the fall of the Berlin wall. There is a sinister parallel here to the 30's: it was by crushing Communist-led workers' movements that the liberal democracies opened the road to fascism. Yet there is a new element in the equation -- the opening of Europe's national borders to the free flow of people, goods and services.
The hard right isn't wrong when it says that since 1985, when the opening began, the European Union has benefited mainly big business. A turning point has been reached: in the past decade unemployment has nearly doubled across the Continent -- three million jobless in France, close to four million in Germany. At the same time, the providential social benefits put in place after World War II are being abrogated from the top down. Why? To meet the stringent budgetary criteria mapped out for the European Union, which hopes to introduce a unified currency by 1999. Simultaneously, taxes have reached historic levels -- almost 44 percent of G.D.P. in Germany, 44.7 percent in France. (Not incidentally, whenever I hang out with the National Front I meet desperate men and women who say they joined the party after taxes destroyed their companies.) The average citizen is struggling harder and getting less and less.
As a result of these trends there is a "developing dual society," in the words of Marc Swyngedouw, a Belgian political scientist: an increasingly affluent, educated, multilingual social and political elite ruling over a growing, increasingly impoverished underclass whose members see themselves as competing for housing, jobs and benefits with recent immigrants from Turkey, West and North Africa and Eastern Europe -- former "guest workers" and political refugees.
To make matters worse, the European elites are wallowing in corruption at precisely the moment that they are demanding new sacrifices. During the huge French public service strikes this winter, pollsters discovered that three-fifths of the French believed that their leaders were "unconcerned for the common welfare" and "dishonest." Just before the strikes, Prime Minister Alain Juppe was caught in a housing scandal and escaped prosecution only through the legal acrobatics of the Ministry of Justice. Similar affairs have rocked every country in Europe, most notably Italy.
By discrediting the elites, the corruption issue seems to validate other items on the hard right's program. In 1986, Jorg Haider's major asset in voter polls was his personal image, which decisively outweighed his anticorruption plank; the immigrant issue wasn't even on the map. By 1990, voter disgust with "scandals, abuses, privileges" had become the leading reason for backing Haider, with "teaching a lesson" to the established parties coming third and the "foreigner question" a distant but rising fifth. In 1994, fighting corruption remained the Freedom Party's best issue, and the immigrant problem had climbed to third. Why believe those who call Haider a racist after they're shown to be crooks?
The hard right has another, surprising advantage. Like the evangelical right in America, it has revived door-to-door politics with brilliant effect. In the provincial French town of Montargis, the National Front's two city counselors visit aged victims of street crime and offer them chocolates and help filling out insurance and police forms. The Vlaams Blok is the last party left in the rotting neighborhoods of working-class Antwerp, where it holds regular meetings in pubs, listening to gripes and promising a better day. The Northern League holds rallies in "bowling alleys, bars, parishes, video arcades, even stadiums," marveled the daily Corriere della Sera, while its Establishment adversaries "have almost completely lost their activist base," according to two researchers, Carlo E. Ruzza and Olivier Schmidtke.
Nor does the hard right sell only hatred. As Swyngedouw points out, "They are also selling a utopia." They offer a world in which the land and the people will finally be one, just as soon as the snake -- the foreigner, the multinational capitalist -- is driven from the garden. The hard right calls itself a family, and it creates a close, busy environment for its recruits in an endless round of "Tupper parties" (as the National Front calls them), rallies, postering nights and discussion groups. "It's very important for the new arrivals," a top Front official told me, "especially those whose political ideas aren't very structured." Note the implication that what comes first isn't politics so much as getting new members into the family.
There's a generation largely missing from this family: what Americans call the baby boomers. The Freedom Party vote is strongest among those under 30 and over 70, and the National Front has actually lost support among voters aged 35 to 49 since 1988. The Front's cadres claim that their younger adult troops don't dare stand up in public because they might lose their jobs, and that has indeed happened. Yet alongside the obvious class vengeance driving the hard right there is the continuation, as Elizabeth Noelle-Neumann, a German political scientist and pollster, puts it, of "a war with heavy casualties," the generational conflict of the late 60's. What the hard right hates -- drugs, abortion, racial integration, resistance to authority, sexual liberty -- is what the baby-boom generation tolerated or legalized as it came to maturity. Thus, the newly old, whose children attacked them in the 60's, and the newly adult, who must pay for the ruinous binge of the 80's, have come together in the hard right.
It is striking that the only other European political force to arise since the 1980's is the ecology-first Greens, whose demographic profile contrasts starkly with that of the hard right: more heavily female, much more educated and further to the left than the general population and dominated by the 35-to-49 age group. Yet both movements believe that the era of abundance is over and will never come back. The hard right spends much less time talking about economic growth than about how immigrants and politicians are stealing society's wealth, while the Greens say flat out that the planet can no longer support an ever-growing population. If you add their votes together, you see that between a quarter and a third of European voters share the sense that the biggest problem facing the world is how to divide a shrinking pie.
That fear is spreading. More and more, mainstream politicians find themselves forced to enact tougher measures against foreigners. "The Vlaams Blok says clearly that we're adopting their program," says Dirk Van den Bulck, a Socialist and the immigration policy chief at the Belgian Ministry of the Interior, "but we have to do something." The same trap is closing on France's ruling center-right coalition. Thus the goals of the hard right are advancing, even when it loses elections.
How far can the hard right go? That will depend on its adversaries. As a National Front militant told me, "If unemployment goes down, we're finished." But that's not the forecast. Nor is it sufficient. Europe needs a new generation of mainstream leaders who look upon public service as more than an opportunity for self-enrichment and who can offer a realistic vision of a just and open society for others than the privileged few. For now, those leaders are nowhere in sight.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 41; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3267 words

HEADLINE: Three to Watch: Populists of the Hard Right

BYLINE: By Gregory Crouch; Gregory Crouch is a correspondent with "Nachtjournal," a German version of "Nightline." This is his first contribution to the Magazine.

 BODY:

Gianfranco Fini
 
STANDING IN HIS SPACIOUS OFFICE NEAR ROME'S SPANISH Steps, Gianfranco Fini reaches for a bit of Americana. From a bookshelf that once held his infamous collection of Mussolini's greatest works, he takes down a somewhat lighter read -- a biography of New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, personally inscribed, "To Gianfranco, Good luck."
Fini turns the book over in his hands, repeating the Senator's best wishes, quietly emphasizing his tiny but growing credibility outside Italy. "I have been defined in the Italian press as the Italian Gingrich," he says proudly, taking what is for an extreme right-winger a surprisingly pro-American stance. "It's a great country." 
 Once dubbed the heir to Benito Mussolini, Fini claims he has shed his Fascist skin, transforming himself into Italy's favorite politician and a sought-after dinner guest. He is at pains to point out that he even received an invitation from the Israeli Embassy to attend a memorial concert for the slain Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin. "Everything has changed," he says.
So he claims. Nonetheless, the suspicion remains that his reincarnation as a "post-Fascist" is just an airbrush job to reassure moderates as he gets closer to real power. The same holds for his party, the increasingly influential National Alliance.
Just a day before the concert for Rabin, for instance, Italy's newspapers were filled with pictures of a high-ranking Alliance official making a Fascist salute at a wedding party. A year or so earlier another official suggested that homosexuals be put in concentration camps. And one Alliance member punched a Green Party member on the floor of the Chamber of Deputies, touching off a brawl.
Fini, it seems, has trouble controlling his troops -- a motley assortment of Mussolini fanatics, neo-Fascists and run-of-the-mill conservatives: the troops haven't necessarily undergone the same transformation as their leader. Even so, Fini becomes irritated when anyone questions his, or his followers', sincerity. "It makes me angry when people think we are pretending."
Fini, 44, joined the neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement when he was 17, outraged by a Communist demonstration that had prevented him from seeing a John Wayne movie, "The Green Berets." After working briefly as a journalist, he was elected to Parliament in 1983 under the Movement's banner and consolidated his control of the party in 1991. Last year he renamed it the National Alliance in an attempt to distance himself from both his own and his party's past shenanigans.
The image makeover, which will be tested in today's national elections, seems to be working. Many, perhaps most, Italians have
forgot Fini's black-shirt tactics, his nationalistic rallies, the skinhead groupies following him around chanting "Duce, Duce, Duce" and his notorious comment two years ago that Mussolini was "the greatest statesman of the 20th century." Indeed, an astounding 61 percent have rated him Italy's best politician, though far fewer -- about 20 percent -- said they would actually vote for an Alliance candidate.
"I am happy that the Italians think I have changed the face of the Italian right," he says. "I hope to show that this is not a momentary thing connected to my personality but a definitive kind of change."
Like many of Europe's new hard-right politicians, Fini has profited from a plethora of problems dragging down Italy's political establishment, including high unemployment, increasing crime and a Roman-size wave of government corruption that has washed away two former Prime Ministers and scores of other officials.
And Fini got a boost from Silvio Berlusconi, the media mogul turned politico who caused an international stir two years ago when he included Fini and other Fascists in his short-lived coalition Government. The National Alliance was rewarded for its loyalty with five ministerial positions.
Much has been written in the international press about Fini's elegance. He does, in fact, wear designer glasses and trim-cut suits. But he is only modestly chic by Italian standards. What actually draws many Italians to Fini is his ordinariness, which he works hard to project. He, his wife, Daniela, and their 10-year-old daughter live in a suburb. He loves amateur boxing, takes his video camera on vacation and likes to make political pronouncements at his favorite disco, his wife dancing wildly in the background.
That said, some women find him irresistible, and he obviously enjoys the attention. One woman, for instance, asked Fini for an autograph but couldn't find any paper. So she opened her blouse and told Fini to sign her chest.
Pity, he remarked, that his name is so short.
"Politicians used to be old and invisible," he says. "Now there is a search on for fresh blood."
What endears Fini to mother and daughter alike is that all of his joshing is done in good fun -- he lets everyone know that he loves his wife and makes a point of championing monogamy as part of his party's traditional values. He is, in short, the good son any Italian mother would like to have.
Daniela, on the other hand, is a lot more out there, a Roman version of Madonna who is every bit as popular as her husband is. She still has Fascist sympathies, sports a tattoo and loves to unload her pistol at shooting ranges around the city. She charmed Italians recently when she said in a television interview that it was more important for her soccer team than for her husband to win.
Harmless as Fini may seem, his opponents fear that his success could act as a sort of welcome wagon for all kinds of right-wing nuts, including those in his own party. While Fini's politics are driven more by personality than by issues, his party's platform is still nebulous. Local party offices are sometimes hotbeds of racism, homophobia and antifeminism. Nevertheless, few think that a Fini victory would endanger democracy. In a country that has had 55 Governments since World War II, the chances that Fini or his party would survive long enough to cause any real damage are low. What is perhaps more worrisome is the climate change that a neo-Fascist victory in Italy could trigger elsewhere in Europe. Once neo- or post-Fascists are welcomed at one table, it's that much harder to deny them a place at another.
For the time being, Fini has his eyes on one prize: a constitutional reform that will allow Italians to elect their president directly, as in France. However, even Fini says Italy isn't ready for a "post-Fascist" president and refuses to speculate on when it will be. "It's in the laps of the gods -- nobody knows," he says. "But things are accelerating."
 
JORG HAIDER
 
JORG HAIDER WAS SITTING DOWN FOR ANOTHER OF HIS frequent made-for-television interviews when the sound technician noticed a problem. An intercom chattering away with a debate in Parliament was interfering with the camera crew's sound system. "Is it possible to shut off Parliament?" asked the technician. "Not yet," joked Europe's most successful right-wing extremist.
The remark was typical Haider: a touch of humor for his million or so working-class and anti-Establishment constituents and a sly reminder for Europe that it's got a potentially dangerous bully in its midst, masked by a winning smile and packaged in a trim build.
Over the last 10 years, Haider has ratcheted his Freedom Party up to an astonishing 22 percent of the vote through a relentless populist attack on Austria's stodgy democracy. Along the way he has blamed immigrants for just about everything -- calling them parasites -- and indulged in bouts of Nazi nostalgia. He has praised Hitler's "proper employment policy," referred to concentration camps like Auschwitz as "punishment camps" and refused to issue a blanket condemnation of the SS.
"It's wrong to say an organization is a criminal organization on the whole," Haider said recently. "You cannot say some of this organization are criminals and therefore the whole organization is a criminal organization."
Haider is too clever to say anything directly against Jews or other minority groups. But, like a David Duke or George Wallace in America, he acts as official taboo breaker, saying subtly what many people may be thinking, things like putting an end to all of this Holocaust talk by proposing a general amnesty for old Nazis.
"It is necessary to draw a line after all these events, after 50 years," he says.
At this point, virtually no Austrians see Haider objectively -- they've lived with him too long and he is too polarizing. He is either vilified as the second coming of Hitler -- yes, he came from Austria too -- or championed as the fair-haired boy who will save the nation.
Wearing hiking books and blue jeans, Haider plops down in his Vienna office below framed photos of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Maria Shriver, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and an anonymous border guard. "Gruss Gott," he says. "May God greet you" -- the standard hello in Austria. He looks at least a decade younger than his 46 years.
The curious photo gallery -- he appears in nearly every picture -- sums up his method: a glimmer of Hollywood, some legitimate politics and constant scapegoating of immigrants. Haider is, in fact, the closest thing Austria has to a screen idol, adept at marketing his good looks. In one notable instance he posed practically nude for a women's magazine. "It was an interesting project," he says. "A new type of politician in Austria. He is like he is."
Just the very mention of Haider elicits a swoon from a top United States diplomat and a paraphrase of a line from "My Fair Lady." With a smile, she says, "You know -- he has so much charm he just oiled his way across the dance floor."
"Oily is right," says her less-smitten Austrian assistant.
Haider, who holds a seat in Parliament and is chairman of the Freedom Party, is unlikely to win a national election outright. Nevertheless, he could be called upon after the next general election, in 1999, to participate in a coalition Government. That makes more than a few people nervous. He talks vaguely about setting up a "third republic," which sounds uncomfortably like the Third Reich. He has said he would like to combine the chancellor's and president's positions and possibly move the Justice and Interior Departments into a "Security Ministry."
What's clear to Haider and everyone else is that Austria's current, second, republic is in a rut after spending the better part of the last 50 years under coalition rule -- something akin to a perpetual Clinton-Gingrich headlock. The Government hasn't tamed record unemployment or agreed on how to reduce a mammoth budget deficit. Haider's staff feeds the public a steady diet of corruption scandals that further tarnish the political establishment. And Haider serves up easy answers to difficult questions like joblessness: "There are 140,000 unemployed Austrians," he likes to say, and "180,000 foreigners."
Haider's parents were devoted, card-carrying Nazis. His father, a shoemaker, joined a Hitler Youth group in 1929, when he was 15, and later helped bring Hitler's ideology to this tiny mountainous country. "He's typical for this older generation," Haider says. "He was engaged as a Nazi, had a vision of another world, a better world, and was disappointed and destroyed, totally destroyed. Then he had to start once more to rebuild his life."
The de-Nazification program carried out by the Allies doesn't appear to have worked on Haider or on a troubling number of his countrymen. Anti-Semitism and racism bubble to the surface quicker here than in neighboring Germany. Haider, for his part, says he might have done exactly what his father did. "I'm far from saying I would have chosen my way in another form if I were in the same situation."
Haider's hesitance to condemn his family's Nazi past is all the more troubling when you consider the source of his considerable wealth: a 3,800-acre Alpine estate sold to a relative by a Jewish owner fleeing from the Nazis. Haider insists it was "a fair transaction," but others -- including the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal, who has followed Haider's career -- scoff at that.
Although a champion of traditional family values, Haider keeps his home life off-limits to the press. Even his political intimates say nobody really knows him. He is married to an Austrian hausfrau and has two teen-age daughters, but none of them play any significant role in his career. Because Haider surrounds himself with young men and is rarely seen in public with his wife, Austrian and German reporters have taken to calling his Freedom Party a "little-boys' club."
"We make a good distinction between the private life and the political life, and I think it is a good thing," Haider says.
Odd that Haider's skin is still a tad thin after all these years. He has built up his career by attacking others and has sued everyone from Wiesenthal to a schoolteacher who dared to denounce him in the classroom. To Haider's dismay, the Simon Wiesenthal Center's Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles has hung his picture in the "Contemporary Demagogues" section, along with those of Idi Amin, David Duke and Jean-Marie Le Pen.
"And there he shall stay," Wiesenthal says confidently. "History doesn't repeat itself. People just keep making the same mistakes."
 
FILIP DEWINTER
 
FILIP DEWINTER GOT INTO POLITICS WITH HIS FISTS, AND HE still enjoys a good brawl. But the fight he is waging this particular morning in Brussels requires a more diplomatic approach.
A top leader of the extreme-right Vlaams Blok, Dewinter has called a news conference to try to charm his way off Belgium's "black list," a federal index of potential threats to national security. How is it possible, he asks, that a democratic political party -- representing 13 percent of Belgium's Flemish-speaking electorate -- could be lumped together with Islamic militants?
Part of the answer lies with the Vlaams Blok member who -- almost as Dewinter spoke -- was being arrested on suspicion of smuggling mercenaries and weapons to white resistance groups in South Africa. Fifteen years earlier the same man had been expelled from the United States after meeting with a white supremacist, J. B. Stoner. "I'm not responsible for every weirdo and lunatic who's thinking he can organize a sort of violent revolution over here," Dewinter says.
For journalists this morning, the incident was further proof that Dewinter and some of his compatriots have even more in store for Belgium than what is listed in the party platform -- which is pretty horrific in its own right. The Vlaams Blok is calling for the partition of Belgium, to cut Flanders loose from the poorer Francophone region of Wallonia. And it advocates the forced deportation of non-European immigrants according to a plan that looks similar to the Nazis' Nuremberg race laws. The party's motto: "Our Own People First."
Dewinter, 33, says he would also like to set up a European federation of right-wing extremists. He has visited the like-minded in Croatia, Russia, Ukraine and South Africa. He plans an expedition to the United States in the spring. The morning's news conference -- a public-relations disaster for any other party -- was still a good show for the Vlaams Blok and its star parliamentarian. Dewinter got his baby face on television and scored a few digs against the beleaguered Belgian Government. He had, in other words, gone down swinging.
"You should never run away," Dewinter says. "In our movement, you have to defend yourself sometimes. We are not the smooth and easy politicians of the traditional parties."
From the outside, Dewinter's English-style-cottage home looks like the others that fill the suburbs around Antwerp -- if you overlook the 15-foot sign featuring a clenched fist and the exhortation "Beat corruption, vote Vlaams Blok." Inside, his two youngest daughters are playing with dolls in a cheerfully sunny playroom. Dewinter's wife, Lutgarde, and their oldest daughter are running late, returning from a Flemish youth club. He really is, as many friends say, a doting father, the flip side to his tough image.
One needn't look very hard, however, to find clues as to why Belgian authorities are so leery of him. On one of his bookshelves is a heavy marble sculpture of the Celtic cross, adopted by some neo-Nazis as their version of the swastika. On a dresser, a photo of the French far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen mingles with those of Dewinter's wife and kids. For Dewinter, Le Pen is like family, a father figure even.
Dewinter's own father -- a railroad administrator -- was also a Flemish nationalist, his mother a mainstream conservative. Born in the fairy-tale-like city of Bruges, Dewinter says he was a bit spoiled as an only child. He dropped out of college -- after getting into serious fights with left-wing extremists -- but he managed to pick up a degree from a journalists' trade school.
Dewinter walks past two tasteful paintings from Flemish artists, uncertain whether they are from the 16th, 17th or 18th century. He picks up a pair of boxing gloves and grins. "Let's knock down the Government," he says, echoing the feelings of an ever-increasing number of his countrymen.
Belgians joke that their country is the most democratic in the world -- and the most divided. One national Parliament and six assemblies and councils serve the Flemish-, French- and German-speaking communities, and there is a prime minister and a king -- all for 10 million citizens in a country the size of Maryland. This national identity crisis -- coupled with an ongoing corruption scandal and a growing immigrant community -- provides fertile ground for the Vlaams Blok, which has grown steadily since 1981. In Antwerp, Belgium's second biggest city, it is now the largest party, with 27 percent of the vote.
After visiting America last year -- where he says he saw for himself that multiculturalism would never work -- Dewinter is now more committed than ever to his immigration policies. Immigrants, nearly a third of them from Islamic countries, make up about 10 percent of Belgium's population. Under his so-called 70-point plan, Dewinter would deny non-European immigrants the right to vote, put their children in separate schools, force their employers to pay higher taxes and deport as many as possible, even second- and third-generation citizens. "We must stop the Islamic invasion," he says. "It's very difficult to accept somebody over here who believes in Islam. I think it's, in fact, impossible to assimilate in our country if you are of Islamic belief."
Dewinter makes his strongest electoral showings in mixed neighborhoods -- he calls them ghettos -- where poor whites feel "Islamicized," as he puts it. Dewinter denies that he is bigoted, though he concedes that some of his followers are. "A lot of people are becoming racist," he says. With national elections three years off, Dewinter busies himself now with foreign affairs, by which he means helping other extremists fire up their nationalist movements, just as Le Pen once did for him.
On his office wall, the fighter in him has hung a poster from his nationalist friends in the Balkans. "Croatia needs you now," it reads. "I saw the whole nation was fighting for this," he says. "It was not only a small group of military men. No, it was a whole nation who stood with their army and the people who were fighting. And that was really amazing to see, that something like that could happen."

HEADLINE: STYLE;
Barneys Bashing

BYLINE: By Holly Brubach 

 BODY:
The announcement, in January, that Barneys New York was filing for bankruptcy has prompted an outcry so gleeful and vindictive that it seems out of all proportion to the event itself, when you consider that the event is the financial collapse of a mere store. "The tyranny of fabulousness" is the term one gloating pundit used to describe the power that Barneys seems to have wielded over innocent, upstanding citizens who wanted nothing more than to go about their business, oblivious to fashion. In magazines and in newspapers (including this one), writers claim to have been oppressed by style in general and by Barneys in particular to such an extent that one begins to suspect some underlying grudge of long standing. They talk as if the store were staffed by that clique of cool kids in junior high who wouldn't let the rest of us sit at their table in the cafeteria.
At least as far back as my memory serves, one or another store in New York has been cast in the role of exclusive club. First, Bloomingdale's, in the early 70's; then, Bendel's; now, Barneys. What these stores, in their heydays, had in common was the fact that their identity resided in an esthetic. While other stores offered service, they offered attitude. The salespeople were unaccommodating, even aloof -- as if they were sitting in judgment on the customer, as if it were up to them to bestow their merchandise on those who measured up to the store's uncompromising standards. I knew women with a somewhat wobbly sense of self-assurance who would steel themselves for a trip to Bloomingdale's or Bendel's, and come away feeling that they'd passed some sort of test: they hadn't been humiliated or intimidated; they'd held their ground in the face of the salespeople's scorn, real or imagined. 
 What is striking about this particular brand of tyranny, I find, is that it requires the complicity of the victim. No one was forced to go to Barneys. If some of us are having a hard time working up any sympathy, it's because the person who has been abused by fashion must have bought into it in the first place. If we rely on the images we see in magazines and in advertising to satisfy our appetite for glamour, then we run the risk of being turned away: the world they describe is a closed one. The sting of rejection is in direct proportion to the hunger for admission.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Kenneth O. Decko;
How Business Sees the State's Economy

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years Kenneth O. Decko, a lawyer, has been involved with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, which, with more than 9,500 members, is the state's largest business organization.
Most association members have fewer than 25 employees. "We even have a huge number with under 10," said Mr. Decko, adding, "this is reflective of the state of Connecticut in terms of its business demographics." His advice to members is: "Never think you are successful. Never feel that you have achieved your goals. The minute you do that you get lazy and someone is going to take your market away from you." 
 Recently Mr. Decko discussed aspects of Connecticut's economic life. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. From your perspective is Connecticut's economy improving?
A. Slowly but surely. It's a long process. In 1994 we gained 15,000 to 20,000 jobs; in 1995 we gained slightly over 20,000. Those all came from small and medium-sized businesses. There was still substantial downsizing of large companies, particularly defense contractors.
There are a lot of good things happening. The trouble is we are going through a radical restructuring. All those institutions that gave us stability, long-term family employment opportunities for decades, were precisely the types of companies that have been hit the hardest.
Defense. Who expected the cold war to end as abruptly as it did? We're getting probably one-third of the defense dollars in Connecticut that we got less than a decade ago. Huge drops in employment from very large companies.
In the insurance industry there are tremendous competitive pressures with mergers between Connecticut Mutual and Mass Mutual, and Aetna selling off Property Casualty. Travelers selling their group insurance to somebody who then sells it to somebody else. A huge amount of change is occurring, with companies trying to find their niche doing what they do best. In financial services we had some very large banks that are now based outside Connecticut. All those had substantial job reductions.
Companies are trying to get competitive dealing with the global economy, changes in technology and consumer demands. All hit at the same time. That's a very painful long term adjustment. What we see happening is Connecticut companies, manufacturing and service, are really becoming competitive which will produce slow job growth as we go forward.
Q. Will Connecticut ever return to the prosperity of the 80's?
A. The boom in this state was a false boom based on real estate speculation. Expectations that we're ever going to return to that are unrealistic.
The other problem was a business climate that was perceived to be one of the worst in the country. In the early 90's when a company was merged or a product line ended the decision was made to move to another state. We are beginning to see some of those decisions made in favor of Connecticut.
Not just the Swiss Bank and Tenneco, but 30 smaller companies moved into the state last year. There have been some new announcements of smaller manufacturing firms moving here from New York.
Q. How about Connecticut's reputation as a high-cost state for doing business? Is that changing?
A. Our costs are lower now than in New York and Massachusetts. Short term that serves us well in terms of attracting companies from those states. Longer term we have to be competitive with North Carolina and Georgia. Those are states that have good education systems, good quality of life and good business climates. They have high-tech jobs. You look at Research Triangle in North Carolina, there are more Ph.D.s than anywhere else in the country. South Carolina has an incredible number of manufacturing facilities, a lot of foreign companies.
Connecticut needs to have its costs lowered. We don't need to be the lowest cost. We need to be in the middle of the pack. We still have a high-skilled value-added productive work force. Our quality of life can match other areas. We do have some assets.
Q. What's the association's involvement with education?
A. Education is critical at all levels. All of manufacturing today is high tech. It is also true of service industries; everybody uses computers.
To deal with competition, people must work in teams, solving problems together; they need good communication skills. That's in addition to the traditional reading, writing and calculating. Computer literacy and problem solving are basic skills in order to be employable today.
Our public schools served us very well for decades but the world changed really quickly. They need to adapt. Other institutions need to change too. Our members value graduates of the state university system and UConn. On the other end of the spectrum graduates of the vocational-technical schools aren't valued and that's supposed to be a feeder system. We are trying to turn that around.
While Connecticut used to be on top in terms of its skilled work force we need to adapt so we don't lose that edge. That's an asset we have today but we won't have it forever.
Q. Why do you oppose increasing the minimum wage?
A. Most of our members are not affected by the minimum wage. It's one of those proposals that look good on paper but when you look at what really happens you hurt the people you say you're trying to help.
The overwhelming number of people at minimum wage jobs are the elderly supplementing their income or trying to keep active, young people just out of school, second-income wage earners. You find very few primary wage-earners.
The minimum directly affects restaurants, tourism, seasonal employment. When you raise their costs they have only one choice: They reduce their work force. They can't pass on the costs to the consumer; they have to reduce overhead. There are fewer opportunities for people, particularly for those who need them most.
Q. What proposals do you have for amending environmental legislation?
A. Environmental regulations are getting better. We had gotten overregulated; Connecticut regulations exceeded Federal regulations.
The other part was a lot of paperwork and bureaucracy. Companies were waiting up to four years for a permit. With shorter product life cycles, technology changes accelerating, the global economy -- you can't operate that way. We told them, "You have to respond within a couple months." That's happening.
Also, fines for paperwork errors. Not environmental pollution, just missing forms. As you eliminate some of the paperwork hassle then it's much improved.
Q. The association is fighting the regulation of managed health care. Why is that?
A. This is a battle in every state in the country. There is a selection process in terms of providers. Those who are on the losing end -- chiropractors, podiatrists, some professionals -- are not very happy. They pressed the legislature to have managed care regulated in the health department which they feel they control so they can get back into these plans. That destroys the savings.
We were the highest per employee cost in the country in health benefits. Managed care is beginning to produce savings to employers. We don't want to see re-regulation.
Q. Are you still committed to regionalism?
A. In Connecticut our three largest cities are tiny. In the vast majority of this country your cities and your suburbs are in the same city. So we do have poverty, but people in the suburbs aren't focused as much as they should be on the problem.
This is the land of steady habits, which is a nice way of saying you're not getting rid of town government any time soon. You can begin legislatively to take government programs and add incentives to regionalize the program. More regional services will create more cohesion to deal with city problems. I think our political leaders are probably behind the public; the acceptance level has risen where we can do some things.
Cities can't survive being so small. You don't have a viable middle class base. You need to have people who are around the city who are thinking about the city and if you regionalize some services I think that begins to occur. You also begin to spread around some of the burden.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kenneth O. Decko, of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, on competition. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
The Stylish Small Change Of a Paris Rich in Talent

BYLINE: By John Russell 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
THERE ARE MUSEUMS that jump about every which way in hopes of giving a new spin to their exhibitions pro grams.
Others stick to a policy that suits them and with which they have come to be identified. One of these is the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. Its director, Phillip Dennis Cate, has mastered many alleys and byways in French art and literature as they were practiced in Paris between 1870 and 1914. Rather than chase after big-ticket paintings by Impressionists and Post-Impressionists that can now be as expensive to borrow as they once were to buy, he decided long ago to concentrate on secondary material. 
 The Zimmerli is not a rich museum, but some years ago Mr. Cate started to reach out to fellow enthusiasts for the Parisian fin de siecle. Thanks to their backing, he has been able to buy extensively in areas where he did not, as yet, have much competition. He bought prints, drawings, posters, illustrated books and magazines, theater programs, puppets, shadow-theater silhouettes, postcards, document'ry photographs and evocative ephemera.
He could have made a stylish little show with just a fraction of the museum's material. Instead, he has put more than 200 items on display in an exhibition called "The Spirit of @ontmartre: Cabarets, Humor and the Avant-Garde, 1875-1905." On view through July 31, it is the apotheosis of a certain bohemia known for its rowdy, free-living cafes and clubs. The show is nothing short of a visual pandemonium in which image and text vie for our attention. This is an exhibition to look at closely and for hours, but it is also one to read.
Major artists -- Toulouse-Lautrec, Bonnard and Vuillard -- make cameo appearances. A major poet, Stephane Mallarme, is evoked over and over, not as a participant but as an august presence who gave encouragement to others. There is also, here and there, an echo of the poet Jules Laforgue, who later influenced the young T. S. Eliot.
But this is primarily a show of auxiliary adventures, many of which will be unfamiliar to the American museum audience. For instance, there is the shadow theater. Still fabled, this was an entertainment in which shadows of the human figure were cast from behind onto a white screen. Though often life-size, the shadows were made with cutout silhouettes only a few inches high.
It is made clear both in the silhouettes and in a film lent to the museum by the Musee d'Orsay in Paris that the shadow theater could be a medium capable of sustaining a narrative line and a large cast of characters. Though apparently effortless and produced from almost nothing, it often had a momentum that made it a true precursor of the movies. Sometimes it also came with a musical accompaniment composed for the occasion.
A star performer in the Zimmerli show is the humorist Alphonse Allais (1854-1905). Allais was not a stand-up comic in print; he never raised his voice, pulled faces or tugged at the reader's sleeve. On the contrary, his way of working verged on the surreptitious. He could use words with a wonderful economy, and he could make duets for text and image.
In the present show there is a little picture by Allais called "Funeral March for a Great Man Who Was Deaf." It consists of nine measures of total silence on an empty sheet of music paper and the indication "Lento rigolando' ("very slowly and just in fun").
The work, from 1897, has not dated at all, so lightly does Allais bring it off. It had a distinguished ancestor in the series of monochromatic paintings he made in 1879. In the heyday of the anecdotal salon painting, with its often lengthy descriptive titles, Allais suggested, in effect, that if the title told the whole story there need not be anything on the canvas.
In each of the seven images that make up his "April Fools' Album," he produced a field of plain color (black, green, beige, ocher, blue, red and white) with titles to match. The red one, for instance, is called "Apoplectic Cardinals Harvesting Tomatoes on the Shore of the Red Sea." More than a century later, with the single-color painting still with us from time to time, this too has topicality.
Allais and the masters of the shadow theater were complete professionals who knew when to cut a story short. So did Coquelin Cadet (1848-1909), a leading actor of the day, who liked to get away from the Comedie Francaise for an hour or two. When in Montmartre, he perfected a consummate cabaret turn, made up of monologues delivered in a deadpan but highly mannered style. "The monologue," he wrote, "is one of the most original expressions of
modern humor. Cooked up in an extraordinarily Parisian stew pot, it combines elements of French farce and French catch phrases with the violence of American conceptions."
Another great professional in this show is Alfred Jarry (1873-1907). His ribald and disrespectful spirit came out at full strength in "Ubu Roi," a satirical play that broke the mold of bourgeois theater once and for all. The Zimmerli collection includes a wealth of material about Jarry and "Ubu." Much of it is unfamiliar and has a ferocious actuality at a time when laconic and almost casual massacres are rarely out of the news.
That Montmartre should have been the center of such activities is a remarkable historical phenomenon. Its celebrity caused a whole troupe of minor characters to come running. Some of them still look good. We are by now familiar with Marcel Duchamp's 1919 "Mona Lisa" w'th a beard and mustache. So there is something truly startling about the date -- 1887 -- of the photo-relief of "Mona Lisa With a Pipe" by Eugene Bataille, who called himself Sapeck.
Among the resident stalwarts who carry much of the show on their shoulders, Theophile-Alexandre Steinlen, draftsman, and Henri Riviere, printmaker, deserve long-service medals. There are also times when triviality and self-satisfaction run riot. At such moments, a high tolerance of bohemia is needed. But it is the essence of the later part of the show, which includes a mass of material drawn from a wall journal called Le Mur, that it functions as a visual flea market. A close look here and there will reveal a diamond among the dust.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Mona Lisa With a Pipe," an 1887 work by Eugene Bataille, known as Sapeck, on view in New Brunswick, N.J. (pg. 35); "La Marche a L'Etoile," a 1891 poster for a musical, by Henri Riviere. (Jack Abraham/Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum) (pg. 42)
