SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1454 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
It's Their Album. They'll Cry if They Want To.

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
IT'S OFFICIAL: AMERICA'S NEW national pastime is self-pity. There's so much to sulk about -- economic insecurity, social disorder, frustrating jobs, romances going wrong and, for baby boomers, the inevitable responsibilities and disappointments of aging. And now, self-pity no longer means suffering in silence. In the 1990's, it's a proud, gutsy misery, strong enough to shape a whole identity. Politicians cater to it, offering scapegoats and palliatives; talk shows parade self-styled victims. And popular music, always the vent for troubled feelings, has groaned and whined its way through the decade.
For the last two years, the reigning crybaby has been Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish, which will release "Fairweather Johnson" (Atlantic) on Tuesday. The title tune is a 50-second ditty about sports fans who cheer only for winning teams, a none-too-subtle allusion to all the new supporters the band found when it became a blockbuster with its album "Cracked Rear View," which has sold nearly nine million copies since its release in 1994. "Fairweather Johnson" is Hootie's second major-label album but actually the band's fifth recording; it released independent-label albums in 1990 and 1992 and an EP in 1993. 
 Hootie and the Blowfish was started in the late 1980's by four friends at the University of South Carolina; its name combined the nicknames of two other U.S.C. students. The band, whose members are now in their late 20's, worked its way up a frat-party and club circuit that eventually stretched from Georgia to the Wetlands club in New York. But comparatively few people had heard of them before "Cracked Rear View" came out and began its stranglehold on radio and music-video channels, especially VH-1. With ringing folk-rock guitars and Rucker's hearty baritone emoting through choruses like "Hold my hand" and "I only wanna be with you," Hootie and the Blowfish suddenly came barreling down the middle of the road.
Folk-rock has become the style that spans rock's generation gap. Counting Crows certified the neo-folk-rock boom with its 1993 debut album, "August and Everything After," which sold five million copies. The Gin Blossoms, Toad the Wet Sprocket, the Rembrandts, Deep Blue Something and a Hootie soundalike, Dog's Eye View, have also strummed their way onto the charts. In the new folk-rock, baby boomers hear pleasant echoes of past favorites from Bob Dylan to the Allman Brothers; younger listeners connect via R.E.M. and its collegiate-rock disciples. Folk-rock easily straddles radio formats from classic rock to modern rock.
Amid the distortion of grunge and the claustrophobic crunch of hip-hop, Hootie's basic three-chord harmonies and steady-strummed guitars seem comforting, and they never attack. In the word most often used by Hootie's fans and detractors alike, the band sounds "normal."
Normality is the image that promotes the band. Hootie's four members -- Rucker, Mark Bryan on guitar, Dean Felber on bass and Jim Sonefeld on drums -- present themselves as hard-working regular guys: football fans and golf buddies who hang out together, drink beer, eat fast food and roll on down the road. Felber, who majored in finance, set up the band as a corporate partnership, with tax withholding and health insurance like any other full-time job.
The band flaunts no intellectual pretensions, no extreme clothes or haircuts, no androgyny, no antisocial tendencies, just a willingness to please audiences with music that sounds familiar because, by and large, it is. The fact that Rucker is black and the other three band members are white also provides a reassuring image of racial harmony as something that can be taken for granted (although "Drowning," on "Cracked Rear View," does confront bigotry). But if Hootie defines normality, then regular guys must be feeling mighty sorry for themselves.
THE BAND MEMBERS' MANLY camaraderie, the chiming major chords of the songs and Rucker's gutsy voice all guarantee that Hootie isn't a bunch of wimps. And that frees Rucker to bawl all he wants. In half of the songs on "Cracked Rear View," he sings about crying ("You wonder why I'm such a baby," he admits in "Only Wanna Be With You").
On "Fairweather Johnson" he's even more tormented; he's still crying, but he has also moved on to rage and thoughts of death. He promised lasting love in the hits on "Cracked Rear View," but the band's new songs follow through on that album's unhappy "Running From an Angel": they're laments about infidelity and and shaky or broken romances, with Rucker letting loose his wounded bellow. "Let me scream, let me scream, let me scream!" he howls in "Honeyscrew."
He also sings about screaming in "So Strange," "When I'm Lonely" and "Tucker's Town." But that's no surprise; when Hootie and the Blowfish like a word or image, they stick with it, especially if it's vague and steeped in cliche. The album keeps coming back to dreams and sun, smiling and breathing, feeling and lying and dying. "Let Her Cry" was a hit from "Cracked Rear View." On the new album, Rucker entreats, "Let me in," "Let me dream," "Let it breathe," "Let me feel it" and "Let me be the one." On "Cracked Rear View," Hootie paid tribute to Bob Dylan by quoting a verse of "Idiot Wind"; now, in "Fool," the singer is drunk and listening to Bonnie Raitt sing "Give It Up" on the radio.
"Honeyscrew" and the album's opener, "Be the One," represent the new, more openly turbulent Hootie. In "Honeyscrew," the music shifts tempo and builds churning crescendos while the singer rails at a woman who has left him. "I called today just to make me feel hopeless," he admits. In "Be the One," a rare Hootie song in a minor key, Rucker punishes his voice, rasping and slobbering incoherently about an elusive woman he's willing to die for. Both songs end with penetrating and sustained (but perfectly tuned) feedback notes; the band's not completely unfamiliar with alternative rock.
"Cracked Rear View" hid its tears in surging, optimistic tunes, and Hootie holds on to that formula for most of "Fairweather Johnson." "Old Man and Me," with a rolling Allman Brothers vamp and a Dickey Betts-style guitar solo, mulls over war, prejudice and motherly or mothering love ("When I cried, she wiped my tears"). Its chorus mentions the death of millions, but it still sounds upbeat as Rucker sings, "When I get to heaven."
THE LOYALTY AND FIDELITY that the songs begged for on "Cracked Rear View" have collapsed on "Fairweather Johnson." "I just can't find the way to let me feel like all is well," Rucker announces in "Silly Little Pop Song," before he demands, "Are you seeing someone?" Usually the singer is the one who's getting dumped; he's desperately trying to hold on while his girlfriend/lover/old flame wants to get away. The band, like good friends, unfailingly takes his side, bolstering him with tunes that reshape his maundering into anthems.
"She Crawls Away" tootles along with organ and accordion like John Mellencamp's "Cherry Bomb" (which was made, like both of Hootie's Atlantic albums, with the producer Don Gehman). It praises a woman whose "smile is like sunshine," and the chorus sounds like an affirmation as it begins, "I believe." But it goes on to say that she's "playing with another" and, later, "laying with another," as Rucker's voice turns raw and agonized. In "Tucker's Town," which takes after Dylan's "Like a Rolling Stone," Rucker pines for a woman whose father hates him but comes up with a bracing chorus for the words, "I don't know what I can't see."
"Cracked Rear View" put a happier face on Hootie's search for true love, and it often made the singer sound like Prince Charming, a guy who always made the right promises. "Fairweather Johnson" shatters that facade; its narrators seesaw between childish dependence and compulsive womanizing. In "When I'm Lonely," derived from Van Morrison via Southern rock, the singer cheats on his lover, who then tries to cheat on him. "I struggle with life when I'm lonely," he moans. He makes a similar confession in "The Earth Stopped Cold at Dawn." Over sympathetic mandolin and fiddle, he sings, "Can't wait for a friend when loneliness calls." No wonder the women are walking out on him.
The music on "Fairweather Johnson" still provides the certainties of folk-rock, with its rudimentary chords and its homey strumming and picking. Meanwhile, the lyrics have grown less complacent, though without losing much of their triteness. Hootie's recent fans, if they're paying attention, probably won't find "Fairweather Johnson" as soothing as its predecessor. Even the normal guys, it turns out, are self-absorbed and hapless in love; no wonder they're whimpering too.

HEADLINE: DANCE;
At Ballet Theater, A Rebound Amid All the Bounding

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KAYE; Elizabeth Kaye, a contributing editor for Esquire, writes frequently about the arts.

 BODY:
DANCERS CONVEY MEANING through gesture. At times, these gestures take on a meaning beyond what the dancers intend. For example, the reasons for the renaissance at American Ballet Theater could be read in 'ne graceful gesture offered to the company by its premier danseur Julio Bocca in the final moment of the 1995 New York season.
On that June evening, Mr. Bocca danced the lead role of Basilio in Ballet Theater's new production of Petipa's "Don Quixote," spaged by Kevin McKenzie, the company's artistic director, and Susan Jones. Then, interrupting the tumultuous ovation for him, he turned to the 36 dancers behind him and bowed to those young women and men, mainstays of what he calls "the greatest company in the world." 
 It was a telling moment: the dancer often described as the world's leading male virtuoso paying tribute to a company that had weathered a dark interval and emerged to reassert a claim to primacy in the ballet world. At one level, it was a spar acknowledging a debt to gifted persons not often accorded due respect. Beyond that, it testified to the fact that a ballet company can thrive only through the labor and commitment, energy and gift that alchemize onstage into enchantment.
This enchantment is something that Ballet Theater's members expect to create consistently during their eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which opens on Monday, April 29. "If your dancers can't bring magic to an audience," says Guillaume Graffin, a principal dancer, "you're just taking their money."
American Ballet Theater, founded 57 years ago, is the phoenix of ballet companies, risen from ashes that accumulated during the 80's and early 90's, when reports of its imminent death were, to adapt Mark Twain's phrase, not really all that exaggerated.
In those years, against a backdrop of economic recession and dwindling financing for the arts, the company floundered. Under the direction of Mikhail Baryshnikov from 1980 to 1989 and of Jane Hermann, who had been the Metropolitan Opera House's presentations director, from 1989 to 1992, it became flat broke and demoralized. Though both directors were immensely talented, their often thankless, always taxing job seemed to extract from them a sourness that filtered down through the company.
"But no one person or event created the problems the company faced," says Robert Pontarelli, a spokesman for Ballet Theater who has been with the company since 1980. "The ballet boom had ended, and it was a difficult time."
Directing a company may be the balletic equivalent of scaling Mount Everest, and Ballet Theater offers a steeper climb than most. From its founding in 1939 by Richard Pleasant, with the financial backing of Lucia Chase, the troupe has been quartered in New York City, which has assured it a high profile but also a high 'egree of scrutiny. Moreover, Ballet Theater has been America's largest touring dance company and has had no home theater, two facts that result in special problems.
The company proved to be ballet's citadel of high drama, and a haven for phe glamorous Russian defectors Natalia Makarova, Alexander Godunov and Mr. Baryshnikov. A company that consistently managed, for better or worse, to cross over from the arts to the gossip pages, it became known for Mr. Baryshnikov's tempestuous pomance with the ballerina Gelsey Kirkland; for Ms. Kirkland's autobiography, with its rendering of Mr. Baryshnikov's qualities as a sexual partner and of her drug-taking, as well as for the drug-related death of the stunning dancer Patrick Bissell.
BUT FROM THE EARLY 1940'S Ballet Theater was distinguished by lustrous creative periods. Mr. McKenzie, who has overseen the company's steady resuscitation since he took over as artistic director in fall 1992 after 12 years as a dancer with the company, identifies these as its first two golden ages.
The first, as he sees it, was defined by the brilliant choreography of Antony Tudor, Jerome Robbins, Agnes de Mille and even George Balanchine, whose "Theme and Variations" was created for Ballet Theater. The second golden age, in Mr. McKenzie's view, emphasized glorious dancers, culminating with Mr. Baryshnikov and Ms. Makarova and including most of the stars of the 1960's and 70's, among them Anthony Dowell, Rudolf Nureyev, Carla Fracci and the Danish danseur noble Erik Bruhn.
As a young man, watching the elegant Mr. Bruhn, Mr. McKenzie thought, "That's what I want to be when I grow up." And during the years he performed, he became a true premier danseur, romantic and ardent, able to merge flash with style.
Still, the soft-spoken Mr. McKenzie was not an obvious choice for the role of savior. And when he was named director by Ballet Theater's board in the bleak days of 1992, when the company was facing a $5.7 million deficit, the appointment struck some in the dance community as less than inspired. Within the company, it was seen differently. "Kevin had been part of the family for so long," says Mr. Pontarelli, "that he had a clear vision of who we were and where we had to get to."
Mr. McKenzie has apparently turned out to be the right man at the right time. With a manner both commanding and unassuming, he can navigate the straits between toughness and malleability, garnering respect from dancers who nonetheless regard him as "one of us."
"I think it's important to keep that connection," he says. "They'll work for you if they're working with you."
The climate he has established permits his dancers to feel both safe and challenged. "He encourages dancers to be themselves," says the ballerina Susan Jaffe. "And he is the one person who can say during rehearsals, 'I don't buy it,' and I won't feel offended."
This ambiance has lifted company morale. While Mr. Baryshnikov could inspire dancers, he was never easy on a dancer who achieved less than perfection. That attitude had its benefits but, as one company member put it, "It's not much fun to dance when you're afraid to mess up."
In Mr. McKenzie's company, dancers seem to enjoy themselves. This was evident at Ballet Theater's studios on lower Broadway one day recently as Susan Jones conducted a noontime rehearsal with the women of the corps, instructing them, in the Shades scene from "La Bayadere," to give their arabesque an extra reach, "to make it seem from another world." An hour later, Ms. Jon's handed out fans to female soloists w'o summoned an entirely different spirit rehearsing the first act of "Don Quixote."
Nearby, seated on a trunk in a hallway, Michael Cusumano, a member of the corps, studied a video of the new Twyla Tharp piece "Elements," to learn the role that will be danced by the 20-year-old phenomenon Angel Corella. In an adjacent stu'io, Mr. Corella rehearsed with another young star, the 21-year-old Paloma Herrera; they will open the season in the lead roles of "Don Quixote." "We can'p wait," says Ms. Herrera. "We're so happy when we're on the stage."
While a ballet company's success may rest with dancers, other things must be tended to before there can be dancing. Those things are the purview of Ballet Theater's new executive director, the 42-year-old Michael Kaiser, whose temperate demeanor obscures the zeal of a leader.
Raised in New Rochelle, N.Y., he studied to be an opera singer. Convinced that he lacked the talent to be a performer, he went into business, eventually making the transition to arts administration, where stakes are high and jobs are scarce. He came to Ballet Theater last year after overseeing a remarkable turnaround at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. He had started there in 1991, when Ailey was in danger of closing its doors. Three years later, he moved on, leaving behind a deficit-free company. He is modest about his contribution to the Ailey success. "The only arts organization that can be turned around," he says, "is one that makes good art."
Turnaround is an inexact science, and no simple task for a company as big as Ballet Theater, which now has 88 dancers, as many as it had in the prosperous years of the late 70's. It is a process, Mr. Kaiser maintains, with a strong psychological component. When Ballet Theater was falt'ring, he says, "all anyone spoke of was the deficit." "But," he continues, "you have to get people to focus on the promise, on the good being done today, while you deal with the problems."
Some stabilization of the company had been achieved by his predecessor, Gary Dunning, but in the seven months since he took over the job, Mr. Kaiser has stepped up the recovery's pace significantly:
*The company now has an operating surplus of more than $1.5 million.
*Recently, the chairman of Ballet Theater's board, Peter T. Joseph, pledged to contribute $5 million over four years if Mr. Kaiser could find matching contributions, which he is doing.
*The company has received a $1.5 million grant from the Mellon Foundation.
*An annual fall New York season is planned, to start in 1997 at City Center, focusing on experimental works.
*Two new full-length ballets have been commissioned: an "Othello" to be produced with the San Francisco Ballet and choreographed by Lar Lubovitch, with music by Elliot Goldenthal, and "A Suite for Human Nature," choreographed by the former dancer Kevin O'Day, with music by Wynton Marsalis.
And in addition to the performances the complete Ballet Theater will give this year in many major cities, to accommodate demand, the dancers will also divide into two troupes to perform major repertory around the country.
"Success breeds success," says Mr. Kaiser. "Optimism breeds optimism."
No change is more significant than that achieved through the hiring of new dancers for Ballet Theater, which hap previously been able to guarantee a full house for the performances of only three dancers: the dazzling Mr. Bocca, his bewitching partner Alessandra Ferri and the fluid Russian ballerina Nina Ananiashvili.
Although Mr. Baryshnikov brought in both Mr. Bocca and Miss Ferri as principals, for the most part he dissolved Ballet Theater's custom of importing stars, a practice that had initially accounted for his own presence with the company. These stars' photographs graced posters and programs; they danced leading roles at sold-out performances. As a result, they could convert a company that was their host into their hostage. "It was all what they can do and what they can't do, and with who and with what," Mr. Baryshnikov once complained.
SO HE INSTITUTED THE system he grew up with at the Kirov Ballet, where many dancers advance from the corps to soloist to principal. When he left in 1989, this plan had produced markedly less than expected, though eventually it begat a bevy of special dancers, including the exquisitely precise Amanda McKerrow, the sinuous Ms. Jaffe and the ethereal Julie Kent.
"When you come out of the corps," says Ms. Kent, "you have a better understanding of the whole picture. When I was in the corps, during Act III of 'Swan Lake,' I sat on a little pillow the whole time. I made up my own story about why I was there, but I really wanted contact with the Prince and Odile. Now that I'm dancing Odile, I try to connect with everyone on the stage, to let them know they're as important to me as I may be to them."
Mr. McKenzie has made his mark by bringing in new soloists and principals, in the process taking the risk of damaging morale by promoting them over dancers who endured years of reduced schedules and pay. Last year, he added four men who were so gifted that their presence has served to elevate the mood and pride of most company members. They are the exotic Vladimir Malakhov, who tries to dance, he says, "the way Maria Callas sings"; Jose Manuel Carreno, whose silky charm has a distinct charm; Mr. Corella, with a smile as glittering as his leaps and spins, and Maxim Belotserkovsky, who commands the stage with brio.
"A'd they're listed as company members, not guest artists," points out the principal dancer Victor Barbee. "The asterisks are gone."
Today, Kevin McKenzie believes that Ballet Theater is embarking on a third golden age, which, with its combination of notable dancers and choreographers, could be a synthesis of the two previous eras. Given a repertory that ranges from Petipa to Tharp to Tudor, the company's signature is proving to be not the style in which it dances but the level of excellence at which it dances anything. In this regard, Ballet Theater may be on the verge of becoming the company it always wanted to be, one that announced itself in 1939 in this way: "The Greatest Ballets of All Time Staged by the Greatest Collaboration in Ballet History!"
The audience seems to sense this direction: the day the box office opened at the Met, $120,000 worth of tickets were sold, twice as much as on that day last year.
Company members sense it, too. "The dancers," Mr. McKenzie says, "are in a mode of: Go for it."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Eloquent Champion of the Vernacular Landscape

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS HAVE THREE more days to catch "A Sense of Place, a Sense of Time," the Municipal Art Society's small, delightful show of drawings by J. B. Jackson. But those who miss the show at the Urban Center (451 Madison Avenue, at 50st Street) can catch it at the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence, where it will run from April 29 through May 25. And those who hop on a train to see Jackson's drawings will not regret the journey. They will have the chance to travel through Jackson's subject: the American landscape in all its battered, democratic glory.
John Brinckerhoff Jackson, 86, is America's greatest living writer on the cultural forces that have shaped the land this nation occupies. In a series of insightful essays, many of them originally published in Landscape magazine and later collected in books, Jackson has taught several generations of designers to see the environment with fresh eyes. His drawings are valuable chiefly for the light they shed on his writings. No one familiar with the writings needs further proof that Jackson has an eye. But like Ruskin's drawings, Jackson's graphic work shows that the man has a hand as well. 
 Jackson has always insisted that we look at the environment in other than pictorial terms, and his drawings should not be seen just as pictures of buildings, hills or highways. For Jackson, it seems, drawing is not primarily a way of depicting things. It is a tool for framing things, a technique for fixing or loosening the boundaries around the object on view.
A 1959 drawing, for example, focuses on the Institut de France, the Renaissance palace that faces the Louvre from the Left Bank of the Seine. We can make out the Institut's famous dome, the architectural crown of the fabled Academie Francaise. But the rest of the building is reduced to a block of shadow stacked atop another shadow, the wall rising from the river. Trees intervene, and so does a row o' barges; the lovely Pont des Arts loops through the river's reflected light. The picture examines these peripheral effects as closely as it does the historic monument they frame.
"Telephone Poles," a 1947 drawing, conveys the futility of bounding the boundless. The two dimensions of the paper frame a road, a sky and telephone lines that recede into infinite space. This is a counter-Renaissance design, the American antithesis of paintings in which 15th-century architects visualized the ideal city in terms of the new technique of perspectival space. Yet Jackson also depicts an ideal city, at least as Frank Lloyd Wright once envisioned it: the decentralized city made possible by cars and telephones. Jackson records the bleakness of this city even as he suggests its potential for freedom. He uses perspectival space to illustrate the mythology of the open road. The frame is made to be escaped.
Jackson was born in France in 1909 and educated at Harvard College. He left the East for New Mexico, where he took up ranching. During World War II, he served in Europe as an intelligence officer in the United States Army. The earliest drawings in the show are pencil sketches produced in the line of duty: a bridge in Austria, farm fields and town squares in provincial France.
Jackson's wartime service was news to me, but it makes perfect sense that he developed his outlook at a time and place where people risked their lives for the sake of borders. In his writings, Jackson emphasizes the political as well as the social, economic and esthetic forces that carve up the land. The early drawings help explain this emphasis. A bridge, a field, the crest of a 'ill are not just picturesque landmarks. They delineate the edges of savagely contested terrain.
In 1951, Jackson founded Landscape magazine, a journal he published and edited until 1968. This achievement gained him a wide audience. Though aimed at professio'al landscape and garden designers, the magazine embraced the larger mission of expanding the definition of landscape beyond the scope of professional practice. In his essays, Jackson talked about roads, forests, the patterns of agriculture.
EVEN IN PEACETIME, JACKSON never ceased to be an intelligence officer, a writer who reports back to his readers on his observations from the field. Highways, telephone poles, irrigation systems and mobile homes are elements of political as well as physical organization.
In short, he extended the borders of landscape over the entire land and everything built on it. This resulted in a kind of Manifest Destiny recast in intellectual terms.
One key to Jackson's influence is the literary skill with which he made this outrageously ambitious claim appear reasonable, even modest. Jackson conquered through common sense. His ideas are straightforward, his scholarship sound but unshowy. His clear prose is the verbal equivalent of the vernacular buildings he writes about. Indeed, he is one of the few writers who can make you think that a love of the vernacular need not be a twisted form of philistine rage against the exceptional.
Though he has been a major influence on environmentalists, Jackson does not style himself an ecologist. S'me of his sharpest words are aimed at those who believe that a landscape can be beautiful without the human presence.
"The older I grow and the longer I look at landscapes and seek to understand them, the more convinced I am that their beauty is not simply an aspect but their very essence and that that beauty derives from the human presence," Jackson writes in "Discovering the Vernacular Landscape," published by Yale University Press in 1984.
"For far too long we have told ourselves that the beauty of a landscape was the expression of some transcendent law; the cdnformity to certain universal esthetic principles or the conformity to certain biological or ecological laws. But this is true only of formal or planned political landscapes. The beauty that we see in the vernacular landscape is the image of our common humanity: hard work, stubborn hope and 'utual forbearance striving to be love. I believe that a landscape which makes these qualities manifest is one that can be called beautiful."
Jackson writes as if culture itself were an ecological system, an environment in which art, politics, philosophy and other spheres of information are constantly interacting. At times, it seems that Jackson is using landscape as a metaphor for the complex links between these spheres.
Those who fall under Jackson's spell will find it hard to look at buildings as distinct objects, even though that is the way architects usually design them. Though a building has physical boundaries, its meaning and value depend on its relationship to the city outsid' them. Not just the physical space around the building, but also the economic, social, political and historical forces converging on its site. The building provides a frame for examining those forces.
Jackson, who continues to write from his ranch near Santa Fe, did not invent this way of looking. A century ago, Louis Sullivan wrote that "once you learn to look at architecture not merely as an art more or less well or more or less badly done, but as a social manifestation, the critical eye becomes clairvoyant." Jackson's eye may be the most penetrating this century has produced.

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
We Need a Ron Brown Award for Business

BYLINE: By ROBERT M. TOMASKO; Robert M. Tomasko is a business adviser in Washington and author most recently of "Go for Growth" (John Wiley & Sons, 1996).

 BODY:
COMMERCE Secretary Ronald H. Brown was an extraordinarily effective ambassador for our country's business community, and he will be missed.
But we can commemorate both his life and his belief that business can be a force for good by establishing an award that would be granted -- as a parallel to the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards -- to our nation's top exporters and most thoughtful, responsible overseas investors. 
 Well-managed, prestigious incentives like the Baldrige awards encourage positive corporate behavior. While it is important to hold business accountable for its missteps, as the press has done recently about downsizing, the impact of knuckle-slapping is usually short-lived. Shining the limelight on positive corporate role models is much more likely to produce lasting change. Not every company is downsizing; many are fueling job growth through what Mr. Brown made his personal mission: the selling of American goods and services abroad.
As a management consultant, I've been pleasantly surprised by how seriously companies take the Baldrige quality award. It has had a ripple effect on much corporate behavior. But while quality is vital, it is no longer sufficient. It may provide entry to the global arena, but it no longer guarantees that a business will prevail.
That is where Ron Brown's mission comes in. His tenure as Commerce Secretary was marked by total commitment to American companies' achieving growth through full participation in the world's markets. He also knew that such growth carried with it social responsibilities -- to the host countries' laws, to foreign consumers and to the emerging global consensus on issues like pollution and child labor.
A Ron Brown award would help keep his vision alive. Let the prize go to those companies -- small and large -- that fuel our country's growth through prowess in world markets. If the history of the Baldrige awards is a fair guide, the Brown awards might be the catalyst that business needs to turn its sights outward, toward growth.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Ending Rent Controls the Massachusetts Way

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A LAWYER named Charlyn Burton-Goldman is no friend of a property owner named Ronald Brown. He was her landlord in what she describes as a lovely pink three-story building with a courtyard at 38 Brown Street, a 51-unit condominium in the town of Brookline, just outside Boston. It was converted from a rental in 1983, but her own apartment was never purchased.
The two were antagonists in court on overdue rent charges and service complaints for years. Mr. Brown won an eviction order, and the lawyer-tenant kept appealing. But it all ended last June. Ms. Burton-Goldman bought a two-bedroom condominium in the same complex from an owner-occupant. 
 "I knew I would be out on my fanny by December, so I figured I had better be out fast," she said.
The sudden urgency was the result of rent decontrol in Massachusetts. Small property owners in Cambridge succeeded in getting a question on the state ballot in 1994 to eliminate existing controls and bar localities from imposing them without economic compensation for owners. The owners raised more than $1 million -- somewhat less than half of it from state and national trade organizations -- and collected more than 100,000 signatures in a citizens initiative. They won with 51 percent of the vote.
The prohibition was to take effect comprehensively on Jan. 1, 1995. But after the referendum the communities affected -- Cambridge, Brookline and Boston -- petitioned the Legislature for an exemption. A bill passed but Gov. William F. vetoed it. Then he signed a bill allowing a phase-out over two years.
Tenants without a demonstrable financial need were decontrolled on Jan. 1, 1995. But if the tenant's income was under 60 percent of areawide median, or under 80 percent for the elderly or disabled, decontrol was deferred. The deferral ran to Jan. 1, 1996, for condominiums or small buildings (three-families or less, or owner-occupied buildings with up to 12 apartments), and to Jan. 1, 1997, for everything else.
The income guidelines apply in Boston only to tenants who have continuously occupied their apartment since 1976. Boston enacted vacancy decontrol in that year -- with a free-market rent when a controlled apartment is vacated. But since 1983 tenants have had a right to file a grievance with the local Rent Equity Board over lease-renewal increases. This right they have now lost. Brookline also has vacancy decontrol, but in a purer form and only since 1990. There is no grievance procedure on renewal leases.
The immediate impact of deregulation has come in situations where tenants were paying rents far below true market value. Many tenants like Ms. Burton-Goldman have moved out, sometimes into purchased homes or apartments. Others have stayed on at rents that are now marching rapidly toward market levels. On the pertinent question of what they pay now, or paid before, as a percentage of their income there is no information.
"Will people die from this? I can't say that," said Matt Henzy, interim director of the Massachusetts Tenants Organization in Boston. "But there has been a negative impact. People have had to pay more than they can afford, and move out of their communities."
In one survey in the Fenway neighborhood, near Symphony Hall in Boston, it was found that 36 percent of rent-controlled elderly tenants -- 118 out of 322 households -- left the neighborhood between October 1994 and April 1995, Mr. Henzy said.
There has also been a psychological change, most notable when it is expressed by the small owners in Cambridge who led the anti-rent-control movement. They feel they have won control over their property, which a harsh enforcement of a rent-control law had denied them.
W E bought a house with rent-controlled apartments on Chester Street in Cambridge in 1986 planning to live in it," said Denise Jillson, chairwoman of the Massachusetts Homeowners Coalition, which led the ballot drive. "Then we went to the rent board to try to get possession. I found I could pay $10,000 to the tenant plus her moving expenses and she would need 90 days to leave. The 'mediation' that the tenant advocates were proposing was nothing but extortion."
Ms. Jillson and her husband, George Pereira, who have two children, had sold their house in New Hampshire and were planning to occupy one of the four renter-occupied apartments in the Chester Street house -- a seven-room unit in which the 10-year tenant was paying $200 a month and subletting out four of the rooms. The couple finally did dispossess the tenant. Then they fought with the rent board over its refusal to reimburse them through rent increases for the reconstruction work that Mr. Pereira personally undertook on the building.
The Massachusetts events are a striking illustration of small property owners rising up to overcome their local weakness at the ballot box. It is not an option available to the disaffected small owners of New York City, who long have felt themselves the principal victims of New York regulations.
The New York Constitution does not permit citizen ballot initiatives. In any event rent regulations usually do not affect buildings with fewer than six units. And the law lets buyers who intend to occupy an apartment dispossess a regulated tenant to do so (with protections for the elderly or disabled). The regulations implement the Emergency Tenants Protection Act of 1974, which is renewed by the State Legislature periodically. It comes up again next year.
Even in California, center of citizen-initiated ballot questions, property owners have not attempted an anti-rent-control drive, apparently because controls are so widespread that their chances are slim. But vacancy decontrol is in effect in most places with rent controls, and last year the Legislature mandated vacancy decontrol in the handful of communities that lack it, including Berkeley and Santa Monica.
The Cambridge owners failed in 1989 to place on the local ballot three propositions that would have made it easier for condominium buyers to get possession of their apartments. After that, changes on the City Council led to tighter enforcement of existing regulations, and the decision by owners to seek a statewide referendum.
The Cambridge rent board will go out of business next month, said Terrence P. Morris, who left city employment this month after serving as the board's executive director since 1990. Although there are no figures on how many renters moved after decontrol, he said that in the 12-month period after the referendum the number of registered voters in Cambridge declined by 6,000.
"Thousands moved, but many were living in apartments that they could afford and they are still living there," he said. The inventory of controlled apartments has shrunk from 16,200 to 1,300, he said.
Condominium conversions were common in Cambridge in the 70's. In 1979 the city set up a regulatory procedure that condominium buyers had to follow to take possession of their apartments. It was largely ignored, Mr. Morris said, setting up an aggrieved class of owner-occupants years later when Cambridge tried to enforce the law against buyers who were deemed to have taken possession of their apartments illegally. These owner helped fuel the anti-rent-control movement.
Larger owners say they are not trying to force longtime renters to pay market rents all at once. One such owner, Edward E. Zuker, principal in Chestnut Hill Realty in Brookline, said he was phasing in rent increases to a total of 80 percent of the market rent, with the dollar amount of the monthly increase in any year capped at $75 to $150, depending on the size of the unit.
In a typical situation -- 37-41 Auburn Street in Brookline, with 34 apartments -- 12 apartments were decontrolled on Jan. 1, 1995, because of the referendum. Half the tenants have stayed. A tenant who had been paying $650 a month in 1994 for a one-bedroom now pays $850, Mr. Zuker said. When the rent reaches $880 in January it will be at 80 percent of market value, he said.
Among younger people who have saved money while living at below-market rents, buying has been an option. Kenneth Westhassel, a tenant in his 40's who lived for 20 years in a four-unit walk-up near Symphony Hall in Boston, said his landlord had tried to raise his rent in one shot to $1,500 a month from $802 a month.
But Mr. Westhassel, a secretary at Boston University law school, had saved to buy a house. He has bought one for about $150,000 in Medford, six miles north of Boston. "I'm enthused and frightened at the same time," he said. "But my mortgage payments are $60 less than my old rent and I have two-and-a-half to three times the space."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
'Take Our Daughters'? Always Have

BYLINE: By VERNON McCLEAN; Vernon McClean is professor of African-American studies at William Paterson College.

DATELINE: WAYNE

 BODY:
IN the Virgin Islands, my mother worked as a maid for Mr. Sebastian, the European proprietor of a white-owned store on Main Street. As a small boy, I'd come to work with her each day; I remember that she once slapped my face after I'd used his bathroom. (I later understood that I shouldn't have flushed: water was scarce on the island. But how was I to know? We blacks didn't have indoor plumbing at all.)
I think about Mr. Sebastian's house whenever I think about Take Our Daughters to Work Day, which is to be observed on Thursday. This is the fourth such observance; the day was started in 1993 by the Ms. Foundation for Women as a way for girls aged 9 to 15 to see what goes on in the working world. 
 But black women have always taken their children to work. Of course, the lessons we learned going to work with our mothers were not necessarily the lessons white feminists might have wanted us to learn. As a young boy, I learned that white people are powerful: they can make you abuse your children. I also learned that we were poor -- which is why my mother, and like so many other black mothers, took her children to work. She had no day care, so she had no choice.
Which is not to say that I never learned anything of value. Another memory is that of my mother baking bread in Mr. Sebastian's oven. Through observation and with her guidance, I too learned how to bake bread. I helped her make the beds and wash the floor in Mr. Sebastian's home, so she could get home early. Decades before the word "sexism" was coined, she was a pioneer in non-sexist child rearing.
As I had children of my own, I too took them to work -- partly out of economic necessity, partly out of a paternal nurturing instinct. Why should I put my daughter in day care when I could lecture to a class at William Paterson College while she was sleeping in a box in the back of the classroom? And of course, my experience is not unique.
The experience of being with a parent at work, of learning the world of work, is far too important to be confined to a single day a year. That holds true for everyone, black or white or Latino or Asian. But there is a racial dimension to this issue that cannot be ignored, for the overall experience of work depends heavily on whether or not you are black. Consider the following:
* Despite affirmative action, according to a bipartisan Federal commission, white men make up only 29 percent of the work force but hold about 95 percent of all top management positions. The report by the Glass Ceiling Commission cited studies suggesting that "the glass ceiling exists because of the perception of many white males that as a group they are losing -- losing the corporate game, losing control and losing opportunity."
* While an increasing number of white women have joined the work force in the past decade, the percentage who do so out of economic necessity is still far lower than the percentage for minority women. Whereas white women's income may be supplemental, black women's income is required to maintain middle-income status.
 * Finally, far too many black workers, and especially women, are confined to a sort of glass cellar. At William Paterson, for example, black women are still disproportionately represented among those cleaning the bathrooms. While the 325-member faculty has only 8 black women, the janitorial staff has many times that number.
As a whole, our parents -- too many of them -- still work in white people's homes, taking care of your daughters. Our daughters do not want to go to work in your home. They want other options. Black people want jobs for themselves and their mates. We want an education, and an end to race discrimination. We want programs of value to accomplish these aims, not one day a year exhorting us to "take our daughters to work."

HEADLINE: Economics of Caring for the Aged

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
CLORINDA MORELLI turned 106 last week, celebrating the occasion quietly with her 80-year-old daughter, friends at the nursing home where she resides and, if not as many candles on the cake as years, then at least memories of a life well lived.
The secret to her longevity: "Hard work and a happy-go-lucky attitude," said Mrs. Morelli, who traveled by ship from Milan, Italy, to America when she was 19 to marry her boyfriend, Luigi. Later she worked in a dress factory, raised three children and only moved to the county-run nursing home, the Ruth Taylor Geriatric and Rehabilitation Institute in Valhalla, when her daughter grew too old to care for her. 
 But as unusual as passing the 100-year mark might seem, it is rapidly losing its special meaning, according to the United States Census Bureau. By the year 2050, projections indicate that there will be 834,000 Americans who are at least 100 years old compared with 36,000 in 1990.
In Westchester, Mrs. Morelli is a member of the fastest-growing population group -- the elderly over the age of 85. In 1990, there were 13,794 people in the county in that age category; by 2020, that number is expected to double, according to projections from the county's Planning Department. The over-65 population in general is also expected to grow, from 829,946 or about 14 percent of the county's population in 1990 to a projected 839,618 or 17 percent by 2020.
With those kinds of demographics at work, new industries are rushing to tap what is considered an under-served population. Elder law specialists, health care professionals, continuing care housing developers and geriatricians report that Westchester's increasingly well-heeled and politically empowered senior citizenry represents a lucrative market.
"Clearly, the elderly are a resource to be tapped, an industry if you will," said Valerie Hail, an elder care specialist who also is the host of radio and cable television programs for the elderly.
Ms. Hail counsels the elderly and their adult children on Medicare and other insurance issues, prescription drug programs, financial matters and long-term care problems. Her radio program on WVIP-AM (1310) and her television program, each of which are heard four times a week, often feature older people who are "getting advanced degrees, starting new businesses, becoming authors or even falling in love," she said.
"Sixty-five doesn't just mean retiring and gardening anymore, especially when you may be looking at a good 20 or 30 years still to come," Ms. Hail said.
With new longevity projections in hand, developers of retirement communities are eager to tap the growing senior market, especially since New York recently eased its regulations governing continuing-care housing. At the same time, many older citizens are willing to roll over equity from their single-family residences to housing that will allow them to live independently at first and offer them assisted living and even nursing home care if the need arises.
"All of the elements are coming together," said Phillip M. Anderson, vice president of development and acquisition for Classic Residence by Hyatt, which is planning to build the state's first life-care community in New Rochelle.
"The demographics are right," Mr. Anderson said. "Westchester has the upscale buyers, and we have the upscale product. It's an underserved population."
The Chicago-based company, a branch of the Hyatt Corporation, hopes to build one- and two-bedroom cooperative apartments selling for $200,000 to $600,000 at the 17-acre New Rochelle site and at another undisclosed Westchester spot, he said. The developments would also include health care centers for assisted living and skilled nursing services.
Monthly maintenance fees of about $1,900 would cover meals, activities, operating costs, assisted living and nursing services and taxes, among other things. The company has built similar communities in West Hartford, Conn., Naples, Fla., and Monterey, Calif. It has also built upscale rental units in Teaneck, N.J., Chevy Chase, Md., Dallas and Reno and, in Florida, in Naples, Pompano and Hollywood.
In Rye, Mark R. Zwerger, chief executive officer of the Osborn, a retirement community, said the 56-acre campus there is undergoing a $70 million expansion, adding a four-story, 54-unit apartment building, 13 two-family houses and an 84-bed nursing home. There is already a waiting list for the expanded services, which will be available later this year.
Mr. Zwerger said that in addition to the recent changes in state law, which had previously banned life care communities, real estate prices in the county for commercial property have dropped, making continuing care developments more lucrative for builders.
Also, he said that fewer retirees are moving to southern locations and that many are instead choosing to remain close to part-time work options in the Northeast or families and community amenities.
"All preconceived notions of what one typically does in his or her 70's and 80's are changing," Mr. Zwerger said.
Apartments at the Osborn will also require a deposit of $200,000 and up, plus maintenance fees. At both the Hyatt and Osborn projects, deposits are refunded when the owner either moves out or when he or she dies, in which case the deposit goes to the estate.
A less expensive retirement community of 1,500 units in Greenburgh is being proposed by Senior Campus Living, a Baltimore developer. That project would require a deposit of about $170,000 and a monthly maintenance fee of $1,200.
Ms. Carpenter, at the county's Office for the Aging, said that although many of Westchester's elderly residents are wealthy, there are those who are "cash rich with houses, but they don't have $2,000 a month."
She continued: "There are lots of seniors with equity in their homes but no real income. There's definitely a market for them, too."
Meanwhile, lawyers and doctors are also profiting from the demographics. Janet K. Schloat, executive director of Legal Awareness of Westchester, a nonprofit White Plains organization, said that just a decade ago most elder law was concerned with trusts and estates.
"Now lawyers are helping clients understand nursing-care issues, how to pay for long-term care and how to plan ahead. Increasingly, they're very busy," she said.
Steven Shurkman, a White Plains lawyer specializing in elder law, said his clients are concerned about asset protection, long-term health care costs and insurance options.
"Even the wealthy are worried about how to pay for these things," he said. "As people live longer, their need for long-term care is also likely to increase. There is a great concern about preparing ahead."
Geriatricians, too, are seeing growing practices because the elderly are living longer. Dr. Thomas J. Kalchthaler, director of Geriatric Services, a Yonkers-based private medical practice, said more effective treatments for hypertension, diabetes and heart disease along with healthier life styles, which include proper diet and exercise and the absence of cigarette smoking, were beginning to pay off.
Dr. Jeffrey E. Escher, who is also with that practice, said that as many of his older patients live longer and healthier lives, they are also growing impatient with the stereotyping of older citizens. "They refuse to be talked down to anymore," he said.
Ruth Inabu Fox, who is on the national board of the Gray Panthers and a member of the Westchester chapter, said her group was fighting against "three 'isms' -- racism, ageism and sexism."
"We're concerned about social security, Medicare, housing for the elderly and a host of other issues," she said. "But most of all, we want an end to the stereotypes."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2048 words

HEADLINE: Route 6 Uproar In the Quiet Corner

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM

 BODY:
DEAD corn stalks poke out from a farmer's field along the roadside, under the flickering embers of a late afternoon sun. The rolling landscape of Coventry seems to stretch on forever, and the sight of angular clapboard homes spread far apart among the hillocks suggests a Connecticut before the age of the automobile, perhaps even rail.
To enter Coventry is to understand why the northeastern part of the state is called the Quiet Corner. In Coventry, as in many towns in Tolland and Windham counties, development has been slow. Many say business has atrophied in recent years, to the point where the main city in the region, Windham, has wilted under high unemployment and a depleted tax base. 
 Yet in Coventry, there are many who are comfortable with the community the way it is, like Tracy Enders, who moved to the town from the Washington, D.C. area. "There are people out here trying to raise families, concerned about the quality of life," she said. "We accept that you have to go a little slower out here. We accept that it takes a little longer to get to the grocery store, or 25 to 30 minutes to get to the mall."
Michael Williams, another Coventry resident, interrupted: "Or getting stuck behind a farmer's tractor."
Ms. Enders nodded. "You laugh about it and go on," she said. "It's not like D.C., where you have stop-and-go traffic outside your driveway for 10 to 15 minutes." That could change, they argue, if the state is allowed to build a four-lane expressway across their town (37.3 square miles in size). Since Coventry is only a dozen or so miles from Hartford, Ms. Enders and others say such a highway would likely be the last straw for a town already vulnerable to what they call "urban sprawl."
The controversy has plagued Connecticut for more than a generation.
It is known as the "Route 6" issue, not only for the highway that would be built (designs for which have been in a constant state of flux for years) but also for the two-lane highway that is presently in operation.
The existing Route 6, with only one lane going in each direction from Bolton Notch to the Columbia-Windham border, is viewed by the State Department of Transportation and many area residents as unable to handle demand -- from the tide of commuters shuttling between Hartford and northeastern Connecticut and those who use Route 6 as a link between Interstate 84 and Providence, R.I. Driveways and access roads to some 200 homes line the 11-mile stretch, and tend to disrupt the flow of traffic. So too can a car being driven at the posted speed limit, which may find itself the lead vehicle of a very cranky motorcade.
But inconvenience is not the reason the thin ribbon of road earned the monicker "Suicide 6," or was named one of the nation's most dangerous highways last year by Reader's Digest magazine. According to D.O.T. figures, there have been 37 fatal automobile accidents on the road since 1974, many involving head-on collisions.
D.O.T. staffers argue that their newest expressway design, called Alternative 54 or Manny, would improve safety and decrease demand along existing Route 6 by rerouting through traffic, which constitutes half the road's current capacity. But no action is expected, at least not for a while.
The Transportation Department has yet to submit a formal request to build Manny, originally one of three alternatives. (Remember the Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe and Joe -- who helped when the car went on the fritz?) The Army Corps of Engineers says Manny would cause immense ecological harm to the region, in particular to the Hop River and Nathan Hale State Forest, and has indicated it would not approve Manny. That has been seconded by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
While the dispute is commonly portrayed as one between state and Federal government, there is likewise a wide divergence of view on the issue within the region most affected. Pamela Z. Sawyer, a State Representative from Bolton, is one of the leading voices for Manny, even though the current design would come within an eighth of a mile of her own home. Her stand has not made her especially popular with some neighbors, she admitted.
But she cites safety and business needs. "I don't think you can separate those two when you look at the one word: Future," Ms. Sawyer said. "This community is going to have to grow, and we have to look at a long-range plan to satisfy the needs of Connecticut." She noted that Route 6, according to D.O.T. estimates, handles 12,000 to 18,000 vehicles a day.
A planner with the Transportation Department, J. Mark Foran, said Manny would significantly decrease the number of trucks and other through-traffic vehicles by providing a quicker alternate route. "In general, traffic along Route 6 would drop," he said. "It would rise as the area became suburbanized, but not as high as it is now for the next 20 years."
Mr. Foran's superior, the department's policy and planning chief, Richard Martinez, points to an impressive list of supporters for the Manny plan, including the State Department of Environmental Protection, the State Historical Commission and three of the four towns in the Manny corridor: Bolton, Andover and Columbia. All three towns showed majorities in favor of Manny in public polls taken last summer, as high as 91 percent in Colombia.
In addition, Connecticut's national delegation has come out in support of the plan. In late February, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Representatives Sam Gejdenson and Barbara B. Kennelly met with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency Administrator, Carol M. Browner, for an hour to discuss Route 6. An aide to Ms. Kennelly, Robert J. Croce, said the object "was to impress on the E.P.A. the severity of the Route 6 issue."
In the other corner have been a variety of environmental interest groups, led by the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. Donald S. Strait, the organization's executive director, complained that the D.O.T. has continued to press for similar highway plans despite earlier denials at the federal level.
"We don't feel Conn D.O.T. has taken any kind of serious look at alternatives that can improve safety and efficiency without incurring tremendous loss," he said.
Coventry has also been a significant bastion of opposition to Manny. One reason is obvious to anyone looking at a map: For more than half of Manny's 11.2-mile length, the new highway would snake across two separate sections of the town (crossing a corner of Andover in between).
There is another aspect, opponents say. "We are at a point in time where we need to get away from the malignant kinds of development highways spawn, and think about clean air and the resurgence of local communities," said Bruce Bellm, a Mansfield representative to the Windham Regional Planning Agency. "Hartford's air quality is bad for a reason," he said. "We don't want that reason to come up here."
One of the centers of gravity for the anti-highway movement has been Matthew O'Brien, a member of the Coventry City Council.
Mr. O'Brien said that if Route 6 had been upgraded, and "they had put in a raised median and left-hand turn lanes, they would have eliminated more than 70 percent of the fatalities, just like that."
"It's all within their right of way," he said, "they don't even have to widen to four lanes."
Mr. O'Brien disputes several D.O.T. statistics, including the agency's assertion that half the vehicles traveling Route 6 are through traffic. He also said that the biggest single reason for Route 6's dangerous reputation is driving habits. "People drive like maniacs here," he said.
But he and his supporters view the D.O.T. as the big villain. "People are dying on this highway, no question about it," Ms. Enders said. "And the state D.O.T. has realized if they keep those people dying, that's their ticket to building a highway."
Comments like these leave D.O.T. staffers like Mr. Foran shaking their heads. They also anger highway supporters who live within the Route 6 corridor, and who argue that most highway opponents are little more than speculators who took advantage of falling real estate prices when the exact positioning of a new highway was still in flux.
"The main movers and shakers in Coventry are those that live right along the corridor, that have moved there since 1988," Ms. Sawyer said. "And a couple of them are out of work."
Others characterize the highway opponents as obstreperous if not menacing.
"There's no compromise," said Rose Fowler, a former Coventry First Selectman who argues there are many like her who support a highway but are afraid to declare themselves. "This small group, whose homes are going to be taken away," if a highway is built, "they are vicious, they are cruel." "They are the type of people who stand up at a meeting and say it doesn't matter if lives are lost, we have to save the lizards."
She recalled a meeting held in Coventry in January of 1995, one that highway opponents point to as a sign of their strength because no one there spoke in favor of a highway. Ms. Fowler agreed this was so. "I walked out of that meeting, and felt like I didn't belong," Ms. Fowler said. "It was like if I had spoken, I would have been physically attacked."
Mr. O'Brien called the charges of land speculation "nonsense," saying that many of those in Coventry opposing the highway have lived there for generations.
Some supporters say a four-lane highway would actually protect the suburban character of the corridor, which would not have any interchange with the highway, by diverting through traffic. Mr. Foran points to Route 154 along the Connecticut River, which, since being replaced by Route 9 as the major connector between Hartford and Interstate 95, has become more rural in character.
Adella Urban, Columbia's First Selectman, said the only feasible alternative, widening existing Route 6 by two lanes, would be worse.
"If everybody bucked a road like we have here, we'd have an ox-and-cart transit network," she said.
Ms. Sawyer didn't dispute the idea that a highway would open up area farmland to development, but added that the rural character of northeastern Connecticut would disappear regardless of Manny's fate. "The farmers there are older than 35," she said. "There are not the 20-year-old farmers coming up." In Bolton, she noted, there were four dairy farms six months ago, and only two as of last February.
Last year was the year Route 6 went national, after it was profiled by Reader's Digest and on television programs like "Inside Edition." Yet in other respects it was not a good year for highway supporters.
When Edith Prague of Columbia ran for a State Senate seat in 1994, one of her campaign planks was to support Manny, Alternate 54. That changed after she attended the Coventry meeting.
"It was the first time in my political career that I said I'd do one thing and did another," she said. "My job is to represent the people in my district. The people in Andover and Columbia love 54, because it doesn't do anything to them. But the people in Coventry are so opposed. My job is to represent all the people in my district."
Another blow came with the election of Ed Turn as Andover's First Selectman. Despite the fact Andover residents came out strongly in favor of Alternative 54, they nevertheless elected Mr. Turn, who not only opposes a highway but also helped found the main opposition group, Citizens for a Sensible Six. The vote was a close one, however.
Douglas Thompson, a wetlands ecologist with the E.P.A.'s regional office in Boston, calls the proposed highway "one of the most damaging projects in terms of the wetlands" in the northeastern United States in the past decade. Even though that impact would be substantially less than an earlier D.O.T. plan, he said, it was still too much.
For the moment, the epicenter of the debate seems to have shifted to Washington, D.C., where both sides appear content to let the issue play itself out.
Dianne Grenier, one highway supporter from Andover, jokes that after a generation of squabbling and considering alternate highway plans, both sides may be suffering from battle fatigue.
"There's nothing left for us to do," she said. "They know how we feel. It's time for them to take charge."

HEADLINE: Federal Budget Knife May Cut Aquaculture

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
A FEDERAL aquaculture laboratory that helped make Connecticut a leading producer of oysters -- and is poised to revive the state's scallop industry -- may be eliminated in the 1996-97 Federal budget.
The National Marine Fisheries Service's laboratory in Milford could be eliminated or have at least 50 percent of its $2 million budget cut, said Scott Kovarovics, an aide to Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat. 
 In the 1970's a survey by laboratory scientists determined that less than 1 percent of the state's historically most productive beds were still capable of producing oysters. But the lab's scientists helped develop advanced methods of cultivating local stocks, making harvests possible again. Currently the state produces nearly 850,000 bushels of oysters each year with a wholesale value of about $40 million. (Connecticut is the second-largest producer of oysters in the United States, after Louisiana.)
The laboratory was vital in this effort and it is definitely needed to re-establish the state's scallop industry, said Dr. Richard Cooper, director of the Marine Science and Technology Center of the University of Connecticut. One of the center's first projects is to re-establish a Connecticut scallop industry in cooperation with the laboratory. According to Federal fishery reports, the last commercial harvest of scallops occurred in 1965 when 12,000 pounds were harvested in Stonington and Niantic waters. Since then, the state's mute swan population has exploded, and they have decimated the eel grass needed by juvenile scallops.
Currently three UConn employees are working at the Milford laboratory, said Dr. Cooper. The intent of the cooperative venture is to develop a sort of cookbook or manual that will allow state residents and private businesses to cultivate marketable scallops indoors, in nets, or specially designed docks that could also be used by marinas.
The Milford laboratory is developing strains of phytoplankton to feed the scallops that would accelerate their growth and increase their scallops' market value, and could be provided to local producers at low cost. The laboratory is also developing strains of scallops that could be profitably produced indoors or in state waters. If a commercial scallop industry is developed, the state's waters could be restocked and recreational scalloping could become an important part of the state's tourism industry, said Dr. Cooper.
But if the laboratory is eliminated, or if its budget is suddenly cut in half, the revival of the scallop industry will have been made impossible, Dr. Cooper said. Though it may be possible to find private support to replace the Federal funding, that takes time, he said.
Aquaculture has a new importance because of the collapse of vital commercial fisheries, said Dr. Anthony Calabrese, officer in charge of the Milford laboratory. Although aquaculture will never replace the ocean's natural fishery resources, the development of aquaculture will give fisheries the opportunity to recover from overfishing, he said.
The laboratory is also trying to develop aquaculture techniques for tautog, commonly known as black fish.
In Connecticut, "aquaculture is the fastest growing and the second largest segment of our agricultural industry," wrote Representative Rosa DeLauro, a Democrat of New Haven, in a February letter to other members of Congress urging them to restore $1.25 million to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's aquaculture budget.
"In these tough economic times," she wrote, "Congress must support cost-effective methods to strengthen the aquaculture industry on which so many jobs in coastal areas depend."
The cut in aquaculture funding is being proposed by House Republicans, who had sought the elimination of the Department of Commerce in earlier budget proposals. The Milford laboratory is part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which in turn is an agency of the Department of Commerce.
President Clinton has proposed increasing the Commerce Department's aquaculture funding, said John Klein, an aide to Representative DeLauro.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

THE AGE OF EXTREMES: A History of the World, 1914-1991
By Eric Hobsbawm. Vintage, $16.
The author views the past through a Marxist lens, analyzing events in terms of their economic and social consequences. Highly critical of unfettered capitalism, he sees it as an extreme with as much destructive potential as the former Soviet system. Last year our reviewer, Stanley Hoffmann, called the book "a bracing and magisterial work from a rich and acerbic mind."
 
LADDER OF YEARS
By Anne Tyler. Fawcett Columbine, $12. 
 Delia Grinstead, dutiful daughter, wife and mother, does the unexpected: at age 40, she walks away from the beach and keeps going. Disappearing from her family during a vacation, she takes on the identity of a single, unencumbered woman. But in Anne Tyler's 13th novel, Delia discovers that a new life can become as messy and imperfect as the old one. "So measured and delicate is each observation . . . so astute and open the language, that the reader can . . . experience the work as something real and natural -- even inevitable," Cathleen Schine wrote here last year.
 
THE MONKEY WARS
By Deborah Blum. Oxford University, $14.95.
How ethical is it to experiment -- often painfully -- on primates who are genetically so close to our own species? This book examines the benefits (health advances like the polio vaccine) and the costs (cruel proofs of self-evident theories). The author "is a terrific reporter. . . . And she is scrupulously fair," Douglas H. Chadwick said in the Book Review in 1994.
 
THE WINSHAW LEGACY: Or What a Carve Up!
By Jonathan Coe. Vintage International, $14.
The scene is Margaret Thatcher's England, where Michael Owen, a young writer, has been asked to write a history of the Winshaws, whose riches and morals go back to the slave trade. The result "is a big, raucous and exhilarating novel," Michiko Kakutani wrote in The New York Times last year.
 
HARLEM: THE MAKING OF A GHETTO.
Negro New York, 1890-1930
By Gilbert Osofsky. Elephant/Ivan R. Dee, $14.95.
Now restored to print, this social history traces the evolution of a neighborhood from a well-built suburban enclave to a downtrodden area inhabited largely by the poor and black. When it was first published in 1966, our reviewer, Richard J. Whalen, called it "a pioneering scholarly achievement." Another facet of urban racial history emerges in THE BLACK CHURCHES OF BROOKLYN, by Clarence Taylor (Columbia University, $16.50). The author analyzes the role of the church, from storefront congregations to major institutions. This is "a fine overview of a too-long-neglected chapter in New York history," Hanna Rubin said here last year.
 
Entertaining Angels
By Marita van der Vyver.
Translated by Catherine Knox. Plume, $10.95.
Griet Swart, a South African writer and editor of fairy tales, seeks a happy ending for her own life after she loses her baby and her husband. "It's hard to resist a novel with a heroine who is as good company as Griet is," Jacqueline Carey wrote in these pages in 1995.
 
THE PRAIRIE KEEPERS: Secrets of the Grasslands
By Marcy Houle. Addison-Wesley, $11.
When the author was a graduate student, she investigated the Zumwalt Prairie in northeastern Oregon, home both to ranchers and to remarkably large populations of hawks. Her exploration is "a lively record of the delicate ways humans alter seemingly untouched ground," the Book Review said last year. Birds of prey are also the subject of THE GOSHAWK, by T. H. White (Wilder Places/ Lyons & Burford, $14.95), restored to print after many years. The book chronicles the ambivalent relationship between White, author of "The Once and Future King," and the hawk he trained. Their battle of wills "gives the book its peculiar charm," H. M. Robinson wrote in The New York Times in 1952.
 
SEDUCTION THEORY
By Thomas Beller. Warner, $11.99.
Growing up male is the theme of these short stories, many of which feature the same hero, Alex Fader, who learns about women first from his mother, then from lovers. His portrait "is graced by elegant turns of phrase, a fresh way with metaphor and real insight," Eils Lotozo said in the Book Review last year.
 
MATRON OF HONOR
By Sallie Bingham. Zoland Books, $10.95.
Marriage is an escape leading to a trap for two very different sisters in the 1970's. The rebellious older one has already acknowledged her mistake; the younger, meeker one is about to commit hers. This novel is a "sensitive evocation of life in a troubled upper-class Southern family," Polly Morrice wrote here last year.
 
VANISHING ACT
By Thomas Perry. Ivy, $5.99.
Jane Whitefield is a Seneca Indian guide -- not for tourists, but for people who need to disappear. A kind of one-woman witness protection program, she takes on the troubling case of a former policeman. Thomas Perry "keeps pulling fresh ideas and original characters out of thin air," Marilyn Stasio wrote in these pages in 1995. Laurel Graeber
