HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Drugstores;
The Rite Aid Chain Takes Manhattan, the Bronx . . .

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
WALK past the Rite Aid drugstore at 84th Street and Lexington Avenue, turn east on 86th Street, and there it is, another Rite Aid. Walk east one more block, Rite Aid again.
Look across the street from the Duane Reade drugstore at Third Avenue and 53d Street, and voila, a Rite Aid. Don't bother looking for the Pathmark drugstore that sat at 70th Street and Amsterdam for decades. It's a Rite Aid now. 
 Lately it feels as though one cannot walk more than a few blocks in Manhattan without running into a Rite Aid drugstore. No matter that a competitor is next door; if the spot looks good, Rite Aid grabs it. No matter that residents are loyal to a local pharmacy; Rite Aid buys the business, closes the store, and hires the pharmacist.
It is the same story in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. And, if the Federal Trade Commission is unsuccessful in its attempt to stop Rite Aid from buying Revco, a huge drug chain with many stores in Staten Island, Rite Aid could become ubiquitous there, too.
"We want to own New York City," said Gary B. Lowitt, Rite Aid's local director of real estate. "We want to be in the South Bronx and the Upper East Side, in the East Village as well as Brooklyn Heights."
Not everyone is sure that is such a great idea.
"Manhattan, with its traffic and high rents, is hostile to chain retailing, and an aggressive acquisition policy is always risky," said Gary Vineberg, a drug industry analyst with Merrill Lynch who has been recommending that investors sell the stock.
Martin Grass, Rite Aid's chairman, thinks otherwise. He figures Rite Aid's large stores -- its prototype is about 10,000 square feet -- cannot help but be profitable in New York.
"Most of New York's drugstores are 4,000 square feet tops," he said. "They are inefficient stores with small selections and little buying power, and we can easily compete."
For landlords, Rite Aid's new fascination with New York is excellent news. The huge Camp Hill, Pa.-based chain -- 2,759 stores, with nearly 500 more planned for this year -- has a solid credit rating, something that any landlord who lived through the recession has learned to value.
"We've had landlords ask specifically, 'Can you get them in my building?' " said William Ilaria, a retail services director at the Lansco brokerage.
"Owners want Rite Aid on the lease, even if they have to chip in to build the store," said Robert Futterman, a senior managing director at the Garrick-Aug brokerage.
Moreover, brokers say that while Rite Aid drives a hard bargain, it fights fair.
"They won't agree to high annual rent bumps, and they'll insist on lots of renewal options," said Michael N. Hirschfeld, who heads his own brokerage. "But they make deals quickly and they don't make the landlord take really hard hits on rent."
They are not nearly so gentle with competitors, though.
Cory Zelnik, CVS/Pharmacy's New York real estate representative, says CVS is "going full throttle in Queens," where it has eight stores, but Rite Aid's onslaught is making it rethink its strategy in Manhattan, where CVS has only two stores.
"It's tough to penetrate a market when another chain has so much share," he said.
Indeed, Rite Aid, barely a presence in this city a few years ago, now has 94 New York City stores, 26 of them in Manhattan. It has 46 more on the drawing boards, 6 slated for Manhattan, and Mr. Grass expects to "pick up a few more in the course of the year." Why? "When it comes to drugstore chains, New York is one of the most underserved cities there is," he said.
Actually, with Duane Reade, McKay drugs and other chains expanding, that seems less true than ever before. So why is Rite Aid pushing into New York now?
A lot has to do with the changes Mr. Grass has instituted since he took over the chairmanship from his father, Alex, in 1994. The senior Mr. Grass took Rite Aid into such disparate areas as dry cleaning, books and auto parts; his son has divested those businesses and can now pay full attention to the core drugstore operations.
He has given the managers of the pharmacies and of the sundries sections of the stores incentives to cooperate with each other. And he has spent millions on technology to streamline inventory procedures and prescription records. All have increased Rite Aid's per-store profits.
M EANWHILE, opportunities elsewhere have dwindled. Kmart, Wal-Mart and many other anchor tenants at malls now operate pharmacies, making it hard for a new drugstore to compete. And new mall construction is at a virtual standstill.
To Rite Aid, then, New York City is like the final frontier.
"Long Island is a great market, too, but it already has about 125 Genovese stores and close to 100 CVS's," Mr. Lowitt said. "New York City is wide open."
Duane Reade, with its more than 60 New York stores, might dispute that, but Rite Aid seems to view that ubiquitous chain as little more than an irritant.
"Their stores are cramped and badly stocked, their people are not helpful, and no one expects them to be around much longer," Mr. Lowitt said.
Barry Weston, Duane Reade's new chief executive, did not return several calls. Brokers say the chain, gasping under heavy debts from a leveraged buyout a few years ago, has been shopping itself around, but its huge debt load is a deal-breaker.
"Sure, we'd like to buy them, anyone with half a brain would, but the numbers just don't make sense," Mr. Lowitt said.
Mr. Lowitt does not brush CVS off quite so cavalierly. The two chains have gone head to head across the country, and there is no clear winner yet. "We've turned down sites in Westchester because they were across the street from CVS," Mr. Lowitt said. It was probably a wise decision: CVS and Rite Aid are on opposite corners at 24th Street and Eighth Avenue, and they seem to be battling to a draw. "We're both doing well, but neither one of us is doing very well," Mr. Lowitt said. (Mr. Zelnick of CVS insists his store is doing just fine.)
Nor is that Rite Aid's only problematic store. Last year Rite Aid bought 30 Pathmark drugstores, 24 of them in New York. It also purchased 20 supermarket sites from the Red Apple Group, which also owns Gristede's and Sloan's.
Rite Aid has had to acquire some dross with the gold. The 70th Street Pathmark, for example, is only about 3,000 square feet and sorely in need of renovation, not exactly the image Rite Aid wishes to project to the dense Lincoln Square market. Rite Aid does plan to move the store to bigger quarters, but cannot chance shutting it down in the interim, lest its pharmacy customers get used to going elsewhere.
The company also would not have chosen to open three Rite Aids so close by in the East 80's; one had been a Rite Aid for many years, one was a Pathmark that came with the package, and the third was a former Gristede's that Rite Aid did not want to chance a competitor grabbing.
Rite Aid's acquisition binge also brought it to towns outside New York City that kept the welcome mat firmly rolled up. Chappaqua, for example, already had three local pharmacies and a longstanding belief that any chain store would violate its small-town flavor, so town officials hated the idea of a drugstore opening in its former Gristede's.
"The town feared it would turn into a hangout for kids, and they worried that, if they let one chain in, how far behind could a McDonald's be?" said Richard Seligman, an Edward S. Gordon senior managing director who lives in Chappaqua.
Rite Aid opened last fall, anyway. Its store stays open much later than the two other pharmacies (Rite Aid hired the third store owner as its own pharmacist), it offers home delivery and Sunday hours, and it has put in what has become a very popular postal and parcel service counter.
"It's turned into a wonderful amenity for the town," Mr. Seligman said.
A N impending space crunch in New York City may yet force Rite Aid to look favorably at more such suburban towns. Rite Aid has yet to find suitable space on Fordham Road in the Bronx, or on main shopping streets in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Manhattan is filling up quickly, too.
"I'm not going aggressively after drugstore tenants because most of my buildings already have them," said Rob Nager, director of retail leasing at Colliers-ABR and the leasing agent for several office buildings.
But until the space is really gone, Rite Aid will probably continue leasing every good New York spot it can. After all, every spot it grabs is one that CVS cannot get. And the more stores any one chain has in an area, the easier it can justify its advertising costs.
Rite Aid insists that, while it does not discount the threat of eventual oversaturation of drug stores, that is of less concern in New York than anywhere else.
"Anyplace else you have to do demographic studies to see if the population can support a store," Mr. Lowitt said. "Here, we do demographic reports just for the fun of it. We know the people are there."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
For West New York, a $650 Million Hudson Enclave

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK

 BODY:
EXCEPT for a golf driving range, West New York's nearly mile-long Hudson River waterfront remains the industrial wasteland left behind when shipping and rail operations there ceased more than 20 years ago. But that may soon change.
At a news conference last Wednesday Roseland Property Company of Roseland, which six months ago acquired the 150-acre site owned by Arthur E. Imperatore that comprises most of West New York's waterfront, unveiled a $650 million plan for a waterside enclave of 4,080 market-rate for-sale and rental units linked to this square-mile Hudson County town of 39,000 atop the Palisades. 
 Mr. Imperatore still owns 204 adjacent acres in Weehawken, the base for his ferry service to Manhattan.
The West New York project, for which Roseland was designated the redeveloper Wednesday night by the town, is to have an 80,000-square-foot retail complex as well as recreational and open space, including a public riverfront walkway required by state law.
Under the plan, which awaits approvals, the property will be developed over the next 10 years. Roseland will divide the site into parcels, building on some itself and selling others to developers. The proceeds of the property sales will help finance more than $10 million in infrastructure improvements such as roads and water and sewage connections, said Marshall B. Tycher, a Roseland principal.
He said three neighborhoods, with a total of 1,075 units, could be started by early next year. Roseland, in a joint venture with the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark, will build 275 apartments to rent for $1,300 to $2,000 a month.
A second neighborhood of 250 town houses priced in the high $100,000 to $200,000 range will be built by K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest developer. And the Related Companies of Manhattan, known for its apartment buildings, will construct 550 rental apartments, for which rents have not yet been set. Both are under contract to buy parcels, contingent upon approvals.
"This site represents both a tremendous task and an opportunity," said Mr. Tycher. Its redevelopment, he added, comes at a time when the state's entire 18 miles of Hudson River shoreline "is resurrecting itself."
More than 1,500 mostly rental units are underway or planned on Jersey City's riverfront and Hoboken has a plan in place for the city-owned portion of its waterfront that calls for up to 2.3 million square feet of commercial, housing, open and recreational space.
By the year 2005 it is estimated that some 10,968 housing units, including those in West New York, and 17.3 million square feet of office space are to be built on the Hudson County riverfront, according to the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City.
This summer work is to start on the first half of a 20.5 mile light-rail system that will run from Bayonne to Ridgefield. The first segment, Bayonne to Hoboken, is to be completed in 1999, the remainder by 2005.
This is sweet news for West New York, which missed out on the mid-80's building boom. Mayor Albio Sires said that he was eager to get his town, among the state's poorest and most densely populated, the tax revenue and jobs it badly needs.
Like others who grew up here, Mayor Sires, who emigrated with his family from Cuba 34 years ago, remembers the old waterfront and how he played on the tracks. He also recalls wondering then about the site's future and, later, watching grand development plans abandoned, including one to turn the riverfront of West New York and neighboring Weehawken into a Venice on the Hudson. So he made riverfront development a campaign promise that helped bring him into office 10 months ago.
"We are determined to rebuild the waterfront," Mr. Sires said. While skepticism persists, he added, many residents feel "a sound, well-planned project would be a shot in the arm."
Industry analysts say the team assembled for the project is aggressive and financially strong enough to get it done. The plan, they add, is also more realistic than earlier proposals.
"It is another signal that the grandiose plans of the last decade will not be realized," said James W. Hughes dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
S INCE 1980 the West New York land and the adjacent property in Weehawken had been owned by Mr. Imperatore, whose Port Imperial vision of a Venetian-style city was never realized. Also unrealized was his plan for 5,800 units on the West New York site. Though he received approval for some 2,500 units after years of debate over height and density issues, the project was defeated by the recession and financial problems that led to the threat of foreclosure. Only the golf driving range was built -- to generate cash, not as part of the project -- before Roseland bought the site.
The deal lifted the threat of foreclosure against Mr. Imperatore by the Crossland Federal Saving Bank, which held a $50 million loan on the West New York site as well as 62 acres in Weehawken. Roseland paid in the low $20 million range for the loan, said Mr. Tycher.
Mr. Imperatore retains the Weehawken land, which adjoins the 142 other acres he owns there where he runs a marina, restaurant and ferry service. The ferry service, which is to be improved, is considered a criticial amenity for the waterfront.
New York Waterway, the Imperatore ferry company, recently received $6.1 million in Federal loan guarantees for a new ferry and to refinance four existing ones, freeing up capital to expand services. It also got a $1 million loan to begin work on a new terminal, to be completed in three years, that will be linked to the light rail line.
Now, said Mayor Sires, "a window of opportunity exists" to develop West New York's riverfront. Still, the details of the plan must be hammered out and its impact must be analyzed, he said.
Some important first steps have been taken. For one, the town agreed to slash in half the property's $50 million assessment, ending a tax appeal by Roseland that was originally filed by Mr. Imperatore. West New York also put an ordinance in place exempting any new rental construction from rent control. Both were crucial in moving the plan forward, said Mr. Tycher of Roseland.
In addition, the town adopted a riverfront redevelopment plan this month "giving it more control over the development process," said David Spatz, West New York's planning consultant.
Though the site's zoning allows 5,800 units, Mayor Sires said the 4,080 proposed by Roseland "is more manageable." The zoning also requires that the heights of buildings to be at least 10 feet below the top of the Palisades, and that 30 percent of the land be kept as recreational or open space.
Such requirements, along with the walkway, Mr. Sires said, will help join the new waterfront to the rest of the town, a concern for West New York where the cliffs separate it from the river. And discussions are under way with Roseland to carve a public pathway from the cliffs to the waterfront below, he added.
Public access is also key to the Hudson River Waterfront Conservancy, a nonprofit riverwalk watchdog group. "To work, the walkway must be designed so public and private interests don't clash and the housing is not a gated compound cut off from the town," said Leah Healy, a board member, referring to riverfront projects that went up in the last decade.
The current waterfront plan may face opposition. But Mr. Spatz said the upside of the years of debate over the earlier plan is that the public's input has been included.
Mr. Tycher said the plan, designed by the Martin Organization of Phildelphia, meets the zoning and is "sensitive to the environment." By reducing the density by 30 percent and including more low- and mid-rise buildings, he said, the height and density issues have also been addressed.
Mayor Sires said he is optimistic that when all the reviews are done West New York will have a plan that works. "For the waterfront is where the town's future lies," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Housing and retail developments, left, are to be built over next 10 years. (Tanya Auselrod); Development will include rentals, right. (The Martin Architectural Group)

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2402 words

HEADLINE: Another Harvest: One Farm, One Life

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: MAHWAH

 BODY:
"SHE'S coming back?" said Brian Goode, executive sous-chef of Union Square Cafe in Manhattan. "That's good news for us. Last year she was saying: 'This is it. I'm selling the farm. I'm retiring.' "
This weekend, if all goes well, Alvina Frey will pull out of Chad's Farm here before dawn, drive through the Lincoln Tunnel to her spot across from Nobody Beats the Wiz at Union Square and unpack her first load of the year: geraniums, delphiniums, basil, small boxes of Kentucky bluegrass. There she and her sister, Elsie Wickenheisser, will hail customers new and old, distribute biscuits to their dogs (many by name) and sell their wares. It's greenmarket season again. From now until October, every Wednesday and Saturday, Mrs. Frey will bring her fruits, vegetables, herbs and flowers to the people in the city. 
 The city people, including chefs like Mr. Goode, will crowd her booth. They will run their fingers through her trays of yellow and fava and lima beans. They will squeeze the tomatoes and pinch the gooseberries and stick their fingernails into the baby zucchini skin. They will paw the French beans one by one, measuring them, before selecting six. And, as the summer progresses, some will exchange names with Mrs. Frey, confiding their problems while they buy her beans. By the end of each market day, every bean and berry in the bushel baskets will be gone, as thoroughly as if set upon by locusts.
Alvina Frey is 65. She has been farming in Bergen County since she was 5. She has farmed seriously, for a living, since she graduated from high school. She farms the land her parents, and their parents, farmed before her. Long ago, she was one of many farmers in Mahwah and Bergen County. Now she is one of the last.
Most people would find that growing vegetables the way she does, vegetables that several Manhattan chefs call exquisite, is simply too much work for too little money. Those who would be willing to live the life of a small farmer -- and certainly there are some who would gladly trade an office job for the all-encompassing labor and beauty of farming -- can't afford the land.
New Jersey farmland is worth a fraction of open property with development rights. The only way to own a small farm is to inherit it, the privilege of very few. The average age of New Jersey farmers is 54, and increasing at each count.
In addition to houses, highways and supermarkets, New Jersey residents have long been emphatic about wanting farms, woods and open spaces.
They overwhelmingly approve referendums for farmland preservation and "green acres" -- public money for open spaces. But economics is rapidly, inexorably pushing most of New Jersey's open land into development.
Across the road from Alvina Frey's 20-acre farm is a development called Paddington Square, consisting of hundreds of identical cream-colored town houses with garages and driveways. Down the way is Route 17 with its malls, car dealers, diners and fast-food restaurants. Look out from Chad's Farm and you can practically see the condos, service stations and golden arches moving closer.
For several summers, Mrs. Frey has talked of quitting, of selling the land and retiring. This time, she may do it. This week she let a real estate agent sink a "for sale" sign in front of her farm.
She's definitely ambivalent, testing the idea. "I don't want it to be sold," she said. "I want it to go when I want to go." But if she gets a high enough offer, she'll sell. And as for what she'll do afterward? She is quiet for a moment. Then she gives a reply of sorts: "Once the farm is gone, that's it."
AROUND the turn of the century, Alvina Frey's grandparents, who immigrated from Germany, bought 150 acres of farmland. Her father fixed looms for extra cash, but the family's heart was in the farm, where they grew vegetables and had apple, cherry, peach and pear trees.
"My grandmother worked until she was almost 91," Mrs. Frey said. "Outside! In strawberries!"
Her father eventually took over the farm, selling tomatoes, corn, cauliflower, and raspberries wholesale at the Paterson market. Alvina, the eldest child, "was the designated farmer," said Mrs. Wickenheisser, the youngest, who as a child was so unenthusiastic about farming that she'd weed with her toes. "My brother I guess wasn't too crazy about it either," she said.
As a girl, Mrs. Frey never had the luxury of determining how enthusiastic she was about farming. Growing up, her days consisted of farming and school, farming and Friday night piano lessons, farming and farming.
"I never went to the church picnic," she said. "I never had too many friends. Father didn't give us a life after farming."
A skilled classical pianist, Alvina found a job after high school graduation playing music at a restaurant. Her father balked -- he needed her on the farm. From that, her life's course emerged. "When I found out this is what I had to do, this is what I did," she said. She and her husband, Anthony Chadorowski, named the property Chad's Farm.
They grew fruits and vegetables, selling them at the Paterson market and at the farm's roadside stand. Year after year they got by. But as taxes and other expenses rose, and the Paterson market and road stand became more unprofitable, getting by got harder. They sold one piece of land, and then another, to pay taxes.
Mrs. Frey's farm would have been single-family houses years ago, if not for two unrelated occurrences.
The first was farmland assessment, which New Jersey established in 1964. It is a program that lowers the taxes of working farms by as much as 80 percent over developed property.
The other was New York City's Greenmarket. Mrs. Frey's second husband, Ed Frey -- whom she married after Mr. Chadorowski died of a heart attack -- heard about Greenmarket in 1976, at its inception. He was buying potatoes in upstate New York when another farmer told him about it: city people, it seemed, were thronging to the new 59th Street market and paying high retail prices.
"I don't care what you brought down, they bought it," Mrs. Frey said. "From that market each person found their own niche, what they should grow."
For Mrs. Frey, it was beans -- all varieties of beans. "I kind of like beans," she said, in a profound understatement. And she'd tried some of the other farmers' beans. "Like eating wood. They had a string on them. I knew I could do better."
Five years ago when Mr. Frey died, Alvina Frey went on alone. By then, she had sold about 120 acres of Chad's Farm. But the 20 remaining acres were enough. These acres she plowed, sowed, watered, weeded, harvested. April to October, twice a week, she trucked her produce into the city to sell. With her beans, heirloom eggplant, silver corn, she enriches the lives of both city dwellers and her own, by her friendships with them, urban people whose daily lives diverge radically from her own in Mahwah.
OVER the past 20 years at the Union Square Greenmarket, Alvina Frey has met many people of the city. To her stand have come the famous or nearly so: Sigourney Weaver; Claudia Schiffer; Geoffrey Beene; Claus von Bulow, Sarah Jessica Parker, Cicely Tyson; the man who does Ivana Trump's hair; the maid on "As the World Turns," and "what's her name, Woody's girlfriend." Mrs. Wickenheisser wanted to take pictures, but Ms. Frey stopped her. "That's a no-no," Mrs. Frey said. "They come with their anonymity. They want to be left alone to shop."
She has had at her stand "bums, panhandlers." And "older gay men and gay couples -- I hate to say how many I've lost. AIDS."
And there is the usual crew of urban eccentrics, like the man with the "itty-bitty mustache who only buys eight beans, one cucumber, three little zucchini," and the man "who goes through all the trays of yellow beans, every one, and says, 'I have to be certain.' " Some customers bring her fancy French pastries; others drop by to say hello even if they're not shopping.
She yells at people who manhandle the tomatoes or break the beans. She once shook a broom at a homeless man who refused to let her set up. When people complain that her beans are $1.40 a pound, while the ones down the way are $1, she snaps, "You want dollar beans, go buy dollar beans." But when somebody confides he's out of work, Mrs. Frey stuffs an extra handful of beans into the bag. She has visited her regular customers in the hospital. She has attended their dance concerts.
Mostly, she knows faces, not names. Before she knows the humans, she knows their dogs. She recognizes the owner of Flora-Dora, "a fancy poodle," because the mistress resembles her pet.
"It's very interesting, the city," Mrs. Frey said.
Many shoppers might recognize a truly fresh vegetable. But it's the professionals, the chefs, who understand the degrees of freshness and superiority, and who appreciate and honor the labor involved in growing, say, crisp, needle-thin French beans. It is they who grasp for words to convey the essence of a Frey bean.
"Her limas are sort of unique," said Mr. Goode of Union Square Cafe. "Her tiny French beans are really, really good -- the best. She does only a limited amount. They're consistent, beautiful to look at. They look like they're alive, like they just got picked out of the earth."
Peter Hoffman, owner and chef of the Savoy restaurant in SoHo, calls her beans "fabulous."
"She's extremely meticulous about proper beans -- what's overgrown and not acceptable," he said. "She goes picking through the vines over and over again. She wants a baby zucchini 3 1/2 to 4 inches. No monsters. They're tender, delicious. Her lima beans, very few people in Greenmarket grow -- they're thorny things, a labor of love.
"She grows things nobody else wants to grow because they're a pain," he said. "Black currants. Gooseberries. She showed me her arms, all scratched and scabbed from picking, and said: 'I've had it. I'm not picking any more gooseberries.' The next week she shows up with another couple bushels and says, 'They just looked good; I thought people would want them.' Her eggplant is an heirloom. Her husband got it from some guy in South Jersey 20 years ago. It's white eggplant -- incredible flavor, no bitterness.
"It's like she aspires to some Platonic ideal of what is right," he said. "Like she wants to do justice by the plants and her customers."
EARLY mornings, across the street at Paddington Square, car after car pulls out, heading for offices. School buses collect children. It's the usual daily routine of suburbia.
But shoulder-to-shoulder as she is with the suburbs, Mrs. Frey follows much older rural rhythms, the rhythms of the farm.
The work varies according to the season. Summer -- sowing, weeding, picking. Fall -- harvest, cleaning, stowing equipment. Winter -- planning, and maybe selling Christmas trees and fruitcakes. Spring -- plowing and sowing.
Mrs. Frey no longer does her own plowing. But she drives one of her three tractors -- one is 25 years old, the others 50 -- to disk the fields, making them "nice and smooth, cutting them all up." She drives another to mark the rows to be planted. She sows some seeds by tractor but most -- including corn and beans -- she sows by hand. She grows flowers with cuttings, but vegetables from seeds always. Her father once planted what he thought were beefsteak tomato cuttings and got plum tomatoes.
"We learned a lesson," she said. "Never trust it if you don't grow it yourself."
She drives the third tractor to cultivate and fertilize.
April to May, she said, "I go gung-ho." She plants beans every two weeks through August. Beans take 50 days to mature, except limas, which take 80. One bean plant will yield three or four batches. It is a point of pride that she picks her beans every other day, except the French beans, which she picks every day. Lesser farmers would pick a few times a week, which would result in bigger, woodier beans.
Her flowers, including the 1,200 blossom-covered "short and squatty" geraniums, are a profitable sideline. She grows them in her three plastic-covered greenhouses. When the plastic tears, she climbs a ladder and stuffs the hole with rags.
Her methods of farming are similarly low-tech. She exhibits a sense of propriety in the fruits, vegetables and flowers she grows. Her opinions on them are definite and unwavering.
She hates fancy-colored bell peppers. She thinks the Blue Lake beans everybody thinks are so wonderful are anything but. She knows people loved her pimentos and cried when she cut them off, but too bad -- they were too much work. She knows the Chad's Farm soil is bad for potatoes and onions. As for carrots, her grandmother tried them long ago; they tasted like soap.
They are the opinions of one who knows farming, every detail.
Along with her dislikes, Mrs. Frey reserves the right to complain. "One thing I know is this year I won't make any money. I know I won't make money. I know."
She has also, lately, reserved the right to have fun, doing things far removed from farming. She's gone on cruises to Mexico. She's tried para-sailing, which involved running along the beach, strapped to a parachute, until a boat lifted her and she flew over the water. She's in the altar guild at Christ Lutheran Church, caring for the linens and wine, and has taken flying lessons.
Chad's Farm should go for at least $1 million, said Frank Pelz, her brother, who takes care of the accounting. "She's 65 and she's got to consider slowing down," he said. "She gets nervous farming, nervous that she can't get the work done. It would be the end of an era. I'm sure she hates to see it. I hate to see it, too. Because when it's over, it'll be done, disappear, up in this area with all the building going on."
Mrs. Frey refuses to be sentimental. "I don't want to change my life style, not until I can't do it," she said. "But I can't do anything about it. Progress is progress, as my grandmother used to say."
Others, however, will supply the sentiment she's not expressing, and then some.
"I don't like to think of Alvina retiring," said Joel Patraker, a Greenmarket manager who, whenever he can spare the time Saturday mornings, calms himself by pitching in at her stand and weighing beans. "It makes me heartsick. Let's be honest. Alvina could retire if she sold that land; then she wouldn't have to do all that work. I know she complains. But I think she loves it."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1220 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
FUNDS WATCH

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:

Advisers Play Bigger Roles
Individuals are ceding more control of their fund investments to independent financial advisers. 
 The amount of mutual fund assets controlled by advisers has increased sixfold since 1992, to $45 billion at the end of last year, according to a report by Lipper Analytical Services, the fund tracking firm in Summit, N.J., and Cerulli Associates, a financial services consulting firm in Boston. That amounts to about 2 percent of the more than $2 trillion in all stock and bond funds.
These gains are particularly significant because growth in funds in general has slowed outside the retirement market, according to the report, which projected that advisers would oversee $180 billion by the turn of the century.
The report was based on filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, data from industry groups and interviews with more than 500 of the estimated 12,000 investment advisory firms.
What services do advisers provide? Often they justify their fees, which tend to be about 1 percent a year of the assets they manage, by ferreting out high-performing funds with a low profile. They also screen out funds that stray from their stated styles and approaches.
Financial advisers keep a sharp eye on fund expenses, and roughly 20 percent of them said they would not offer funds that carried an annual 12b-1 marketing fee. The Cerulli-Lipper study also found that their loyalty to fund groups was continuing to erode because tracking the performance of individual fund managers had become simpler and less expensive.
But returns are not the only consideration. Financial advisers are increasingly concerned about how managers are investing their money. Advisers with at least $50 million under management typically examine how big a stake a manager has in his own fund, the quality of analysis at the fund company and the number of administrative distractions.
 
When Is 3% Not Really 3%?
Do investors in a fund with a 3 percent sales charge pay only 3 percent? Not really, writes a reader in Arlington, Va. The way he sees it, the load should be figured on the net investment, not on the gross amount of the check.
Say you buy $10,000 worth of shares in a fund with an upfront sales charge -- a "load" in industry parlance -- of 5 percent. Under the usual calculation, your sales charge is considered to be $500. But that's more than 5 percent of the $9,500 that will be invested in fund shares. Looked at that way, the sales charge would be 5.3 percent ($500 divided by $9,500).
The Securities and Exchange Commission says both methods are valid. The gross method is used consistently throughout the industry, making comparisons meaningful, and it has the advantage of simplicity. Other industries use it, too; real estate commissions on property sales, for example, are calculated in this way.
The S.E.C. requires both calculations, the gross and the net percentage, in fund prospectuses for funds whose sales charges have "break points," or investment levels at which commissions are reduced.
Another reader, in Ohio, professes to be confused about sales charges in general. Often, the charge is described as the payment for the services of a broker or financial planner, she says. But she buys her funds -- with or without loads -- without any help, so why do some levy sales charges and some not?
Back when the mutual fund industry was small and simple, funds were sold with a sales charge -- usually 5 percent to 8 percent of the amount invested -- that represented a payment to a financial intermediary. Others were sold directly to consumers, without a charge. Now the line between loads and no-loads has become blurred, especially by "low-load" funds, those with sales charges of up to 3 percent.
Low-load funds are usually sold directly to investors by fund companies that also sell no-load funds. Fidelity Investments, the country's largest fund company, is one example. At such companies, the sales charge generally is used to cover the firm's marketing expenses, like customer service and toll-free telephone numbers.
 
Cautionary Tone From Vanguard
Henry Kaufman, an economist and money manager, is said to have joked that his colleagues had predicted 10 of the last 3 recessions. John C. Bogle of the Vanguard Group is starting to sound a bit like them.
Mr. Bogle, Vanguard's chairman, warned investors about a year ago that good times in the stock market wouldn't last forever. Though the good times have kept rolling so far, he is reinforcing that message.
His cautionary note is part of the 1995 annual report for the Vanguard Index Trust 500 and is being sent separately to prospective investors in the fund. About 80,000 shareholders received the letter in mid-April.
Extraordinary performance and huge cash inflows prompted the additional warning. The letter notes that the Index Trust 500 gained 37.4 percent last year, outpacing 85 percent of actively managed mutual funds. It would not be realistic to expect such returns more than once a decade, Mr. Bogle warned.
The secret of the fund's success has been the surge in the large-capitalization stocks in the index it tracks, the Standard & Poor's 500. When small-capitalization stocks become market leaders, the fund will probably underperform the average equity fund, which tends to own smaller stocks, on average, than those in the S.& P. 500.
 
New Managers
Peter Anderson, senior vice president for investments at IDS Mutual Funds, leads the group that took over IDS Managed Retirement from Richard Lazarchic, who picked up IDS Global Growth from Edward Korff. Mr. Korff left the firm.
Ben Hock, formerly an equity analyst, took the reins of the John Hancock Growth and Income fund from Brian Grove and B. J. Willingham, who left the firm. Bernice Behar, leader of the management team in charge of the John Hancock Growth, Discovery and Global Marketplace funds, picks up Emerging Growth from Edgar Larsen, who also left the firm.
 
Wired for Data
Thornburg Funds has an Internet site (http://www.thornburg.com) to let investors retrieve investment guides, prospectuses and data on specific funds without having to provide personal information.
T. Rowe Price Associates has begun offering mutual funds and investment information on America Online (keyword: T. Rowe Price). On the site are prospectuses, daily fund prices, performance information, market updates and more.
 
In Brief
Scudder Global Small Company has been renamed Scudder Discovery. It also said the median market capitalization of the stocks in its portfolio would be $750 million .
Fidelity Investments has teamed up with the United States Chamber of Commerce to offer retirement plans designed for member companies with fewer than 100 workers.
Templeton Global Utilities has been merged into Franklin Global Utilities, and a 1 percent redemption fee will apply to old Templeton shareholders for six months after the merger, effective March 29.
Oppenheimer Enterprise has closed to new investors, but shareholders in accounts opened before April 1 can continue to contribute up to $5,000 a month.
 In addition, T. Rowe Price Investment Services is making available free educational brochures, covering stocks, bonds, options and margin and short selling (800 225-5132).

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Jim Gainey's Step Up

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
JAMES GAINEY will talk your ear off, and the point is he knows a thing or two. He has sat in the cab of an 18-wheeler on a rainy night thinking mainly about a cup of coffee 50 miles down the road, but also musing about why black people have had to put up with so much in this 220-year-old country. He has been in homeless shelters so bad he suspects prisons must be better. He has learned enough to reduce the lessons of a hard life to aphorisms, ones that rattle around in your mind for awhile.
"You got to be a poor rat to have only one hole," he said. "A good rat, he got at least two holes." 
 So it is that at 5 each morning the 40ish Mr. Gainey wakes up in a Bowery flophouse, says his prayers, drinks a glass of water, maybe takes a shower and does some push-ups. He then walks across town to the Carmine Street Recreation Center to put on a crisp khaki security guard's uniform and get down to business, the daily task of building a new life.
Opportunity has not been a regular knocker at Mr. Gainey's door, but he is now scrambling to create opportunities for himself, which, he will gladly tell you, are better than none. His vehicle is a City Parks Department program for the most motivated of welfare workers, a program involving training and the promise of a shot at a job.
And the plain fact is that as a single person on welfare, he has no choice but to work for the city for 22 hours a week. "If you don't show up, you're on the street," he said. "And it's scary to be out on the street."
So here's the deal: As a participant in the Park Career Training Program, or Pact -- to which he was recommended for his eagerness to collect garbage -- he gets the chance to work half again as much as other welfare workers, 35 hours a week at his security guard job. The pay is no more than if he worked the shorter period: a total of $352 a month in home relief, plus $112 in food stamps and Medicaid.
But he also gets job training, coaching on how to write resumes and interview for jobs and information about job openings.
"All I've ever known is struggle," Mr. Gainey said. But that does not mean he cannot hope, and he now feels somebody just might care about his future. "I have no doubt in my mind that this is going to work," he said.
It is already working for the city. The workfare army of 19,000 people, sweeping streets, cleaning parks and scrubbing government buildings, has taken the edge off municipal layoffs. Some 90 percent of city parks are now considered clean, the Parks Department says, up from 76 percent a year earlier, an improvement officials credit mainly to the welfare workers.
And the 500 who volunteered and were then selected for Pact fill a particularly acute need, specialized labor. Half the 4,000 workers in the Parks Department have left since 1990 through layoffs and attrition, and the raw recruits of welfare contribute mainly by doing basic maintenance. Welfare's elite in the Pact program do everything from horticulture to computer chores.
Mr. Gainey works as a security guard at the rec center in Greenwich Village. His journey began in South Carolina. As he tells it, his family came north when he was very young and settled in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The boy played in fire hydrants on summer days. He remembers hitching rides by holding on for dear life to the back of a bus. He remembers the Myrtle Street elevated.
His dad, an auto mechanic, moved the family to New Jersey where work was more plentiful. Near the end of his senior year at Irvington Technical High School, the family needed money, so he quit school to get a job pumping gas. He wanted to make sure his two younger sisters finished high school -- they did. He could always go back.
OF course, he never did. There were four years in the Army. There were jobs as a mechanic, as a welder, as a driver of big trucks. There was somehow never time to start a family. The lack of a diploma hurt more and more in hiring halls. "I'd be walking out and everyone else was still sitting there," he said. "That makes you feel bad, I mean bad."
The longer out of high school, the tougher the high school equivalency classes he would periodically take. Then six years ago came the blow that sent him on his downward spiral. He got a series of traffic tickets and lost his commercial driver's license. The recession was deepening, and jobs were scarce. Unemployment ran out, he went on welfare and found himself bouncing between some of the city's ugliest shelters. He said he never took solace in alcohol or drugs. Miraculously, he found his way to the shelter run by Volunteers of America on Ward's Island, and finally glimpsed daylight.
A counselor there guided him to a G.E.D. course, where he finished high school, and then to a nurse's assistant course. He was sure he was on his way after he was accepted by New York City Technical College to study to be a registered nurse.
His plans then collapsed. First, he could not find a job as a nurse's assistant: Welfare mothers were getting first shot at home care and city hospitals were not hiring. His college plans were squashed when the city ordered him to go to work if he wanted to keep getting his welfare check.
So he found himself in a park holding a broom. He immediately volunteered for the most disgusting job, working on a garbage truck. His supervisor was Harold Vanderbeck and nobody had ever asked to work on the truck before. And Mr. Gainey worked hard. So Mr. Vanderbeck recommended him for Pact. "He's the type of person who deserves a real shot," Mr. Vanderbeck said.
Mr. Gainey volunteered to be a security guard, sensing a kind of security in wearing a uniform as he did years ago in the Army. His approach is one of meticulous detail. He checks the temperature of the pool just in case people ask on the way in; he makes sure the computer room stays locked until the teacher comes in. And sometimes he takes broader responsibility, as when he visited the nearby police station to ask if a beat cop could include the recreation center on the rounds. One now comes regularly.
Is a life being put back together? Mr. Gainey regained his commercial driver's license and has gotten state certification as a security guard through the Pact program. He has begun to go on job interviews. He has somebody to give him a recommendation. On his own, he has learned to type and has managed to keep up his $150 annual malpractice insurance should he ever find employment as a nurse's assistant.
"I got choices now," said a man who believes one rat hole is never enough.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Throwing Some Cold Water on Lottery Fever

BYLINE: By BRETT BRUNE 

 BODY:
TALES of desperation involving people addicted to gambling are nothing new; stories of broken homes and beleaguered bank accounts have inspired more than one movie maker. But now state-run lotteries are feeling the heat. With their new Quick Draw keno games in bars and delis, the states are turning ordinary people who never get near a casino into the addicted, Money magazine says in its May issue.
Lotteries, often chastised as preying on the poor, don't take a spare dollar a week just from those who can least spare it. They also take money from young professionals who might do better by putting it in their 401(k) plans or elsewhere. 
 "I know I'm probably going to lose," a 29-year-old electrical engineer says of his attraction to Quick Draw, "but I keep playing because I might just get lucky."
And the human cost is not the only downside to the lottery business, Money reports. It contends that even the taxpayers who do not play the games are being duped. That is because the game playing may amount to just that when it comes to state budgets.
Money says its six-month investigation shows that "the lotteries have neither lowered taxes" for residents of the states that offer them, "nor boosted funding for education, as their champions have often promised."
Lotteries are not an efficient way to raise public money, the magazine concludes. It says that states keep just 34.4 percent of the proceeds, on average.
Money lists New Jersey and New York as the most efficient states (each keeping 41.1 percent of the revenue) and Idaho as the least efficient (21.1 percent).
Which states directed the most lottery money to education in 1994? Idaho and Kansas, at 66 percent each. And the least? Massachusetts and New Hampshire, at 20.6 percent each.
Gary Landry, a spokesman for the Florida Education Association, calls the lottery "a big shell game." He says Florida's lottery money goes into the general budget, where its use is difficult to track. As rising school enrollments put new demands on schools, "the state has simply replaced general revenues with lottery money," he says.
 
SCROOGE EXTRAORDINAIRE Most everyone knows a modern-day Scrooge, a model of emotional bankruptcy. But it is hard to believe that any have an edge on J. Orville Wood, profiled in the May issue of Worth magazine.
When Mr. Wood died in 1985 at the age of 102, fewer than a dozen people attended his funeral. Even his two children were absent. Little wonder: The child who speaks openly for the magazine article, Roger, recounts how his father, who died with $1.1 million in investments, had instructed him to use only two squares of toilet paper during each trip to the toilet, forced him to wash in his sister's bath water and refused to contribute any money toward his college education.
The article, titled "The Master Passion," is more about a son's painful quest to understand his father than it is about the miser himself. Its worthwhile message: Children of misers can develop healthy relationships with other people, as well as with money.
J. Orville Wood left the bulk of his money to the University of Pittsburgh, for which he had expressed no real affection. (He left his third and last wife, Ruth, just $20,000 a year, to be forfeited if she remarried. He left Roger $2,000 a year, to begin after Ruth's death.)
His second wife and Roger's mother, Helen, once gave the miser a copy of "A Christmas Carol," hoping that he would change his ways. In return, she got a divorce.
To find some peace of mind, Roger has visited his father's haunts and spoken to his stepmother about the ordeal.
Roger, now 75, seems to have conquered the past. He sees his three children nearly every week and leads what appears to be a contented life with his wife, Phyllis. He says he has to fight certain stingy instincts, but when his first grandchild was born a few months ago, he took the opportunity to leave a legacy much different from his father's. He wrote a check for $5,000 for the child's education fund.
 
BABIES AND BILLS Listing all the expenses of having a child can be as difficult as counting the number of times a parent says no to a 2-year-old. But two of the larger possible costs -- conceiving a baby when you have a fertility problem and finding child care -- are addressed in separate articles in the May issue of Kiplinger's.
"The Agonizing Price of Infertility" lays out the problems and solutions for those who want a child no matter the price. Kiplinger's reminds readers that it is common for infertile couples "to spend $30,000 or more in their quest for a child."
One woman describes how she worked the system rather than letting it work her. When her doctor would not refer her to an infertility specialist -- called a reproductive endocrinologist -- she called the specialist's office, asked which doctors in her health maintenance organization had made referrals and then switched to one of those doctors. When her insurance coverage for the fertility procedure ran out, she switched to another health plan offered by her employer to obtain coverage for additional attempts. Although she did not conceive, she saved a great deal of money and is now planning to adopt.
The magazine says other useful tools are medical spending accounts that allow employees to pay their expenses with pretax dollars, prescriptions that can be filled for far less cost in Mexico or other countries, and partial-refund plans from fertility clinics for failed efforts.
For general information, Kiplinger's recommends an infertility support group called Resolve (617 623-0744) and the International Council on Infertility Information Dissemination, which can be found on the World Wide Web at http://www.inciid.org/.
Finally, with babe in arms, parents may need to look for child care -- in some cases so they can return to work to pay those bills for infertility treatments.
In "Finding the Right Caregiver," Kiplinger's says time-pressed parents can hire a private investigator to check relevant public records. Though it may sound extravagant, it can be done for less than $100 and can save many headaches, the magazine says.
Graham/Sheehan Security Services of Brighton, Mass., for example, takes cases across the country and charges $70 for a standard package, "which includes a criminal-records check, credit check, verification of education and professional licenses, a check of all previous employers, driving history and a review of worker's comp claims."
The agency can be reached at (617) 787-2262.
 
QUICK MONEY So you're committed to buying your first home in three years. Now all you have to do is decide how to invest.
 In its May issue, Smart Money offers a rational guide for readers with specific short-term goals, like a house purchase or a luxurious vacation. The article, titled "The Best Short-Term Investments," suggests a mix of Treasury strips that represent the principal-only portion of a bond; fixed-income securities of varying maturities; prime-rate funds backed by bank loans, and mutual funds known to be stable and dependable.
 With a quick worksheet to help readers determine their risk tolerance, the article reassures that there are safe ways to invest for the short term besides certificates of deposit, with their relatively low rates of return.
A second worksheet shows how much a reader needs to save to meet his goal. For something as complex as a home purchase, however, the worksheet comes up a bit short: It shows the probable impact of inflation and your investment choices, but it doesn't take into account the potential for wild swings in the real estate market.
 For the mutual funds portion of the investment mix, Smart Money tries to reduce anxiety about risk by recommending 10 stock and bond funds and, for investors in high tax brackets, eight tax-exempt bond funds.
 Topping the former category is Lindner Dividend, with an average three-year return since inception of 64.8 percent. Its worst performance for any three-year period is a 24 percent gain. On top of the list of tax-exempt funds is Invesco Tax-Free Long-Term with a 37.2 percent average return for three years. Its worst three years: 14.2 percent.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Club's Textbook Case In Playing the Market

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
MOST college seniors take along resumes when they go to job interviews, but Charles Phippen also likes to show potential employers an investment portfolio worth $126,000.
Actually, the portfolio belongs to the student investment club managed by Mr. Phippen and a few dozen classmates at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa. Like a Generation Y version of the Beardstown Ladies, that now-famous Illinois club of small-town, salt-of-the-earth investors, the Lafayette students use their investment skills to buy and sell stocks and bonds for a common fund. 
 Their skills are not inconsiderable. The students can easily offer tips on how to determine a stock's price-to-book value, or how to place a stop-loss order. Any skeptic need only consult the bottom line: The club's fund grew from $103,000 on March 31, 1995, to $126,000 a year later -- a gain of 22 percent. Not bad for neophytes: while the performance was obviously aided by a bull market in stocks, the portfolio still has about a quarter of its assets in bonds and cash.
How did the students do it? Here is an example from Zdenek Hezky, a junior from Ontario studying business and economics. In January, he sat down at his PC and analyzed the average percentage of profits that computer companies were reinvesting in their businesses. The percentage, called a plow-back ratio, was large, and that set Mr. Hezky thinking.
"I just knew that with a plow-back ratio that high, you had an industry that had the potential for more growth," he said. Add the fact that technology stocks were then declining, and he urged members to expand the club's holdings in computer companies.
The club did so, and the move has paid off handsomely. In February, it bought 100 shares in America Online at $45.375 and 200 shares of Dell Computer at $28. At Friday's close, America Online was at $59.50 and Dell, at $41.25.
Campus investment clubs have been around for decades, but they have grown increasingly popular during the market-happy 1990's. There are now at least three dozen clubs, at schools as varied as Bryn Mawr, Brigham Young, U.C.L.A. and the California Institute of Technology, according to Edward C. Lawrence, a professor at the University of Missouri in St. Louis who tracks the organizations. The club at Ohio State University has the biggest fund, about $10 million, Professor Lawrence said.
The clubs are usually financed by alumni or faculty contributions, and about half the clubs are managed by students who are working on master's degrees in business administration. But the Lafayette fund is run by undergraduates who are majoring in a variety of disciplines, and freshmen are included, too. Meetings are usually held once a month; 30 to 50 students typically attend.
"Our club is inclusive and we like to focus on students who may know less about the market," said Donald R. Chambers, a professor of finance at Lafayette and the club's faculty adviser.
The Lafayette fund, which is held in the college's name, is now invested about 75 percent in stocks, 20 percent in bonds and 5 percent in cash. Besides America Online and Dell, its 19 stocks include blue chips like Coca-Cola, Dow Chemical and Ford Motor, and more recent plays like Genentech and LSI Logic. The fund is well diversified; its largest holding, 150 shares of Caterpillar, accounts for less than 9 percent of assets. The club also has shares in the Emerging Tigers Fund, a closed-end mutual fund that focuses on developing markets.
These investments produce about $3,000 a year in tax-free dividends and other income. The students use half that money for club expenses -- to bring prominent speakers to campus, to finance an annual day trip to Wall Street or to provide the pizza for club meetings. The other half is donated to Lafayette. Last year, the money helped buy library books, while part of this year's contribution has enabled prospective students from minority groups to visit the campus.
The club is a long-established feature on campus -- so ingrained that no one is sure how it started. School legend says the fund began around World War II, with a $3,000 contribution possibly made by soldiers bound for war. That theory would explain an early name for the club: the Veterans Investment Research Foundation.
BUT the fund's performance is no mystery and is even more laudable given the wide berth under which most such clubs operate.
"To my knowledge," Professor Lawrence said, "none of the faculty advisers who are involved with funds have overridden an investment decision -- even when they know that a decision isn't in the fund's best interests."
On Monday, Mr. Phippen, the president of the fund, and 13 other club members made the annual trip to Wall Street. After visiting Alan R. Griffith, the vice chairman of the Bank of New York and a Lafayette alumnus, they toured the New York Stock Exchange.
Later, the students, many in blue blazers and khaki pants, laughed and joked their way down the narrow streets around the exchange. They sounded like any other college group on an outing, but ask these investors about their holdings and the talk can turn board-room serious. "Value stocks are important to us, but our major goal is long-term growth," Mr. Phippen said.
Such observations are not just talk. The students do their investing homework: interviewing brokers, reading Value Line, researching investment sites on the World Wide Web and using the analytical software provided in the college's investment course. In 15-minute presentations, members pitch and defend their investment ideas to the rest of the club.
One thing they don't do is hurry.
"At our meetings, we may decide to hold a stock, or buy it later at a lower price, or maybe research it a bit longer," Mr. Phippen said.
Still, the portfolio hasn't exactly been gathering dust in a dormitory closet. This school year, the club has made several major trades besides the purchase of shares in America Online and Dell. In November, for example, the students decided to buy 100 shares of First Brands, the consumer-products company whose lines include Glad plastic bags and STP auto products. The company has enjoyed growing overseas sales, and its shares have risen from the purchase price of $19.125 to $26.75 at Friday's close.
In other years, many club investment decisions have also been on the mark. For example, the students bought 50 shares of I.B.M. at $68 a share in the fall of 1992, when the company was out of favor on Wall Street. Since then, I.B.M. stock has soared; even after falling more than $10 on Wednesday in the face of a company official's concern over future growth, the shares managed to finish the week at $105.25.
Another smart move was the purchase in 1992 of 50 shares in Catalina Marketing, which makes computer scanning systems for grocery coupons issued at the checkout counter. The idea was pitched by two women who weren't that active in the club -- women typically make up only about 10 percent of the membership -- and their approach was different than the club's customary practice.
"Catalina wasn't sold to us on the basis of financial analysis or price-to-earnings ratio," Professor Chambers said. "It was sold as a concept, based on the observations of two people who went to a supermarket and kept their eyes open.
"The rest of the club went along with the students just to be nice," he continued. The courtesy was rewarded. The club bought the stock at $31.25. It closed Friday at $75.50.
Of course, not every deal turns out right. In the spring of 1993, the club's assets were less diversified, with 25 percent in just two companies: Intel and Merck. Concerned that the fund would be hit hard if those stocks fell during the summer, the students placed a stop-loss order on them in June. Such an order authorizes a broker to sell a stock if its price touches a certain floor.
During vacation, the two stocks indeed fell to the stop-loss threshold, and the equities were converted into cash. But the students were a bit too risk-averse: the two stocks rebounded after the sale.
The students also stumbled with International Gaming Technology, a maker of slot machines. The club bought the stock for about $61 a share in February 1993, at the height of excitement over the gambling industry. It sold the 50 shares in December, for just $12 each.
The club faltered, too, in some bond investments, many of which were in term trusts. These trusts, which are bond funds that may contain adjustable-rate mortgages, zero-coupon bonds and other fixed-income instruments, ran into trouble in recent years when interest rates rose.
But the students are not deterred. They are keeping an eye on foreign investments. They are wondering if they should buy shares in Apple Computer, whose cash-flow and product problems have punished its stock price. And they are wondering if they should dump their stock in Kmart, which has been hurt by competition from Wal-Mart Stores and others. The stock, bought at $15 a share in June 1992, closed Friday at $9.875.
As the club looks ahead, Mr. Phippen is also hoping that it yields a really great return: a job. Lately, he said, his interviews have included Lehman Brothers and Citibank.
"I get a lot of interest with the portfolio," he said. "I'd say we spend about 80 percent of the interview time talking about it."
