PUB-DATE: April 21, 1996

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3078 words

HEADLINE: Mitzvah or Mania?;
Party-Hopping at the High End of the Theme Bas and Bar Mitzvah

BYLINE: By LANG PHIPPS 

 BODY:
MARCH 9 is still a hair early for an Oscar party, but on this particular Saturday night it certainly looks like that's what Laura Belle's been done up for. Two giant Oscar cut-outs survey the dance floor like flat, sexless totems, and tropical flowers and trees on the bandstand, the tables, and the bar of this retro-glam supper club on West 43d street, welcome guests in from the cruel cold outside. There's even a replica of those arid Western hills and the famous outsized letters that rise before them, except something's not quite right here: instead of Hollywood, the sign reads, "Mollywood".
Indeed this is not a party to honor Oscar, but a celebration of 13-year-old Molly Lindenbaum's bas mitzvah. On this special night, the joyous end of her daylong initiation into Jewish womanhood, Molly's parents, Herb and Bonnie, have done all they can to make this event unforgettably Molly. 
 The theme is Hollywood because she loves the glamour of the movies. Her film canister-shaped cake is draped with dark chocolate "film," and before it sits a white and dark chocolate "clapper" with "Mollywood" written in as the film title. A table full of Oscar statuettes awaits the family and friends who will come up to toast Molly and pick up their award. On the children's tables, glass jewels are strewn, and there are Mollywood match boxes whose fat matchheads reveal themselves to be mints when viewed from the side.
A booth on the balcony where the children are seated is busy turning out "Mollywood, U.S.A." fake license plates, with pictures of the children's faces laminated inside them. Downstairs, on each of the adult tables, a sign links the table's number to a movie: 1 Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, 2 For The Road, 3 Faces Of Eve, 4 Seasons, 5 Easy Pieces, etc. After dinner, singing waiters descend from the balcony and belt out "Hello Molly" to the little girl who sits in the center of it all.
Not only is this extravaganza all for a 13 year old, but for private school students of a certain social stratum, it is almost commonplace. Two or three times a week, seven months a year, they may find themselves invited to such events. Could this, ladies and gentlemen, be Mitzvah Mania?
The ante for this kind of affair was raised in the 80's when Gerald Guterman, the real estate tycoon who was the controlling partner in a limited partnership that later declared bankruptcy, leased the Queen Elizabeth 2 for his son's bar mitzvah. What we're seeing in the 90's at the high end is a somewhat less extravagant type of party, played out in a prolific variety of themes.
Few families can afford the Cecil B. DeMille approach -- and many who can, don't want it, taking the middle ground in their bas and bar mitzvahs. These also appear to be growing in popularity.
Angie Zablo and her husband, Randy, run New Jersey-based Foremost Caterers, a company that has been providing glatt kosher food to bar and bas mitzvahs in New York, New Jersey, Long Island, and Washington for 46 years. She has seen a 40 percent increase in business in the last eight years, a boost she attributes, in part, to the emergence of bas (for girls, as opposed to bar, for boys) mitzvahs, as women are taking a more significant role in Jewish religion.
Who gets involved in the state-of-the-art New York version of this ancient tradition? Mainly children of privilege who attend Dalton, Riverdale, Horace Mann, and Fieldston. Why now? Largely because all the successful Jewish baby-boomers who deferred marriage and children until later in their careers, now have kids who are coming of age at the same time.
Many of these parents grew up poor or middle-class and would love to give their children the mitzvah party they never had (and a chance at a vicarious second mitzvah for themselves); most are also beginning a commitment to traditional Jewish life, with all the new-found cultural identity and religious fulfillment that can confer.
The bar or bas mitzvah is one of the most important Jewish traditions. In it, the boy or girl turning 13 becomes a full member of the Jewish religion. This is regarded as a good deed, one of God's commandments.
Living in the vibrant midst of it, these seem to be the halcyon days of the Grand Mitzvah Era. But since the Jews came to America, this tradition has transmuted into something purely American.
"What's going on today are variations on a theme," said Jenna Weissman Joselit, author of "The Wonders of America: Reinventing Jewish Culture 1880-1950" (Hill and Wang, 1995). "The fancified bar mitzvah dates back to the 20's, or even earlier. In the 20's, kids got ice sculptures in their image, and in the 40's, bar mitzvah invitations were often elaborately styled after the Torah scroll. Like everything else in America, these parties were oversized, out-of-scale."
Keeping a sense of balance has always been an issue -- even the rabbis of the 1880's groused about the pomp and frivolity of the ur-American bar mitzvahs. Has the grand mitzvah tradition, building up steam over the decades, encouraged unhealthy competition for the most boffo event in our time, leaving the less wealthy feeling inadequate and the honorees with the wrong lessons about values versus consumerism?
Even Marc Lustgarten, vice chairman of Cablevision, and the host of "Jessie On Broadway," (his daughter's bas mitzvah), acknowledges the dangers.
"We baby boomers are prone to excess, and we're high-octane achievers," he said. "Unfortunately, with this level of affluence it's not so much 'We gotta outdo them' as 'We can't look bad next to the Joneses.' When your child is going to 40 or 50 bas mitzvahs a year, would you want your child's to look bad next to the others?"
But, he added: "This is a major milestone, not just a 13-year-old's birthday. After the bas mitzvah, she will have become a full-blown member of the Jewish religion. My wife and I, and Jessie, will look back on this for the rest of our lives. Why not make it as special as you possibly can? And try to bring as much joy as you can to yourself, to your child, and to your friends and relatives?"
How much does one of these momentous events cost? Assuming the head count is 200, the venue alone (food and drink included) could cost $20,000 to $40,000. Decorations, centerpieces, flowers and sundry games will cost from $5,000 to $10,000. The photographer and video team will charge between $3,500 and $7,000. The master of ceremonies, disc jockey and dancers will range from $4,000 to $6,000. The celebration cake is $500 to $700, and the event planner may cost from $2,500 to $7,000. The total costs generally run about $70,000, but $100,000-plus events are not unheard of.
The event planner may not be the costliest component, but it is the most important. Parents like Herb and Bonnie Lindenbaum couldn't create an event like Mollywood by themselves. They need someone who knows the territory, has boundless energy, patience, and imagination, is theatrical, and is Jewish himself. They need, in other words, a Mitzvah Maven. Luckily for the Lindenbaums, Lee Tannen was available.
Mr. Tannen and his partner, Tom Wells, run an event planning and catering company called Showstoppers. Tom, the southern WASP, handles the less antic side of the business -- private events for the likes of David Rockefeller and the Sultan of Brunei.
Mr. Tannen, in the natural declension of things, creates Mitzvah Mania. He grew up Jewish in the Bronx when it still had a thriving diaspora community, and for 15 years he wrote advertisements for clients in the New York theater. His love of flourish and the small effect qualify him as the ideal Mitzvah Maven, because the details are everything at these events.
Extreme care is taken here -- the party must be as perfectly assembled as a Patek Philippe watch, and it must be one of a kind, as singular as the honoree. Planning may begin as far as 24 months in advance. As many as 20 different sites may be considered throughout the city, with parents and children visiting restaurants, hotels, lofts, mansions and even boats.
Nothing is more important than the theme, which derives from the boy or girl. That your theme is fingerprint/snowflake unique can be life or death to these children in the first throes of the adolescent identity crisis. No matter how personalized, the production must never distract the focus from the boy or girl, who is there to bask in the love of family and friends. As Jessie Lustgarten notes, "If someone had a huge bar mitzvah and no one cared about the kid, it wouldn't be fun."
Molly thought Laura Belle was "fabulous" and the night was a success -- "everyone danced" -- but above all, "it was the best party because it was mine."
Almost the only exception to the absolute originality rule -- the common whorl in the uncommon fingerprint -- is Lonnie the hip-hop dancer and all-around mitzvah Pied Piper. Everyone wants Lonnie at their party: he's cool, he's nice, and no one does the electric slide smoother than he. "The kids like me because I love being a kid myself," he says. He's in great demand and a total professional, but he has made a vow never to carry business cards -- too grown up.
Mr. Tannen brought Lonnie into this circuit, as well as M.C. Greg, whose aerobic-class pep and Energizer Bunny tirelessness has whipped up mania at a few parties lately. Mr. Tannen has also hatched "Twins," a joint bar mitzvah for the Cohen twins, and he masterminded "Jessie On Broadway" for the Lustgartens.
"Twins" turned a featureless banquet room at the Princeton Club into a black and white nightclub, complete with a checkerboard dance floor and 3,500 black, white and silver balloons. The tables were decorated with twins themes, like a model of the twin towers, an oversize Doublemint gum pack, an illustration from the Arnold Schwarzenegger movie "Twins." Mr. Tannen scoured the world for twin disc jockeys and somewhere on Long Island, found the "M & M Twins," Marco and Michael Posillico.
Tavern on the Green could not have been improved upon as the venue for "Jessie On Broadway." After all, it was created by one of the original showstoppers, Warner LeRoy. But Mr. Tannen managed to transform the mirrored passageway leading to the party rooms into "Jessie's Alley." Eight-foot theater posters lined the walls on both sides, enveloping the arriving guests with the theme. Inside the glass-covered dining room, Mr. Tannen filled every corner with life-sized billboards of Jessie in full costume standing under the marquees of "Cats," "Les Miserables," "Grease," and "Sunset Boulevard."
Her cake was a rendering of the masks of comedy and tragedy in white and dark chocolate, and guests who came up to make toasts to Jessie were accompanied by the appropriate show tune. "Consider Yourself Part Of The Family" from "Oliver!" played as friends of the family came up; when Marc Lustgarten's boss, Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, arose, "The Company Way," from "How to Succeed In Business Without Really Trying" came on.
The kids drank virgin blender drinks, "mocktails," and made kid-vids at a booth that produced MTV-like music videos. A rich moment was when a brace of mothers, their 13-year-old daughters on the side in hysteria and horror, did a spot-on perfect performance, pouty and wriggly, to "I'm Too Sexy." This was an event where parents and kids partied on equal terms, a common occurrence on the circuit, and a great part of its charm.
In the 20-odd years since Mr. Tannen was bar mitzvah-ed, much has changed. He sees the children much more involved. They spark the parties with their manic energy, and the parents follow. At the first note of music, a sort of line dance-aerobic class begins to the calls of M.C. Greg and the moves of Lonnie. In his day, Mr. Tannen's parents and their friends chose the music -- no M.C. Greg here -- and out of four sets of Sinatra, maybe one set was ceded to the kids' music.
The parents may love these parties, but the grandparents often just don't get it. At every event there's a bank of white-maned men and women who sit silent as stones at their tables, wearing expressions of vague dismay, if they register any reaction at all.
"It's not music, and it's not dancing," groused Molly's grandmother, Rose Ganz, as the hip-hop pounded on and on at Mollywood. "I'm getting a headache here."
She finally did move though, to do a heartbreaking dance, delicate and spare, as "Hava Nagila" played during the hora.
How does hip-hop music, the electric slide, and all the excess of Mitzvah Mania, fit in with the religious tradition of Jewish life?
Rabbi Marc Schneier was a guest on the QE II for the Gutermans' 1986 bar mitzvah. The 80's, Rabbi Schneier remembers, were "too much bar and not enough mitzvah."
Now, he says, the parents have a lot invested in Jewish tradition and continuity. "They send their children to Hebrew school, and sometimes the mitzvah ceremony is held in Israel," he said.
Bonnie Lindenbaum said she saw the bas mitzvah as a continuation of Molly's Hebrew school education. "The party was the joyous culmination of her years of study," she said.
At the Kiddush meal before the party, Rabbi Schneier spoke of Molly's Hebrew name, Malkah, which translates into "queen." Two hours later he stood in Laura Belle as M.C. Greg pumped the air like Arsenio Hall, shouting "Let me hear you say, 'Molly's in the house!' " The two images can coexist, he said, because "That's who Molly is, a New York kid, with all that that means." The sober sustenance of these children's faith is leavened by their being 13 and vibrantly modern.
If anything, they are depressingly grown up. One girl, dressed in a black, spaghetti-strapped number, sunglasses in her "Friends"-style coif, described Laura Belle as "a great space, perfect ab-fab room for a party." She zeroed in on the one-upsmanship that underlies these showy events. "The first thing the women do is pick up a knife to see if it's plated or real silver." One boy, now jaded after two parties a week all winter long, had only this to say: "These things only exist for the caterers."
Rabbi Jeffrey Salkin, author of "Putting God On The Guest List" (Jewish Lights Publishing, 1992), a guide for parents seeking greater spiritual depth in their bar or bas mitzvahs, is more critical of these extravaganzas than Rabbi Schneier.
"Yes, Judaism encourages celebration," he says, "but families have to ask themselves what their values are and whether these type of celebrations, which have been known to bankrupt families with their expense, fit in. I'm all for healthy celebration, but our young people can become numbed by too much materialism."
At "Jessie On Broadway," Marc Lustgarten achieved what Rabbi Salkin has termed "a massive ethical upgrade" by donating a contribution in each of the guests' names to Mazon, a nonprofit organization that provides food for the hungry worldwide.
Do these families really have to worry about overextending themselves? "There's a fine line when these large celebrations mean borrowing, or in some way incurring an economic stretch that affects family life and values," said Mr. Lustgarten. For the well-off, values are an issue, he said. He recalled that Cablevision -- a part owner of Madison Square Garden -- has received calls from people asking to rent Madison Square Garden for a bar mitzvah, or to get Patrick Ewing to come sign autographs.
"One could argue that's over the line," he said, acknowledging that the Knicks dancers have actually been hired for bar mitzvahs in the past.
Elise Kleinberg, one of Molly Lindenbaum's classmates, recalled, "My mother said I'm going to have to elope, my bas mitzvah cost so much."
Despite the downside, the party goes on. Which brings us back to the Mitzvah Maven, busy with his May 4 schedule. That day Lee Tannen will do three parties in 24 hours. The lunch event is a bas mitzvah for a little girl who loves horses and Mr. Tannen is turning the Bryant Park Grill into Churchill Downs for Kentucky Derby day.
From Bryant Park, he is racing up to the Park East Synagogue on Madison Avenue for an afternoon bar mitzvah, and by 8 P.M. he'll be overseeing another one at the Town Club on East 86th Street. By the end of this day of juggling musicians, magicians and florists, the Mitzvah Maven should be so insane, you could well call him the Mitzvah Maniac.
Although he's hardly complaining. "I've got the best job in New York," he says. "Who else my age gets a chance to run around and be a kid again."
 
A Son Recalls the QE2
TEN years ago, Jason Guterman had the most fabulous bar mitzvah, when his father, Gerald, a real estate magnate, took the celebration to another level. He rented out the entire Queen Elizabeth 2 and invited 650 friends and relatives to join two orchestras, a string quartet, as well as clowns, dancers and magicians, on an overnight cruise in New York Harbor. Ivan Boesky landed on deck in a rented helicopter. The event became a symbol of 80's excess.
Looking back, the bar mitzvah boy, Jason Guterman, a 22-year-old junior at U.S.C., says the event "wasn't that big of a deal" to him then. He often attended elaborate social events. He recalls having fun, getting many presents, having his first drink and even gambling in the on-board casino.
But he says he is not an extravagent person and that the event did not mangle his values. In fact, he says, he rarely talks about it. He says he "always wanted to be just like everybody else, longing to live in a cookie-cutter house with neighbors close by.
"I remember my friends making a bigger deal out of it then I ever did and that sort of bothered me," he says. "When you're little you don't want to feel separated from your friends and that separated me."
Jason lived on a 14-acre estate in Bedford Hills, N.Y. The scariest part of the event was singing at the Park East Synagogue on the East Side.
"I felt pretty popular for awhile," he said, "but I was really uncomfortable with all the attention." He admits he did start dating one girl who wasn't interested in him until after the party.
Even the teachers treated him differently. "One English teacher gave out an assignment and in front of the whole class he said that as a present to me, I didn't have to do it," he says.
Soon Jason decided to go to public school. Then, his family moved to Aspen, Colo., where no one knew about the affair. He was happy about that. MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2315 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Nanny-Tax Tally of '95: Who Paid, Who Lied?

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
LAST Monday, a New York City couple met with their accountant to file their 1995 taxes. They had an income of $100,000, a hefty mortgage and a nanny the Internal Revenue Service knew nothing about. And they kept it that way.
When their accountant came to line 53, which for the first time asks about household employment taxes, the couple lied, without hesitation. 
 "I feel terrible about not paying the taxes, really I do," said the wife, an editor at a magazine in New York who agreed to talk only if she was not identified. "I pay our nanny $360 a week, and I know she makes practically nothing for the important work she does. But I can't afford to pay another $2,000 for her taxes. And I understand from my friends that if I pay her Medicare and Social Security taxes, and ask her to pay part of the contribution, she'll hit me up for more money."
For millions of nannies and housekeepers, April 15 was to have been a landmark day this year. If all had gone as planned, many more Americans than ever before would have paid Social Security, unemployment and Medicare contributions for their domestic employees with their Federal income tax returns. Now that the Form 1040 asks point-blank about household employees, people can no longer assert, as they could in the past, that they didn't understand their obligation to pay the tax. And they can be punished for perjury on top of being assessed for back taxes.
 While it will take months for the Internal Revenue Service to determine how many Americans actually paid on behalf of domestic employees, the early evidence suggests that the compliance rate continues to be low. Without conducting an official count of returns, officials at several big accounting firms, like Ernst & Young and Deloitte & Touche, said last week that they saw no significant increase over previous years in the number of clients who paid household employment taxes.
"A lot of people just refuse to pay these taxes," said Merlin Larsen, president of Pacific Benefits, a payroll deduction service based in Salt Lake City. "I've heard that of the 75,000 live-in nannies in the U.S., only 20 percent of their employers pay their household taxes. Most people still pay their nanny in cash on Friday night and let it go at that."
So why should things be any different this year? Advocates in Congress had argued that more people would pay the tax, which provides Social Security and other benefits for domestic workers, if it was simpler to ante up. Until this year, taxpayers had to pay quarterly, an extra burden that helped keep on the sideline about three-quarters of the two million Americans who owe the tax for domestic employees like nannies, gardeners and maids. This year, people were required to pay the tax only once, as part of their Federal income-tax returns.
"We expected a lot more people to pay their household taxes with the new one-payment system," said Marshall Washburn, national director of specialty taxes for the I.R.S. "People have no more excuses not to pay this. If more people don't pay it, then I'm really disappointed. I have a hard time rationalizing that."
Taxpayers, however, tell a different story. Several who balked at paying this year said they were left with little choice. Many who employed illegal aliens as nannies didn't dare risk having them deported. Once employers pay the tax, they must keep doing so in the future or face a higher risk of audit.
And then there was the trouble of actually paying. Despite a simpler Federal system, employers still had to make quarterly payments in most states. And those payments could be hefty. Many household employees -- including nannies and maids -- say they are unable to pay their share, which forces employers bent on compliance to make the entire contribution.
It may turn out that the I.R.S. had its greatest compliance two years ago, after Zoe Baird, President Clinton's first nominee for Attorney General, and several others were exposed for failure to pay household employment taxes. Ms. Baird, whose name still makes many nannies chuckle and many employers wince, was denied the post and asked to cough up $11,000 in back taxes and fines.
Those who had hopes of landing a job in Washington quickly became fervent payers. Leslie and Michael Ray, of Laguna Beach, Calif., voluntarily paid two years of back taxes after Ms. Baird's fall from grace. Mr. Ray, a commercial developer who served as President Clinton's campaign manager in Orange County, had hoped for a political appointment but has yet to receive one.
If the President calls, Mr. Ray is ready. The Rays routinely pay their household employment taxes, even though most of their friends who have live-in help do not.
"What's so aggravating to us is our friends, who are Republicans, go after the children of illegals -- wanting to cut them off from our schools and health care -- but they hired their parents," Mrs. Ray said. "We'll just feel morally superior now because we know they're lying" on their tax returns.
SEVERAL taxpayers who acknowledged that they had lied about household employment taxes this year pleaded special circumstances. The most forceful complaints came from women who had struggled for years to find legal nannies who worked well with their children. Too often, they said, the only way they could find competent child care was to hire illegal aliens. Paying the employment tax, they said, would have tipped off the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which could send the nannies packing.
"People who establish these taxes do not understand how difficult it is to find a legal person to care for your children," a New York doctor said. "Over the years, I've made every human effort to comply with this law, and at times when it came down to having someone good or having someone legal and paying the tax, my children came first. If your nanny can't get a Social Security number, how can you pay the tax?"
While that argument runs rampant among two-income families -- and the I.R.S. points out that it has a procedure for submitting taxes for illegal aliens -- it doesn't sit well at nanny-placement agencies. Officials at those agencies say many employers are out to hire inexperienced women on the cheap instead of hiring experienced nannies through a network of agencies nationwide.
"There are plenty of nannies who are available," said Leslie Weinberg, president of Hand-in-Hand Agency Inc., a child care placement service in New York. "Some of these employers may be out to hire someone cheaply to stay within their budget. A lot of people come to see us that cannot legally work in the U.S., but we don't ever send them out."
People who cannot find an affordable, legal nanny need only to look to Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby. They found one. Despite earning some $160,000 last year, according to their just-released tax return, the Patakis paid their live-in nanny a scant $11,597, or $223 a week, to take care of their four children, who still live at home.
"The Governor gets his nanny through a service and pays them," said a spokeswoman for the Governor. "It's not like the Patakis determine how much their nanny earns."
The notion that finding a legal nanny is difficult also riles the minority of families who do pay the household employment taxes. "It's totally irresponsible not to pay these," said Dee Aldrich, an editor at Conde Nast Traveler, who just paid $2,675 in Federal taxes for her nanny. "What kind of employer would leave the person who takes care of their children totally unprotected? You have to watch out for their interests."
Nannies, however, appear to be split on the tax issue. Like many others who are working legally in the United States, a nanny in Queens has asked her employers to pay their share of her Social Security and Medicare contributions. "I'd be treated like a slave if my employers didn't pay these taxes," said the nanny, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "It makes me happy that I'm eligible for these benefits if I need them."
BUT other women say they are better off pretending that the I.R.S. doesn't exist, because they don't want to pay income tax on their earnings. "I don't want my employer to pay these taxes," said another nanny, a 20-year-old from Poland who works on a student visa. "I can only work 25 hours a week, and if my boss takes money from me for these taxes, I won't make as much."
Competition among nannies to land a job may soon come down to the tax issue. For the first time, situation-wanted ads are flagging when a nanny has a green card or is willing to work on the books in the hope it will be seen as a competitive advantage. "I have no problem having my employer pay the taxes or working without them," said Jenny Peters, a 36-year-old woman from Grenada who is hoping to land a full-time nanny position. "There's incredible competition on the market right now. I have my green card and I lose jobs to a lot of people who can't legally work here. That can be very frustrating."
What riles employers, however, are nannies who are inflexible when it comes to the taxes. Legally, an employer can ask a nanny to pay half of her Medicare and Social Security benefit, which comes down to 7.65 percent of her annual salary. The employer picks up the other half, also 7.65 percent, and the unemployment insurance benefit and sends it to the Federal Government. Often, the nanny objects to having any money deducted from her paycheck, forcing the employer to cough up the entire 15.3 percent.
But that can create additional havoc. "If you decide to pay the nanny's Social Security taxes for them, this additional payment will be deemed taxable compensation," ratcheting up the amounts that are owed, said Alan Goldberg, president of Nanny Tax Inc., a New York payroll tax service. "If she makes $10,000, and the employer pays the nanny's 7.65 contribution, her taxable income becomes $10,765."
Several employers also complained that they were expected to file the nannies' Federal returns for them. "My nanny is very, very good," one publishing executive said. "But not only do I pay the entire 15 percent, she has no idea that this is unusual. I actually thought that she expected not to pay income taxes."
While many people who have nannies and housekeepers opt not to pay any tax, accountants say the main offenders are those with part-time help. Because people pay part-timers so little, they don't believe they owe the tax. They are wrong; the law requires those who pay a domestic worker more than $1,000 a year -- that's $19.24 a week -- to withhold the tax to avoid committing perjury on their tax returns.
"If the person who comes in and cleans your apartment twice a month is self-employed, then you don't owe the tax," said Bob Tighe, an accountant in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. "But chances are that person is just a part-time worker. If you give your maid instructions and she uses your mop and soap, then she is a domestic employee. You owe the tax."
But try to explain that to a taxpayer determined to get a refund. One executive at an Atlanta public relations firm pays her maid $40 a week -- thereby subjecting her to the tax -- but balked at paying up.
"Are you kidding me?" she said. "You think I'm going to pay this to the I.R.S.? Well, let me tell you something. I was in my office yesterday and this auditor from the I.R.S. phoned and said, 'Sorry, but we didn't get your 1993 return.' I said, 'Sure you did.' And I faxed them another one. They can't even find a whole return. Now do you honestly expect them to miss what I pay for my maid?"
But others fear the wrath of the I.R.S. The nanny industry is worried that tax collectors may ask for records from agencies as a way to find people who didn't pay the household tax. "We've heard they plan to do that and it's scary," said Ms. Weinberg of Hand-in-Hand Agency Inc., the placement service. "It's certainly an invasion of privacy."
The I.R.S. does not deny that it may try those tactics, even though most of its policing will come through regular audits. And the penalties -- up to one-fifth of the amount owed -- can add up quickly. This year, for example, an employer who pays a nanny $300 a week would pay $1,249.40 in Federal household employment tax, which includes unemployment insurance, plus $1,193.40 remitted from the nanny's paycheck. If this employer decides not to pay the tax and gets caught in three years, the payments plus interest and penalties would total $4,243, said Mr. Goldberg of Nanny Tax.
The threat of those penalties may not be enough to make most taxpayers ante up. While the Federal payment system may be simpler after the overhaul, many taxpayers say state systems, particularly in New York, often remain an adventure in purgatory. "There was a time when I filed the taxes myself," said one mother of two. "But then I ran into the New York State tax forms and I literally pulled my hair out."
The sudden interest in household employment taxes has been a boon for a few accountants, who have developed a specialty in domestic payrolls. Mr. Goldberg, who charges $340 a year to shepherd clients through the paperwork, said his business doubled this year, thanks to a growing number of taxpayers who have grown tired of the record-keeping. And some taxpayers prefer the quarterly payments to avoid a big hit at tax time, but those procedures are now even more complex.
Well-to-do families with large staffs appear to be the most compliant. Sharon Umphenour, a fund-raiser who lives in Atlanta, has a full-time gardener, a maid and a secretary and insists on paying their benefits, regardless of the hassle.
"I really appreciate my employees," Ms. Umphenour said. "You ask me if it bothers me that other people don't pay their household employment taxes. Sure it does; this is the law. I obey it. Now you tell me: Why shouldn't everyone?"

HEADLINE: An Exit From the Inner City: Training for New Auto Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
IN high school, Quincy W. Huff worked part time stacking merchandise on drugstore shelves. Now, six years later, Mr. Huff can be found sitting at a computer in the library of a nonprofit group called Focus: Hope, creating intricate models of automobile parts.
Mr. Huff, 24, who spent several years working for auto-supply companies before enrolling in Focus: Hope's engineering program, knows he will have to work harder to get a high-paying factory job than people who grew up in the suburbs a few miles away. 
 "Some people I've known who have gotten into Chrysler were just regular people," Mr. Huff said. But he isn't taking any chances.
"I could have gotten lucky, then again maybe not," he added. "The older you get and the less educated you get, your luck kind of plays out."
Every year, Focus: Hope trains 1,000 young adults from Detroit's inner city, like Mr. Huff, for auto industry jobs. And the contrast between the decay and occasional bedlam of the public schools they left behind and the intellectual challenge and unforgiving discipline they encounter here couldn't be starker.
Before, they could often skip classes with impunity, and many dropped out. Now, anyone who shows up even a minute late more than three times in the first seven weeks loses the chance of being recommended for more advanced studies; anyone tardy six times is expelled. And while many of the students barely learned to read and write in high school, here they must master the complexities of computers and geometric equations.
Auto executives would like to see more programs like Focus: Hope as they start their biggest hiring spree in a quarter-century to replace 170,000 retiring workers by 2003.
"There is a crying need in the country for the development of skills that would allow people to work in these high-paying jobs," said John F. Smith Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation. He said schools in the United States should move toward offering European-style apprenticeships for blue-collar workers.
Robert J. Eaton, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said high schools used to do a better job of training young people for factory work.
"I would like to see a dramatic change in schooling in the United States," he said. "I would like to see far more opportunity for technical skills." He recalls taking high-school courses "like sheet-metal shop, machine shop, welding" and using the expertise he picked up to tinker with cars after school.
Focus: Hope is bringing back that kind of hands-on training, offering everything from remedial reading to advanced engineering degrees. At the low end, it has designed a seven-week session to bring students -- typically unemployed teen-agers, many of them high-school dropouts -- up to 10th-grade math and reading levels. "I see young people that are graduating from school and they've got a high school diploma but they have fourth-grade math," said Eleanor Josaitis, the group's co-founder.
Just 60 percent make it through that relatively short introductory phase and go on to the school's core curriculum, a 31-week stint at the Machinist Training Institute. There, five days a week for eight hours a day, students strap on a royal blue smock and learn the basics of working in the auto industry. They spend half the day in classrooms studying applied math, manufacturing theory, computer programming and blueprint reading. Then they hit the shop floor, where they use lathes, mills and grinders to precisely slice metal, making hammers and other equipment found in factories.
Most students work part time to pay their bills while they study at Focus: Hope. By the time they are finished, they have gained self-confidence and the skills to land jobs paying an average of $22,000 a year. When nearby Big Three factories are looking for workers, they sometimes hire Focus: Hope's entire graduating class.
Some students, lured by the prospect of higher pay, stick around for a more advanced program that lasts 26 weeks and enables them to earn a part-time wage from Focus: Hope, making auto parts sold to local companies, while they study. And the true die-hards stay for advanced studies that can last years in fields like engineering or computer-aided design. They earn associate, bachelor's or master's degrees from six local universities during their time at Focus: Hope.
Focus: Hope graduates are joining the ranks of a higher-skilled work force that is expected to help make American auto companies more efficient. The University of Michigan calculated that in 1994, the Big Three assembled 66 cars and trucks per worker a year. By 2003, that figure is expected to jump to 90 vehicles an employee, an efficiency level that Toyota has already exceeded.
Mr. Huff fears that people from the inner city have a long way to go to get a piece of the action. "Half don't even know what the Internet is," he lamented. "Half of them have never used a computer. Kids coming from out in the suburbs are more prepared."
And many inner-city children aren't even aware of the opportunities they are missing, he added. Where he grew up, he said, "it was unheard of for a person to make $20,000 a year." Indeed, it wasn't until he earned enough money to buy a car and drive out past Eight Mile Road -- the dividing line between Detroit and its northern suburbs -- that he realized so many people lived a life he had seen only on television.
With so many jobs to be had, Mr. Huff said, "I can't believe people aren't grabbing this opportunity." He paused, then said, "I can see why people waste it, because they don't know any better."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1181 words

HEADLINE: It's Not a Wage Gap But an Age Gap

BYLINE: By W. Michael Cox; W. Michael Cox is vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Congress appears bent on raising the minimum wage in an attempt to accomplish by legislative fiat what many claim the economy can no longer do on its own: give low-income workers a bigger piece of the pie. What legislators perhaps don't understand is that if poor Americans can gain entry into the work force, even at low wages, they usually move up the economic ladder.
The 20 House Republicans who have joined Democrats in calling for raising the minimum wage are apparently swayed by endlessly repeated popular myths: The rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer; the middle class is going nowhere; today's twentysomething job seekers are destined to be the first Americans in history not to live as well as their parents. 
 Census Bureau data seem to verify this pessimism. In 1994, the latest year available, the bottom fifth of households earned just 3.6 percent of the nation's income and saw their share of the wealth fall from 4.2 percent in 1975 to 3.6 percent. The top fifth, meanwhile, received almost half of the nation's income, up from 43.7 percent in 1975. After adjusting for inflation, the income of households in the lowest fifth rose only $87 from 1975 to 1994. The top tier, meanwhile, gained $25,934.
Yet the doomsayers ignore an important economic fact: Inequality is not immobility. The Census Bureau's static snapshots of income distribution don't gauge Americans' ability to move up the economic ladder. The actual people in each percentile change from one year to another.
To gauge opportunity in America, it is essential to track individuals in the labor force or those trying to join it (people 16 and older who are working, unemployed, laid off, in school or retired) and to follow them over a period of years, capturing the ups and downs in their income.
The University of Michigan's Panel Survey on Income Dynamics has done exactly this, providing the longest-running record of Americans' earnings. In 1968, it began collecting detailed information on 50,915 people of all ages and income groups, and it compiled data through 1991.
The study gives a startlingly optimistic picture of economic mobility. Take those who were in the bottom fifth of all earners in 1975. The conventional view would lead us to believe that these people were probably worse off in the 1990's. But the Michigan study found that only 5 percent were still in the bottom fifth in 1991.
More remarkable, 80 percent of the bottom fifth in 1975 had made it into the top 60 percent of earners -- middle class or better -- over that 16-year span. And 29 percent rose to the top fifth. This evidence suggests that holding low-income jobs is largely a transitory stage for people with little work experience.
How mobile are Americans? Of the Michigan group, less than 1 percent of those in the lowest fifth in 1975 remained in the bottom 20 percent every single year until 1991. Nearly a quarter of those in the bottom tier in 1975 moved up the next year and never returned. More than three-quarters of those in the lowest fifth in 1975 spent at least one year among the top 40 percent of income earners by 1991.
The poor in the Michigan sample also made dramatic gains in annual income. Those who started in the bottom fifth in 1975 saw their average annual income increase by $25,322 by 1991, adjusted for inflation. Among 1975's top 20 percent of earners, the increase was only $3,974.
But not just the poorest workers from the 1970's did well. Among the second-poorest fifth, more than 70 percent had moved to a higher bracket by 1991, with 26 percent making it to the top 20 percent. From the middle fifth, almost half managed to raise their incomes. And a third of the people from the second-highest group made it to the top bracket.
What about the rich of 1975? Some fell to lower tiers, most likely because they retired or were laid off from high-paying jobs. Even so, nearly two-thirds of the group could still be found in the top tier in 1991. Less than 1 percent plummeted to the bottom.
The Michigan study isn't the first to look at individuals over time and find strong evidence to contradict the myth of a society sapped by declining opportunity. The Treasury Department reached a similar conclusion in a 1992 study. In analyzing tax returns from 14,351 households, it found that 86 percent of those in the lowest fifth in 1979 moved to a higher group by 1988. Two-thirds of these people reached the middle 20 percent or higher in just nine years, with almost 15 percent making it to the top fifth of income earners.
Not only do the statistics show that our economic system is biased toward success, but also they teach an important lesson about staying mobile in the economy of tomorrow. If people get into the work force -- at any level -- and stay there, they will likely be rewarded. There is a permanent underclass, but it consists for the most part of people who drop out of the work force entirely.
Getting people into the work force has taken on a new urgency in the postindustrial economy. Lifetime earning patterns have changed substantially. Traditionally, a worker's income rose rapidly in the early years of working, peaked in middle age, then fell as the worker eased toward retirement. But over the past four decades, earnings have been rising more sharply as workers age.
According to the Labor Department, in 1951 workers reached their peak earning years from the ages of 35 to 44. The average annual income of individuals in this group was 1.6 times the income of those from 20 to 24 years old, and slightly greater than that of workers between 45 and 54. By 1993, the peak earning years shifted to ages 45 to 54, and these workers earned almost 3.1 times more than the those in the 20-24 age group.
Older workers are doing better because the economy has shifted toward services and technology: brain power can continue to expand long after muscle power has begun to falter. Thus as the country retools itself for a more knowledge-intensive era, workers are increasingly rewarded for what they've learned in the workplace. Earnings for those with experience rise sharply, and the gap widens between youth and middle age.
This in part explains the apparent discrepancy between the Census Bureau's figures and the Michigan study. There is an income gap, but it driven more today by the steepening earnings of workers as they age.
It's not that the young are worse off; it's that older, more experienced workers are doing much better. Those who can stay in jobs almost certainly will receive their reward. Thus it is job experience, not government, that makes work pay. The key is to get a start and stay working.
So why is Congress talking about raising the minimum wage when economists of all stripes agree that even a 90-cent increase would reduce employment by hundreds of thousands of jobs over the long term? This would expel from the working class the very people whom the raise would purportedly help: the inexperienced. It is the kind of help poor Americans can't afford.

HEADLINE: It's Lonely for the U.S.;
Walking Loudly, Carrying Trade Rules

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE arsenal of the economic age is trade sanctions, and these days it sometimes seems as if President Clinton's advisers can think of nothing else.
Last weekend, before Mr. Clinton left for Asia, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary William Perry, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and the new Commerce Secretary, Mickey Kantor, spent hours discussing the double sanctions likely to be applied against China in coming weeks, first for proliferating nuclear weapons, then for pirating American music, software and videos. 
 A few weeks before, the same cast was tightening the noose on Cuba and threatening legal action against third countries that continue to invest there -- including Mexico and Canada. And there is a movement afoot in Congress to whip up new sanctions against companies from any nation that do business in Iran.
There's only one hitch: virtually none of America's allies is going along. To the contrary, they are denouncing America's use of its economic gunboats as counterproductive in the case of China, extraterritorial in the case of Iran, and a violation of worldwide trade accords in the case of Cuba.
To the White House, not surprisingly, the same set of facts looks very different. Mr. Clinton's advisers declare that only America has the leadership to stand up to world's bad actors, and that allies from Europe to Japan are, in the words of Mr. Kantor, "happy to hold our coats, and then reap the benefits of America playing the heavy."
 
 
 
Following Suit
 He should know. Weeks after he negotiated a trade agreement with Japan last year on autos and auto parts, the European nations that had denounced America's heavy-handed threats showed up in Tokyo asking for the same deal. (They got it.) The same could happen in China. Its 30 illegal compact-disk factories rip off Madonna and Windows 95, but they also churn out Japanese love songs recorded by Sony, and hits produced by the German recording giant Bertelsmann A.G. and by Polygram, which is Dutch-owned. Yet none of those countries has warned China, as the United States did again last week, that unless Beijing lives up to its agreement to shut the plants, they will close their markets to billions of dollars in Chinese imports.
In fact, Japanese business executives regularly use the tensions with the United States to portray Japan as China's more "reliable" trading partner. And the Europeans used a visit to Paris this month by Li Peng, China's premier, to wrap up a $1.5 billion aircraft deal that Boeing desperately wanted. "If we move to sanctions against China," one of Mr. Clinton's top strategists predicted the other day, "everyone else will privately tell us we're doing the right thing -- and then they'll send five new trade missions to Beijing."
 
 
 
The Best Conditions
 The problem for the Administration -- though one it will not talk about publicly -- is that if the United States acts alone, sanctions are far more likely to fail. In a study of economic sanctions since 1914, Gary Hufbauer and Daniel Rosen of the Institute for International Economics in Washington found that they work best when the international community is unified, when the target of the sanctions is weak, when they are implemented swiftly, and when they are aimed at "discrete goals" rather than "reshaping a country's political character."
"China is a classic case, because it fits almost none of the criteria," Mr. Hufbauer said in an interview. "It's big and powerful. It has figured out how to play the Europeans, the Japanese and the Americans off against each other."
The real political complications set in whenever talk turns to the ultimate sanction: Denying China "most favored nation" status, which gives it the lowest tariffs that the United States applies. Four years ago Mr. Clinton accused President George Bush of coddling dictators by automatically extending the trade benefits, called M.F.N., despite China's repression of dissidents.
Once in office, he changed his mind. American firms that rely on exports from China said that debating China's trading rights every year would be a form of assisted suicide. Hong Kong and Taiwan, which produce many of the goods they sell to America in factories in southern China, have joined the huge lobbying effort to preserve M.F.N. Mr. Clinton, not wanting to reverse positions twice on the same issue, has vowed to renew M.F.N. in June, even while threatening China with specific sanctions for exporting nuclear parts to Pakistan and ignoring last year's piracy accord.
And now Senator Bob Dole, a longtime public supporter of M.F.N., is suggesting that he would like to change his position. If he does, he could make Mr. Clinton look like the man who is coddling dictators this time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Now, Iran-Bosnia;
Who Knew What and When?

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT'S an election year, so perhaps it should come as no surprise that, suddenly, the Clinton Administration has its very own scandal involving Iranian ayatollahs and secret arms shipments.
Or does it? 
 Obviously, the Republicans think so. They are planning no fewer than six Congressional hearings to investigate the legality and wisdom of President Clinton's unannounced decision in 1994 to do nothing to stop Croatia from sending Iranian arms into Bosnia.
Just by calling in the investigators, they are planting the familiar impression that there is something to be exposed -- a flawed policy, an end-run around Congress, and perhaps even criminality.
But this episode isn't Iran-contra II. If there is a budding scandal here, so far it involves a failure to inform Congress of a decision it probably wouldn't have opposed anyway, the prospect that the White House will withhold documents and some sloppy handling of who knew what when.
Bob Dole, the President's challenger this year, has expressed shock: "It's duplicitous, to say the least," he said, "to tell us one thing while they're trying to covertly sort of wink and nod to the Iranians." He neglected to mention that in 1994 he was leading the charge in the Senate for lifting the arms embargo, and when reports surfaced of Iranian arms shipments, he did not object.
The Administration argues that Mr. Dole is posturing. Officials recall that news organizations reported that arms from Iran and other countries were arriving in Bosnia via Croatia and that reports on the shipments were in the daily classified intelligence reports that circulate throughout the Government.
What are the facts? In the spring of 1994 Bosnia's Muslims were under siege by the better-armed Serbs. The Administration (and Senator Dole) wanted to help the Muslim-led Government by lifting the United Nations-mandated arms embargo. But America's European allies, who had thousands of peacekeeping troops on the ground, vehemently opposed such a move. The Administration ruled out breaking the embargo on its own, arguing that this would tear NATO apart.
 
 
 
Didn't Ask, Didn't Tell
 If Ronald Reagan had been in the White House, he might have ordered William Casey, his Director of Central Intelligence, to cook up a covert operation to send arms secretly, just as they had done in Nicaragua and Afghanistan.
But covert operations don't seem to be Mr. Clinton's style. This one would have tied the United States to the fate of the Bosnian Muslims and enraged the allies. Besides, Mr. Clinton had a poor relationship with James Woolsey, the Director of Central Intelligence, who would have had to carry out any covert operation. By law, Congress would have had to have been informed. Inevitably, the operation would have leaked.
So Mr. Clinton came up with a watered-down alternative: covert inaction.
On Air Force One on April 27, 1994, while en route to Washington from Richard Nixon's funeral, the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, presented Mr. Clinton with a way he could give a green light to Iranian arms shipments. Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, was preparing to ask the United States what it would think about an Iranian smuggling operation, and Mr. Clinton decided not to oppose it.
So Peter Galbraith, the American Ambassador to Croatia, told Mr. Tudjman that he had "no instructions" about such a plan. A few days later, an Iranian 747 bearing arms arrived in Croatia. And then Congress passed legislation requiring the Administration to stop enforcing the arms embargo, so ignoring such arms shipments became official policy in late 1994.
Until two weeks ago, the Republicans in Congress weren't making any fuss over the fact that Iran helped Bosnia fight a war that the Administration and Congress wanted Bosnia to win. That all changed when the Los Angeles Times reported Mr. Clinton's personal involvement.
It may well turn out that the Administration did nothing illegal, but the episode still raises questions about how well it makes decisions. Why, for example, didn't Mr. Lake, the co-author of a 1984 book on flaws in how foreign policy gets made, ask for a formal National Security Council meeting so that all the President's top advisers could be consulted? Mr. Woolsey, kept in the dark, assumed there was a rogue operation run outside the Central Intelligence Agency. White House officials acknowledge that Secretary of Defense William Perry and Gen. John Shalikashvili, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were not consulted in advance either. Mr. Perry, more than once, expressed concern about Iranian arms shipments, said a senior Pentagon official, though he never tried to get them stopped.
Mr. Christopher, by contrast, who has made economic and diplomatic sanctions against Iran a pillar of American foreign policy, formally recommended to the President that the United States not try to stop theashipments. "Warren Christopher told me that this was the way to go," said Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff.
Lawmakers may want to know whether Administration officials were completely honest about American policy. When Mr. Christopher was asked in Geneva about reports of the first Iranian 747 shipment, he replied, "The United States expects compliance with the embargo."
Fair or not, the Republicans will try to use the Iranian connection to tarnish the Clinton Administration's peace agreement in Bosnia, much as the Democrats went after George Bush's record as a war President by arguing that he had mistakenly tried to befriend Saddam Hussein before the Iraqi President invaded Kuwait. It may only be theater; it may only be politics. But the Iran episode certainly gives the Republicans one more opportunity for a show trial.

HEADLINE: The World;
Finally, Japan May Have a Future in the Military

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
FOR the last 50 years, Japan has sat out Asia's disputes, its armed forces limited strictly to self-defense. Now, that may be changing. The Japanese-American summit meeting in Tokyo last week may be remembered as a milestone -- the occasion when Japan took the first steps on a long journey to exorcise the ghosts of war and take up a role in international security.
"Last year in Japan we commemorated the 50th anniversary of the end of the war," Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto declared in a toast during President Clinton's visit. "This year, we are taking the first steps toward a new era." 
 The biggest immediate news from the flurry of meetings surrounding the summit was a decision by America to hand back 11 military installations, in all or in part, on Okinawa. But the deeper meaning of President Clinton's visit and the American-Japanese joint declaration may be that it was a landmark moment when Japan began to come out of its shell.
 
 
 
The Biggest Little Fish
 "I think the kinds of approaches in the declaration will be in the long run more noted than the return of some acreage," a senior State Department official said.
The emergence of Japan as a player in the security of Asia would have significance around the world. The world's second-largest economy, Japan has been until now an economic whale and a military minnow. But a colossal reshaping of the security scene is now under way in the Pacific, and the United States and Japan both see room for a larger Japanese role.
The most important feature in the new Asian security topography is China, which with 3 million troops has the largest army in the world, as well as land or sea disputes with most of its neighbors and ambitions rather like Germany's in the late 1800's: to channel an economic boom into building a modern military machine, to create a blue-water navy and to overcome a legacy of humiliations by winning more space at the dinner table. In Germany's case, the result was World War I.
For thousands of years, at least since the rise of Sparta triggered the Peloponnesian wars, nothing has been so disruptive to international order as the friction that comes with the rise of new powers. And there has never been a rising power quite on the scale of China.
East Asia is also in flux because of the prospect of the collapse, peacefully or violently, of North Korea. And there are huge questions about the future course of Asia's other countries -- for example, Indonesia, the fourth most populous in the world with 200 million people.
It all adds up to a certainty: security in Asia will be highly uncertain.
"The status quo is not going to hold in Asia much longer," noted a senior Defense Department official.
Next to these cosmic trends, the steps that Japan has just taken toward a greater security role seem tiny. But their direction is what counts.
First, Japan agreed to a military supply agreement that will allow Tokyo to sell spare military parts to the United States -- albeit, for now, only in peacetime.
Second, Japan agreed to review the 18-year-old guidelines for military cooperation with the United States during a military crisis. This is not expected to go so far as to lead Japanese troops to fight alongside Americans in Korea. But it might allow American military planes to use Japanese civilian airports in an emergency, or it might permit Japan to refuel American naval ships in war or treat wounded American servicemen. In particular, the joint declaration emphasized the need to cooperate "in dealing with situations that may emerge in the areas surrounding Japan" -- meaning Korea.
The United States is now pressing Japan to play a greater security role, but one of the limitations is from Article 9 of the Constitution that the United States imposed on Japan after World War II: ". . . the Japanese people forever renounce war . . . and the threat or use of force." Yet it is entirely possible that in the coming years Japan will reinterpret the provision to mean that it does not apply to a crisis that affects Japan's security, which is almost anything this side of Bosnia.
On its face, for example, the Constitution also bans "land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential." Yet, due to the wonders of constitutional interpretation, Japan has built its self-defense forces into one of the most powerful armies in Asia, supported by a $45 billion military budget, the second- or third-largest in the world (after the United States' and probably Russia's). Japan will also continue to host 47,000 American troops, for whose maintenance Tokyo contributes about $6 billion a year.
In any event, a broad debate is now under way in Japan about what kind of military it should possess.
 
 
 
A Taboo Drops
 "Until recently it was a taboo to discuss this matter," former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who has been leading Japan to take a more assertive position in security issues, said in an interview. "But now it's not a taboo and people are thinking about it seriously." Mr. Nakasone wants Japan initially to change the interpretation of the Constitution and then to amend the Constitution when that becomes politically possible.
The obstacles to a greatly enlarged military role are not just constitutional but also include public opinion in Asia. In China and Korea, in particular, memories of the horrors associated with Japanese invasion are still deep and bitter. Within Japan, many people also believe that their country must stay out of military spats and be, in the phrase of the newspaper Asahi Shimbun, "a conscientious objector nation."
The newspaper reflected the unease of many Japanese liberals when it warned in an editorial last week: "We cannot help but be concerned that a completely different direction is about to be taken." It said the result could, "in the worst case, involve Japan in an American war."

HEADLINE: The World;
Warlords Ascend In Liberia's Ruins

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
SINCE freed American slaves first arrived to "settle" this steamy swampland in 1822, there has been one constant in this country's tortured history: Liberia has always belonged, like so much real estate, to its boldest sons. Now in a renewed state of civil war, it waits for the strongest to assert themselves.
From the very start, the land of the free envisioned by Liberia's American founders never included the indigenous tribes who were displaced by firepower and subterfuge. And to cement their grip, the Americo-Liberians, as the newcomers were known, instituted a subtle version of apartheid that ended only in 1980. In that fateful year, 28-year-old Army Master Sergeant Samuel K. Doe overthrew the hegemony of the American-descended ruling class, killing the President, William R. Tolbert. 
 If this class revenge after decades of deprivation and scorn was deeply satisfying for many indigenous Liberians, their pleasure would be brief. Soon enough, Mr. Doe's terror produced a sobering hangover: without its traditional elite, however selfish and corrupt, Liberia was ungovernable. Sitting amid the ruins of a country that once had one of West Africa's most developed economies, Liberians of every background craved a savior bold enough to topple their bloody and unschooled dictator.
Enter Charles Taylor, a ruthless descendant of the American settlers, who bribed his way out a Massachusetts prison, where he was awaiting extradition to Liberia on embezzlement charges. In 1989 Mr. Taylor, promising national redemption, invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast. The following year Mr. Doe was captured and executed by a breakaway militia. With conflict splintering, the country was without any organizing thought besides the raw, boundless ambitions of Mr. Taylor and his many rivals.
Liberia's latest troubles, the resumption of a war in which the battlefield switched terrifyingly in the space of a weekend from the thick bush of the interior to the streets of the capital, were the logical next chapter.
The year before, a political agreement that made the warlords co-vice chairmen on a transitional ruling council last October provided the first real sense of hope the country had known since the Doe coup. The agreement, brokered by the 16-member Economic Community of West African States, also set up a timetable for elections. It may one day be seen as a textbook case of how not to settle an African civil war.
Liberia's peace pact effectively opened the gates of a relatively tranquil capital to the new vice chairmen and as many as 60,000 teen-age warriors before even beginning to tackle thorny questions like disarmament, re-education or employment.
"If only we could have mounted something economically, we could have drawn these fighters away from the militias and into some kind of productive activity for the first time in their lives," said one Western diplomat, who saw pledges of international aid evaporate with war. "Everything we were picking up indicated that people, starting with the fighters, were tired of the war, but we never got anything going."
Meanwhile, the 10,000-man West African peacekeeping force, weary after five years here, dropped its guard. Members of the Nigerian-led force saw deployment here as an opportunity for plunder. By the time the shooting broke out on Easter weekend, what had begun as a model of regional peacekeeping had degenerated into a contraband-running, shakedown operation where the least desirable jobs were those that had anything to do with keeping the peace.
The worst mistake in Liberia's return to chaos, however, may have been giving only three militia leaders, including Charles Taylor, seats in the new Council of State. Already disgruntled over the size of the piece of the cake reserved for them in the settlement, members of the Krahn ethnic group, a small but battle-hardened people who were the backbone of Mr. Doe's army, needed little persuasion to rally behind the latest bold leader pulling the oldest maneuver in Liberian politics: the naked power play.
 
 
 
Mutual Destruction
 Persuasion came from Roosevelt Johnson, the leader of a breakaway faction of the United Liberation Movement. In February, Mr. Johnson, who was unhappy about not having been named to the council, attacked peacekeepers near Tubmanburg.
At the same time, the gardens of Mr. Johnson's suburban villa had become a recruiting center for hundreds of idle Krahn youngsters who flocked there advertising their one and only skill: trigger pulling.
What ensued was a conflagration that none of Liberia's many international partners, including influential Americans, were prepared for. Sensing a dangerous challenge just as his six-year bid for power was nearer than ever to bearing fruit, Mr. Taylor, whose forces had been infiltrating the capital faster than anyone else's, issued a warrant for Mr. Johnson's arrest on specious murder charges.
In the space of two of the most destructive weeks in this country's long history, Mr. Taylor and the outside world learned that whatever the balance of power might be in the bush, warfare along tribal lines in Monrovia's close quarters is mutually assured destruction. With corpses rotting in the streets, cholera sweeping muddy urban refugee camps and little left of a badly looted city that once called itself the Manhattan of Africa, the only question seemed to be whether this ambiguous prospect would be enough to usher in some form of deterrence.

HEADLINE: In America;
Poison Numbers

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The Cato Institute, a conservative think tank, released a study last fall that made the provocative claim that welfare families typically received a benefits package equivalent to $17,500 in income, and thus were doing much better than many working families.
In several localities, according to the institute, welfare was paying the equivalent of a $25,000-a-year job, and in some it paid even more. 
 The study concluded, "If Congress or state governments are serious about reducing hard-core welfare dependence and rewarding work, the most promising reform is to cut benefit levels substantially."
It was just what the social Neanderthals wanted to hear. The study was seized upon as proof that poor people were ripping off the system, living the life of Riley at the expense of the more solid types willing to work for a living. Many politicians, including the governors of New York and California, cited the study as a justification for large cuts in welfare benefits.
It turns out the Cato Institute was wrong. A carefully researched new study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has determined that the Cato report was based on errors and distortions of fact that resulted in findings that were wildly exaggerated.
A close reading of both studies makes it difficult to avoid the conclusion that the errors and distortions in the Cato report were deliberate. Without doubt, they were destructive.
The center's study found that in a typical state a family of three (the example cited by Cato) receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children and food stamp benefits gets the equivalent of "less than $9,000 in income, rather than $17,500, as Cato mistakenly alleges."
With that income, the welfare family remains about $3,000 below the poverty line.
In their study, the Cato researchers consistently overstated the income of welfare recipients, and consistently understated the income of working people. For example, they counted food stamps as income for welfare families but did not count them as income for the several million working families that receive them.
They counted housing assistance as income for the "typical" welfare family when, in fact, just one in four welfare families receives a rental subsidy. According to the center's study, "Cato adds between $2,000 and $8,600 to the income of the typical A.F.D.C. family in every state on the erroneous assumption that the typical family receives housing assistance."
Cato's researchers counted WIC benefits, which are food vouchers for young children at special risk for inadequate nutrition, as income for the typical welfare family. They should have known that more than 80 percent of the children on welfare do not get WIC benefits. Most of the children who do get WIC benefits are in working families that are not on welfare. But the Cato researchers perversely assumed that the typical welfare family had two children receiving WIC benefits, and that low-income working families had none.
"Particularly egregious," said the center's report, "is Cato's practice of counting Medicaid as income for welfare families while counting neither Medicaid nor employer-provided insurance as income for poor working families. Census data show that 62 percent of children in working poor families that do not receive government cash assistance are covered either by private health insurance or Medicaid."
The Cato study was especially insidious in that it used poison data to pit two groups that are not doing well -- welfare recipients and the working poor -- against each other. The politicians who seized so gleefully on the study's conclusions have no interest in fairer economic treatment for either group.
Robert Greenstein, the center's director, went out of his way to acknowledge that low-wage workers are struggling mightily to make ends meet. But he said attempts to address the problems faced by working families are not helped by misleading information about welfare.
The Cato study was a travesty, an exercise in bad faith disguised as serious research. For politicians to continue to rely on its discredited findings would be an even bigger travesty.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Don't Gamble With Gamblers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Sometimes the good guys get so taken with the justice of their cause that -- as they approach their goal -- they blow the whole thing.
The goal is to focus the nation's attention on the spreading evil of state-sponsored and government-encouraged gambling. The need is urgent because state lotteries are a tax fraud, and because the sales pitches enticing suckers into tax-dodging casinos and debilitating debt are corrupt public policy. 
 Now, finally, with public and private gambling predators skimming billions from their prey, and with phony Indian tribal leaders ("casino-owning Americans") turning our aboriginals into a nation of croupiers, the non-suckers are awakening. The way pious politicians help hook young people into a lifelong addiction to gambling and its get-rich-quick philosophy is a national disgrace.
National, not just local. To meet the menace of gambling, step one is to set up a national commission to marshal the damning facts about gambling's phony promises and ruined lives.
Bills to do that were offered in House and Senate. The National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling organized grass-roots support, and with some prodding from moralizing pundits, the Christian Coalition joined its crusade. In response, the gambling lobby raised a $2 million ante and hired Frank Fahrenkopf and Ken Duberstein, the Republican lobbyists, to delay, weaken, and -- if unable to stop the legislation -- to subvert the commission with pro-gambling members from Nevada slotpots and Indian "reservations."
Thanks to House Judiciary Chairman Henry Hyde, a bill giving the commission real authority to hold hearings and subpoena witnesses, written by Frank Wolf, Republican of Virginia, passed the House without a dissenting vote.
The weaker Senate version, sponsored by Paul Simon and Richard Lugar, and shepherded by Governmental Affairs Chairman Ted Stevens, was better funded and given more time. But Simon-Lugar never had subpoena power and went into the markup session burdened with amendments hamstringing the commission, appointing at least one high roller and protecting casino operators from embarrassment.
Not acceptable, but negotiable from strength by the good guys because Bob Dole's four-word order to Stevens was "get the bill through." At that point, a sophisticated anti-gambling lobbyist would have gone to Stevens, cut the cards and cut a deal: Let the gambling lobbyists have a few face-savers to justify their whopping fees, let the Nevada Democratic Senators similarly mollify their Las Vegas constituents -- all with the clear understanding that subpoena power, direct commission investigation and open hearings would prevail in House-Senate conference.
Unfortunately, the good guys, heady from belated media attention and a House triumph, are not wise in the ways of getting most of a loaf. They read the horrendous amendments and got great press for hitting the panic button, denouncing Stevens for "gutting" the bill and for selling out to the monied immoralists.
Steaming, Stevens yanked the bill off the passage track. He asks: You insist on subpoena power in the Senate bill, which never had it? That'll require hearings. With 40 legislative days left, Nevada's Richard Bryan, the gamblers' friend, could conduct a semi-filibuster, effectively killing the bill for 1996.
I asked Stevens, a co-worker in the 1960 Nixon campaign and a closet good guy, what was needed to rescue the commission. "These fellows have got to settle down," he says of irate moralists, "because I'm not about to get a hot foot twice." (Who today remembers the "hot foot"?)
Advice to my side: Don't demonize Stevens; deal with him to get a Senate bill passed. Then put the heat on Dole to appoint non-Nevada conferees who will agree with the House on ways to seriously investigate gambling's economic impact and personal ruinations.
The purpose is to publicize, not prosecute. Shame is the weapon. In New York, Gov. George Pataki just caught the wave of the future by telling his state's lottery to stop fooling the people by advertising fantasies of wealth.
Cut the fulminations and get a gambling study going now. We have watchmen to watch the watchmen.
