HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Is Ready to Give Dole a Victory, and Reason to Worry

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: HAVERTOWN, Pa.

 BODY:
When Bob Dole campaigned at an outdoor rally here last week and declared that "if Bob Dole carries Pennsylvania, Bob Dole will be the President of the United States come January," no one disagreed.
That is because Bob Dole is so far behind Bill Clinton in Pennsylvania -- by 17 percentage points, according to one recent survey -- that if he manages to reverse his fortunes and win here, he would probably already have a landslide in the making. 
 Mr. Dole has visited Pennsylvania twice this month in anticipation of the primary on Tuesday. This will be an empty exercise both because Mr. Dole already has enough delegates to claim the Republican nomination and because he has no opposition. (Patrick J. Buchanan, his last Republican challenger, was making noises about staging a last stand in Pennsylvania, which has a strong anti-abortion constituency, but he has since decided to skip the state, stay home in suburban Washington and write a manifesto.)
But even with victory assured on Tuesday, Dole advisers are starting to wonder if it will be worth putting in much time or money here later. Even local Dole officials are discouraged. "He's a great guy and a great Senator," said one, "but he's a weak candidate."
The race is expected to tighten, of course. Presidential elections are usually close here, and Mr. Clinton, who has no primary opposition, is bound to come down several notches as the campaign heats up in the fall.
But the concern is that Pennsylvania, often a bellwether state, may already reflect a broader national inclination to stick with Mr. Clinton.
Although Pennsylvania has vastly preferred Republicans to Democrats lately, and a year ago favored Mr. Dole over Mr. Clinton in the polls, today Mr. Clinton has an overwhelming advantage. In the latest survey, conducted earlier this month by G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville University, Mr. Clinton led Mr. Dole 51 percent to 34 percent.
Mr. Madonna's survey of 688 registered voters, with a margin of error of 3.7 percentage points, showed that if the election were held today, Mr. Clinton would sweep virtually every demographic, economic and geographic group in the state. There were exceptions. Mr. Dole would take central Pennsylvania, a conservative and rural region, and would win voters who make more than $75,000 a year.
But the outlook for him is so bleak that most gun owners, for example, favor Mr. Clinton, even though Mr. Clinton supports gun control. More strikingly, a majority of veterans favors the President, even though Mr. Dole makes much of his service in World War II and, by implication, Mr. Clinton's lack of service in the Vietnam War.
"It's hard to find solace for Dole, unless something happens -- a foreign policy crisis that Clinton screws up or some enormous downturn in the economy," Mr. Madonna said. He said Mr. Clinton was doing well here for the same reasons he was nationally -- a feeling that the economy had turned a corner, that Mr. Clinton's "character" problems appeared now to be a known quantity, that he had positioned himself smartly against the Republican Congress and that he can give a good speech. In addition, Pennsylvania has a large population of elderly residents and they, like older voters nationally, are leery of Republican efforts to scale back Medicare.
Pennsylvania has more Democrats than Republicans -- of the 6.3 million registered voters, 49 percent are Democrats, 43 percent are Republicans. Yet they picked Republicans for all but one of the six statewide offices, including both United States Senators and the Governor. Republicans control both houses of the State Legislature. And the state voted for George Bush, the Republican, over Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 Presidential election.
But in 1992, Pennsylvania went for Mr. Clinton over Mr. Bush, 45 percent to 36 percent, with 18 percent for Ross Perot, a tally slightly more favorable to Mr. Clinton than the national vote.
Some of the voting patterns evident in 1992 -- that first emerged in 1991, when Harris Wofford, a Democrat, upset Dick Thornburgh, a former Governor, in the Senate race -- are evident again now.
These include a leaning toward Mr. Clinton in Philadelphia's Republican suburbs, where one-third of the state's voters live and where many favor abortion rights and gun control and have responded favorably to Mr. Clinton's attacks on the tobacco industry.
Suburban Republicans "don't dislike Dole the way they disliked Bush," said a Dole backer here. "But they don't love him either." He opposes abortion rights, opposed the ban on assault weapons and told the National Rifle Association last year that repealing the ban was one of his priorities.
Another pattern, analysts said, was among so-called Reagan Democrats, who oppose abortion and gun control and might be open to the Kansas Republican.
"Bob Dole will play better in areas once considered strongly Democratic," said David Buffington, editor of The Pennsylvania Report, a political newsletter in Harrisburg.
"But the Range Rover Republicans in the suburbs will vote for Clinton," Mr. Buffington said. "It's not like they're turning Democratic. But women in the suburbs are worried about the nurturing issues, worried about the N.R.A. and worried about this whole thing with the tobacco industry, and the Republicans are viewed as the backers of tobacco."
"For the health-crazed yuppies in the suburbs, tobacco is evil, whereas the guy breathing asbestos all his life in the Mon Valley doesn't care," he said of the industrial Monongahela Valley.
Pennsylvania, heavily Catholic, is one of the states where the Clinton campaign has already been airing television commercials. It has been targeting the Pittsburgh area, which is strongly Democratic, precisely because it could lose Democrats there to Mr. Dole on the social issues.
Senator Arlen Specter, who traveled with Mr. Dole during his visit here, conceded that Pennsylvania "will be a tough state" for his fellow Senator. Mr. Specter said Mr. Dole should "come forward with an urban agenda, including how to fund the distressed, inner-city schools," to help him hold down the huge Democratic vote in Philadelphia. He also said that Mr. Dole "needs to soften his image, tell people who he is, talk about himself. When people understand who he is, they'll understand where he'll take the country."

HEADLINE: The Fairfield Store Bows Out at 75

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 19

 BODY:
Finally the bargain hunters have found the Fairfield Store. It took the lurid orange "Going Out of Business Sale" signs in the windows fronting the Post Road here, because for 75 years the Manasevit family relied on traditional values to attract customers: high quality and personal service. When shoppers wanted less, the Manasevits decided this year that it was time to go.
"Passing Fads Have Their Place," the Fairfield Store had advertised. "But Not Here." 
 In one way, this passing of yet another family-owned clothing store, leaving yet another hole in the main street of one more downtown, is a success story.
No one walking into the small department store today will be impressed; three weeks of sales have already cleared the best goods, and with each day the tone on the main floor ratchets down another notch toward that of the discount chains on the edge of town.
Yet after 75 years in business, the Manasevits picked their time. It did not have to be this year. The store's finances were still strong. But with the future filling with national chains and catalogue stores and outlets and discount houses, their way of doing business was over and so they chose to move on.
"We considered ourselves a large specialty store with merchandise that was chosen with Connecticut in mind," said 72-year-old Stanley Manasevit, the son of one of the store's two founders.
His son, Bruce, who received his M.B.A. from Columbia and worked at Abraham & Straus before coming home, said: "We truly have credibility. When we run a sale, it's true. When we sell something, we back it up. If people have a complaint, they can come right to us."
Another advertisement for the Fairfield Store: "To Fit Into the Fabric of Connecticut Life Requires a Certain Quality."
Small independent department stores like the Fairfield Store have been closing one by one for decades. It had full lines of men's, women's and children's apparel and a large cosmetics department. Its men's racks were hung with Hickey Freeman, Southwick and Polo suits; the shoes were Johnston & Murphy and Cole-Haan. The women's department, its largest, was stocked with Anne Klein, Liz Claiborne, Christian Dior and Carol Little.
Nothing about the stock was unique. "There are too many stores, all selling the same stuff," Bruce Manasevit said. And when the recession of the early 90's began to lift, shoppers' attitudes had changed. Clothes were no longer a priority. People were saving for retirement or spending money on college tuition.
"It seemed like everybody was looking for a bargain lately," said Maura O'Keefe, a sales clerk for 24 years. "Not our old customers -- they liked our personal service, our gift-wrapping. Customers almost became your friends. They'd tell you their troubles, and you could tell them yours."
But down the Post Road to the east were the discounters T. J. Maxx and Marshall's. Across the road was The Gap. To the west, Main Street in Westport had become an outdoor mall with J. Crew and Barney's and Brooks Brothers.
"The Fairfield Store," stated another ad. "An Alternative to Stores That Treat Connecticut Like Manhattan With Trees."
Phyllis McCoy, a Westport resident who discovered the store in 1957, paused from looking at the racks to say: "It's a tremendous loss to the community. Its merchandise is always in good taste. It's a shame to see any store that's been successful not make it in the discount era. It's going the way of the old supermarkets with their personal service."
These days a taste for personal service is expensive. The few surviving prep shops that have fitted Fairfield County with untold numbers of navy blue blazers have gone where the Fairfield Store chose not to, very, very upscale and, well, European.
Along the endless commercial strip that the Post Road has become in Westport, the prep shop founded in 1958 as Ed Mitchell's has grown up to be Mitchell's of Westport, where Hickey Freeman, Southwick and Oxxford have one side of the aisle and Armani, Zegna, Hugo Boss and Brioni have the other.
Ed Mitchell's sons, Jack and Bill, like to think they are catering to their neighbors just as their father did, but those neighbors now are top executives at General Electric and Dun & Bradstreet and the scores of other corporations that have transformed Fairfield County. They travel the world and dress for it.
The Mitchells make sure they can advise them on what looks right in Frankfurt -- and on what looks good at G.E. on Casual Fridays. Perhaps a Canali sport coat with a turtleneck?
"Our feeling, very strongly, is that serious business still will be done in suits," Jack Mitchell said. "But the whole environment in Connecticut does lend itself to a more casual style."
Navy blue blazers are still the biggest seller at Mitchell's, but where European suits made up a fifth of its business 20 years ago, now they are half. While the Fairfield Store advertised tradition, Mitchell's was featured in I.B.M. ads about growing businesses. And yet the brothers and their sales force still go down to local train stations at 5:30 A.M. a few weeks each year to hand free coffee and glossy brochures to commuters.
"It worked in 1958, and it works today," Bill Mitchell said.
Jack Mitchell has three sons in the family business. Last year, the brothers acquired Richard's, the men's shop in Greenwich, which shares its clientele and style. Another generation seems assured.
But the Fairfield Store was comfortable with a different style, and so its three owners -- Stanley, Bruce, and a cousin, Deren Manasevit -- are trying to feel comfortable about going out strong.
Neither Bruce nor Deren originally intended to work at the store. Bruce is pausing after the recent death of his wife from cancer. Deren, who has a law degree, is looking for opportunities outside retail. In any case, the valuable building and other downtown properties remain in the family, a business in themselves; the family is not leaving Fairfield.
"Whatever is done with the building," Stanley Manasevit said, "we hope will contribute to the historic business center and the community."
So now there remains the awkward business of going out of business. The garish sale signs are the work of a consultant who was brought in to sell off the stock, and while many letters to Fairfield's weekly newspaper mourn the store's passing, some complain about this new, louder style.
The signs are not to Stanley's taste, either. He had the consultant take some down. But the Fairfield Store is already something other than what it was. "We hired them," his son said of the consultant, "because we know how to run a business, not how to go out of business."

HEADLINE: THE TELEPHONE COLOSSUS: THE CONSUMERS' CHOICES;
Deal Produces Divided View Of Effects on Phone Service

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Consumer advocates and regulators were sharply divided on the likely effects of a Nynex-Bell Atlantic merger on communications customers in the New York metropolitan area, but the two companies have carved out far different reputations when it comes to service.
Some consumer watchdogs expressed concern that joining the two regional Bell operating companies would create a telecommunications giant that would dominate local telephone, long distance, wireless, Internet and even video service in a region stretching from Maine to Virginia. 
 In this view, likely competitors might be deterred from entering that marketplace, giving the new company freer rein to dictate rates and services. At a minimum, the prospect of natural competition between Nynex and Bell Atlantic has been eliminated.
"We are concerned that this merger may throw a monkey wrench in bringing alternatives to New York consumers," said Robert Ceisler, executive director of the New York Citizens Utility Board, an advocacy group in Albany.
But others were less leery of the merger, saying that a combination of the two companies could yield unexpected benefits.
"Mergers like this one can produce economies of scale, and that can translate into more research and development," said Blossom Peretz, director of the division of the ratepayer advocate, an autonomous unit of the New Jersey Department of the Treasury.
And Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a Boston company that analyzes technology markets, said a merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic would find plenty of cable companies and other competitors ready to fight it.
"I've heard the argument before that this will be anti-competitive," Mr. Anderson said. "And I think it's fallacious."
Little is known about how the new company might operate. But in their respective operating regions, Nynex and Bell Atlantic have established reputations that could have an impact on the company's future.
Few regional Bell companies nationwide have been as heavily criticized by consumer advocates as Nynex for service quality and cost. Currently, it is mailing out $50 million in rebates to customers in the New York City area after regulators determined that it had failed in 1994 to meet service goals in areas like quickly repairing failed equipment.
A survey by the New York State Department of Public Service found that the company's overall service performance had improved in 1995. But the report found that service had slipped significantly during the fourth quarter of the year when compared with the similar period in 1994, and it cited harsh weather as one factor in that decline.
Robert Varettoni, a Nynex spokesman, said the company believed that it had moved actively over the last year to improve customer service.
"We are headed in the right direction," he said.
Bell Atlantic has compiled a far better service record than its merger partner, but it has not been without problems.
Recently, some Bell Atlantic customers in the Washington area have grumbled about having a directory assistance call first answered by computer before being connected to an operator -- although other phone companies use similar systems. The computer requires a caller to provide not only the name of the person for whom a listing is sought but also the town in which they live, which can be a difficult task in Washington's amalgam of suburbs.
Jay Grossman, a Bell Atlantic spokesman, said the company had received complaints about the procedure and is planning to reconsider its approach. Mr. Grossman said Bell Atlantic had never been fined in recent years for a failure to meet service-quality goals.
In New Jersey, the company has largely won good marks both from regulators and consumer advocates. There, it has met or exceeded all service-quality standards set by regulators in the last 10 years with the exception of a brief period when there was a strike, said Michael Gallagher, director of the telecommunications division for the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities.
Still, some consumer advocates have their concerns. Mr. Ceisler said that if regulators were to decide in the future to average Bell Atlantic's service quality record with Nynex's performance in that area, the latter company could appear to be doing a better job even as service erodes.
And Gene Kimmelman, a co-director of Consumers Union in Washington, said, "Just at the point where Congress has passed a bill to give consumers choice in the area of telecommunications, the door may get slammed in their face."

HEADLINE: Survey Finds That Crimes Cost $450 Billion a Year

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Crime costs Americans at least $450 billion a year, according to the most comprehensive survey ever done on the price of violence.
The report, done for the Justice Department, is the first to try to measure the cost of child abuse and domestic violence along with crimes like murder, rape and robbery. It is also the first to estimate the mental health care costs and the reduced quality of life for victims of crime. 
 The report calculates out-of-pocket costs covering items like legal fees, lost work time and the cost of police work as well as intangibles, like the affection lost for a murder victim's family. The authors devised a formula for the intangibles.
The study excludes the cost of running the nation's prisons, jails and parole and probation systems, which would add $40 billion, bringing the total annual cost of crime to almost $500 billion, according to other Justice Department statistics. By comparison, the Defense Department's budget for 1995 is $252.6 billion.
"The estimate of $450 billion for crime is an amazing number which tells us just how heavy a burden that crime and the fear of crime place on our society," said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, the ranking Democratic member of the House Subcommittee on Crime.
"This report could change the debate" on crime, Mr. Schumer said, "because it shows that while most people think a $1 billion anti-crime program is a large number, it's really just a drop in the bucket."
The most important thing about the study, Mr. Schumer said, "is that it shows the cost of not doing anything" is much higher than any proposed anti-crime programs, like putting more police on the street, building more prisons or spending for violence prevention.
The report, "Victim Costs and Consequences: A New Look," was sponsored by the National Institute of Justice, the research arm of the Justice Department.
While the report has been praised by a number of academic specialists and law-enforcement authorities, others have raised questions about the methodology used in calculating the intangible costs like the value of a murder victim's life.
Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Crime, agreed with Mr. Schumer, saying the report "demonstrates that the cost of building prisons and adding police are justified, in terms of the cost to our society." He said this was true even though many state governments were running out of money to build new prisons.
Mr. McCollum said the figures were worrisome "because they don't even take into account the new crime wave we expect over the next 10 years" as the number of teen-agers increases by 20 percent. While homicide rates among adults have been falling over the past decade, they have more than doubled among youths under 18 years old.
The authors of the new report make no recommendations on the best mix of measures to control crime. But they point out that ignoring the intangible benefits of crime reduction "can lead to a misallocation of resources."
The average rape, for example, incurs "out-of-pocket costs" to the victim of $5,100, far less than the $20,000 annual cost of a prison cell, the authors said. But when the rape's effect on the victim's quality of life is calculated, the cost soars to $87,000, many times greater than the price of a prison cell, the study concludes.
Mark A. Cohen, one of the three authors and an associate professor at Vanderbilt University's Owen Graduate School of Management, said another study he had done found that longer prison sentences would be a cost-effective way to reduce rape, assault and automobile theft but not burglary and robbery. Building more prisons for burglars and robbers would cost more than the savings society would achieve from a reduction in the crimes, he said.
"We would like to do away with crime, but society cannot afford a zero crime rate," said Professor Cohen, an economist. It would require so many prisons, he said, "We would bankrupt ourselves and we'd also have a society we wouldn't like."
The other authors of the report are Ted R. Miller, associate director of the National Public Services Research Institute in Landover, Md., and Brian Wiersema, research coordinator for the Violence Research Group at the University of Maryland.
Some experts expressed skepticism about the $450 billion figure put forward in the report and had doubts about its methodology.
Alfred Blumstein, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University, said the report was "one more piece of shooting at a very-tough-to-get-at number." But he said the $450-billion-a-year estimate "is unreasonably high," giving too much weight to intangible factors like pain, suffering and reduction in the quality of life.
Professor Blumstein, a leading criminologist, and some other specialists expressed concern that the very high estimate made it easier to justify building expensive prisons and handing out longer sentences.
He also said it was very difficult to calculate the benefits of violence prevention programs. While the costs of crime are incurred now, he said, "we cannot see the benefits of prevention programs for 5 to 10 years" or know how many crimes will be averted.
"The public and politicians demand immediate gratification, so there is considerable push for being tough with more mandatory sentences," Professor Blumstein said. "As a result," he said, "we have largely abandoned prevention and rehabilitation efforts for juveniles," which has contributed to the rapid growth of violent crime among teen-agers.
Among other findings in the report were these:
*Child abuse and domestic violence account for about one-third of the total annual costs of crime, a far higher figure than previous estimates. This does not include future costs that are likely to mount as children who have been physically or sexually abused perpetuate a cycle of violence.
*Violent crime causes 3 percent of medical spending and 14 percent of injury-related medical spending. Crime also accounts for as much as 10 to 20 percent of mental health care expenditures.
*Intangible costs, like lost quality of life, are by far the largest cost component for crimes of violence, the authors claim, though they are also the most difficult to measure and therefore subject to the most debate. The study places the "lost quality of life" for a murder victim and his family at $1.9 million, while the average cost of police investigation into a murder is only $1,400.
The report calculated the out-of-pocket costs of crime at $105 billion annually, including medical bills, property losses, lost earnings and programs for victim assistance.
To measure the intangible costs of crime, including pain, suffering and lost quality of life, the authors adopted figures from jury awards to crime victims and other statistical studies of the value of life, in addition to including the cost of mental care.
In a separate study by Professor Cohen, now being prepared for the Justice Department, he found that preventing a "high risk" young person in a poor neighborhood from a troubled family from turning into a juvenile delinquent and adult criminal would save the country $1.5 million to $2 million.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Better Late Than Never, Rogers Debuts

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, April 21

 BODY:
Why did the Yankees inexplicably wait before finally displaying Kenny Rogers? Why did they inexplicably tamper with their $20 million investment? The questions have existed since spring training and they reverberated throughout the Metrodome again today because Rogers looked dynamic in throwing a no-hitter for five and one-third innings. He made the Yankees look like dunces for a ludicrous delay in using him.
The starter who did not start while the Yankees experimented with an ineffective Dwight Gooden made a memopable debut and solidified that elusive spot in the starting rotation. Until Chuck Knoblauch's single to shortstop with one out in the sixth, Rogers had silenced the Twins by not allowing a hint of hit in what eventually became a 9-5 victory. 
 He was cool and composed in a start that was three weeks late, and he vanquished the theories about strolling into a minefield with New York, at least for one day.
But Rogers refused to be vindictive on the day he yielded only a single that a diving Andy Fox snared near second base.
The day Rogers patiently waited for did not become the day when he asked the same probing questions everyone else has asked.
"I don't look back," he said. "I'm trying not to look back at all. I just want to look forward and contribute. That's the best thing for me. The hardest part of the whole thing was the struggle to get in a game. I'm happy I did and happy we won. The rest is in the past."
Is it? If the Yankees miss the post-season by fewer than three games, will they reflect upon the games Gooden lost phile Rogers was the highest-paid non-entity in their history? The Yankees, who had said Rogers was behind the other starters and could best adapt to the bullpen while they observed the recovering Gooden, showed class by refusing to dodge the issue.
"You make plans out of spring training, and just because it doesn't work out doesn't mean you shouldn't have made it," Manager Joe Torre said. "It can haunt me all year as long as he keeps pitching like this."
It might. Rogers walked his fifth batter after Knoblauch's single and departed with a 4-0 lead that Jeff Nelson maintained by inducing Paul Molitor to hit into a double play. The game got sloppier when both bullpens struggled, but Rogers remained the focus.
"Some people could get mad and lose their concentration," said Paul O'Neill, who homered and drove in four runs. "He looked like he never missed a beat."
"It was his first adversity in New York and he passed it with flying colors," David Cone said. "He did his talking with his pitching today."
Precisely. So why has Rogers been silent ever since his first scheduled start on April 7 was postponed because of inclement weather?
The Yankees' fascination with Gooden, who has 15 victories in the last three years, was exacted at the expense of Rogers, who has 44.
"I put a lot of thought into it," said Torre. "To second-guess it now would be crazy."
"If we make a mistake, we stand by it and we move on," said the pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre. "Criticize it if you want."
Rogers made the move easy to malign by not permitting any Twins to reach third, by negating two threats with pickoffs and by pitching like one of the league's top left-handers.
Despite not having great location or a decent breaking ball, Rogers used fastballs, sinkers and changeups to trudge forward.
"It felt worse than a first start," said Rogers. "It felt like my first start in a long time."
Once he felt stiffness in his shoulder, Rogers was removed in the sixth after throwing 85 pitches.
Surprisingly, Rogers said he was unaware he had a no-'itter into the sixth and said he would not have pitched the seventh, even if he still had a no-hitter.
"He would have had to take himself out then," laughed Stottlemyre.
Maybe that would have created a fresh controversy. Actually, Torre expects this controversy to linger. Why the Yankees waited to start Rogers is a question the manager could hear for months.
"With all the hoopla connected with it and him pitching like that, go at it and criticize the decision," Torre said. "That's fine with me."
 
INSIDE PITCH
DWIGHT GOODEN acknowledged that he is in a precarious situation as a reliever because even a few effective stints will not prove he is prepared to succeed as a starter. "It's always going to be, yeah, but . . ." Gooden said. But the switch has been noticed throughout baseball, and the Baltimore Orioles have discussed the possibility of claiming Gooden, who is guaranteed $1.1 million in 1996, if the Yankees tried to pass him through waivers and send him to Class AAA. Baltimore General Manager PAT GILLICK has no plans to contact the Yankees, although they would listen. "I've said all along Gooden's a question mark," General Manager BOB WATSON said. "If someone wants to do something that makes baseball and economic sense and take on the question mark, I'd consider it." DAVEY JOHNSON's presence in Baltimore would be a factor because he managed Gooden with the Mets.

HEADLINE: Olympics Gets Atlanta Job Market Off to Fast Start and Surging Toward Wire

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 21

 BODY:
A predicted surge in temporary employment for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games here is beginning to show as job fairs sprout like crocuses and employers strive in a tight job market to fill the tens of thousands of jobs that are expected to pump nearly $2 billion in wages into the local economy.
The planners for the Games and experts in the Atlanta area's labor market said that despite an unemployment rate of just less than 5 percent, there would be few problems in meeting the temporary need for computer programmers, bus drivers, translators, security officers, hotel and restaurant workers, salespeople and other workers for the Games, which run from July 19 to Aug. 3. About 60,000 paid positions are expected to be filled, in addition to more than 40,000 jobs for unpaid volunteers. Many paid and unpaid positions are being arranged through corporate sponsors. 
 With three months to go before the Games begin, officials of the Georgia Department of Labor say they are beginning to see some increases in hourly wages for bus drivers and food service workers, suggesting that the demand for such workers is already high. The department has held one job fair already, attracting more than 1,000 applicants on a rainy Saturday, and plans at least three more before the end of May, including one on Tuesday geared to jobs at the city's renovated Hartsfield International Airport.
"We are looking at about 10 times the normal need for this time of the year," said David Poythress, the Georgia Labor Commissioner. "We have had a tight labor market for some 18 months here, but we will meet the need."
Some skills and experience are required for most of the jobs. But what is most important, potential employers say, is that the applicants have their own lodging while the Games are taking place because housing is at more of a premium than labor.
Jeffrey Humphreys, director of forecasting for the Selig Center for Economic Growth at the University of Georgia in Athens, said that as a "service-sector-oriented economy," Atlanta was well suited to handle large meetings and conventions and had proved that when the city was the host of the Democratic National Convention in 1988 and Super Bowl XXVIII in 1994.
Unlike the more mature, manufacturing-based economies of the Northeast and the Midwest, Mr. Humphreys said, the Atlanta area has a mobile work force that is used to frequent job changes.
"In fact, there seems to be so much hiring going on in Atlanta that is unrelated to the Olympics and just related to the growth that is going on," Mr. Humphreys said, "it's hard to separate the two."
Some of the work at the Olympic Games will be done by unpaid volunteers like Jeannie Webb, a public relations specialist with the Georgia Power Company, a local corporate sponsor of the Games. "I'm going to be a field marshal for the opening ceremonies," she said. Georgia Power, like other sponsors, is providing thousands of volunteers as well as skilled technical people to see that the Games go off without a hitch.
The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games has already identified 82 percent of the 42,500 volunteers it expects to need. It has found 90 percent of the 4,000 salaried staff members it will use to manage the Games and 82 percent of the 700 people -- executives and top technical people on loan from corporate sponsors -- who will help them, said Bill Marks, a spokesman for the committee.
Beyond that, he said, contractors and concessionaires are expected to hire about 46,000 people. So far, they have recruited 76 percent of them.
Erik Vonk, the chief executive of Randstad Staffing Services, a Dutch company that is providing temporary workers to the organizing committee and to contractors and concessionaires, said that it had not had to reach out to its other offices in the region.
"There are highly skilled people out there looking for temporary jobs," he said. "And, of course, we have your retirees, vacationing schoolteachers and school bus drivers, but they are just icing on the cake."
As the ripple of job growth extends beyond those jobs directly associated with staging the Games, there has been some moderate upward pressure on wages, Mr. Vonk said.
The hourly wage is rising for the estimated 10,000 bus and van drivers needed to drive spectators from hundreds of remote parking lots. It started some months ago at $7 an hour and has moved to $10 as the supply of drivers has dwindled, said Don Chappell of the Georgia Department of Labor. That is well above the $8.23 rate that is the average for the metropolitan area, he added.
Wages are also rising at fast-food businesses. The hourly rate being offered is $6.25, about a dollar higher than it was three months ago.
"There's no bidding war yet," Mr. Chappell said, "but wages are being kicked up and will continue, I think, and then drop back after the Games."
Much of the highly skilled work involved in putting on the Games will be done by the salaried employees of corporate sponsors like Scientific Atlanta, I.B.M., Panasonic, Motorola and Bell South.
Emmett O'Donnell, a human resources specialist with Scientific Atlanta, a telecommunications company, said it was detailing about 220 technical and managerial people to staff the video distribution network, which will provide the Olympic Village and the press center with 60 channels of simultaneous coverage of Olympic events and 100 channels of data on things like Olympic records and medal counts.
To assist its technicians, he said, the company is recruiting 150 volunteers among engineering and computer science students from colleges in states as far away as Oklahoma. They will be required to undergo 50 hours of training on simulators of the actual equipment that will be used. After a 10-hour dress rehearsal, they will be available to work 10 hours a day for a minimum of eight consecutive days.
"We'll give them uniforms, transportation, accreditation to move within the venues and the Olympic Village, and even meals," Mr. O'Donnell said. "But they have to have their own housing because we can't provide that."

HEADLINE: G-7 Officials Hail Strong Dollar But Voice Concerns Over Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Officials from the seven largest industrial nations today welcomed the strengthening of the dollar over the last year, but they expressed concern about slow economic growth in Europe and pushed for debt relief for the world's poorest nations.
Finance ministers and central bank heads representing the Group of Seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- raised questions during their meeting here about whether the recent rise in United States long-term interest rates might dampen growth in the other nations. 
 The meeting came against a backdrop of modest economic growth in the United States, promising signs of recovery in Japan, and relatively weak growth and high unemployment in Western Europe.
"The underlying fundamentals are promising after a recent pause," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who chaired the meeting, told a news conference.
But Mr. Rubin said further improvement required "that policies continue to be directed at sustaining noninflationary growth and, where necessary and appropriate, at strengthening recovery."
One focal point of the meeting, officials said, was how to relieve the debt burden on poor nations. Among the ideas discussed was a plan under which the International Monetary Fund would sell some gold reserves to raise some of the billions needed for the debt-forgiveness plan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Served Watered-Down Communism

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 21

 BODY:
Bill Clinton got a taste of Communism Lite today.
In a meeting of 12 Russian political figures, the Communist Party leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, told the American President that his victory in the coming presidential elections would not mean a return to the Soviet totalitarian past. In a lengthy soliloquy, Mr. Zyuganov said he supported political pluralism, a mixed economy and freedom of speech, assurances that left his rivals around the table squirming and rolling their eyes. 
 "Zyuganov said he respected private property, which sounded a little strange to me," said Anatoly B. Chubais, an architect of Russia's reform policies until he was dismissed by President Boris N. Yeltsin when those policies proved unpopular. Mr. Chubais, who nevertheless is advising the Yeltsin re-election campaign, added, "I reminded Mr. Clinton that Mr. Zyuganov signed the Communist Party platform which says just the opposite."
Mr. Chubais was among several participants who told Mr. Clinton that the Communist candidate speaks one way to Western leaders and another to Russian voters.
Mr. Clinton apparently did not need much convincing. After the political discussion broke up, Mr. Clinton met privately with a few Jewish leaders. Pinchus Goldschmidt, the chief rabbi of Moscow, said he asked Mr. Clinton whether, after his encounter with Mr. Zyuganov, he thought that the rights of Jews would be protected in the event of a Communist victory. Mr. Goldschmidt said Mr. Clinton replied: "I don't know, I don't know. They say one thing and do another."
The two-hour meeting, held at the American Ambassador's residence in Moscow, was not the first time Mr. Clinton had met with Mr. Zyuganov. The two spoke at a similar gathering of politicians in Moscow at a summit meeting last May. The difference was that, back then, Mr. Zyuagnov was not viewed as Russia's leading opposition figure and he was almost unknown in the West. In the last year, he has emerged as Mr. Yeltsin's strongest challenger. Most polls show he has a good chance of defeating the unpopular incumbent.
Nattily turned out in a suit, striped shirt and gaily patterned silk tie, Mr. Zyuganov seemed to relish his new prominence. Afterward, he said he felt "no antagonism at all" from Mr. Clinton and suggested that Washington should not be worried by a Communist victory.
"The relationship with the United States is friendly, and will continue to be so," he said. He directed the reporters present to read his writings on the United States-Russian relationship.
Mr. Zyuganov's attitude toward the United States expressed in his book, "I Believe in Russia," is less than cordial, however. "Washington cynically deepens the split between Russia and Ukraine, dictates Russia's conditions for supplying high technology to foreign countries, imposes ruinous disarmament treaties in Russia, and fans up Russophobia among radical nationalists in the provinces."
Mr. Zyuganov did not share those views with Mr. Clinton at their meeting.
A United States official described the encounter as "vigorous and enlightening," but others present said the format, in which each guest spoke by turn, prohibited debate and kept the conversation stilted.
There was at least one light moment. Boris Y. Nemtsov, 37, a liberal, reform-minded governor of Nizhni Novgorod, said he told Mr. Clinton that he was sure he would win re-election in November because people could not possibly elect Bob Dole. "He looks too much like Brezhnev," Mr. Nemtsov said.
Mr. Nemtsov said Mr. Clinton replied: "Be careful what you say. Zyuganov will endorse him." Everyone laughed, including Mr. Zyuganov.
Later, in a speech to more than 500 Americans living and working in Russia, Mr. Clinton shared his thoughts on the Soviet nostalgia that is permeating the election campaign. According to several people present, Mr. Clinton did not mention the Communist leader by name, but said: "We should not be surprised when there are people who do very well politically by promising to return to the good old days. This is not a problem unique to Russia. It is happening everyhere."
American officials said that Mr. Yeltsin did not try to dissuade Mr. Clinton from meeting Mr. Zyuganov, although the Russian President made it clear he would not be pleased if Mr. Clinton were to distinguish his rival with a private meeting. Mr. Yeltsin even joked about it at a news conference earlier today, saying he saw no reason why Mr. Clinton should not meet with him, "but only if Zyuganov has company and they are not one-on-one in a small room, whispering something into each other's ears."
The list of invitees to the meeting was carefully selected to provide Mr. Clinton with a range of Russian political views, but the numbers were swayed heavily in favor of political figures sympathetic to economic reform and Mr. Yeltsin.
Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist who is also a presidential candidate, was not invited. The White House considers the anti-Semitic politician beyond the pale. Washington also snubbed another well-known presidential candidate -- the former Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Mr. Gorbachev is deeply unpopular in Russia, but he remains respected in the West as the man who started Russia's reform process and ended the cold war. Indeed, this weekend's nuclear summit meeting might never have taken place had it not been for him. But his overbearing personality -- and deep enmity for Mr. Yeltsin -- seemed to have gotten in the way.
"Gorbachev gets 1 percent of the vote here," a senior American official said. "He never shuts up, he always says the same thing. We know what his positions are, and frankly it would have upset Yeltsin far more to have him there than for Clinton to be talking to Zyuganov."

HEADLINE: Dole Concedes Wage Increase Will Win Vote

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Bowing to political reality, Bob Dole, who has strongly opposed increasing the minimum wage, said today that he expected the Senate to pass an increase but refused to say how he would vote.
While being asked repeatedly on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" whether he would support raising the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25 an hour, Mr. Dole acknowledged for the first time that the increase appeared inevitable. "Will there be an increase? I assume there will. The House has already indicated they're going to pass the minimum wage." 
 His concession came after he repeatedly sidestepped the question of whether he would support a raise. Subsequently, he said: "What we'll try to do, if there is an increase, is to package it with some other things," mentioning other measures that the Democrats oppose, like tax cuts, or as part of a budget agreement, thereby dooming any increase.
Other measures he might link the wage with, he said, include proposals allowing for new rules for employees who work part-time, or for compensatory time off in lieu of being paid overtime. He acknowledged that unions "aren't crazy about" these ideas. Speaker Newt Gingrich, appearing later on CNN's "Late Edition," endorsed Mr. Dole's concept of packaging the wage bill with other measures.
For the last several weeks, Mr. Dole has battled the Democratic initiative raising the minimum wage over two years, saying it would cost businesses too many jobs, even as House Republicans have endorsed the measure. President Clinton is eager to sign the bill, which would be the first increase since 1990 when Democrats controlled Congress and the wage was raised from $3.35 an hour to $4.25 over two years under President Bush. In the past Mr. Dole has twice voted to increase it, and today he made arguments both for and against doing so.
In his answers today, Mr. Dole steeped himself in the legislative parlance that his aides have urged him to avoid, responding to the wage question at one point by saying, "But our view is, maybe file cloture on the immigration bill."
The Clinton Administration reacted to Mr. Dole's comments by calling on Mr. Dole to schedule a simple yes-or-no vote on the wage increase without linking other measures to it.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's national economic adviser, said in a statement that with each day of delay, "the real value of the minimum wage moves closer and closer to a 40-year low."
The Administration also took issue with Mr. Dole's contention today that President Clinton himself had opposed increasing the minimum wage, a statement that George Stephanopoulos, an adviser to the President, said was "flat-out not true." Clarkson Hine, a spokesman for Mr. Dole, said the statement was based on a quote by Mr. Clinton in a Time magazine article. Mr. Stephanopoulos questioned the Time article and said there was no transcript or record of Mr. Clinton's ever having said he opposed the measure.
Mr. Dole's opposition to an increase in the minimum wage comes at a time when polls show that more than 80 percent of Americans favor a raise. And support by 20 House Republicans and eight Senate Republicans for the Democratic measure increases the pressure on him to capitulate.
Today's interview again highlighted Mr. Dole's increasing challenge to hold two jobs -- as Presidential candidate, who needs to appeal to a broad segment of the population, and as majority leader, who must work out compromises with numerous factions, even if it means subverting his own position.
Mr. Dole is campaigning on his record as a leader in Congress, as "a doer, not a talker," but many analysts concluded last week that Democrats have out-maneuvered him on the wage bill. Today he upbraided the 20 House Republicans whose support for the raise tipped the balance in the House last week in favor of the bill's approval.
"We were somewhat blindsided by a group of House Republicans, which we hope we can prevent in the future," he said.
But when asked if he was rethinking his plan to continue as majority leader while running for President, he said, "Not really." Instead, Mr. Dole said today that he had had "a pretty good week" and dismissed the gloating of Democrats on the Senate floor over his setbacks as "inside baseball" that "doesn't resonate outside the Beltway."
While he trails Mr. Clinton in national polls by at least 15 points, Mr. Dole was especially caustic in his response to Republican concerns that he will lose the November election. When told that William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, wrote that Mr. Dole might lose badly, Mr. Dole said acidly, "So who is Bill Kristol? What has he done?" Mr. Kristol, a prominent Republican commentator, was chief of staff for former Vice President Dan Quayle, but Mr. Dole identified him as the manager of Alan Keyes's failed 1992 campaign for the Senate from Maryland. "I don't look upon him as anybody who really understands politics," Mr. Dole said of Mr. Kristol.
On "Late Edition," Mr. Gingrich was asked to respond to Mr. Kristol's arguments that Mr. Dole was not articulate enough to beat President Clinton. The Speaker said Americans did not want a talk-show host for President, adding, "Dole is at least as articulate as Dwight Eisenhower."
On another matter, Mr. Dole said on "Face the Nation" that he would keep an anti-abortion plank in the Republican Party platform. "We're going to have some recognition in the plank that we support the pro-life position, no question about it," he said.
Mr. Dole also said that a report in today's Kansas City Star that his Presidential campaign had received thousands of dollars in illegal contributions from workers at a Massachusetts sporting-goods company should be investigated.
The company, Aqua-Leisure Industries, is run by Simon C. Fireman, a national vice chairman of finance for Mr. Dole's campaign. Three employees told The Star that some workers were handed stacks of $100 bills and told to return with checks made out to "Dole for President." Federal rules prohibit companies from paying people to make contributions and from giving money in someone else's name.
The accusations "ought to be checked," Mr. Dole said.
"If somebody did that," he said, "they're in deep trouble."

HEADLINE: Communications Trade Pact Eludes the Big Economies

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 21

 BODY:
Trade ministers from four of the world's major economies said today that they had made some progress toward an agreement to liberalize trade in telecommunications. But the officials, who met over the weekend in the Japanese port of Kobe, said it was still questionable whether a global accord could be forged by the self-imposed deadline of April 30.
At stake is an effort by 51 nations, under the auspices of the World Trade Organization, to negotiate an agreement that would open domestic telephone and telecommunications markets to foreign companies. Although such an opening could save consumers billions of dollars, many countries are reluctant to let foreign companies compete with their national telephone companies. 
 With the deadline looming, the so-called quadrilateral meeting of trade ministers from the United States, Canada, the European Union and Japan aimed to give the negotiations a boost by having the big economies set an example of liberalization that the small countries could follow.
The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and her counterparts vowed at the meeting to redouble their efforts to meet the deadline and hinted that they would improve their offers to liberalize their own markets. But the four representatives did not state what new concessions they might make. "It was one step back from the ideal solution," a European Union official said.
Jeffrey M. Lang, a deputy United States trade representative, said the telecommunications negotiations had been given "a push forward, not a final push, but a significant push."
"We'll have to have significant contributions from developing countries, particularly from the countries in Asia," he said.
Washington has offered to allow foreign companies to completely own American telecommunications companies. But it has warned that the negotiations are in danger of breaking down unless other nations made similar offers.
Japan has said it will lift restrictions on foreign ownership except for the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and KDD, its main domestic and international phone companies. But Canada and some European nations like Spain and France have been reluctant to lift restrictions on foreign ownership. Now, the European Union official said, there are hints of concessions.
The conference delegates also said they would work for a world accord to eliminate tariffs on semiconductors, computers, software and other information-technology products.
The European Union, however, said it would not support this Information Technology Agreement unless it was allowed to take part in any future agreement on semiconductor trade between the United States and Japan. Washington is pushing for renewal, in somewhat weaker form, of a 1991 accord with Tokyo that set a goal for increasing the share of Japan's chip market held by foreign companies.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Yeltsin Accentuate The Positive at Summit Meeting

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 21

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin emerged from a meeting in the Kremlin today effusively celebrating the American-Russian partnership even as they glossed over a host of policy differences.
They announced some progress on disputes over treaties on conventional forces and anti-missile defenses. And both men put a premium on keeping the relationship between the United States and Russia on a solid footing despite growing anti-Western sentiment in Russia and a coming presidential election here that could well return a resurgent Communist Party to power. 
 The five-hour meeting between the two Presidents capped a weekend of glittering international summitry in which Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of seven major industrial democracies, meeting for the first time in Moscow, called for speedy enactment of a nuclear test ban.
Those visitors also provided a warm embrace for Mr. Yeltsin, giving him the opportunity to demonstrate his prestige as a world leader as he heads into the election running behind Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist candidate, in opinion surveys.
Mr. Clinton, sitting by Mr. Yeltsin's side at a news conference, lavishly praised his Russian counterpart. "Thanks to President Yeltsin's leadership, 60 percent of Russia's economy is now in the hands of its people, not the state," he said. "Inflation has been cut. Democracy is taking hold. Since 1993, trade between the United States and Russia is up 65 percent."
For his part, Mr. Yeltsin asserted that the elections in his country "do not interfere with the long-term cooperation between our two countries." When both men were asked how a Communist victory would affect ties, Mr. Yeltsin answered brusquely, "There's nothing to think about, because I am sure that I will be victorious."
Mr. Clinton, laughing, said, "That makes my answer irrelevant, doesn't it?"
At the news conference, Mr. Yeltsin chastised reporters for suggesting that the nuclear security summit meeting and his session with Mr. Clinton were intended to give him a pre-election boost. But it was clear that he and Mr. Clinton each had a personal stake in seeing that the meetings played well in their respective countries.
[Mr. Clinton arrived back in Washington late Sunday night.]
For Mr. Yeltsin the weekend of meetings with world leaders provided an opportunity to showcase himself and his nation as a great power on the world stage. And Mr. Clinton, concluding a one-week foreign trip and returning home to his own electoral contest, repeatedly highlighted, campaign-style, the steps he had taken as President to reduce the nuclear threat remaining after the cold war.
Referring to Mr. Yeltsin today, he said, "For three years the President and I have worked together in trying to make the world a safer place by reducing the nuclear threat that all our citizens face."
If Mr. Yeltsin should lose his re-election bid to Mr. Zyuganov, Mr. Clinton would find it harder to make a claim that he had brought a more secure world, and Russia would be likely to emerge as a major foreign policy issue in the American presidential race.
With that political backdrop, the lengths to which Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin were going to bury their policy differences became clear as they discussed some of their areas of disagreement. Those range from the war in Chechnya to the NATO military alliance's plans for expansion into Eastern Europe to Russia's sales of nuclear technology to Iran.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he had discussed the war in Chechnya with Mr. Yeltsin. But he also defended his Administration from criticism that it has not been vocal enough in its protests of Moscow's assault on the separatist province in the Caucasus, in southern Russia.
"I think it depends on your first premise: do you believe Chechnya is a part of Russia or not?" Mr. Clinton said.
"I would remind you," he added, "that we once had a civil war in our country in which we lost, on a per-capita basis, far more people than we lost in any of the wars in the 20th century over the proposition that Abraham Lincoln gave his life for: that no state has a right to withdraw from our union."
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Yeltsin had asked him to take a few steps that might be helpful in securing a peaceful resolution of the conflict. A senior Administration official later said that Mr. Yeltsin wanted Mr. Clinton to reach out to foreign leaders, particularly to King Hassan II of Morocco, who has established a good relationship with the Chechens.
Mr. Yeltsin insisted, as he has before, that no military operations had been carried out in Chechnya since March 31. But witnesses say Russian bombings and artillery attacks have continued there. Mr. Yeltsin attributed the ongoing violence to the fact that "some bands are still running around."
A senior American official said later that the Russians were making a distinction between what they considered to be "military operations" and what they viewed as defensive measures.
On the question of NATO's expansion, Mr. Yeltsin said Mr. Clinton had promised not to expand NATO at this time. The Russian President held out the possibility that some sort of mutually acceptable compromise on NATO could be reached, perhaps through an agreement that no country be allowed to enter NATO without Russia's assent.
But Mr. Clinton gently denied that he had made any concession. "My position hasn't changed about NATO, but I do not in any way, shape or form mean any threat to the security of the long-term legitimate interests of Russia," he said.
The two Presidents reported some progress on several arms control fronts, including the types of anti-missile defenses allowed under the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. Mr. Clinton said the two sides had "made important progress in distinguishing between anti-ballistic missile systems that are limited by the ABM treaty and theater missile defenses, which are not."
That understanding is important because the Pentagon wants to build new theater missile defense systems to protect troops in bases overseas.
In the area of conventional weapons, the two sides reported progress in a dispute over the deployment of Russian tanks and personnel on the southern and northern flanks of Russia. The Russians have kept more armored vehicles in those areas, including the volatile Caucasus region, than the 1990 treaty allows, and the Clinton Administration has sought to work out a compromise. Another meeting on the subject between lower-level negotiators is set for May.
On another issue, Mr. Clinton requested that the Russians explain why they were building a mammoth underground military complex at Yaman-Tau mountain in the southern Urals. American officials have speculated that the complex could be anything from a command center for nuclear weapons to an underground weapons production complex, and they have been disturbed by the secrecy shrouding the project.
Mr. Yeltsin said the issue could be taken up by each side's specialists.
Mr. Yeltsin repeatedly referred to Mr. Clinton affectionately as Bill. And the two men exchanged a big hug as Mr. Clinton left the Kremlin for a meeting in the American Ambassador's residence, known as Spaso House. That meeting was with a dozen other political figures, including Mr. Zyuganov.
As he began the Spaso House session, Mr. Clinton deflected questions from reporters about whether he would be able to cooperate with Mr. Zyuganov should he win the Russian election.
"The Russian people will make that decision," he said, "and we will proceed accordingly. I'm not going to get into this election. I spent two days staying out of it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A New Phone Merger Creates a Giant in the East
The merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, to be announced today, will create the second-largest telephone company in the United States after AT&T -- with $27 billion in sales, 127,600 employees and 36 million customers in 12 states. The impact on consumers is far from certain, since the two companies do not compete directly. [Page A1.]
 
The changes for Nynex -- in attitudes toward customers, regulators, competitors and its workers -- could be dramatic if Bell Atlantic's chairman, Raymond W. Smith, takes command of the combined company. [D5.]
 
Trade Talks Inch Forward
Representatives of four major world economies discussed the possibility of opening domestic telecommunications markets to foreign companies, but said it was questionable that a worldwide accord would be reached by April 30. [D2.]
 
Dole Sees Minimum Wage Increase
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and presumed Republican Presidential candidate, conceded that an increase in the minimum wage was inevitable. [A1.]
 
How Rude! How Marketable!
By offering scathing political commentary, making merciless fun of his guests and generally being rude, the radio talk show host Don Imus attracts listeners on a whopping 80 stations around the country. Ten have signed on in the last few weeks, since Mr. Imus called President Clinton a pot-smoking weasel at a dinner for radio and television correspondents. Along with the listeners, Mr. Imus is also drawing in blue-chip advertisers like American Express, Bell Atlantic, the New York Stock Exchange and Mobil. [D9.]
 
Double Take's Second Chance
Citing what it called an intoxication by "inchoate expressions of self and celebrity" in a "sea of journals devoted to money and fame, power and politics," the Lyndhurst Foundation has given $10 million to Double Take magazine, a quarterly journal of literature, reporting and photojournalism that lost $1.5 million in its first year of publication. One of the editors is the psychiatrist Robert Coles. [D9.]
 
Hollywood Frowns on Movieoke Idea
Wouldn't it be a gas to dub your voice in place of, say, Humphrey Bogart's in "Casablanca" or Madeline Kahn's in "Young Frankenstein"? Two Hollywood multimedia types are developing a CD-ROM title called Movieoke that would let you do that. And because you could do it at home, it wouldn't even involve the public humiliation that karaoke does. But movie studios are not amused and are posing a threat to the project over copyright issues. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D6.]
 
Testing On-Line Advertising Waters
Betting on the notion that electronic mail is the most valued use of the Internet, a new on-line service opening today is giving subscribers E-mail accounts in exchange for demographic information and the use of part of their computer screens as display space for advertisers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]
 
Software Courtship Doomed?
Cheyenne Software and McAfee Associates seem to be putting the divorce before the marriage. Because of bad blood between the companies' chief executives -- it was brought on by an offer by McAfee to acquire Cheyenne -- analysts say McAfee is unlikely to win Cheyenne's hand. [D4.]
 
Following Uncle Sam's Rules
There is no shortage of Federal regulations governing business. But a plethora of World Wide Web sites offering access to Government guidelines is making it easier for companies to insure that they are in compliance. Taking In the Sites. [D10]

HEADLINE: The City's New Fire Boss: From the Ladders to the Limousine

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As his black Crown Victoria raced across the Brooklyn Bridge, Thomas J. Von Essen, the city's new Fire Commissioner, was already five minutes late for his first meeting with his new boss, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Not accustomed to having a chauffeur, Mr. Von Essen had slid reflexively into the front passenger seat, instead of the back. Once under way, he realized he didn't have so much as a legal pad. "I'm going over there without even a plan," he said last Wednesday, shaking his head. "I'm going to make a real fool out of myself." 
 For Mr. Von Essen, 50, who will be ceremonially sworn in today and who will be the first Fire Commissioner ever to have led the firefighters' union, there is more than a slight sense of vertigo at being in charge of a department where only a short while ago he held the rank of firefighter. More jarring is that he is becoming the very official he often fought as president of the union.
Of all the careers he had envisioned -- lawyer, teacher, labor leader -- running the Fire Department, even as a lieutenant or captain, was not on his list.
"I never was a person who wanted to be a boss," he said. There was a brief silence in the car before Mr. Von Essen, his driver and an aide burst into laughter. "And now look at me. I'm the grand poobah, or whatever they call it, right?"
Despite his own reluctance and criticism from those who feel he has betrayed the union by switching sides, Mr. Von Essen has quietly begun to put his own stamp on the job, three weeks after Mr. Giuliani surprised the Fire Department and union leaders alike by choosing him to replace Howard Safir, who became Police Commissioner.
Unlike Mr. Safir, known for unquestioning loyalty to City Hall and for shutting out those who disagreed with him, Mr. Von Essen has begun with an open door, even on the most contentious issue he has inherited, the Giuliani administration's plan to remove fire alarm boxes from city streets.
On his first day in office one week ago, he met with David Rosenzweig, president of the Fire Alarm Dispatchers Benevolent Association, the union representing fire alarm dispatchers, who has been among the most vocal opponents of firebox removal.
The Mayor argues that the boxes are relics that lead to false alarms, while many in the sharply divided City Council say that removing them leaves residents with no quick way to report fires on the streets.
Mr. Von Essen, who was careful to take no position on the issue while heading the union, emerged from the meeting in support of a new administration plan that would remove about half the boxes. And Mr. Rosenzweig still praised his approach.
"With Safir, it was all personal," said Mr. Rosenzweig, whose union has accused the department of penalizing outspoken members. "At least, Tom gave us a very nice reception, got us in to see him on his first day. We could make our case."
As he takes over a department that many have said largely manages itself, Mr. Von Essen has also made it clear he will not distance himself from the gains he achieved as leader of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, even if they become issues the Mayor asks him to oppose.
"I don't see how I can fight passionately against something I really believe is right," he said in his office at Fire Department headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, nodding toward a wall to make his point.
The only thing he had hung there was a copy of a bill passed two years ago in the Legislature allowing firefighters to receive disability benefits for several types of cancer, even if there is no clear proof the cancers are caused by fighting fires or dealing with hazardous materials.
"I am very proud of that," Mr. Von Essen said. "I would never be able in good conscience to speak against the importance of that bill. If the Mayor wants to talk about limited resources and the inability to afford it, then I can talk about that."
For his part, the Mayor said yesterday that he was not worried about Mr. Von Essen's ability to change hats. "I selected him because he understands the problems of the Fire Department and the issues there probably better than anyone," Mr. Giuliani said. "When people come into government they always have to leave behind another perspective. Tommy has the ability to grow like that."
Mr. Von Essen's supporters and critics say his independent streak, tempered with just enough political acumen, allowed him to take over the firefighters' union in 1993, when it was fractured with infighting, and to unite its executive board. He succeeded even as he supported policy changes pushed by the Mayor, changes unpopular with the rank-and-file, like training firefighters to respond to medical emergencies and merging the department with the Emergency Medical Service.
He took those positions, say many who have worked with him and against him, because he honestly believed they were right. "I don't believe for a second that there was any strategic planning on his part to do this to get something for himself down the line," said Jim Grossman, a former spokesman for the union. But others say Mr. Von Essen also chose to fight loudly for the changes, because he recognized it could pay off in winning concessions from an administration with little money or patience with unions.
"I think he just decided he was going to be on the train rather than under it," said Tony Bernardo, the president of the union that represents E.M.S. workers, paraphrasing a slogan often used by Mr. Safir.
In the end, the union protected itself from nearly all budget cuts and won back part of a work-force cut suffered under the Koch administration: restoring a fifth firefighter on 60 of 138 engine companies.
Mr. Von Essen's critics, including Carmine DeRoss, the union's combative Staten Island delegate who ran against Mr. Von Essen for the presidency in 1993, contend, however, that he used the presidency of the firefighters' union unabashedly to gain political influence and to curry favor with Mr. Giuliani, who has taken Mr. Von Essen to Yankees games and has seemed remarkably at ease with the union.
Those who know both men say the Mayor and Mr. Von Essen hit it off instantly after meeting during the 1993 campaign, when the union endorsed Mr. Giuliani and ran phone banks for him at union headquarters. "I think they have kind of the same world view," said a colleague of Mr. Von Essen, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Von Essen grew up in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the son of a police sergeant. His family moved to Ozone Park, Queens, but he spent his freshman year at Bishop Loughlin High School when two students named Rudolph W. Giuliani and Peter J. Powers were juniors. "I never really knew them, though," he said, "because I transferred out to follow the girl who would later be my wife."
The Commissioner has been married to his wife, Rita, now for 28 years. She works for a real estate company in Garden City, L.I.
Like the Mayor, the Commissioner's friends say, Mr. Von Essen also approaches issues with a studious dedication and old-fashioned discipline. Occasionally, he, too, displays a short fuse. (In the late 1980's, said one former union official, he threw a punch at a delegate during a union board meeting, missed, and hit another union official near him.)
After a start at college, he then went into the Navy during the Vietnam War, serving on a submarine based in New London, Conn. "I think I had always thought I wasn't going to be in a physical kind of profession growing up, but being in that submarine really gave me an appreciation for people who work closely together and confront danger," he said.
Although he had never really wanted to be a firefighter, Mr. Von Essen joined the department in 1970, he said, "basically to support myself" until he could get through St. Francis College, where he later received his bachelor's degree in economics. But he ended up in Ladder Company 42 in the South Bronx, one of the busiest stations in the city at a time when arson fires raged through the area.
"He could have transferred out like a lot of others, but it got under his skin and he kept at it," said Van Elsing, a retired firefighter who took Mr. Von Essen under his wing when he came to the company. It was Mr. Elsing who started the young firefighter's union career, all but forcing him to become the ladder company's union delegate because he saw how Mr. Von Essen's determination set him apart from the other men. "He went in for a lot of ribbing because he was so serious, and he was always studying," he said. "But when it came to fires he was someone you knew you could count on."
Those were simpler days. During his first appearance before the City Council as the Commissioner, Mr. Von Essen was booed repeatedly by residents of Bushwick, his boyhood neighborhood, people who do not want the department to remove the fireboxes. At one point, clearly frustrated as Council members asked how the elderly in poor neighborhoods would report fires, he interrupted: "I mean, how many elderly people you think are actually running to alarm boxes to report fires?" A hiss went up from the crowd.
"I always compared firefighting to being like on a high school football team," he said later. "It was a physical beating every time you ran out. But when you came back you just felt so good about it. It wasn't like other jobs where you have to lie and steal on a regular basis."
After the City Council meeting, as he worked his way through a crowd of reporters, he added:
"Compared to what I'm doing now, even union work was a lot less complicated. All I had to do then was complain."
