HEADLINE: Giuliani Says He Is Open to Scaling Down Stadium Proposal

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
After weeks of touting the creation of a $1 billion multipurpose Yankee Stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was open to other possibilities, even to the construction of a smaller, cheaper baseball-only ball park.
"Some people feel that a single-use stadium would be easier to finance and would cost the city less money," Mr. Giuliani said. "Other people feel that multi-use, because it would bring in football and major events, would bring the city more revenue. We haven't come anywhere close to a decision on that yet. It's open for discussion, debate. We have an open mind about it." 
 When asked about his support for a multi-use stadium, the Mayor said: "I've said that's one of the claims that's made. There are other ways to do it."
His comments came in the wake of increasing questions about how the city would finance a multipurpose stadium as it struggles to balance its budget. While Mr. Giuliani has never ruled out the other stadium alternatives, including keeping the Yankees in the Bronx, he has spent the past few weeks aggressively promoting the more costly and ambitious multipurpose stadium that was first recommended by a consulting firm hired by New York City, the state and George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the Yankees.
But in the weeks since its release, the specific proposal for the giant stadium -- and the consultants' plan in general -- has been criticized by some stadium experts, politicians and baseball fans who complain that not only would it cost too much but also that it would clog traffic to the Lincoln Tunnel and buck a nationwide trend toward smaller, more intimate baseball fields.
A final decision has yet to be made about the stadium's future, and a financial plan has yet to be released assessing the alternatives sites. Indeed, Mr. Steinbrenner has not said whether he will even abandon the Bronx stadium that has been the home of the Yankees for 73 years. But the fear that the Yankees will abandon New York City if a new stadium is not built has ignited eager speculation about the various sites under consideration, and almost every new utterance by the Mayor on the topic has been weighed and analysed and held up to the light as if each public pronouncement were a tiny crystal ball with the power to show what is to come.
Thus, it was no surprise that the description of a rift between the Mayor and Gov. George E. Pataki over the future of Yankee Stadium, which appears in an article in today's New York magazine, attracted attention. The Mayor made his latest comments in response to that article, in which Charles A. Gargano, the economic adviser to the Governor, expresses doubts that a multiple-use stadium would attract the conventions, concerts and trade shows necessary to keep it afloat.
"What I have learned so far is that often these facilities don't have much use beyond baseball and football," Mr. Gargano was quoted as saying. "And a Manhattan location would not significantly change this."
Governor Pataki's aides have said privately that they worried that the multipurpose stadium proposal was being advocated to the exclusion of other, less costly alternatives.
Since the city is counting on the state to help finance the stadium, these concerns are impossible to ignore. The Mayor and his aides have said the city and the state could issue bonds for it and pay them off by tapping revenues from ticket sales, luxury boxes, advertising and even the exclusive rights to sell beer.
And since the consultants' report -- by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum -- said that a two-sport, retractable-dome stadium situated near the Hudson River between 30th and 33d Streets would bring more business and more money to the city, the Mayor had touted that plan as the one that made the most economic sense for the city. Such a stadium -- which could house football games, conventions and concerts as well as baseball -- would generate revenue estimated at $199 million, while a baseball-only stadium would produce $129.6 million.
Echoing that view last week, the Mayor said: "If you want a personal preference as opposed to a business decision, my personal preference would be for a single-use baseball field. I think they're more fun. But that doesn't mean that that's the best decision for the city of New York."
But with a $1 billion price tag, the stadium would likely be the most expensive in the nation's history, costing three to four times more than highly praised ball parks in Baltimore and Cleveland. And stadium experts doubt that revenues generated from increased attendance, concessions and advertising would be enough to cover the financing of the deal.
In a measure of some of the skepticism over the proposal, a poll released last week showed that 70 percent of the New Yorkers surveyed said they wanted the stadium to stay exactly where it is -- in the Bronx. And doubtful Democrats in the City Council introduced a resolution for public hearings on a possible move.
The skepticism even extended to Republicans in Albany, where some of Mr. Pataki's aides worried that Mr. Giuliani was pushing too hard for a plan that required additional study. And they also worried that by vigorously expressing his support for a new stadium, the Mayor was giving too much leverage to Mr. Steinbrenner, who has not said publicly that the Yankees were leaving the Bronx.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he and Mr. Pataki have never been at odds over the issue. "The Governor and I have very close communications about that," he said. "We probably see it in precisely the same way."
And how does the Governor see it?
Interviewed after a speech at the United Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew in Manhattan, Mr. Pataki said, "I think the best thing would be to convince George Steinbrenner to keep the Yankees in the Bronx and to have the Bronx have the improvements for parking and transportation, improvements to the stadium, if necessary."
"If the only alternative is a different site, and the city comes forward with a proposal where they seek the help of the state," he said, "we'll be pleased to look at it and try to work cooperatively with them, understanding that we're not going to commit a large amount of tax dollars to what is essentially a private purpose."

HEADLINE: Help New York's Media Entrepreneurs Now

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Our organization was the lead sponsor of the New York new-media industry survey (editorial, April 16). We conceived the idea, applied for the grant and directed execution of the Coopers & Lybrand survey. 
 New media are an example of a model of economic development that has worked wonders in other regions in the last decade, driven by entrepreneurs who create new industry clusters at a regional level.
Metropolitan areas like San Francisco (computers and software), San Diego (biotechnology) and Nashville (health-care services) have benefited from the sweat and pluck of entrepreneurs. National statistics support the role of small business as the generator of job growth in the last decade.
New York has not given this trend much heed. Our economic-development culture is heavily invested in supporting the monolithic private and public institutions that have been the mainstays of the economy but cannot provide growth today. At the same time, our tax code has tilted the playing field against the entrepreneur.
You highlight these obstacles to growth, but have no call to action to remove them. Yes, the fiscal vise on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is tight, but the ultimate solution to the problem is growth in the private sector.
Any delay in the effort to create a fertile economic climate for entrepreneurs sends the wrong signal to these job creators. The Giuliani administration has proposed a number of policy changes that will improve the lot of entrepreneurs. When considering the tradeoffs that the city's fiscal condition requires, we urge the administration to protect these measures from the temptation to wait until next year.
 
BRIAN T. HOREY
Pres., New York New Media Assn.
New York, April 18, 1996

HEADLINE: Brave New Ball Game

BYLINE: By Raymond J. Keating and Matthew Carolan; Raymond J. Keating is chief economist with the Small Business Survival Committee, a private Washington-based group. Matthew Carolan is executive editor of National Review.

 BODY:
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Scarsdale, has offered the quintessential New York solution to keeping the Yankees in the Bronx. If George Steinbrenner tries to flee to New Jersey, invoke eminent domain and have the state take over the team.
Brodsky no doubt figures that since Yankee Stadium is government-owned -- stadium socialism, if you will -- the Yankees might as well be, too. Given New York's history, we can imagine the following scenario: 
 In a fit of Albany bipartisanship, Republicans and Democrats vote to seize control of the Yankees. Immediately, a Department of Baseball Development (D.B.D.) is created, and for his bold vision Brodsky is named commissioner. With a first-year budget of almost $1 billion, the department buys Yankee Stadium from New York City.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announces that the city will put the money from the sale into a new Baseball Assistance Ticket program: Under B.A.T., the city will guarantee every resident'sright to attend games, no matter what his or her income. Public Advocate Mark Green states:"Yankee baseball cannot become elitist, the domain of only those individuals who can afford to buy a ticket."
The Department of Baseball Development's Office of Baseball Protocol and Sensitivity holds a news conference, during which community activists ask New Yorkers to stop calling the Yankees the Bronx Bombers -- a nickname, they say, with a negative connotation in the Bronx. Fernando Ferrer, the borough president, declares:"The Bronx is a vital community, not a bombed-out city."
Brodsky ends the Yankees' relationships with the Madison Square Garden and WPIX television stations and WABC radio, and games are broadcast on public television and radio stations. While Phil Rizzuto agrees to announce a handful of games, the other Yankee announcers leave. Officials announce the new Yankee broadcast team of Mario Cuomo and Alan Chartock, the Albany radio host. Reacting to the reuniting of the former public-radio duo, one public radio bureaucrat declares: "If they bring the same compassion and compelling insights to baseball that they brought to New York State politics, the horizons of baseball fans will be expanded greatly. I see a new era for sports and social awareness."
Meanwhile, the state budget is once again late, and the Yankees, citing lack of funds, forfeit their first dozen games.
When the season gets under way, the Cuomo-Chartock team brings protests from the New York Conservative Party. Its chairman, Michael Long, opposes Cuomo's ramblings about Newt Gingrich, Rush Limbaugh and the need for infrastructure improvements. For balance, the conservative columnist and baseball savant George Will joins the broadcasts. Ideological conflicts lead Rizzuto to retire once again, declaring: "Holy cow, what a bunch of huckleberries!"
PBS adds a post-game show with Charlie Rose as host. In an interview, Rose is punched in the nose by the Cincinnati Reds manager, Ray Knight, who explains: "I couldn't get a word in edgewise."
The Department of Baseball Development, citing job creation measures, moves all Yankee minor league teams to New York and builds new stadiums for them. Debates rage in Albany over Yankee salary differentials: Is there a glass ceiling over weak-hitting shortstops? State job-retraining programs expand to meet the needs of players forced out of baseball because of deteriorating skills. The Yankees struggle to emerge from last place, and fans begin longing for the good old days under Steinbrenner.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: Unearthing the Tales Of a Lost Settlement;
Glimpses of Black History in a Place That Faded From Maps and Memory

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
They are easy to overlook, these four woodframe houses, simple and spare, the paint peeling from their facades.
Except that on a block lined with a towering housing project, they stand alone in a clearing, tucked behind a fence on Bergen Street in Brooklyn. Except that when surrounding buildings in Bedford-Stuyvesant were razed and replaced, they somehow survived. Today, they are all that remains of one of the earliest and largest settlements of free black people in the North, and their presence give context to lives lived in a distant time. 
 "Each one of the houses has a different story, has had a different life," said Joan Maynard, an artist who has made the preservation of these houses her life's work.
The Hunterfly Road Historic Houses are the last remnant of Weeksville, a community that came to be in the 1830's and thrived for nearly half a century before fading from maps and memory. At least 40 families lived there, and its population often rose when black people in Manhattan and on Long Island fled to escape discrimination and racial violence.
The saga of these houses, and the effort to preserve them, has in many ways mirrored the struggles and triumphs of the community where they stand. For more than 20 years, the Society for the Preservation of Weeksville and Bedford-Stuyvesant History has struggled to restore the four dwellings and create a museum. But despite their status as a city landmark, the houses have suffered a setback with nearly every step forward.
One house was burned to the ground in 1973 and had to be rebuilt. Another was nearly destroyed by vandals. Last February, a car crashed into the house nearest Bergen Street, destroying renovations that had taken two years to pay. The houses have been closed to the public until money can be raised to repair the damage.
Though the society receives city and state funds for educational programs, it relies on donations, membership dues and admission fees to pay salaries and other operating expenses.
Despite spending roughly $1 million on renovations, the society estimates that it still needs half a million dollars to complete work on all four houses. Only one has been completely restored. Others need their foundations shored up, their cracks filled in, their battered clapboards removed and replaced.
Inside, the relics of Weeksville and its time are on display: a Civil War boot, an old steam iron, a pair of shackles worn by a slave. In one house, there is a mannequin displaying the dress Harriet Etta Lane, a Weeksville resident, wore on her wedding day in 1908. And in the kitchen there is a butter churn and a washboard to remind visitors of how hard day-to-day life could be.
In two houses, the re-creation of history is left largely to the imagination. The society hopes to ultimately fill them with artifacts found at the site, and exhibits that illustrate the major restoration effort the houses needed and the importance of archeology in connecting to one's past. Members of the society have also talked with city officials about constructing a reception building nearby, with classrooms and administrative space.
The society believes that the houses, built between 1840 and 1883, stand as symbols of perseverance and possibility in a part of Brooklyn where poverty is high and hope sometimes dim.
"We have had people say, 'You should pick up the houses and move,' " Ms. Maynard, the society's executive director, said. "I said, 'This is exactly where it needs to be. It needs to be here, where many of the people have no knowledge of their own history.' "
For years, Weeksville was all but forgotten, and the peak-roofed homes off Bergen Street were simply known as the houses on the alley. The "alley" was Hunterfly Road, a once important thoroughfare. And most of the houses along the street had been toppled in the name of urban renewal. But the four cottages were hidden by larger buildings facing the main streets, and so they were spared.
"The very fact the houses still exist is really a miracle," said Claudine Brown, who is the director of the arts program at the nonprofit Nathan Cummings Foundation and who has worked with the Weeksville preservation effort. "The community really changed as a result of very early urban renewal. New housing was built, schools were built that replaced the earlier schools for colored children. It's almost as if those houses still existed as an afterthought."
From its beginning, Weeksville was a sanctuary for Southern black people fleeing slavery as well as Northern blacks escaping hostility and sporadic racial violence. It was farmland and some local historians believe that the first families to settle in the area were spurred to leave by the anti-abolition riots in Manhattan in 1834.
Weeksville was named for James Weeks, a stevedore from Virginia who bought a plot there in 1838. Though no one is certain, historians believe that the community was bounded by Fulton Street on the north, East New York Avenue on the south, Ralph Avenue on the east and Troy Avenue on the west. It quickly became a social, religious and political nexus for black residents in Brooklyn and home to various institutions ranging from an orphanage to the African Civilization Society. Several of its churches were stations along the Underground Railroad. And during the 1863 draft riots in Manhattan and other flare-ups of racial unrest, blacks took ferries across the East River and traveled from cities like Newtown, L.I., -- now a part of Queens -- to seek refuge in Weeksville.
"I think the physical location of Weeksville says something about slavery because it was established by blacks who had only recently been freed from slavery themselves," said Dr. Craig S. Wilder, a professor of history at Williams College who has studied Weeksville. "It was isolated. It was a place where that free black community could establish its institutions, its own social relations and its own community support system."
By the late 1800's, the physical place known as Weeksville began to disappear, with many of its homes and institutions torn down to make way for new streets and dwellings. It survived in public memory for a while, but historians say that by the 1950's its name was hardly remembered. It was not until the 1960's, during a rebirth of interest in local and black American history, that a search began for the once-upon-a-time neighborhood. The four houses were discovered in 1968 when a historian and a pilot flying overhead noticed a small row of woodframe homes on a hidden lane.
The houses, eventually bought by the Society for the Preservation of Weeksville, were made a New York City landmark in 1970 and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1972. But many believe that the location that made Weeksville an ideal place in the 19th century for black people seeking new lives is now an obstacle to attracting more visitors and funds.
"We're not close to a transportation hub," Ms. Maynard said. "We're not in a glamorous part of town. But because the history is here, we've got to turn this thing around. That's the challenge."
Only bits and pieces are known about those who lived in three of the houses. But a former resident is still alive to tell her story.
Mary Bernice Jenkins moved into 1698 Bergen Street in 1924, when she was 3. Her father and grandmother were born in the community and she remembers when trolley cars rolled through the streets and horse-drawn carts brought bread and vegetables to her family's front door.
The name Weeksville had been forgotten, she said, but the essence of that community remained.
"It was very warm," said Mrs. Jenkins, whose sister lived in the home until the late 1970's. "Everybody knew everybody else. Kids seemed to congregate in my yard, so if mothers were looking for someone, they just came, peeked over the fence and there their child was."
At Weeksville, the past holds hands with the present. Every summer, there is a Weeksville Family Festival featuring black cowboys, musicians and horses. Neighbors from the housing project across the street tend a community garden there, planting eggplant, tomatoes and collard greens.
And behind the houses, members of the Weeksville preservation society have planted three trees: one for the tennis great Arthur Ashe, another for Nelson Mandela and a third for a young man from the neighborhood who was killed.
"We can't have a fabulous-looking house and everybody is suffering around us," said Ms. Maynard, who hopes that the houses can bring tourism to the area and foster new businesses and pride within the community. "We feel we can be a part of that revitalization. We're trying to nurture confidence that can help the present-day community reach its potential."
Ms. Maynard is planning a summer conference on historic preservation and economic development that she hopes will bring visitors and recognition to Brooklyn and, in particular, Weeksville.
"I understand there are many doors that have to be opened and we have to find different keys for different doors," she said. "We know if we get this place fixed right, people are going to find their way here."

HEADLINE: Dutch Re-Create a 1936 Anti-Nazi Art Show

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM

 BODY:
As part of the Nazis' plan to make the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin a showcase of their ideological and racial superiority, Josef Goebbels, the regime's propaganda chief, excluded Jews, leftists and purveyors of "degenerate" art from an Art Olympiad organized to coincide with the games.
In response, a group of Dutch artists and intellectuals challenged the Nazis by calling for a boycott of the event, which had accompanied the summer Olympic games since 1912 and in which painters, architects, writers and musicians were also awarded medals for excellence. 
 The Dutch group organized a counterexhibition in Amsterdam, "The Olympics Under Dictatorship," which brought together 300 works by 150 artists from half a dozen countries. The show also included documentation, cartoons, photographs and drawings illustrating Nazi repression and manipulation of education, science, theater, literature, film and music.
Now, 60 years after that exhibition and during another Olympic year, the Amsterdam Municipal Archives are presenting a reconstruction of part of "The Olympics Under Dictatorship" to pay tribute to artists wh' dared speak out when most European governments were still eager to appease Hitler. The show runs here through May 19 and will be on display at the Sports Museum in Berlin in July to coincide with the Summer Gam's in Atlanta.
The organizers of the 1936 show did not disguise their disgust at the Nazis' attempt to hijack culture. The initials of the show's name in Dutch, "De Olympiade Onder Dictatuur," or D.O.O.D, spell "death" in Dutch. The show's poster, which was pasted up around Amsterdam, portrayed a shot-putter standing in a stadium, his arms trapped by a swastika.
"Let this exhibition become a world manifestation of the will of all bearers of culture that their knowledge and their art may remain free, a blessing to civilization and humanity," the organizers of the show wrote. And they added: "It is not concerned with politics. It is directed solely against the violation of culture."
Not all the works displayed i' 1936 could be found. A good number were destroyed or disappeared during World War II. The Dutch artist Peter Alma burned some of his anti-Nazi sketches when Germany occupied the Netherlands in 1940. Some of Karl Schwesig's drawings called "In the Torture Chamber," which resulted from his own arrest in Germany in 1934, were lost in the Soviet Union. A sculpture by Hildo Krop is anchored to a wall at the United Nations building in Geneva.
Several of the original exhibit'rs also died in German death camps, among them Otto Freundlich and Chris Lebeau. A handful of them, though, are still alive, among them Eva Besnyo, the Hungarian photographer; Carel Weight, the British painter; Henri Jannot, the French painter, and Boris Taslitsky, a Paris-based artist who survived his imprisonment in Buchenwald. All sent works to the reconstruction.
Making this exhibition doubly interesting are recently discovered documents showing that in response to intense pressure from German diplomats, the Dutch authorities insisted on the removal of 19 works of art from the 1936 show on the ground that they were insulting to Hitler. Further, when the show later traveled to Rotterdam, it was closed by the Dutch police after only a few days.
By displaying Dutch police reports addressed to Willem de Vlugt, who was the Mayor of Amsterdam, the new exhibition also captures the intense social unrest gripping the Netherlands at the time, with the conservative Government of the day seemingly more concerned about leftist agitation among disgruntled unemployed workers than about the growing threat posed by Nazi Germany.
Because many artists were lefpists and even members of the Communist Party, the Government viewed them as potential troublemakers, not least when they attacked the dictatorships in Italy and Germany, regimes with which the Netherlands preferred to maintain cordial relations. Even before cracking down on "The Olympics Under Dictatorship," Mr. de Vlugt censored movies, plays and exhibitions he deemed "offensive."
Speaking at the inauguration of the new exhibition in March, the German Ambassador to The Hague, Wilhelm Haas, noted that by 1936 Dutch public opinion already viewed the Nazis with repugnance. "Your politicians, however, were not the only ones in Europe who completely underestimated the nature and the danger of National Socialist polici's," Mr. Haas said. "By meeting German demands, they thought the national sovereignty of a neutral nation could be safeguarded." And he added, "Apparently, they yielded more readily to German pressure when criticism of Germany came from the left."
Still, even though Amsterdam's municipal authorities refused to allow the show to be held in public buildings and some of the most virulently anti-Nazi works were removed, when "The Olympics Under Dictatorship" opened on Aug. 1, 1936, it nonetheless included many works and documents that the German consul in Amsterdam, A. E. Jung, described as "sheer provocation" against Germany.
The organizers of the exhibition invited artists from the Netherlands and neig'boring countries as well as many German artists who had already fled the Nazi regime to contribute works. Among foreign exhibitors were Max Ernst, Jacques Lipchitz, Marcel Gromaire, Georges Vantongerloo, Fernand Legep, Ossip Zadkine and Lucien Pissarro, although many artists were less well known.
With the notable exception of drawings and cartoons in the documentation section of the show, many works were not explicitly political, like Robert Capa's photographs of Holy Week celebrations in Seville and a landscape by Pissarro, although the artists were making a political statement simply by participating in the 1936 exhibition.
Among the 127 works by 73 artists in the reconstruction, however, some directly attack the Nazis or denounce police repression and torture, while a good many mirror the anxiety felt by artists about Europe's deepening nightmare. "The Hordes," by Ernst, for instance, shows frightened brown figures against a pale blue background. "The 20th Century," a painting by Christopher Nevinson, a British artist, portrays Rodin's "Thinker" surrounded by bayonets, warplanes, cannons and burning buildings.
Nola Hatterman's "Friends," a drawing of two men, one white, one black, looks uncontroversial today, but in 1936 it was a clear protest against racism. Similarly, Peter Alma's two oils, "Leftist Front" and "Solidarity Between Workers and Peasants," underline the ideological dimension of the social struggle in prewar Europe.
Carry van Lakerverld, the curator of the reconstruction, noted the relative absence of abstract art, which she attributed to the fact that most of the artists were leftists. "They wanted to express their political involvement both in form and contents," she said. "They therefore chose themes from everyday life and figuration because abstract art would not appeal to the working classes."
While the 1996 show throws light on both government appeasement and artistic courage in 1936, the purpose of the reconstruction is also to remind viewers of the continuing relevancy of the issues raised 60 years ago. "It makes people ask what they would do in a similar situation," Andre Hirs, an official at the Amsterdam Municipal Archives, noted. "And let's face it, there are still plenty of threats to freedom around the world today."

HEADLINE: Dole Has Led Senate to Legislative Success

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Sour Spring for Mr. Dole" (editorial, April 21): 
 In your misguided effort to chronicle phantom legislative "embarrassments" for Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, you succeed in embarrassing only yourself.
Your biggest gaffe is your misrepresentation of Senator Dole's efforts last week to make health insurance more affordable and more available.
Senator Dole offered about $9.5 billion in paid-for improvements to the bill.
These included increasing the tax deductibility of health insurance premiums for the self-employed. He also proposed tax deductibility for long-term care insurance and expenses, and penalty-free Individual Retirement Account withdrawals to pay health insurance premiums while unemployed, as well as provisions cracking down on health care fraud and abuse.
While medical savings accounts were removed on a close vote, they represented only a small part of what Senator Dole proposed. The Senate adopted the rest of his changes -- nearly $8 billion worth -- by a vote of 98 to 0!
That was a substantial victory and enhanced the kind of bipartisan health care changes that Senator Dole has long fought for but that have been blocked for most of this Administration by President Clinton and the Democratic leadership.
Far from a "sour spring," this year has seen Senator Dole lead the Senate to a record of sweet success and break the deadlock on priority after priority.
This year alone, he has delivered the line-item veto, antiterrorism legislation with overdue death penalty appeals reform, a seven-year farm bill with a strong conservation package, telecommunications reform, regulatory relief for small businesses, an increase in the Social Security earnings limit, common-sense legal reform and a tightening of the screws on Fidel Castro.
The list goes on, and it can get longer -- especially if President Clinton and his Congressional allies want to put the American people ahead of their increasing political gamesmanship.
 
CLARKSON HINE
Washington, April 22, 1996
 
The writer is press secretary to Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Higher Against Mark In Side Effect of Italian Election

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the German mark, which weakened against the Italian lira and other European currencies after a center-left coalition won a majority in both houses of the Italian Parliament.
The dollar was also bolstered against the mark after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said that he welcomed the dollar's recent rise against the mark and "wouldn't have any problems if it kept on going to a certain extent." 
 His remarks, which came after officials from the Group of Seven leading industrial nations met in Washington over the weekend, helped drive the dollar as high as 1.5190 marks, its highest rate since Feb. 19, 1994.
The mark's slide began after the weekend election in Italy added to optimism that a stable government could soon emerge there. The mark fell to an 18-month low against the lira. When the mark falls against other European currencies, it frequently falls against the dollar, too, as speculators seek further opportunities to sell marks.
The mark also continues to be hurt by last week's cut in German interest rates. The Bundesbank, the central bank, lowered two important rates by half a percentage point on Thursday.
Lower interest rates tend to weaken a currency by reducing the yields available on investments there.
"People are afraid of marks," said Hans Boman, a currency trader at Swedbank.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5168 marks, up from 1.5120 on Friday. The dollar slipped to 106.65 yen, from 107.36 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5123, from $1.5140.
The dollar was weaker against the yen after Japanese and United States officials expressed satisfaction with the current exchange rate, leading traders to surmise that officials of the two nations would not seek to push the dollar any higher.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said yesterday that he was satisfied with the dollar's gains over the last year.
The apparent shift in attitude hurt the dollar. "Dollar-yen was curtailed by these comments," said Karl Halligan, a strategic currency trader at CIC Bank New York.

HEADLINE: Siege Is Subplot in Town's Survival Drama

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: JORDAN, Mont., April 20

 BODY:
For a town that has barely a tumbleweed's toehold in the high plains of Eastern Montana, life has not lacked for drama around here -- even before arrival of the anti-government fugitives known as the Freemen.
In the four weeks that Federal authorities have been locked in a sort of velvet-gloved standoff with the Freemen, not a shot has been fired from either side. F.B.I. agents complain about getting fat on farm suppers and bored with a watch-and-wait routine as predictable as prairie winds. 
 But all around the island of the siege, people are engaged in a daily struggle to keep their little hold of fast-fading American life from disappearing from the map altogether.
Real drama, says rancher Bev Murnion, her face turned out of the lacerating wind, is getting $300 for the same size cow that brought $500 two years ago, or watching a newborn calf die after a sudden cold snap. A real siege is when a chinook wind melts a foot of snow, and then the standing water freezes at night, and Ruth Coulter still has to drive 30 miles to deliver the mail to three patrons -- down from more than 50 mail stops when she started the job 47 years ago.
A real standoff, says Dan Muniak, a physician's assistant who is the de facto hospital for an area larger than 3,000 square miles, is trying to convince a stubborn ranch hand who is bleeding on his bar stool that he has to take a dozen stitches now, not after the bar closes.
"I do everything from womb to tomb," said Mr. Muniak, whose friends sometimes call him Dr. Maniac, though only in jest. Medicine, such as it is, is one of the fragile pillars on which civilization in Garfield County rests. Mr. Muniak, 50, is the part-time ambulance driver, the part-time X-ray technician, the part-time secretary and the full-time guy who gets called at any hour for a medical emergency.
His hours are so long that his wife took out a big advertisement in the Jordan weekly newspaper not long ago to complain that she had not been able to snuggle much with her husband and that he had missed some golden moments of their lives. He promised, though not in print, to work on it.
The last doctor in town died two years ago, just a few years short of his 100th birthday; he started practicing in the 1920's.
Garfield County, bigger than the state of Connecticut, has only about 1,400 people. What is happening here is going on elsewhere in the northern Plains: people are leaving, farms are closing, real estate prices are flat. There is also much prosperity among the ranchers and wheat farmers who own large tracts of family land. But the trend is toward depopulation, and with beef prices plummeting 40 percent in the last year alone, toward fewer cattle ranches.
This may be flyover country to most Americans, but from the ground, there is not so much as a jet's roar to break the whine of the wind.
Everyone on Main Street in Jordan -- a dusty affair with a drainage ditch going down the middle -- has a story to tell not unlike that of George Bailey's at the end of the film, "It's a Wonderful Life." Such is the tenuous fabric holding this community together, that many a resident believes there would be no town without him.
"If this business folded, I don't know if Jordan would last much longer," said John Fitzgerald, who runs the drugstore and soda fountain. His Coke machine is a 1955 model, and his soda fountain dates to 1927. When Life magazine wanted to snap a picture of timeless rural life at a soda-fountain counter, they came to the Jordan Drug Store -- in 1947. Nothing much has changed.
As for Mr. Fitzgerald, he said he had not taken so much as taken a week's vacation in nearly 40 years -- a frequent complaint. He pulls out a map of Montana and spreads it over the well-worn counter.
"You see here, from the Missouri River to the Yellowstone, from Glendive west for 240 miles, I'm the only pharmacist," he said. "This is a drugstore by the way, not a pharmacy. Pharmacies don't sell malted shakes."
Nick Murnion, the county attorney, has been under a two-year death sentence by the Freemen, who say they want to execute him for failure to uphold the Constitution, as they see it. The Freemen put a million-dollar bounty on Mr. Murnion's head, and then publicized it through militia networks. It has been a rough two years for the town's only lawyer and part-time county attorney.
"I'm supposed to be sitting around here with a gun in my lap waiting for these people to come and get me," Mr. Murnion said. And indeed his hair has gone gray rather quickly, say his friends and relatives. But Mr. Murnion says he has a much greater concern than the bounty the Freemen have placed on his life. Like nearly everyone here, he is trying to keep the county alive.
"We desperately need people," said Mr. Murnion, whose dozen or so relatives here include his sister-in-law Bev Murnion, the rancher. "Most of these farms used to have a husband, wife, a son or two and a ranch hand, but now they're all getting down to just one or two people. It takes twice as much land and twice as many cows now to make the same living you did 10 years ago."
With the outlaw Freemen holed up on a foreclosed 940-acre ranch about 30 miles from here, it may seem like little has changed in Jordan since frontier days. As Tom Jordan, town founder, wrote in his cowboy memoir of turn-of-the-century Garfield County, "Those times in Jordan were wild, and every shady character who could not stand the spotlight of civilization drifted in and around town."
If Garfield County can ever shake the spotlight brought by the Freemen standoff, it may have a future in a new-technology economy, Mr. Murnion said. As a trustee of the telephone company co-op, Mr. Murnion is trying to attract entrepreneurs wed to laptops instead of beef prices. But so is virtually every other place in rural America.
And while Mr. Murnion touts the virtues of Garfield County -- "You can be up on the Missouri Breaks, fishing for walleye or hunting antelope in some of the prettiest country anywhere" -- he also mentions by way of Montana melancholy that winter blizzards with 40-below-zero wind chill can kill you in five minutes if your truck fails.
A side benefit of having the hordes of F.B.I. agents around, Mr. Murnion said, is that they brought in a cell that made cellular phone calls possible. Jordan is now connected to the world.
His other project is an attempt to raise enough money from a shrinking tax base to move the Garfield County "courthouse" out of its present home, a 1914 dance hall that also houses the sheriff, the tax assessor and the county clerk. He has his eyes on the empty building that used to be the hospital, which, like other structures here, is falling prey to the wind and sage.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up Sharply, With Dow Rising 29.26

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks jumped yesterday as investors took heart from big merger deals, stronger bond prices and renewed interest in technology shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 29.26 points to close at 5,564.74 after rising as much as 50 points early in the session. Broader indexes were also higher. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.82 points, to 647.89. 
 "There was little incentive to sell in the face of firm bonds, a continued focus in high techs and mergers," said Marty Kearney, a trader at PTI Securities.
Bell Atlantic's and Nynex's $22.1 billion merger was the most prominent of the $26.8 billion in deals that were announced yesterday. It was the second-biggest day for mergers; the biggest was Oct. 24, 1988, when 13 deals valued at $32.05 billion were done, including the R. J. Reynolds and Nabisco merger, according to Securities Data Company of Newark. Bell Atlantic rose 2 1/4, to 67 1/4, and Nynex fell 2 1/2, to 50 1/2.
In another deal yesterday, Cisco Systems agreed to acquire Stratacom Inc. in a stock swap valued at $4 billion, Stratacom surged 9 3/16, to 47 15/16, while Cisco fell 7/8, to 46 7/8.
"We had two nice mergers which perpetuates this concept of more stock being retired than brought to the market through initial public offerings," said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist of Fahnestock & Company.
Stocks were also bolstered as bond prices rose for a second consecutive session, easing concerns about inflation and higher interest rates.
Reflecting the strength in technology stocks, the Nasdaq composite index rose to its third straight record, adding 14.80 points, to 1,153.50. The index is up 9.63 percent so far this year.
Technology stocks were strong as Soundview Financial recommended that investors increase their holdings in the short term.
And Robertson, Stephens reiterated a "buy" rating on nine technology stocks, saying that bad news about the computer industry had mostly been factored into the market.
"The general feeling now is the group has been washed out and there are some bargains there," said Thom Brown, a managing director of Rutherford Brown & Catherwood.
International Business Machines rose 1 7/8, to 107 1/4, and Intel gained 2 1/2, to 67 3/4. Microsoft added 3, to 112 3/4.
The continuing rush of quarterly corporate earnings reports, with relatively few disappointments, also helped stocks.
General Motors lost 1/2, to 56, after the world's largest auto maker reported a 51 percent drop in profits, in part because of the 17-day strike at two G.M. parts plants in Ohio.
Emerson Electric rose 5 1/8, to 85, after Morgan Stanley upgraded the company's shares.
On the New York Stock Exchange advancing issues led declines, 1,473 to 923, on moderate volume of 394.5 million shares.

NAME: Abbot Low Moffat

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 954 words

HEADLINE: Abbot Moffat, 94, Lawmaker And Then a Diplomat in Asia

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 22

 BODY:
Abbot Low Moffat, a powerful New York State legislator during the Depression who in a second career as a diplomat warned against American involvement in Vietnam, died on Wednesday at a retirement home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 94.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 In a career that spanned much of the century, Mr. Abbot was chairman of the State Assembly's powerful Ways and Means Committee during the 1930's, helped run the Marshall Plan in Europe during the 1940's and served as chief of the Southeast Asian affairs division in the United States Department of State during the 1940's.
As a legislator from the 15th Assembly District in Manhattan, he controlled every piece of legislation that affected New York City. He was the first to propose building a multilane highway from Manhattan to Buffalo that later became the New York State Thruway. He also wrote a report that served as the basis for major revisions in the New York City Charter in the 1940's.
Mr. Moffat's influence was felt well beyond Albany. As a diplomat, he helped mold United States policy toward newly independent nations in Southeast Asia after World War II. He warned repeatedly about a surge of nationalism in regions like Indochina. And he strongly disapproved of the United States' growing involvement in Vietnam.
Abbot Low Moffat was born on the Upper East Side on May 12, 1901. He graduated from the Groton school in Manhattan, and received a bachelor's degree from Harvard in 1923 and then a law degree from Columbia University.
As a young man, he traveled the world with a sense of adventure. He rode for 25 days in a cart through Indochina, accompanied by a Chinese boy and a Russian refugee. From Australia, he stowed away on a freighter bound for the Panama Canal. And he studied at the School of Surveying of the American Geographical Society with a view to doing exploration work for museums.
He entered politics in 1929, winning election to the Assembly at age 27. He was among a small group of insurgent Republicans who took control of the Assembly from the leadership of their own party, ushering in an era when the Legislature played a far greater role in state politics than it had in earlier decades.
"It was a period of great legislative ascendancy," said Frank Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute in Albany. "They were very assertive in establishing their own priorities and not just accept the Governor's priorities."
Mr. Moffat helped shape the current system of state budgeting and proposed fiscal changes that only came into fruition decades later. He fought his greatest battle with Gov. Herbert H. Lehman. He led what historians call the 1939 budget revolt, when the Legislature rewrote the Governor's budget and cut it. The case wound up in court, with the Legislature losing, in a decision Mr. Moffat long felt was wrong but which everyone agrees profoundly strengthened the hand of the Governor in budget making.
Mr. Moffat, a liberal Republican, was the only New York City legislator in a triumvirate that ran the Assembly. In the 1950's, he switched to the Democratic Party, after years of prodding by his wife, Marion.
His tenure in Albany, from 1929 to 1943, was under three Governors, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mr. Lehman and Thomas E. Dewey. While Dewey gets much of the credit in history books for the highway that runs from the New York City line to Albany and then west, to Buffalo, it was Mr. Moffat who, while riding to Albany on Route 9, decided that something better was needed. He called the public works commissioner and asked him to draw up plans for the highway so he could enact a bill.
"They told me, 'You'll never get that bill through,' " Mr. Moffat recalled years later. "I said, 'If the chairman of Ways and Means says he'll get the bill, he'll get the bill.' "
He got the bill through. But much of the road was not built until Governor Dewey organized an authority to issue bonds to pay for it, an act that won the Governor the honor of having the highway ultimately renamed for him. "I still begrudge naming it after him," Mr. Moffat once said. "I thought that was a little extreme just because he got the financing going. But that's all right, except I just call it the New York State Thruway and let it go at that."
When he left Albany in 1943, Mr. Moffat set out on a career in the Foreign Service. He made a name for himself yet again, particularly representing the United States in Asia. He visited the Vietnamese nationalist leader Ho Chi Minh in 1946, and the cables he sent back are now widely regarded as prescient warnings about the course of American policy in Vietnam.
As head of the State Department's Division of South-East Asia Affairs from 1944 to 1947, he expressed great concern about the hard line the United States had taken in confronting nationalist movements like the one Ho Chi Minh was leading in Vietnam.
"I was bitterly disappointed," he said years later. "But the die was cast. We were going to follow a hard line on Communism wherever it put up its ugly head. I thought we were right back in the wars of religion."
He retired from foreign service in 1962 and moved to Princeton, where he remained active in local political and civic affairs. He also went on to write "Mongkut, the King of Siam" -- a project suggested to him by the king's great-nephews, who had been upset with the portrayal of the ruler as a capricious despot in the popular musical "The King and I," and wanted to set the record straight.
Mr. Moffat is survived by a son, Burnham Moffat of Danville, Calif.,; two daughters, Nancy Lifland of Princeton, and Jane-Kerin Moffat of Cos Cob, Conn.; eight grandchildren, and 17 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Report Tries To Counteract Job-Loss Fears

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The Council of Economic Advisers will report Tuesday that more than two-thirds of the new jobs created in the United States in 1994 and 1995 paid better than the average job, Administration officials said today, and that despite waves of corporate layoffs, the length of time most workers spent unemployed in recent years has actually declined.
Nonetheless, the report, written by Joseph E. Stiglitz, the head of the council, found some evidence that the rate at which jobs have been eliminated has risen slightly, despite strong economic growth. Though the evidence is murky -- and subject to differing interpretations within the Administration -- the statistics suggest that managers and other relatively high-paid white-collar workers who have been the focus of the most publicized layoffs are staying unemployed longer. 
 Mr. Stiglitz's report, which the White House plans to issue Tuesday, tries to answer one of the most politically charged questions of the election year: Is there statistical justification for the high anxiety felt in the American workplace today? Mr. Stiglitz has argued that many of the recent reports about declining wages and corporate downsizing, including a seven-part series in The New York Times called "The Downsizing of America," have overdrawn the severity of the turmoil in the American workplace.
"This puts us on a track to say that we've gone through tremendous dislocations, the kind of dislocations that come out of an economy with more job-creating energy than anywhere in the industrial world," a top Clinton adviser said today. "But it's tricky business, because you are walking the fine line of telling people things are pretty good while acknowledging that they are feeling pretty bad."
In fact, as the politically sensitive report has been worked into final form in recent days, some officials of the Labor Department, which also contributed to the study, have complained that Mr. Stiglitz was too intent on emphasizing the pace of job creation, at the expense of what a senior Clinton Administration official called "the clear anxiety you feel whenever you step into a factory."
But Labor officials say they have no argument with one of the most encouraging signs in the report: Evidence that the stagnation of real wages has hit bottom, and that in the past year they have begun to inch back up. Real wages have been frozen for many years, but the issue has gained much attention in the past year or two as the economy has grown rapidly.
The change may be barely noticeable to most workers, however. The most recent Bureau of Labor Statistics survey, for the first quarter of this year, showed median wages are now $25,428, slightly less than the first quarter of last year. But that decline was chiefly a reflection of the continued rise in the number of women in the work force, commanding lower wages, on average, than men. The statistics showed that male workers have seen their wages increase 1.3 percent.
Administration officials were quick to caution today that the study was fairly narrowly focused on a small part of the work force -- the 8.4 million new jobs created in the last four years in an economy of nearly 120 million jobs -- and that much of the data about the changing nature of layoffs in the past two years remained fragmentary.
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton's aides say that the study builds a foundation for the central theme of the re-election campaign, that Mr. Clinton has presided over an economy that is based more and more on "high wage, high skill" jobs, reversing a long trend of job growth in lower-paying jobs in service industries.
But even while claiming credit for the turnaround, Mr. Clinton has usually been careful in his campaign pitch to acknowledge that the pain of layoffs and "downsizings" has been devastating for millions of families. And he says that he is already well ahead of the Republicans in developing plans to aid workers caught in what the report terms the "dislocations" of a tumultuous but growing economy.
That careful balancing act reflects the delicate political nature of the Council's report. Mr. Stiglitz, in several recent appearances, has made it clear that he wants to dispel the popular image that the jobs being created in the economy are low-paying hamburger flippers, receptionists and underemployed "consultants."
"The evidence is fairly strong that we are creating high-wage jobs," Mr. Stiglitz said after a luncheon on Friday at George Washington University. But he said that there were continuing problems with "dislocation" -- workers who lose a good-paying job and cannot find another job at equivalent pay. Work done in preparation for the council report, Administration officials say, suggests that workers laid off from a good-paying job take a pay cut of roughly 10 percent, on average.
Much of the report focuses on the question of whether the "dislocations" that workers have suffered in the last two years are significantly different from those they suffered in the early 1980's or other major periods of change in the American economy.
It is a difficult set of numbers to parse. The most up-to-date Department of Labor statistics end in 1993. In its series of articles on downsizing, The Times used those figures and other data as the basis to estimate losses in 1994 and 1995. The estimate was based on an economic model that has been the subject of some debate in economic circles, and in the Administration.
"It resulted in numbers that are a bit more pessimistic than our own," one of the President's senior economic advisers said today. The adviser noted that the interpretation of those figures also depended in large part on the period to which it was compared.
For example, Henry Farber, a Princeton economist who has studied such labor statistics with care and participated in the council's report, has observed that while the job-loss figures in the recession that lasted from 1991 to 1993 were comparable to losses in the 1981 to 1983 recession -- leading one to believe that little had changed -- the recession in the early 1990's was comparatively mild. And during a milder recession, there is an expectation that job losses should be less severe than during a deeper one.
By coincidence, the report is being issued just as Mr. Clinton is maneuvering to take political advantage of a growing movement in Congress -- over the initial objections of Senator Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee -- to raise the minimum wage to $5.15 from its current level of $4.25. That would be a small step toward remedying the surging income gap between the lowest-paid workers and the highest-paid, a gap that has widened considerably during Mr. Clinton's term in office.
White House officials are scampering to use the unexpected momentum for the election-year increase -- which Mr. Dole now says he will try to attach to other legislation that Mr. Clinton opposes -- to demonstrate that the President is already executing plans to assure that workers get a larger share of a recent run-up in corporate profits.
"The C.E.O.'s of America's major corporations got a 23 percent raise last year -- an average compensation of nearly $4.5 million each," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today. "Why can't we give 90 cents more an hour to millions of our nation's lowest-paid workers?"
But the minimum wage increase may be the most concrete part of the President's plan for immediate aid to American workers. After months of sometimes bitter internal debate, the White House decided several weeks ago to reject Mr. Reich's public calls for an alternative tax system that would benefit companies that fit his definition of conscientious corporate citizens -- those who promised not to lay off workers during profitable times, and who set up comprehensive health care and profit-sharing systems.
It has also rejected proposals from Democrats like Senator Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat from New Mexico, to create tax incentives for companies to hold executive pay to roughly 50 times the wages of their lowest-paid employees. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has been particularly critical of that idea, arguing that the Government should not interfere with the compensation system of companies.
"At least we are getting these ideas on the agenda," Mr. Bingaman said today.

HEADLINE: New York Weeklies Stage a Free-for-All;
Voice and Press in Give-Away Battle

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
In the weeks surrounding the reincarnation of The Village Voice -- from aging alternative weekly to Manhattan's newest and most ubiquitous free paper -- the metropolis has been awash with mysterious rumors.
First, there was the one about the nail-polish-red news boxes that The Voice had planted all over Manhattan -- how homeless people were hauling heaps of papers to the other boroughs, where The Voice still sells for $1.25. 
 Then there was one about the publisher of The Voice -- how he supposedly called another magazine in a snit to complain that one of its columnists was also writing for New York Press, a free weekly that competes with The Voice.
Finally, there was the story about how The Voice was supposedly putting the squeeze on various downtown businesses to stop accepting free copies of New York Press if they wanted to be able to give out free copies of The Voice.
Evidence to support the rumors was hard to find. But at least a couple of them appeared to be emanating from an aerie atop the Puck Building in SoHo, which happens to be the lair of New York Press.
Things are hopping these days at New York Press, the self-styled alternative to the alternative, which has built much of its reputation by selling itself as the anti-Voice, the heir apparent to The Voice's cultural niche.
In recent weeks, the eight-year-old paper has pushed ahead its distribution date by a day, from Wednesday to Tuesday, to beat The Voice onto the streets, and has begun running a series of promotional ads mocking The Voice as geriatric, doddering and over the hill.
It has hired several new columnists, including a dominatrix named Mistress Ruby; a writer on black popular culture, Michael A. Gonzales, and Alexander Cockburn, one of the best-known writers from The Voice's heyday, who left the paper in 1982. All of which the 40-year-old editor and co-owner of New York Press, Russ Smith, said he believes will enable his upstart weekly to knock the paper he has called "a dinosaur, a relic" off the perch he believes it has occupied for too long.
"This is one of the great reasons, for us, that The Voice went free," Mr. Smith said. "Because it really put us into battle mentality. We're in a real war right now."
As for The Voice, he said: "If they are ignoring us, they are in trouble. Because we are truly the Vietcong. We are in the trees shooting at them. We can move a lot faster than The Voice can."
The Voice is, as it turns out, pretty much ignoring New York Press. Its editor and publisher seem less threatened than bemused -- not unlike the editor of big-city dailies back when alternative papers first began sniping at them.
David Schneiderman, 49, the publisher of The Voice, said he read New York Press only rarely. Karen Durbin, the 51-year-old editor, characterizes the supposed battle between the two papers as "Tyson versus what's-his-name."
As Ms. Durbin and Mr. Schneiderman see it, New York Press is simply trying to borrow legitimacy from The Voice, "piggybacking" on the 41-year-old paper's reputation and history in the hope of boosting its own.
"I think of it a little bit like a gnat," said Ms. Durbin, who first wrote for The Voice in 1972, and returned to run it two years ago. "It's kind of running up and kicking you in the shins. You feel a mild hit on your toe. 'Oh, them!' "
As Mr. Schneiderman tells it, free distribution is going swimmingly. When the experiment began two weeks ago, The Voice instantly tripled its Manhattan circulation to 155,000, he said. Only 342 copies were not picked up.
Classified advertisers have said their ads are getting more responses. There have been more calls answering personal ads. Five hundred news dealers still carry The Voice, even though they can't charge for it.
The only problem, Mr. Schneiderman said, is that the copies are being snatched up too quickly. As a result, he said yesterday that he would print 35,000 more copies starting in May, raising total circulation to 235,000. (It was 118,000 in September.)
That would be more than double the 100,000 circulation of New York Press. And Mr. Schneiderman says a full-page ad in The Voice already sells for nearly four times the cost of one in New York Press.
"Ultimately, you're dealing with two very different products," Mr. Schneiderman said of his paper and New York Press. "This is a sophisticated newspaper. It's won Pulitzer prizes and George Polk awards."
And New York Press?
"They put out a newspaper."
Indeed, the competition is a little difficult to characterize. Owned by Mr. Smith and a silent partner, it offers an unusual mix of columns, personal journalism, listings and often cranky, vicious criticism.
The columns have included at one time or another a three-year-chronicle of one columnist's psychotherapy, a column on patents, the musings of a well-educated deadbeat and a series titled "How to Fight With Your Wife."
The April 10 issue, which coincided with the first free issue of The Voice, included a piece of fiction on the cover and a lengthy, few-holds-barred, first-person account of one man's experience undergoing cysto scopy, titled "Prostate With Fear."
The paper's politics are not easily defined, either. But Mr. Smith describes himself as an economic conservative. There is a libertarian columnist and several writers were quite taken with the Republican candidacy of Steve Forbes.
"I think our paper is a lot more representative of New York in the 90's," said Mr. Smith, comparing his paper with The Voice, and suggesting that the true counterculture, in New York at least, is no longer located on the left. "Our political stuff is more evenly mixed. It's not the rote party line."
On that theme, New York Press has been firing carpet tacks at The Voice (and other publications) for years, trashing The Voice as tired, predictable, mushy-headed, no longer an alternative to the mainstream.
One of its new house ads is a parody of the cartoons of Jules Feiffer, which have appeared in The Voice since a year after it was founded. Another ad, making fun of the music criticism of Robert Christgau, a well-known writer for The Voice, begins: "Auteurist avatar of more seminally epochal, randomly eclecticized oeuvres . . . "
The slogan reads: "NYPress: Music criticism for people under 50."
Asked why he had decided to go to work for the opposition, Mr. Cockburn, who worked for The Voice from 1973 to 1982, said in an interview from his home in California: "Oh, anything to give the old nag a kick in the backside."
His debut column caught the attention of James Ledbetter, a press critic for The Voice, who then took the opportunity to accuse Mr. Cockburn of recycling material from a newsletter Mr. Cockburn puts out.
Mr. Cockburn fired back this week, inviting ex-Voice readers "now in recovery" to send along their versions of why The Voice "became the shapeless, self-indulgent, bulimic mess it is today."
Ms. Durbin, for her part, had nice things to say about Mr. Cockburn's first column, calling him "a bit of a rose in a garbage can." But she said she had no plans for any changes in response to New York Press.
"I don't know how one would go about competing with a publication like that," she mused. "Do we turn sharply to the right? Do I tell the writers: 'Enough with the substance; just blow smoke? Write worse?' "

HEADLINE: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "It's Not a Wage Gap but an Age Gap"(Op-Ed, April 21): W. Michael Cox's arguments only confuse the picture of widening inequality in America. Mr. Cox points out that, over time, people have moved up in income, but he admits that the explanation for that finding is that workers tend to make more money as they age. 
 As the economist Frank Levy has shown, the problem is that men today average much lower earnings and move up much more slowly than did men of the same age 25 years ago. Mr. Cox would have us believe that the only wrinkle in the American Dream is that workers now take longer to reach full earnings.
Actually, this age effect is a result of the great plunge in earnings that most young men -- those without college degrees -- have faced in recent years.
You can try to put rouge and mascara on the haggard face of economic reality, but you cannot hide the sad facts. Inequality has grown -- and more so in the United States than elsewhere.
 
CLAUDE S. FISCHER
Berkeley, Calif., April 21, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of sociology at the University of California.

HEADLINE: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
W. Michael Cox (Op-Ed, April 21) says that we should not be concerned about low wages because workers almost invariably move up the pay scale. His point, while valid in the abstract, overlooks an important problem. 
 A minimum-wage earner cannot buy groceries today with the middle-class job she will have in 10 years. The prospect of economic mobility does nothing to soften the blow of low wages while they are being earned.
Wages at the bottom of the scale are too low, even if they are temporary. Even with the earned income tax credit, the family of a full-time, minimum-wage worker with two children will remain below the poverty level.
Perhaps Mr. Cox would prefer that we help this family with another increase in the earned income tax credit. It is not unreasonable, however, to expect employers to pick up some of the tab by paying a higher minimum wage.
 
ELIZABETH HARGRAVE
Austin, Tex., April 21, 1996

LENGTH: 126 words

HEADLINE: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
W. Michael Cox's observation that economic inequality is not economic immobility (Op-Ed, April 21) is worth emphasizing. 
 But if our economy is going to be allowed to grow at only a low rate, about 1 percent a year, then the only way for the some of the "have-nots" to move up is for some of "haves" to move down.
This means that for every poor person who moves up -- and Mr. Cox would suggest that many do -- one of us in the upper strata must fall.
This is not a pleasant thought, and I am trying hard to avoid being one of the downwardly mobile. But unless we can invent a Lake Wobegone system of economics, where we are all above average, we had better stop griping.
 
PETER BLITZER
Fort Myers, Fla., April 21, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 938 words

HEADLINE: Nanjing Journal;
China's Campus Model for the 90's: Earnest Patriot

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: NANJING

 BODY:
His manner was friendly, but his words had a hard, metallic edge to them.
"Pardon me for speaking so bluntly," said Liu Junhai, a junior at Nanjing University, pausing on a walk across the leafy campus to respond to a visitor's questions about student attitudes. 
 "I don't consider that the United States is very friendly toward China," he said. "After all, you have just sent two aircraft carriers to within a few hundred miles of the Chinese coast and even closer to Taiwan."
Mr. Liu, 22, is a business major, and he seemed all business as he explained himself in a way that reflected the strong patriotism -- some call it nationalism -- of Chinese students today.
"We have received a lot of propaganda from the central Government that Taiwan is part of China and the United States should not interfere in China's internal affairs," he said. "So it seems to me the role the U.S. is playing as a world cop is comical. It is none of your business, so why are you putting your foot in it?"
Again apologizing for the unfriendly tone of his remarks, Mr. Liu added, "We have a saying in Chinese for something that seems out of place: It is like the dog chasing the mouse."
Mr. Liu's remarks and those of a number of his classmates sampled on an afternoon walk around one of China's most prestigious centers of higher learning suggested that just as Americans are more inclined these days to think the worst about Chinese intentions toward Taiwan or in confrontations on trade and human rights, the Chinese seem similarly inclined to think the worst of American intentions.
"I don't think the United States wants to see another Soviet Union in the world, in other words, another superpower or another country on its same level," said Huang Jie, a 20-year-old German major.
Hers was a grievance that many Chinese voice today, a sense that behind Washington's threats to impose trade sanctions on China for copyright piracy, behind its pressure on human rights, behind American and European objections to China's entry into the World Trade Organization is a strategy to contain China or to prevent its rise as a great Asian power.
It almost seems out of place these days to speak of the friendly relations that marked the first 10 years of Deng Xiaoping's reforms, coinciding with Mr. Deng's landmark visit to the United States in January 1979. That was the year that China's paramount leader visited the White House to re-establish full diplomatic relations before jetting off to tour America, even stopping in Houston to wear a cowboy hat and ride in a rodeo at the Astrodome.
"I don't think it is a question of being friendly or not," Ms. Huang said. "Nowadays, I think a country's relations with other countries are decided by economic interests."
Not too many years ago, millions of Chinese students, repelled by the corruption and inflation engendered by Communist Party policies, came out of their campuses to demand democratic reforms in the demonstrations of 1989, leading to a violent military crackdown ordered by Mr. Deng and carried out by a hard-line faction led by Prime Minister Li Peng.
Now, university students remain committed to these lofty concepts, but the emphasis has changed.
"Today, we are swimming in a different sea," said a legal scholar in Beijing who explained that Chinese students today are less inclined to place the blame for everything with the Communist Party or the Government in Beijing, and more likely to find fault with other forces in the world, particularly the United States.
When Beijing went all out to win the contest to be named the host of the 2000 Summer Olympics, rightly or wrongly, many blamed the United States for China's failure.
"I think China should first become stronger," said Lei San, a 22-year-old computer sciences major here. "Then we can concentrate on building democracy." In 1989, when students filled Tiananmen Square in Beijing and put up a statue that they called the Goddess of Democracy, Mr. Lei was only 15.
"If there is no economic base," he continued, "then there will be nothing to build democracy on."
Ms. Huang added a different perspective. "The majority of students want to develop both economic and political reforms," she said, "because people cannot live on bread alone."
One thing seemed clear from these youthful expressions: the Communist Party leadership is benefiting from the wave of patriotic spirit -- or nationalism -- that is rolling through the student population.
Not far from this campus, busloads of Chinese schoolchildren arrive each day to tour the museum built in memory of the victims of the Japanese 10th Army in World War II. The invaders swept into this ancient city, whose name means "southern capital" in Chinese, in November 1937 and began a campaign of rape, pillage and killing that left as many as 300,000 dead.
The museum director, Zhu Chengshan, said visits to the exhibition more than doubled in the last three years.
"Our purpose is to provide patriotic education for children and young people, and not to let them forget history as we strive to make the country stronger," he said.
Mr. Zhu was assigned to the museum from the Nanjing propaganda department in 1992, the year that Prime Minister Li issued national guidelines to enhance the "patriotic education" of China's youth, part of the concerted effort by Communist Party leaders in Beijing after the Tiananmen crackdown to win back legitimacy as well as the hearts and minds of students.
"We intend to use patriotism as a unifying force because China needs stability," Mr. Zhu said.
In some places, it appears to be working.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 2, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on April 23 with an article about a resurgence of patriotism among Chinese students misstated the location of the war memorial shown. It is at the Nanjing museum, not on the campus of Nanjing University.
