HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
YOU know those oddballs who go up and down the beach early in the morning with metal detectors, looking for coins? Well, they probably have better luck than people out looking for reasonably priced Burgundy.
The price of good wine -- really good wine -- is soaring, be it from California, France or Italy. But Burgundy is a special problem: there is so little of it. Burgundy makes less than a quarter of what Bordeaux turns out, so when the good stuff runs out, that's it. 
How else to explain $900 for a bottle of 1993 Romanee-Conti? Yes, that's what some of the local shops are asking. Now if that is what your heart is really set on, there is a merchant out on Long Island who can let you have a bottle for $800 and change. He says that he's out of it now, but if you promise to take a couple of dozen cases of Lafite, he will find you a nice '93.
Of course, it you're worried abeut the economy, downsizing and all that, he has the 1992 Romanee-Conti for a mere $730 a bottle.
Tossing around these kinds of numbers makes carping about $80 and $150 wines seem petty. But what about the people who like Burgundy but are not prepared to spend more than they do for a tank of gas?
Well then, here is a list of surprisingly decent Burgundies, both red and white, all no more than $25 and all with true varietal character; in winespeak that means they actually taste like Burgundy.
The principal red varietal -- in fact the only red varietal -- is pinot noir. The whites are all chardonnay, except then they are aligote, but we'll get to that later.
There is really nothing complicated about this, by the way. The official Burgundy region is some 150 miles long, but that includes Chablis, far in the north, and everything down to and including Beaujolais, which ends just north of Lyons. Most people think of Burgundy as only the Cote d'Or -- Golden Slope -- which runs from Dijon southwest through Beaune to Santenay.
And just south of Santenay is another Burgundy region, a small one, called the Cote Chalonnaise. It gets its name from Chalon, a railroad town whose only vines are in some locomotive engineer's backyard.
The Cote Chalonnaise, along with some lesser-known towns in the Cote d'Or, is where the buys are.
Once upon a time the Cote Chalonnaise was known chiefly as a source of grapes for sparkling wine. Remember sparkling Burgundy? The area has come into its own in recent years as prices for most Cote d'Or wines have sailed upward.
Mercurey, Rully and Givry produce good to excellent red wines. Montagny makes good white wines; Mercurey and Rully also turn out good whites. Bouzeron, another town in the appellation, as official French wine districts are called, also makes good whites and reds. One of the best producers in Mercurey is Joseph Faiveley. Once Faiveley's Clos de Myglands Mercurey was in reach of topers of modest means; now it's best to look for his Mercurey Clos-du-Roi. Recently it was found for $25. Today? Who knows? At least one New York store was offering another Mercurey, Chateau de Chamirey 1993, for about $15.
As the boss of the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti, Aubert de Villaine is the fellow who brings you that $900 Romanee-Conti. Each day after work he goes home to Bouzeron, where he makes a delicious Bourgogne rouge -- red Burgundy -- called La Digoine, for about $15. His white Burgundy, Les Clous, is about $13.
Mr. de Villaine makes another white wine in Bouzeron: aligote. Once this was a humble wine often blended with cassis to make a Kir. Mr. de Villaine has turned it into a fresh, racy white wine that stands out over many inexpensive chardonnay Burgundies. His Aligote de Bouzeron is about $12.
Louis Latour, one of the best known of all the Burgundy shippers, makes a pleasant aligote, which sells for $10, and a delicious Montagny, La Grand Roche, $12.
Still in the Chalonnaise, the Chateau de Rully makes a most attractive white under its own name. It sells for $14.
The lowest common denominator in Burgundy is a wine with an oxymoronic name -- Grande Ordinaire. It rarely finds its way to our shores. In the United States, the least among red Burgundies is called just that: red Burgundy. Some of them are awful. The only guarantee of quality in these blends is the reputation of the blender. Look for Louis Jadot's for $12; Domaine Leroy's for $14, and Faiveley's for $16.
The famous communes along the Cote d'Or -- Gevrey-Chambertin, Vosne-Romanee, Meursault and Puligny-Montrachet among them -- are familiar even to wine drinkers who can't afford their wines. But fine Burgundies come from lesser-known towns like Chorey-les-Beaune, Ladoix, Pernand-Vergelesses, Monthelie and Saint-Aubin.
The best-known name in Chorey-les-Beaune is Tollot-Beaut; one of the best in Monthelie is Olivier Laflaive and in Pernand-Vergelesses, Louis Jadot. Ramonet is the famous name in Saint-Aubin but Mr. Laflaive also makes a good white Burgundy there. It sells for about $15.
In Pernand-Vergelesses, Jadot owns a vineyard called Clos de la Croix de Pierre. It is not easy to find -- the wine, that is -- because it has fans that look for it every year. But it does turn up here and there and at $20 is a terrific buy. There are also a few white wines made in Pernand-Vergelesses. A lively one from Antonin Guyon sells for $9.
Finally, we come to the Hautes Cotes (pronounced oat-coat), literally, the high slopes. These are the vineyards on top of the line of hills that form the Cote d'Or. They were mostly abandoned between the wars, when Burgundy was hard to sell. They were replanted when the market began to improve in the 1950's and 60's. The northern half is called the Hautes Cotes de Nuit and the lower half the Hautes Cotes de Beaune. Faively makes the Hautes Cotes de Nuits Hugettes, an excellent buy at about $20.
None of these wines are made in any great quantities, so good hunting. If you have a metal detector, use it -- to find enough coins to pay for the wine.
 
TASTINGS
 
Marimar Torres Pinot Noir 1992.
Green Valley Sonoma,
Don Miguel Vineyard. About $30.
 
 Marimar Torres has been in the United States since the 1970's, representing her family's hugely successful winery near Barcelona, Spain. In 1983, she and her family bought property in the Green Valley area of western Sonoma County and were soon producing a high-quality chardonnay. Later she added pinot noir and now offers two versions, a lighter wine and a somewhat more intense bottling exclusively from grapes from a vineyard named after her father.

HEADLINE: Welfare Study Offered Fair Assessment on Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Bob Herbert's "Poison Numbers" (column, April 22): 
 Our study on welfare published by the Cato Institute profiled the benefits available to a typical recipient family, a mother with two children, ages 1 and 4. This means, for example, that our profile family was eligible for the Women-Infants-Children program, which provides food vouchers for young children at special risk for inadequate nutrition.
Mr. Herbert says we should not have included WIC since 80 percent of welfare families do not receive the benefit. He is technically correct, because only children below school age can receive WIC. But older children not eligible for WIC would be eligible for other assistance to low-income families, including school lunches.
Mr. Herbert also criticizes our decision to include housing benefits in our calculations, noting that nationwide only 25 percent of welfare recipients receive housing. Eligibility for housing is a function of time spent on the waiting list. Since the crisis in our welfare system involves long-term welfare recipients, we felt it fair to include the benefit.
Mr. Herbert says we ignored benefits received by the working poor. Our study discusses those benefits. However, benefits received by the working poor are often time-limited and are offset by the additional costs associated with work, such as transportation, clothing and child care. The largest welfare benefit received by the working poor is the earned income tax credit, which the study accounts for.
There are 77 major Federal and state welfare programs, with many recipients receiving benefits from them. Indeed, our study may have understated the aid a recipient can receive.
 
MICHAEL D. TANNER
STEPHEN MOORE
Washington, April 21, 1996
 
The writers are, respectively, director of health and welfare studies, and director of fiscal policy at the Cato Institute.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
On the Delaware River, once the haunts of heavy industry, a company finds a beauty spot for a plant.

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford 

DATELINE: NEW CASTLE, Del.

 BODY:
A COMPANY that makes bathroom cabinets and shower rods is building a manufacturing plant along the Delaware River here, providing a stark contrast to the chemical plants of the early 20th century that still operate nearby.
The Zenith Products Corporation of Aston, Pa., has started work on a $20 million plant of nearly 500,000 square feet just south of the twin spans of the Delaware Memorial Bridges. But unlike the steel mills and chemical plants that chose the waterfront site for production reasons, Zenith was attracted to the riverfront for reasons of highway access and esthetics. 
 "It's absolutely gorgeous," Briggs Pletcher, Zenith's assistant to the president, said of the undeveloped tract that looks across the river to Pennsville, N.J. "It's hard to believe we could find a site that beautiful and so easily accessible" to Interstate 95, he said.
The land had been scheduled for heavy industrial development as early as 1918. The Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, Pa., bought the 525-acre parcel that year as a possible location for a steel operation.
In the 1970's, after Delaware passed its Coastal Zone Act, Lukens put the land up for sale. The environmental law makes it extremely difficult if not impossible for the land to be developed for new heavy industrial uses. Eleven years ago, Lukens -- by then the diversified Lukens Inc. -- began developing a portion of the property but has since sold its interest.
The State of Delaware has agreed to provide Zenith with a $1 million grant for relocation and improvement costs, and $200,000 for job training. The state expects to recover the money within the next three years through personal income and corporate taxes. Ten years worth of property-tax breaks were provided by the City of New Castle.
The 79-acre site chosen by Zenith is on a stretch of the river whose shoreline has been marred by the smokestacks and fuel tanks of heavy industrial development. The Du Pont Company and Zeneca Inc., a chemical company, have operations nearby. Star Enterprise operates a petroleum refinery nearby in Delaware City, in view of the cooling tower for the Salem nuclear power plant complex on the New Jersey side of the river.
The Zenith site is the most desirable in Riveredge Park, an office and light industry development. In addition to being completely flat, which limits construction costs, it is isolated from other development. A historic plantation-style home on the property is to be restored as a training and conference center, according to Herman Van Fleet 3d, a partner in Architectural Concepts of Malvern, Pa.
The architects have designed the Zenith building to take advantage of views up and down the river, Mr. Van Fleet said. The building will take up about 11 acres, but Zenith was forced to buy more than seven times that amount of land because much of the property is wetlands.
Zenith, a subsidiary of the Masco Corporation, a building materials company based in Taylor, Mich., went looking for a spot to build last year after outgrowing its 320,000 square feet of space in Delaware County, Pa., just south of Philadelphia. The company, probably best known for its bathroom space-saving product -- shelves mounted on floor-to-ceiling poles -- had sales of about $90 million in 1995.
One of the conditions in searching for land was that the new site be within a 20-minute drive of its existing plant, where the company employs about 650 people, according to Zenith's chief executive, James Aruffo. That plant will close. Zenith has had operations in Delaware County for about 30 years, Mr. Aruffo said. Most of the employees will move to the New Castle plant when it opens in December, he said.
Zenith paid roughly $2.2 million for essentially 35 usable acres, or nearly $63,000 an acre, said Charles J. White Jr., vice president of Stoltz Realty Inc. of Wilmington, which handled the sale.
In Delaware, as in the rest of the nation, there is healthy demand for industrial space, said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. Because many older industrial buildings have outdated fire and safety codes, companies are opting for new construction. In addition, the ceiling heights of older structures do not allow for modern racking systems for distribution and inventory retrieval.
The result is that industrial construction in northern Delaware was at a five-year high in 1995, according a survey by the Jackson-Cross Company, a real estate firm with offices in Wilmington. The market has pushed prices for improved industrial sites to $70,000 to $80,000 an acre, it reported.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Again Gains on the Mark, Climbing to a 14-Month High

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar continued yesterday to benefit from the weakness of the German mark, settling in New York at its highest rate against the mark in more than 14 months.
The mark has been battered by last week's cut in German interest rates and by talk that Italy would rejoin Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism within weeks. 
 The dollar broke through a psychologically important level of 1.52 marks in European trading, rising as high as 1.5220 marks. In late trading in New York, it settled at 1.5212 marks, up from 1.5168 marks on Monday. Yesterday's closing price was the highest since Feb. 13, 1995.
The dollar also edged up to 106.67 Japanese yen from 106.65 yen in New York. The British pound rose to $1.5165 from $1.5123.
The mark has been weak since German interest rates were cut by half a percentage point last Thursday. The slide accelerated after a center-left coalition won majorities in both houses of the Italian Parliament in elections on Sunday.
The coalition had campaigned on a pledge to restore the lira to the Exchange Rate Mechanism. The decisive victory by the coalition increased confidence that the European Monetary Union planned for 1999 would become a reality.
The rate mechanism establishes linked trading ranges for the currencies of 10 of the 15 European Union member countries and is a precursor to creating a single European currency.
The lira was taken out of the mechanism during an international currency crisis in 1992.
Establishment of a European currency is generally viewed as being negative for the mark -- regarded as Europe's premier currency -- because such a move would fuse Germany's currency with those of its economically weaker neighbors and might undermine Germany's economy.
Speculation about Italy's rejoining the rate mechanism pushed the mark near 18-month lows against the lira yesterday, and a spillover effect led to selling of the mark against the dollar and the yen, traders said.
The dollar rose a fraction against the yen, buoyed by the dollar's strength against the mark, traders said.
The gains against the yen were limited, however, as Japanese exporters sought to sell dollars at around 106.80 yen, traders said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Enticing Europe's Shoppers

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
For Christie Wright, shopping at the Gap is not really about buying T-shirts or jeans, though she likes to talk about getting "good quality for relatively cheap prices." It's about her 10-year-old daughter, Charlotte, growing up, watching Gap ads on MTV, and getting a dose of America and its styles, all while shopping near home on Oxford Street. So these days Mrs. Wright bypasses the nearby Stefanel boutique and ventures into the Gap.
"It appeals to kids," Mrs. Wright said, as she left the Gap one recent morning, laden with purchases. But not just "kids." In addition to spending 60, about $90, on Charlotte, Mrs. Wright paid as much for T-shirts, jeans and other clothes for herself. 
 The Wrights are hardly alone in being smitten by American styles. After years of seeing American fashions on television or on favorite rock and movie stars, Europeans have become hooked on the casual American look. So over the last decade, American retailers have moved into Britain and, increasingly, are taking the leap to the Continent.
As their presence approaches critical mass, the American marketers are exporting not just a fashion sensibility but ways of doing business that are beginning to transform merchandising in Europe just as they have in the United States. Specialty chains and outlet stores, quick to put goods on sale and to seed racks with trendy merchandise, are supplanting small independent retailers, whose inefficiencies and high prices get much of the blame for stagnating consumption on the Continent.
Nowhere are the trends more apparent than in clothing. Gap Inc., which entered Britain in 1987, now has 71 stores in three European countries, and is fast opening more in France and Germany. Esprit de Corp., the San Francisco clothing maker, has 121 European stores, plus many Esprit sections in department stores. Levi Strauss, with 278 stores in Western Europe, is plunging into the formerly Communist East. The Foot Locker unit of the Woolworth Corporation, which hit Germany in 1987, now has 216 European locations and plans a big expansion.
But clothes are not all that America is hawking across Europe. Toys "R" Us has 201 stores in Europe and Blockbuster Video, part of National Amusements Inc., has 764. Walt Disney and the Warner Brothers unit of Time Warner are opening European stores as fast as they can find locations.
For American merchants, the main lure is "anticipation of stagnation in America," said Joseph H. Ellis, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs in New York.
For European merchants, the result is upheaval on a grand scale. Few Americans may realize it as they browse the tiny boutiques off the Via del Corso in Rome or the Boulevard Haussmann in Paris , but in the last 10 years the share of women's clothing sold through independent retailers in Italy has dropped to two-thirds, from three-quarters, while the share sold at chains and low-price outlets has surged. In France, the independents' share has dropped to one-third, from half.
Despite trying to defend themselves by, say, forming purchasing consortiums, small retailers are being swept away by chains like Hennes & Mauritz of Sweden and Zara of Spain or hypermarkets like those run by Carrefour of France. Increasingly, American chains are profiting from the upheaval.
The Americans do not have it easy. Since malls are still rare, chains like the Gap must bid for high-rent sites on city streets. In some countries, like Germany and the Netherlands, store operating hours are restricted. In the United States, the Gap opened 59 of its Old Navy stores in the first year of that venture; in Britain, it took 10 years to open that many Gap stores.
Retail experts hope the American influence will result in higher productivity and, ultimately, lower prices, increased sales and new jobs.
"I suspect that if Europe is serious about unemployment it will develop its service industries, as in the United States and even in Britain, and one way is to get better at retailing," said William Cullum, an analyst at Paribas Capital Markets in London.
Indeed, American retailers often begin in Britain because, after the deregulation wrought in the 1980's by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, bureaucratic hurdles and costs are lower than in the rest of Europe. Given the weakness of British unions and the lower social security tax payments in Britain, Mr. Cullum estimates, personnel costs can be 50 percent to 60 percent lower than in Germany.
The European success of chains like the Gap is in large measure a result of applying formulas that worked at home.
To assure low prices, the Gap contracts for deliveries of clothing from manufacturers in low-wage countries like Spain and Portugal. To stay abreast of changing fashions, the company feeds new designs and colors into its stores every four to six weeks, compared with four or five times a year for other European retailers. Moreover, wherever the practice is legal, the Gap continually clears inventory by lowering prices on slow-moving items, rather than relying on seasonal sales.
Not that European companies cannot do these things. But analysts say companies like the Gap, accustomed to the size and competitiveness of the United States, often do them better. "The Gap has structural advantages; it has the capability to react to market trends," said Yoram Gutgeld, a retail consultant at the Milan, Italy, office of McKinsey & Company.
In Europe, where stores are smaller, the Gap often has to make do with about 11,000 square feet, the minimum size for its United States outlets. That means there is usually not enough room to combine a regular Gap with a Gap Kids outlet, which is frequently done in the United States. Instead the Gap Kids are separate stores.
Because of delivery problems, the Gap does not sell shoes in Europe, except for infants' and children's footwear. In France, its sizes are smaller, because the French tend to be smaller; in Germany, colors are darker, matching Germans' preferences. Moreover, Gap stores on the Continent do without "greeters," salespeople who welcome shoppers at the door, because Europeans tend to feel the greeters are intimidating.
Still, Gap executives have no doubt that all their products are marketable in Europe.
"We feel that each of our corporate brands -- Gap, Gap Kids, Baby Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy Clothing Company -- can be successful overseas," said William Fisher, the president of Gap International.
As American retailers spread across the Continent, the going gets rougher.
For one thing, while European consumers once were more focused on quality than Americans, slow economic growth and mounting unemployment are making them more sensitive to costs.
"Europeans are now much more price-conscious," said Birgit Kelley, managing director for licensing at Esprit International.
Moreover, the countries next in line to face the American invasion, like Spain, Italy, and France, have strong textile industries.
"This is where companies like the Gap will have it tough," Mr. Gutgeld of McKinsey said.
Increasingly, too, experts say, America's merchandisers will be squeezed by the very revolution they helped set in motion. Even as independent retailers are being killed off, the American chains face the accelerated growth of hypermarkets and manufacturers' outlets, despite bitter resistance from traditional retailers and their lobbies.
European clothing companies like Hugo Boss or furniture manufacturers like Ikea have long operated big suburban outlets, but now developers of factory-outlet malls, including American giants like McArthur/ Glen Realty, are accelerating their plans.
In 1993, McArthur/Glen teamed up with the British Airports Authority to build factory-outlet villages in Britain -- big shopping centers that cluster outlets for clothing, leather goods and other products. Last year, the group opened the first such center on the Continent, outside Troyes, France, southeast of Paris.
Though the French Government recently passed measures to curb such development on the outskirts of towns, and resistance is mounting in Germany and Italy, a recent report by the Richard Ellis real estate group concluded that the concept had been "already implanted" in Europe, and it seemed "only a matter of time before the developers win out."
As for American retailers, this is the type of environment they grew up in, and they are confident they can stay in the race.
"You can point to television, movies or other media" as the source of Europeans' love affair with American fashion, Mr. Fisher of the Gap said. "But the fact was there for everyone to see, and we took advantage of it."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
After Ford takes a greater hand, Mazda consolidates its ad account in Japan.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IN a departure from the usual practice in Japan, the Mazda Motor Corporation has chosen to concentrate all its advertising with Hakuhodo Inc., Japan's No. 2 agency behind Dentsu Inc.
Generally, Japanese auto makers use different agencies for different models; Mazda had had its account at Dentsu and two other shops. The decision to consolidate the account appears to be guided by the Ford Motor Company, which took effective control of the financially ailing Mazda this month and is trying to turn it around, in part by adopting some American practices. 
 Mazda said it hoped that the concentration of its advertising with a single agency would improve its brand image. From 1990 to 1995, the company's sales in Japan declined by 40 percent. Saving money also seems to be a big factor behind the decision, analysts said.
The move follows the consolidation of the Nissan Motor Company's account at a single agency a few years ago, which created waves in the advertising world. Nissan also chose Hakuhodo. (Concerns about conflicts of interest among Japanese marketers are much less prevalent than in the United States, where the idea that, say, Ford and General Motors would both use the same agency would be heretical.)
A Nissan spokesman said that having a single agency would allow that agency's marketing experts to participate in the conception and planning of a new model, rather than getting involved only after the model was virtually completed. In some sense, this is like the Japanese keiretsu system, in which longtime parts suppliers linked with a single auto maker participate in the design of a car.
Takeshi Saito, an editor at Kokoku Journal, an advertising magazine, said the moves by Nissan and Mazda did not constitute a trend. Rather, he said, the two cases simply marked victories for Hakuhodo, which has long played the Avis to Dentsu's Hertz in the Japanese advertising wars.
Certainly, Hakuhodo appears to be on a hitting streak. Last year it introduced commercials for Nissan featuring Ichiro Suzuki, a young baseball star. The campaign helped lift the sales of Nissan, the second-largest auto company in Japan after the Toyota Motor Corporation, after several years of decline.
Hakuhodo stayed on the mound and produced the counterattack ads for Toyota, another client. Those featured Hideo Nomo, the Japanese pitcher who has become a star for the Los Angeles Dodgers and a hero in his home country.
Tetsuji Shimizu, a spokesman for Dentsu, said the agency had tried to sign Mr. Nomo but lost out to Hakuhodo. "It's been a little irritating for Dentsu," he said. "But we still have the largest share of Toyota ads."
Toyota is sticking with its policy of using four agencies, including Dentsu and Hakuhodo. A review is conducted among the shops for the advertising of each new model. Toyota believes that the competition leads to more creative advertising, a company spokesman said.
The Mazda account change has occurred as sales of automobiles in Japan have been growing again after several years of declines during Japan's long recession. The market recovery has fueled a feverish war in automobile advertising as makers scramble for market share.
The consolidation in Japan does not affect the account of Mazda's American unit, Mazda Motor of America, which remains at the Santa Ana, Calif., office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of True North Communications. After trade publications reported that Foote, Cone's hold on that account, with billings estimated at $200 million, was loosening, the office underwent substantial changes in management and the Mazda campaign was revamped to introduce the theme "Passion for the Road." Still, speculation continues that the account could be placed in review if Mazda's American sales slump is not reversed.

HEADLINE: Export Boom In Services Cuts Growth in U.S. Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Erasing about half of a huge January increase, the nation's trade deficit shrank to $8.2 billion in February as sales of American services abroad rose to records, the Commerce Department reported today.
Exports over all climbed 2 percent to the second-highest total on record while imports fell five-tenths of 1 percent. It was the first time since November that the deficit had narrowed. 
 The deficit was about $400 million less than expected, and was accompanied by a downward revision of that amount for January. But private analysts noted two main reasons for the contraction and said that neither was likely to be repeated soon.
One was a big drop in the cost of imported petroleum products, which tumbled $1 billion, to $4 billion. The other was a surge in exports of civilian aircraft in the aftermath of a strike at the Boeing Company, which was settled in December.
Nonetheless, the Clinton Administration seized on the results as an affirmation of its trade practices. In the early Presidential primaries, some of the Republican aspirants asserted that many American workers had been idled as a result of free trade policies.
"Our improved trade picture reflects the ongoing improvement in the competitiveness of the U.S. economy, its productivity growth and innovation, and our own efforts to open the doors of foreign markets to American products," said Mickey Kantor, the former United States trade representative, whom President Clinton named to succeed the late Ronald H. Brown as Secretary of Commerce.
Many economists said that the strong performance in trade, which accounted for much of the economy's skimpy growth in the final three months of 1995, would weigh down performance in the current quarter and might contribute little for the balance of the year.
"The message is that U.S. exports are competitive but they are being held back by softness in some of our major markets," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. He said that European economies were "still wallowing around" and that the dollar's rise against the yen would limit further increases in exports to Japan.
Still, today's report confirmed a marked recent improvement in the American deficit with Japan. It edged up $100 million, to $3.9 billion, in February, but that was down from $4.7 billion in February 1995.
Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, cited the lower deficit with Japan as a chief reason for the overall narrowing of the nation's trade imbalance in the last year.
The deficit with China moved down $300 million, to $2.4 billion, in February, but that was up from $1.9 billion in February 1995. Unlike the aggregate figures, those for individual countries are not adjusted for seasonal fluctuations.
Today's report also showed a $500 million narrowing of the deficit with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, to $1.4 billion; an unchanged deficit with Mexico at $1.3 billion, and a halving of the deficits with Western Europe ($460 million) and four newly industrial Asian countries ($815 million).
The rise in exports for the month was $1.3 billion, to $68.1 billion, with civilian aircraft accounting for just over half the increase, today's report showed. Imports eased $400 million, to $76.3 billion, dominated by the 20 percent drop in petroleum purchases. Imports of motor vehicles and parts were virtually unchanged.
Economists said they would be watching closely to see how these goods sold. "It will either turn out that importers guessed right, and U.S. demand picks up sharply, or they will have bet wrong and be facing another inventory problem later this spring," said David Orr, a senior economist for First Union National Bank in Charlotte. "We'd bet on the latter."
The Commerce Department said it now calculated the January deficit at $9.9 billion, down from $10.3 billion first reported late last month.
February's record export performance in services -- financial, legal, educational, tourist, telecommunications and others -- provided a surplus of $18.4 billion, $600 million higher than in January.
The American surplus in advanced technology products, which briefly disappeared in September and October, climbed to $1.9 billion in February from $560 million in January, the report showed.
Asked at a briefing whether he favored merging the trade representative's office into the Commerce Department, Mr. Kantor replied flatly, "It's not an option."

HEADLINE: Workplace Fears Disputed In Politically Delicate Study

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
In a politically delicate effort to show that it is helping to create jobs that pay well, the Clinton Administration issued a study today that disputes one of the most prevalent stereotypes about the economy, concluding that most new jobs created in the service industries are relatively high-paying executive and management positions.
"The cartoons might make you think these new jobs are all hamburger flippers," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. "In fact, the conventional wisdom is wrong." And the report concludes that another oft-heard joke about the new economy -- "There are 8.5 million new jobs and I've got three of them" -- is also false. The study found no change in the percentage of workers holding more than one job. 
 The council's study was commissioned partly in response to the series of corporate layoffs that seized headlines in recent months. But it also sets the stage for Mr. Clinton to contend that the anxieties over economic change, while understandable, were overblown -- or at least not attributable to layoffs.
"There has just not been that big a change in the displacement rate for workers," Mr. Stiglitz told reporters today. "But the anxieties are real. Perhaps that is because of a 20-year period in which real wages have declined," he said, arguing that the council's data also suggest that incomes are starting to bounce back.
In recent months Mr. Clinton's political advisers have concluded that what matters politically this year is the perception of job insecurity, and that perception could outweigh Mr. Stiglitz's statistics.
A poll conducted by The New York Times in December concluded that nearly three-quarters of all American households have either suffered a layoff, or have friends, relatives or neighbors who have lost their jobs in the last 15 years. And nearly half of those surveyed said they worried that they or someone in their household might be out of work or looking for a job in the next 12 months.
After months of debate about how to handle such perceptions -- and channel them to the President's advantage -- the White House has decided to accentuate the positive. The President is talking a great deal about easing the transition for workers who lose their jobs, with retraining programs and the ability for workers who change jobs to keep their insurance and pensions.
Next month he is scheduled to conduct a "corporate responsibility" conference in Washington, inviting companies that have innovative programs to retain employees and to give them a bigger stake in the profits.
Some of the findings announced today showed significant changes going on beneath the surface in the uncertain world of corporate layoffs. The report found, for example, that in the early 1990's, workers 55 years of age or older were the biggest cohort of laid-off workers, a reversal from the 1980's, when young workers were the first out the door. But the Administration said that it did not yet have the evidence to conclude whether that trend -- layoffs of highly paid, white-collar workers -- accelerated into the first half of this decade.
Most of the details of today's report had been disclosed before publication of the document. The study determined that 68 percent of the net growth in jobs in the last two years were in industry groups and occupations that pay better wages than the median for all workers.
It also concluded that the "vast majority" of new jobs were full time, despite anecdotal evidence that more and more workers were heading into part-time employment. And it concluded that while employment is up sharply, those who lost their jobs were more likely to be dismissed permanently rather than temporarily laid off.
Perhaps the most curious finding in the report -- and the one likely to be most open to dispute -- is the council's conclusion that the big growth in service sector jobs has not come at McDonald's, but at mutual funds and hospitals, software companies and accounting services. And most of those jobs, the council found after parsing numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, came in what Mr. Stiglitz calls "high-wage occupations," in executive suites and among professionals and specialists.
The council sorted data about workers into 45 occupational categories in 22 major industries, creating a total of 990 "industry/occupation cells" -- each representing a group of workers. After eliminating small "cells" from the analysis because they did not contain enough workers to be statistically significant, the council found that more than two-thirds of all the new jobs created in the last two years paid more than $480 a week, the current median earnings for all jobs in the United States.
"Employment in 'hamburger-flipping jobs' actually fell between 1994 and 1995," the report concludes, defining those as workers at food counters, in the kitchen and in other food-preparation jobs.
That finding is somewhat at odds with other studies that covered years running up to 1993. "It's true that these managerial jobs are growing quickly," said Van Doorn Ooms, the director of research at the Committee for Economic Development, which next month is releasing a major study of some of the same phenomena entitled "American Workers and Economic Change."
"But we also find strong growth at the low end -- the hamburger flippers."
It is possible both findings are correct: There is no standard way of categorizing workers, and different studies frequently divide and define workers and their jobs in different ways.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Britain Object to Iraq Oil Plan

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 23

 BODY:
The United States and Britain announced today that they want extensive changes in a draft plan to allow Iraq to sell up to $2 billion worth of oil every six months to buy food and medicine for its suffering civilians.
They portrayed the tightening of the proposal as a way to prevent Baghdad from "manipulating" the accord to weaken the sanctions imposed by the Security Council after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. 
 Iraq has bitterly criticized the proposed changes, saying that the United States and Britain had interfered just as it was close to an agreement with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali that would have relieved much of the poverty and suffering that six years of sanctions have inflicted on the country.
Diplomats said that Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, who rejected two earlier offers as an insult to his country's sovereignty, must now decide whether to continue negotiating on the revised proposal or break off talks altogether.
A statement issued by the United States mission to the United Nations said that both countries have made proposals to insure that the plan will have the intended effect. The statement said the aim was to prevent Baghdad from manipulating the oil sales agreement "for its own ends."
While officials involved praised the Secretary General's performance in negotiations so far, they made clear that the United States and Britain see the agreement he is proposing as one that Mr. Hussein might exploit to his own advantage.
Specifically, the officials said that the resolution provides for $150 million out of every $1 billion worth of oil sold to be used by the United Nations to pay for its relief program in three predominantly Kurdish northern provinces that have broken away from Baghdad and are under the military protection of the Gulf war allies. As a result, the United States and Britain do not want the agreement to give Baghdad any say in which goods are purchased for the north or how they are distributed.
"It's our view that the Iraqis will take any opportunity they can to increase their influence in the north," a senior official said.
The United States and Britain also object to a United Nations proposal that Baghdad be allowed to select the bank where an escrow account will be opened to hold money paid for the oil Iraq sells and take out letters of credit to pay for food and supplies for Iraqi civilians. That risks giving Iraq access to the international banking system, a privilege not permitted under the sanctions.
Finally, while the United States and Britain are prepared in principle to let Iraq use its Government's existing rationing system to distribute the food it buys with the oil proceeds, they say the fairness of such a system should be checked and monitored. The plan is supposed to provide basic staples to every family.
Iraq's Christian minority and the Shiite communities of the south frequently complain that they do not receive their correct entitlement. And a United Nations human rights report in March said the military and senior Government officials enjoy more generous rations than ordinary people.
On Monday, Iraq's top negotiator, Amir Abdul al-Anbari, complained that the British and American intervention led the Secretary General to make changes in "almost every paragraph" of an accord he had said was close to completion. Today Mr. Anbari postponed further negotiations until Wednesday, saying he needed more time for consultations with Baghdad.
The Clinton Administration has pushed hard for the new oil-for-food deal. And last week the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said she wanted an early agreement in part because it would remove the argument that sanctions be lifted altogether to provide for the needs of civilians.

Job-to-Job Health Bill Gains, Covering Mental Illness
The Senate passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, on a 100-to-0 vote. The bill faces a difficult conference with the House, but appears to have irresistible political momentum.
The bill would require insurers to provide coverage for mental illnesses equivalent to that provided for conditions like heart disease. Business groups and insurers denounced the cost of the proposal. [Page A1.]
 
Technology Stocks Soar
Strong earnings at Digital Equipment lifted technology stocks and sent the Nasdaq composite index to its fourth straight record, bringing its gains to 6.3 percent in less than two weeks. The Dow Jones industrials rose 23.85, to 5,588.59. [D8.]
 
Digital Equipment's earnings jumped 68 percent in the quarter, despite weakness in its personal computer business. [D3.]
 
New Data on Job Gains
The Council of Economic Advisers, disputing a widely held view, said in a report that most new jobs in the service industries were relatively high-paying. [D4.]
 
Salomon Earnings Triple
Salomon, recovering from a difficult 1995, tripled its quarterly earnings to $276 million, thanks to robust securities trading. [D2.]
 
Nabisco Earnings Are Firm
With better-than-expected sales in its premium cigarette brands and helped by worldwide sales growth in tobacco and food, RJR Nabisco said first-quarter earnings rose 12 percent on a per-share basis. [D2.]
 
Doctors should question their patients about their use of tobacco, and try to persuade users to quit, a Government agency urged. [A16.]

Profit for United Airlines

Andersen to Pay in Realty Case

Quarterly Loss for Disney

Viacom and MCA Hold Talks
Viacom and MCA, which are partners in USA Network, tried to resolve their difference over a new Viacom channel. Viacom released Frank Biondi, its former chief executive, to head MCA. [D6.]
 
U.S. Objects to Iraq Oil Plan
The U.S. and Britain objected to the terms of a draft of a U.N. plan to let Iraq sell $2 billion worth of oil every six months. [A8.]
 
Cruise Lines in Court
Law firms in four states filed class action lawsuits this week against seven cruise lines, contending that port charges increased the cost of advertised fares. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Lead Gains in Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Another encouraging earnings report in the computer industry sent technology stocks shooting higher again yesterday. The powerful rally lifted the Nasdaq composite index to its fourth straight record and brought its gains to 6.3 percent in less than two weeks.
A jump in oil prices helped lift the struggling Dow Jones industrial average, but hurt airline stocks. 
 The Dow industrials rose 23.85 points, mostly on gains in its three oil stocks, to close at 5,588.59. The Dow spent much of the session with a gain of less than 10 points, once again lagging behind the broader market's record-setting trend over the last week.
Technology stocks, which have resumed their leadership role after a sharp selloff that began late last year, rallied strongly after Digital Equipment issued the latest in a series of strong earnings reports that indicate the industry is not as badly off as feared.
The Nasdaq composite, laden with technology issues, plowed further into record territory, rising 13.26, to 1,166.76. Nasdaq volume exceeded 650 million shares for the first time, with 650.1 million traded. The old record was 641.1 million shares, set Feb. 22.
The American Stock Exchange's market value index, also weighted with technology and other small- company issues, gained 3.36, to 590.73, setting its sixth straight high. It has risen more than 3.5 percent in about two weeks.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 13 to 10 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was heavy at about 453 million shares, well above Monday's pace.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500 list -- both dominated by larger companies that surged earlier this year before sputtering in recent weeks -- posted modest gains. The New York Stock Exchange composite rose 1.78, to 349.60, and the S.& P. 500 rose 3.69, to 651.58.
The continuing weakness in long-term bonds has created an uncertain outlook for blue-chip stocks, said Thom Brown, market strategist at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood in Philadelphia.
The 30-year Treasury bond slid yesterday, with its interest rate rising to 6.77 percent. Stock prices often fall with bonds because higher interest rates raise corporate borrowing costs and slow consumer spending.
Higher rates "mean trouble for basic industry issues" like the Dow industrials, Mr. Brown said.
The Dow was bolstered by its three oil-stock components -- Chevron, Texaco and Exxon -- which rose with crude prices amid news that the United States and Britain have pushed the United Nations to toughen its negotiating position with Iraq over a possible oil-for-food deal.
Despite strong earnings reports, energy stocks struggled Monday amid indications of progress in the Iraq talks. An increase in world crude supplies could lower prices, hurting oil company profits.
In commodities trading yesterday, short-term contracts for crude oil jumped 5 percent, and oil stocks followed suit. Exxon rose 2 5/8, to 84 5/8; Chevron rose 1 7/8, to 57 5/8, and Texaco rose 1 3/4, to 85 5/8, as the Dow's three biggest gainers.
But the increase in oil prices hurt airline stocks. The Dow Jones transportation average fell nearly 1 percent.
Digital Equipment, up 5 1/4, to 60 5/8, reported that its quarterly earnings rose 68 percent as the computer maker posted strong sales increases in its storage and server lines.
Among other Big Boardtechnology issues, Motorola rose 2 1/4, to 61 3/4; Compaq Computer gained 1 1/2, to 43 7/8, and Texas Instruments rose 1 3/4, to 85 5/8. But I.B.M., down 1/4, to 107, continued to struggle in the aftermath of a cautious outlook issued by the company last week.

HEADLINE: Times Square Heralds Megastore

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
"Good glitz," said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Commission, looking somewhat sheepish yesterday, his pants legs soaked with champagne, amid a crush of shoppers and curiosity seekers at the opening of the Virgin Megastore Times Square.
"This is showboating, but that never hurt in Times Square," he said. 
 So it was during the big, brash and thoroughly hyped opening of what the Virgin Group, a British company, calls the largest record, movie, book and multimedia store on earth. At 75,000 square feet, spread over three floors on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets, the store has emerged as the most dynamic commercial enterprise to sprout from the redevelopment of the Times Square area.
Over the last year, the redevelopment effort has made its greatest strides yet, with corporations seeking to get a piece of Times Square's overhaul before all the property is gobbled up.
But many of those deals have yet to change the landscape of the area, and the Virgin Megastore is a sign of what may lie ahead.
"Times Square is the heart of America," said Richard Branson, Virgin's chairman, a master of marketing and hyperbole who had wetted the legs of Mr. Millard and other top development officials while christening the store. Mr. Branson made the comments after he was lowered on a huge New Year's-style silver ball from 100 feet above the store.
"We would like to congratulate city and state officials for doing a great job in improving the character of Times Square," he said.
Virgin said the store would have a vast selection of music and entertainment products and promotions similar to those offered by the megabookstores that have opened across the country. For example, it will promote appearances by celebrity musicians and other performers, including appearances this week by the rock group Foo-Fighters and the actor Mark Hamill.
The store will include a cafe, and its lower level provides the only entrance to a four-screen Sony movie theater, which is to open today.
Yesterday, the fate of the neighborhood's best known building -- One Times Square, where the real New Year's Eve ball is lowered -- became clearer when Jeffrey Katz, a Manhattan developer who bought the building a year ago, said in an interview that he planned to begin extensive renovations within six months.
Mr. Katz plans to strip the facade of the building and replace it on all sides, partly with glass but mostly with large neon signs. He said he also planned to develop four to six floors of retail space at the base of the building, and had been interviewing potential tenants, like restaurants and entertainment-related stores.
Virgin's opening was just one of several store openings in the area of 42d Street and Broadway, where vendors like the Foot Locker and the Magic Max stores have opened in recent months, replete with neon signs, as required by the city for all new stores in the neighborhood.
By June 1, according to state officials who are coordinating the redevelopment of 42d Street, business openings at the intersection will include Hansen's Times Square Brewery Restaurant, operated by a German company; a Ferrara's delicatessen, operated by Ferrara's of Little Italy; Cinema Ride, a virtual-reality emporium, and O'Lunney's, a tavern.
By November, other openings are expected to include an Ellen's Stardust Diner and a Disney Store. The Disney Store, at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, will be next to the New Amsterdam Theater, which Disney is renovating and expects to open by next spring.
The surge of new commercial activity comes after 15 years of lawsuits, public protests and delays over plans by city and state officials to redevelop Times Square.
Urban planners and retail analysts said yesterday that the opening of the Virgin Megastore represented a critical turning point for the neighborhood, because other businesses would quickly follow on its heels.
"Virgin has created a major retail footprint in an area where no one would venture, and it's a brilliant move," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of economics and planning at New York University. "They are going to be to the 1990's what Bloomingdale's was to the 1980's."
Virgin executives said yesterday that they began planning their Times Square store three years ago, but had at first questioned whether enough progress would be made in clearing blight from the surrounding blocks.
"We looked at the heritage of Times Square as an entertainment center and an international crossroads and decided it was the best possible place for our American flagship store," said Brian Regan, a spokesman for Virgin, which operates five other United States record stores and is planning more.
Now, he said, "we are an extension of the energy and vibe that is happening in Times Square."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A crowd on Broadway awaited the big, brash and thoroughly byped opening yesterday of the Virgin Megastore Times Square, promoted as the largest record, movie, book and multimedia store in the world. (Linda Rosier for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as a surprisingly strong Treasury auction pulled bonds off their lows of the day.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 12/32, to 90 4/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.77 percent, from 6.74 percent on Monday. The short end of the market bounced back more strongly in the afternoon, with the rate of the three-month bill falling one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 4.96 percent. The yields of the existing one-year, two-year and three-year bills ended unchanged. 
 Treasury prices were under pressure early in the session as traders and dealers were busy positioning themselves ahead of an $18.75 billion auction of two-year notes. A sharp rise in a weekly retail sales survey and reports showing a narrowing of the nation's trade gap and a rise in import prices prompted market participants, wary of any sign of accelerating inflation, to sell off securities.
But prices recovered after the auction exceeded expectations.
The new two-year notes were awarded at a high yield of 5.939 percent, lower than the 5.95 percent market participants had expected. Traders said bids were more aggressive, with good investor demand.
The sale was especially impressive given that the Treasury auctioned new two-year and five-year notes just weeks ago. Nonetheless, yesterday's auction of two-year notes was $500 million larger than the previous one.
Today, the Treasury auctions $12.5 billion of new five-year notes. Larry M. Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that the volume of interest in the two-year auction led him to expect that the five-year note would receive a similar degree of interest, and ease concerns about supply ahead of next week's report on April employment.
Some traders and analysts, however, expect the auction of five-year notes may not be as successful. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.28 percent.
Several reports pointing to mounting inflation depressed prices early in the session. The Commerce Department said that the nation's trade deficit shrank to $8.2 billion in February, suggesting that economic growth was picking up. In a separate report, the Labor Department said that import prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
But analysts said the data also showed signs of weakness.
For example, the gain in import prices was chiefly a result of oil prices, an often volatile category, which surged 7.1 percent in March.
And Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, said that despite February's improvement, he expected the trade deficit would widen for the first quarter. "A decline in net exports will be a drag on first-quarter gross domestic product growth, holding it to around a 1.5 percent rate," he said. It should also further ease market fears that inflation will accelerate.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes:

HEADLINE: WHAT ROOMS MAY BE WEARING NEXT YEAR;
Give Me That Old-Time Millennium

BYLINE: By LIZ SEYMOUR 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., April 21

 BODY:
On Day 3 of the International Home Furnishings Market, the world's largest retail furniture expo, buyers hurrying between showroom buildings paused while the skies darkened and the temperature dropped. A funnel cloud that someone reported at the city limits never did touch down, but weather remained on everyone's mind.
Retailers from the Northeast and Midwest arrived at the semiannual market after a disastrous winter of record snowfalls. Continued consumer caution and the rumble of higher interest rates did not improve their mood. 
 "Our business was basically devastated for three months," said Elliot Rubin, who opened the New York area's first La-Z-Boy store in Cedar Grove, N.J., in November.
Shipments of new furniture in the $48.7 billion industry were down 2 percent in the first two months of this year, the American Furniture Manufacturers Association said.
This spring, it was a "Waiting to Exhale" market without clearly developed trends. The 2,300 showrooms generally displayed a kind of end-of-millennium nostalgia. A shift toward yellow-green and dark finishes evoked the 1940's, the 50's, the 60's and even the 70's.
Mohair, tweed and chrome (the last used lavishly by Ralph Lauren in a $15,885 four-poster bed and an $8,265 trestle table for Henredon), threatened to return. Even "Mediterranean," a word all but banned from the design lexicon for two decades, was back, most notably in Thomasville's 115-piece Renaissance Collection of ornate, large-scale furniture. Goods ordered at the April market will not appear in stores until the fall.
Along with the color shift came a definite tilt toward Europe, away from Shaker, Mission and other American designs of the last few years. France was the country of choice, but the design menu was more Julia Child than Brillat-Savarin.
Baker unveiled a Directoire bed in its Historic Charleston group, and Hickory Chair redrew international boundaries with French Canadian pieces in its American Digest line.
"This is European styling for the American market," said Tom Tilley, senior vice president of Century Furniture, which uses a robot to distress and add gouge marks and wormholes to the maple wood in its new Town and Country collection.
Even contemporary style was spoken with a French accent. The Art Deco designer Jean-Michel Frank, who died in 1941, was the most famous trend setter not actually in attendance. His angular work inspired the carriage-trade maker John Widdicomb as well as Mitchell Gold, whose customers include Pottery Barn.
The droopy slipcovered look (Early Windstorm) was clearly on its way out. The freshest upholstered chairs and sofas looked tailored and taut, as though someone had put a skate key in the back of each and given it a few turns.
Out, too, was rumpled washed linen and faded chintz: new fabrics often mixed cotton with a little rayon or polyester. Just enough for sheen; not enough to raise your barometric pressure.
 
Restoring the Shop Of a Native Son
MILTON, N.C. -- THE lone stoplight in Caswell County blinks green and red at the crossroads in this tiny town (population 200) near the Virginia border. Two blocks away sits the half-burned shell of the 1815 Union Tavern, shored up with timbers and surrounded by yellow tape.
Union Tavern was once the workshop of Thomas Day, a rare free African-American cabinetmaker whose antebellum customers included the Governor, the University of North Carolina and local tobacco barons; at one time, Day's was the largest furniture making operation in the state. Efforts to restore the tavern, burned in a grassfire in 1989, have brought together a biracial coalition of Caswell County's citizens who hail Thomas Day as their most distinguished native son.
Restoration came one step closer with the introduction at the International Home Furnishinas Market of Craftique Furniture's Thomas Day Collection. The collection is made up of 18 reproductions of Day's Empire and Federal-style designs in mahogany and includes bedroom and dining room furniture. Royalties will go toward the tavern restoration.
"I think he'd be pleased," said Marian Thomas, sipping iced tea in the Craftique showroom at an opening-day party on April 18. Mrs. Thomas heads the committee to re 1/8 store Union Tavern.
"It's a great day for Tom Day," she said.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Doom, Gloom and Some Insults

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"Paul Ehrlich and the Population Bomb," on Channel 13 tomorrow night, is an admiring profile of the environmental Cassandra who has been issuing warnings for three decades about overpopulation in the poorest countries and overconsumption in the richest countries. Despite improvements in farming and health that have given ammunition to critics of his famous 1968 polemic, "The Population Bomb," his predictions of famine and revolution remain as dire as ever.
A few of the critics are heard from in this hour, notably Julian Simon, a University of Maryland economist who has scored some points off the Ehrlichians, but the hour belongs to Mr. Ehrlich. David Suzuki, the Canadian geneticist and television personality who narrates, is positively adoring, and Mr. Ehrlich himself remains as self-assured as he was in the 1970's when, sideburns reaching toward his chin, he often showed up on the "Tonight" show. He told Johnny Carson then, "I do believe doom is coming," and he is saying pretty much the same thing now. 
 Never given to understat'ment or diffidence, this Stanford University specialist in butterflies shows he can still get off some pithy insults. He describes creationists as "a group of morons"; he puts down "flacks of the pesticide i'dustry," who, he adds "have no shame"; he shrugs off most scientists for, unlike himself, doing "dull ignorant work that is of no significance to humanity"; he calls Mr. Simon's assertion that there are no known physical limits to growth "totally imbecilic."t
Dismissing the notion that voluntary birth control can work ("nonsensical"), he has called for "coercion in a good cause," for example forcibly sterilizing Indian men who have more than three children. That has sent a chill even among those who share his concerns. Now in what seems a contradiction or may be, for Mr. Ehrlich, a rare modification, he concedes that birth control cannot be imposed from above and says he finds hope in the increasing education and equality of women in poor countries. How to educate or compel Americans to cut down on consumption, however, remains as daunting as ever.
Mr. Ehrlich and his ally, the physicist John Holdren, now maintain that "The Population Bomb," no laugh riot, was optimistic. They see the world as "close to the edge" of absolute scarcity, with the globe's population heading toward 10 billion by the middle of the next century and Western countries gobbling up the resources needed by the impoverished throngs of Asia, Africa and Latin America.
A program that was less adulatory about the man and more probing about his ideas might have been more illuminating. But at the least, you'll come away understanding why Johnny Carson kept bringing Mr. Ehrlich back.
 
'Rights and Wrongs'
PBS, tonight
(Channel 13, New York, at 10:30)
This sobering series, devoted to dr'wing attention to atrocities around the world, not excepting the United States, begins its fourth season with a look at the China trade in illegal immigrants. Accompanied by a hidden camera and a translator, Jon Alpert, known for his verite camera work, negotiates with middlemen in Fujian Province over the per-body charge for shipping a batch of workers to America. The going street price is upward of $32,000; if you prefer dealing with someone who says he is a Chinese official, that will cost $50,000. The smugglers are called "snakeheads," since they lead a line, or snake, of people.
The program also takes us into a Lower East Side basement packed with immigrants; a maximum security jail in California where some of the unfortunate smugglees on the grounded tramp steamer Golden Venture wound up, and a factory -- also known as a sweatshop -- where a successful immigrant family is making clothes for Brooks Brothers.
In coming weeks, "Rights and Wrongs" travels to Chechnya, the Middle East and Nigeria and looks at the status of women's rights, press coverage of human rights and the doings of the World Bank and the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal. Last season the host, Charlayne Hunter-Gault, took umbrage at charges that the series was tilted to the left; a few weeks should tell whether the right is wrong about that.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Mark Stems Recent Losses, Sending Dollar Modestly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly lower against most leading currencies yesterday in light trading as the German mark staged a moderate recovery from a week of selling.
A lower bond-market close and some lower stock prices also helped pull the dollar down against the mark and the Japanese yen. 
 The mark had been pummeled for a week since Germany lowered its interest rates and an election in Italy revived hopes for European monetary union. Yesterday, currency traders took profits on the dollar's gains against the mark, and the mark recovered some of its lost ground.
But the mark remains weak, hurt by expectations that interest rates will fall further this year and that German monetary authorities want a weaker mark to help bolster exports.
Speculation that the move toward monetary union might be back on track has also hurt the mark, because as Europe's premier currency, it stands to lose the most by a merger with the currencies of Germany's economically weaker neighbors.
Despite the dip of the dollar against the yen and the mark, it remained above highs reached a week ago. The dollar has benefited because higher interest rates have attracted more investors than lower rates in Europe and Japan.
"People are trying to find the next reason to buy dollars," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an investment advisory firm. "The market is still bullish."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.5203 marks from 1.5212 marks on Tuesday. It traded at 106.53 yen, down from 106.67 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5150 from $1.5165.
Traders liked the dollar early in the day after rumors, later denied, that the Japanese central bank was prepared to intervene in the market by buying dollars and selling yen.
According to the rumor, which the bank called "unimaginable," it was asking commercial banks to remain open late and have dollars on hand.
But in New York, American bonds and some stocks lost ground.
"That's why the dollar can't make any ground on the upside," said Hugh Walsh, a foreign exchange vice president at ING Capital Markets Inc. "Obviously, if U.S. assets are being sold off, foreigners need to liquidate dollars in order to liquidate their assets."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
As agency bosses meet, an emphasis on marketing brand names and the growth of new media.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE agenda of the 1996 annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies looks much like those of the last four meetings. But that does not concern the executives who planned the meeting because, as K. C. and the Sunshine Band might proclaim, that's the way -- uh-huh, uh-huh -- they like it.
The reason those executives are reveling in repetition is that the 78th annual meeting of the association, which began yesterday in the sunshine of Indian Wells, Calif., is purposely being focused on a handful of issues that have been deemed significant since 1992, when agencies struggled to emerge from a steep, sustained recession. 
 Before then, the only constant topics from one meeting to the next seemed to be golf and tennis scores. Agendas varied widely -- and sometimes wildly -- as issues went in one year and out the other.
The issues on the agenda for the 1996 meeting, which continues through tomorrow at the Renaissance Esmeralda Resort, near Palm Springs, include the importance of demonstrating to skeptical marketers how powerful advertising can be in selling brand-name products to consumers, finding ways to help agencies exploit the explosive growth of the new media and assisting agencies in recruiting and retaining a diverse work force.
"We're coalescing around common interests to advance the cause of the industry," said Burt Manning, chairman and chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of the WPP Group in New York. He is the 1995-96 chairman of the association, which is also known as the Four A's.
"We're very much committed to programs that work toward a realistic view of how advertising builds brands," Mr. Manning said, "that focus on on-line advertising and how to make it accountable and that look to increasing the diversity of the staffs of the agencies."
David Bell, the 1995-96 vice chairman of the Four A's, agreed, praising the "continuity and consistency" of the agendas.
As for efforts to "promote the value of advertising," said Mr. Bell, who is chairman and chief executive of the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York, he would like to underline how crucial it could be to marketers "by moving the argument directly to return on investment and shareholder value."
In fact, he added, "I'd like the theme of the 1997 meeting to be on the effectiveness of enduring advertising." Mr. Bell's thoughts about next year's agenda are relevant because at a business session yesterday afternoon, he was elected the 1996-97 chairman of the association.
The new media, particularly interactive media like the Internet, will be the subject of several sessions at the 1996 meeting.
"We're trying to balance some of the hype," O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the Four A's, said in a telephone interview from his New York office before the meeting. "Everyone knows there's an Internet. Now comes the hard slogging: the consumer figuring out how to use it in an easy way and the agencies figuring out how to use it properly and cost-effectively."
In a speech today, Mr. Drake plans to discuss the results of a survey of member agencies on interactive technology. "Among those agencies involved in building Web sites," he said, "a full 25 percent say that's the only business they have with the client. That means the interactive business is new business."
And of the 203 agencies that participated in the survey, he added, 180, or nearly 89 percent, said they used interactive media in some form.
The concentration of issues to be addressed at the meeting has coincided with a narrowing of the audience at which it is aimed. Once meant to appeal to agency executives whatever their responsibilities, Mr. Drake said, the meeting has since been "positioned very clearly as a meeting for C.E.O.'s."
A conference for agency media executives is now held separately every February, he added, and the first conference for agency creative executives is set for the fall.
"Broadening the meetings and doing them on a very vertical basis is paying off," Mr. Drake said, citing combined attendance of almost 1,100 for the 1996 media conference, which drew 640 attendees in Orlando, Fla., and the meeting in Indian Wells, with attendance anticipated at about 420.
Mr. Manning said: "Clearly, this indicates the ability of the Four A's to adapt. If you target, you get more people." And Mr. Bell said the format of multiple meetings "has injected new life" into the concept of annual gatherings.
In addition to Mr. Bell's election, Ralph Rydholm, chairman and chief executive of the Euro RSCG Tatham unit of Havas Advertising in Chicago, was elected the 1996-97 vice chairman. And Byron Lewis, chairman and chief executive of the Uniworld Group in New York, was elected secretary and treasurer.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Good news for the down and out, or are the data misleading?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHAT'S all this fuss about income inequality? Sure, the richer are richer and the poor are eating Doritos. But not to worry, says W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm, researchers at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas: Most Americans struggling to make ends meet are on the fast track to affluence.
They found that just 5 percent of a sample of Americans in the bottom fifth of the income distribution in 1975 were still there 16 years later. Meanwhile, 29 percent of them had managed to grab the brass ring, ending up in the top fifth. And "between opportunity and equality," they remind, "it's opportunity that matters most." 
 The Cox-Alm study, published in the Dallas Federal Reserve's 1995 annual report, is making big waves among the movers and shakers of the political right. Indeed, after a ringing endorsement from the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, it has become required reading for conservatives impatient with the current hand-wringing over the alleged plight of the young and immobile.
But a close look at the new research is not confidence-building. Indeed, even a casual look suggests that something -- actually, many things -- are amiss. "Cox and Alm ask the wrong question and give a misleading answer to the question they ask," argues Peter Gottschalk, an economist at Boston College and co-author of "America Unequal" (Russell Sage Foundation).
Standard measures of income distribution amount to snapshots at a moment in time. The large and growing variations between those at the top and bottom that have been reported by the Census are, of course, cause for disquiet. But liberals and conservatives generally agree that mobility matters, too. And without exception, studies that track the fortunes of individuals or families for many years suggest that lifetime income is distributed far more equally than income in any single year.
The Cox-Alm study is in this tradition. It follows 3,725 individuals ages 16 and over who remained part of the University of Michigan's Panel Survey on Income Dynamics for a 16-year period. And their conclusions are nothing short of remarkable. Of those in the bottom fifth in 1975, 95 percent were earning enough money in 1991 to have jumped in the rankings. Poverty in the 1975 snapshot was apparently no impediment to future economic success. The average income of individuals in the bottom fifth rose by $25,322, even after adjustment for inflation.
Mr. Gottschalk, however, notes that the Dallas researchers use unconventional means to reach these astonishing ends. For one thing, they measure incomes actually earned by individuals, rather than assigning individuals some prorated share of family income. As a result, the average earnings of the bottom fifth in 1975 was just $1,153 -- far less than anyone could actually live on.
Who, then, were these people? Probably not the poorest individuals, but the ones who worked only briefly in 1975. Mr. Gottschalk guesses most of them were part-time workers with marginal links to the formal labor force: students with after-school jobs, housewives who worked at the post office in the Christmas rush, and so forth.
Sixteen years later their average incomes had risen a fantastic 23-fold, to $26,475. To Mr. Gottschalk, this suggests that virtually all the former high school and college students in the sample had full-time jobs in 1991, as did most of the mothers whose children had grown up. "I'd be surprised if my teen-ager, who now earns pocket money delivering newspapers, doesn't do equally well," he allowed.
Mr. Gottschalk says, too, that by tracking individuals over time the Cox-Alm study mingles the impact of real economic mobility with income gains linked to accumulating work experience. It should hardly be surprising that 35-year-old carpenters make more than they did when they were 19-year-old carpenters.
What does all this add up to? "We have long known that mobility partially offsets the impact of inequality," says Van Doorn Ooms, director of research at the Committee for Economic Development. "It's still unclear by how much."
One answer that probably better represents the mainstream in economic research comes from Moshe Buchinsky and Jennifer Hunt of Yale University. In a paper published this year by the National Bureau of Economic Research, they estimated that averaging family incomes over a four-year period reduced measured inequality by about one-fourth. But they also found that the rate of economic mobility -- the probability of moving from one-fifth of the income distribution to another in any given year -- had actually fallen since 1980.
"Maybe it would make sense to spend less time splitting hairs over what's happened -- and more trying to figure out what can be done for the losers," Mr. Ooms concludes.
