HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Slide After Auction Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities ended lower yesterday, retreating from highs that were reached during the session after an auction of five-year notes was stronger than expected.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 89 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.82 percent, from 6.77 percent on Tuesday. 
 After an auction of two-year notes showed strong interest on Tuesday, expectations ran high in the market.
While prices moved lower as dealers and buyers prepared for the Treasury's sale of five-year notes, sentiment was generally bullish, especially after a report showed that orders for durable goods, excluding the volatile category of transportation equipment, fell 1 percent in March. Total new orders rose 1.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $167.6 billion.
The Commerce Department report was consistent with current expectations for steady, moderate economic growth over the the next six months, said Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio, said, "The market's reaction was positive going into the five-year auction, with the notion that the five-year note would go at a high yield of 6.29 percent."
The high yield in fact came in lower than that, reflecting strong demand for the notes. The Treasury sold $12.5 billion in new five-year notes at a high yield of 6.279 percent.
But the afternoon rally prompted by the strong results of the auction soon ran out of steam on signs that the Wall Street firms that had bought the new notes at auction were having trouble selling them to customers.
Institutional investors showed little interest, said Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, which meant that dealers wound up owning a large chunk of the auction.
Mr. Donne said, "Dealers aggressively bid the five and ended up owning more of it than they were comfortable with."
One way for dealers to clear out some of the excess securities they hold is to discount the prices, which has the effect of raising the yields and making the securities more attractive to investors.
That appeared to be the case late yesterday as the yield on the new five-year note rose to 6.33 percent in when-issued trading, from the 6.279 percent at the auction.
While there was some market relief at the end of the auction, there is still more supply on the way. The Treasury plans to auction new one-year notes today, and the Government's quarterly re-funding of debt is coming. The Treasury will announce the size of those sales next week.
In the municipal market, the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York sold $820 million in bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The bonds, which were rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's, were initially priced to yield from 3.75 percent for an issue due in 1997 to 5.35 percent for a bond due in 2008.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Climbs to Record For Fifth Straight Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index climbed to a record for the fifth straight session yesterday as the recent boom in technology and small-company issues made it the busiest day in Wall Street's history.
In contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.69 to close at 5,553.90 on concerns that rising interest rates and inflation would impede earnings growth for big companies. The Dow was off more than 50 points earlier in the session before rebounding slightly. 
 Most broad market measures fell, too, but the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite surged 10.07 points, to 1,176.83, on record volume and has now risen more than 7 percent in less than two weeks. Nasdaq volume totaled 728.6 million shares, crushing the mark of 650.1 million, set on Tuesday.
The combined trading volume of all United States stock markets totaled 1.353 billion, edging the high of 1.352 billion set last Dec. 15.
Technology stocks have been riding a wave of surprisingly strong earnings reports over the last two weeks. Yesterday Compaq Computer became the latest industry bellwether to help dispel widespread fears of sluggish computer sales that swept the stock market earlier this year.
Compaq, the world's leading personal computer maker, said its profit rose 8 percent and sales jumped 45 percent during the first quarter. Compaq shares jumped 3 1/8, to 47, and investors quickly bid up other rival computer issues as well, including Digital Equipment, Hewlett Packard, Dell Computer and Gateway 2000.
Smaller-company stocks, which saw little improvement while the Dow surged earlier this year, also continued their sudden record-setting pace. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies set its fifth straight record and has now risen more than 4.5 percent in less than two weeks.
Analysts said smaller stocks have come into favor because their earnings growth is more likely to outpace bigger companies if the economy continues to improve.
Declining issues, at 1,205, outnumbered advances, 1,168, by a slim margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 494.2 million shares as of 4 P.M., well above Tuesday's pace.
The Big Board's composite index fell 0.64, to 348.96, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.41, to 650.17.
The Amex market value index fell 1.68, to 589.05, ending a six-session streak of record finishes.
Analysts attributed some of the broad market's decline to some poor earnings reports, continuing weakness in the bond market and the dollar's renewed strength against other currencies, which hurts multinational companies that convert foreign revenue to dollars.
Bond prices edged lower after the Commerce Department reported that orders to United States factories for big-ticket durable goods rose 1.4 percent in March, the first gain in three months. Although many analysts had expected little change in orders in March, they predict demand will pick up moderately as the year progresses.
"The market is not as bad as it looks," said Michael Metz, market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. "The real weakness is in consumer nondurables.
"If interest rates go up, valuations on these companies fall. And the rising dollar will hurt when companies translate overseas profits. That's finally sinking in with investors."
Disney shares fell 1 1/8, to 60 5/8, a day after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $25 million, partly because of lower movie profits.
Merck, another consumer-stock component of the Dow industrials, slid 1 3/8, to 60 3/8, as other leading drug stocks also gave ground.
Rite Aid, fell, 1 3/4, to 29 7/8, and Revco D.S., was down 1 7/8, at 24 1/8, after Rite Aid withdrew its $1.8 billion offer to buy Revco D.S. following Government contentions that a merger of the nation's top two drugstore chains would dominate the business in the East and Midwest.
Cigna rose 4 3/8, to 112 1/8, after saying it planned to buy back from investors up to $500 million of its stock.
Wm. Wrigley Jr., the chewing gum maker, was down 3 1/2, to 52 after reporting first-quarter earnings that fell below analysts' expectations. Wrigley also announced it would close its factory in Santa Cruz, Calif., which will reduce earnings in the second quarter ending in June by $12 million, or 10 cents a share.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING: NOTEBOOK;
At Indy, Young Drivers in Old Cars

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
The Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced the entry list for the 1996 Indianapolis 500 last week, and it reflected the upside-down nature of things in this year of the boycott: youthfulness where it is the biggest problem (among the drivers) and years of experience where it does the least good (in the cars).
The number of cars entered, 77, is down from just over 100 last year, but the total is good considering that most of the top car owners are skipping the race to protest new qualifying rules and running instead in the U.S. 500 on the same day, May 26. At least 25 of the 1996 Indy entries are cars that are in their fourth or fifth season of racing. 
 The boycott is in response to rules changes announced by the speedway last summer that virtually guarantee 25 of the 33 Indy starting spots to the top cars in the point standing of the new Indy-car series, the Indy Racing League, which was organized by the speedway as a rival to the established circuit conducted by Championship Auto Racing Teams.
Exactly 60 percent of the 35 drivers entered -- 21 -- have never started an Indy 500; only nine drivers have started three or more Indy 500 races. The record for the most rookies in an Indy 500 (other than the first race in 1911) is 19, set in 1919.
One potentially positive consequence of having only 35 drivers fighting for 33 starting spots is that with the chances of being bumped from the lineup so slim, the younger drivers won't have to spend lap after lap in May pushing themselves and their cars to the limit for every last bit of speed. They can concentrate instead on finding a comfortable race-day setup and learning to drive in traffic.
Rookie orientation, set for May 4 to May 6, will probably uncover a few drivers among those 21 first-timers who aren't ready to go over 220 miles an hour, and they will be asked to try again next year. On the other hand, teams can always add drivers, so the exact number of people who will be fighting for the 33 starting spots is not certain.
Even if no more than 33 drivers take a shot at making the lineup, there may still be some pressure on them; the speedway will announce a minimum qualifying speed before qualifying begins.
 
History and Economics 101
 When the Winston Cup cars raced at North Wilkesboro Speedway on April 14, many fans were taking a long, last look at the place, in the belief that it might have been the final appearance of Nascar's top series at its oldest track. But North Wilkesboro's history as a Winston Cup track probably has at least one more chapter.
The North Carolina track, which had its first Nascar race in 1949, is owned by Bruton Smith and Bob Bahre. Smith's company, Speedway Motorsports, also owns Charlotte Motor Speedway, Atlanta Motor Speedway, Bristol International Raceway (each with two Winston Cup dates) and the as-yet-completed Texas Motor Speedway near Fort Worth. Bahre owns New Hampshire International Speedway in Loudon.
Each man possesses a lust for what North Wilkesboro now has: two Winston Cup dates. Bahre would like to add a second date to the July Winston Cup race he now has at his track, while Smith desperately needs a cup race to fill the 150,000 seats he is building in Texas -- although two races are closer to what he will need to cover his $110 million construction bill.
The answer seems simple: Bahre could shift one North Wilkesboro date to New Hampshire and Smith could move the other to Texas.
Before that, there is the second 1996 Winston Cup date at North Wilkesboro, on Sept. 29, to deal with. Smith's track is scheduled to be ready by then. But Bahre, who says he paid $8 million for his half of North Wilkesboro, and Smith have been unable to reach an agreement in time to shift that date to either track.
"Bruton Smith is a very difficult man to work with," Bahre said by telephone this week. Smith, Bahre said, is trying to buy back Bahre's half of North Wilkesboro, but Smith can stop talking. "I don't care what he offers me," Bahre said, "I want a second date."
An issue that could create problems is determining the value of North Wilkesboro's assets for tax purposes. In the long term, those two Winston Cup races are certainly worth a lot more at either Bahre's track or Smith's track than they are at North Wilkesboro, which has only about 40,000 seats.
A decision would have to be made soon, since North Wilkesboro will start selling tickets for the September race next Monday. "As far as I'm concerned, they're going to start selling the tickets," Bahre said Tuesday. "We had a deal partly together for this fall, but it fell apart."
 
Psst! Wanna Buy a Car?
 Many CART teams have been selling their 1995 cars to I.R.L. teams. One CART team owner, Derrick Walker, has shown himself to be the man you want to buy a used race car from. One chassis he sold was driven to victory by Buzz Calkins in the first I.R.L. race and another won the only other I.R.L. race so far with Arie Luyendyk driving. But a third car never made it into the hands of its driver, Richie Hearn, because Walker's team crashed it while testing it. Hearn's team got a full refund.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The S.E.C. chief wades into the battle over accounting rules.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE battle over accounting rules is on, and Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is demanding a bigger role than ever in deciding who picks the people who write the rules.
Mr. Levitt is asking that the Financial Accounting Foundation, which chooses the members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, have a majority of public representatives as opposed to representatives of various groups with a stake in accounting rules. And he wants the S.E.C. to have the power to approve who is chosen for the board.
The move comes at a time when corporate financial executives have been putting pressure on the foundation to reform the F.A.S.B. in ways that would increase the power of business to block unwanted accounting standards. 
 In a talk prepared for delivery last night to the Economic Club of Chicago, Mr. Levitt disclosed his initiative and seemed to come out against the effort to increase corporate power in the process, saying that he was trying "to strengthen and safeguard the independence of financial accounting standard-setting."
The Financial Accounting Foundation is charged with raising the money to support the F.A.S.B. and the Government Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting rules for government agencies, and with naming the members of those boards. And it has the authority to change the way those boards are structured.
Currently, the foundation has 14 trustees, all but one chosen by such various constituency groups as the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the Financial Executives Institute and the Securities Industry Association. The sole public member, chosen by the other trustees, is Kathryn D. Wriston, a director of various organizations and the wife of Walter B. Wriston, the retired chairman of Citicorp.
In a letter to J. Michael Cook, the foundation's president and the chairman of Deloitte & Touche, a large accounting firm, Mr. Levitt said he thought a majority of the trustees should "consist of individuals with strong public service backgrounds, who are able to represent the public interest, free of conflict."
The F.A.S.B. has come under increasing fire over the years from corporations, which have won a series of concessions but have continued to grumble. The board can now approve standards only by a super-majority vote -- five of its seven members, two of whom come from companies. Using political influence, including a vote of the Senate, the companies forced the board to back down when it tried to force them to report as an expense the value of stock options given to executives and other employees.
When that happened, Mr. Levitt had little to say. But in the wake of an effort by some members of the Financial Executives Institute to force wholesale changes, he appears to have decided to step in and fight.
In his letter to Mr. Cook, Mr. Levitt complained that the F.A.S.B. "is not being adequately reinforced by its parent organization and, thus, its public interest objectives are at risk."
Mr. Cook, in an interview late yesterday, said the trustees would address the issues raised by Mr. Levitt at their meeting on Tuesday, and would act quickly. He added that he hoped decisions on changing the F.A.S.B. would be made within a few months, but it is clear that Mr. Levitt wants those decisions to be made by a reconstituted board.
Just who those people are will be crucial. And finding people who are both disinterested and well informed will be a challenge.
In a telephone interview last night, Kenneth Johnson, the controller of Motorola and one of the executives who has been pushing for changes at the F.A.S.B., said he had not seen Mr. Levitt's letter and could not comment on it. But he added that the F.A.S.B. had to be changed. "They are so enamored with theoretical accounting purity that they are unable to look at the practical effects of what they are trying to do," he said.
Mr. Cook said he wanted to make changes that would enable the board to win "higher approval ratings," although he added that any standard-setter would anger some people, and he said changes clearly were needed to make the board more productive.
But the risk is that in winning approval from the corporate executives who are now the angriest, the eventual loser could be the investors who depend on financial statements. "If standards are drawn, or even seen to be drawn, to favor corporate interests over those of investors, faith in our markets will erode," Mr. Levitt said.

HEADLINE: Florida Facing Crisis in Insurance

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MARY ESTHER, Fla.

 BODY:
Sarah Anderson says that after Hurricane Opal last year, her street in this small Gulf of Mexico town in the Florida Panhandle "looked like a combat zone," with roof shingles strewn about, chimneys blown down and waterfront houses flooded.
That storm was a breeze compared with Hurricane Andrew, which in 1992 ravaged parts of South Florida, causing $16 billion in insured losses that made it the nation's most expensive natural disaster. Mrs. Anderson's house was not damaged by the hurricane, but she got a strong idea of the punishment wind and water could inflict. The deductible on her homeowner's policy is doubling to $500, she said, but she feels almost thankful as a new hurricane season nears. 
 "We feel lucky to have insurance," Mrs. Anderson, 58, said. "We've got a lot of our savings invested in this."
But even homeowners like Mrs. Anderson and her husband, Edwin, 65, are in a fragile position should another major storm hit Florida. The insurance industry here still has not recovered from the financial beating inflicted by Andrew. And although Florida is taking innovative steps to keep private insurers in business and has itself become the second-largest insurer in the state, many companies say they need more help.
Some state officials say some companies are themselves to blame for a problem that they created with low prices to gain market share that have led to overexposure. And a state panel of educators, economists and insurance experts has called Hurricane Andrew a temporary setback in what has been "a history of profitability" for Florida's insurance markets.
But insurance companies note that they risk being wiped out because of Florida's population growth, and because of the increased hurricane activity that was seen last year and is predicted by meteorologists for the next 25 years. Florida officials and private insurers agree that they cannot cover the losses should a catastrophic hurricane hit cities like Miami and Fort Lauderdale in the next few years. Indeed, they say thousands of homeowners, who have experienced an average 72 percent increase in insurance rates since 1992, could be left without enough money to rebuild unless the state and Federal governments made major appropriations.
"We're going in the right direction," said Florida's Insurance Commissioner, Bill Nelson, "but we're in a crisis."
Hurricane Andrew, which caused $10 billion in insured damages to homes, led to the bankruptcy of nine small insurance companies and depleted the profits of bigger ones. More important, it warned insurers that they had underestimated a hurricane's capacity for destruction.
After that storm, Florida created an insurance pool, the Residential Property and Casualty Joint Underwriting Association, to provide coverage to homeowners dropped by private insurers. State officials say the fund, which has 875,000 customers and a $1.5 billion line of credit, can handle losses similar to those caused by Hurricane Andrew and can turn to bond financing for a larger storm. Private insurers would be assessed to cover claims the fund cannot meet.
But insurers and state officials alike point out that there are limits to what the state can cover, and they warn of difficulties if a hurricane hits a large metropolitan area and causes residential losses of $25 billion to $50 billion. Florida officials add that the state fund was meant to be temporary and that the goal is for private insurers to return to covering all homeowners.
Bills have been introduced in both houses of the State Legislature to ask consumers to share a larger part of the cost of hurricane damage through higher rates and deductibles. But whether covered by the state fund or private insurers, Florida homeowners are already paying higher rates. In high-risk areas like Dade County, which includes Miami, premiums have more than doubled.
Some homeowners are being forced to forgo certain coverage to reduce their costs. Robert Polo, a junkyard operator in Miami who owns a five-bedroom ranch house, said he just dropped coverage for the contents to keep his annual premium at $1,400.
"It's just going through the roof," Mr. Polo said.
The hurricane risk for the private market is made more acute because half of the state's residential customers are insured by only two companies, which now consider themselves dangerously overexposed. The two -- the State Farm Fire and Casualty Company, with a 32 percent market share and the Allstate Insurance Company, with 18 percent -- competed for market share in the 1970's and 1980's by cutting prices. The companies and others estimate their rates are 20 percent to 40 percent below what they need to meet potential losses here.
Commissioner Nelson said the ultimate solution would be a Federal national disaster fund. Meanwhile, he advocates extending for three more years a 1993 moratorium on most policy cancellations and nonrenewals. The moratorium is to expire this month.
The moratorium has helped prevent insurers from dropping policies en masse. Its extension, the Commissioner said, would allow "breathing room" for the state to stabilize the market. He said Florida was already using financial enticements to attract new insurance companies here to pick up policies from the state pool.
Florida has also set up a reserve fund, unique in the country, to reimburse insurers based on their market share for a significant part of losses if a hurricane causes more than $3 billion in residential damages. The fund, established after Hurricane Andrew, has $1 billion in cash from premiums paid by homeowners, and with time is expected to be able to absorb the economic blow of a major storm.
But small insurance companies want additional help, like more pricing freedom from state regulators and an end to the moratorium. And large companies have called for a way to transfer hurricane risk to the state by taking hurricane coverage out of homeowners' policies.
"We're not talking about shifting a burden to taxpayers -- the burden is already there," said Vince Rio, a lawyer for State Farm in Tallahassee. "What we're talking about is how do we get out of this mess."
State legislators who oppose the idea of transferring hurricane risk to the state say the companies want a quick fix. The state panel that last year studied how to avoid an economic catastrophe concluded that hurricane insurance should remain private but recommended capping insurers' losses.
Premiums earned in Florida have generally exceeded losses. In 1994, the panel said, homeowners' losses were $508 million while $1.4 billion in premiums came in.
"One line of thought," Tim Lynch, the panel's staff director, said, "is that they took the risk, why should they be bailed out by the government?"
In the Panhandle, where Hurricane Opal caused a relatively paltry $2.1 billion in damages last year, rebuilding is still going on in areas like Panama City, Destin, Mary Esther and Navarre as another active hurricane season is being forecast. William Gray, a hurricane forecaster at Colorado State University, has predicted 11 named storms, including two major hurricanes, for the season.
Florida waits.
"If we have another big hurricane," Mr. Nelson said, "all bets are off."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nearly seven months after Hurricane Opal struck the Florida Panhandle, repairs continue in Destin, but there are growing worries that insurers may be unable to cover losses from a storm like Hurricane Andrew in 1992. (Manuel M. Chavez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Teeth at the F.T.C. (Fangs to Some);
Commissioner Steps Up Antitrust Work and Broadens the Agency's Role

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
About a month after William Baer handed the Justice Department a humiliating courtroom defeat, deflating its effort to prove that the General Electric Company had rigged the prices of industrial diamonds, the antitrust lawyer was approached about a new job.
His visitor early last year was Robert Pitofsky, a colleague of Mr. Baer's at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and President Clinton's nominee to be chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. Mr. Pitofsky's proposal: that Mr. Baer turn his skills to work for the Government by heading the arm of the F.T.C. that scrutinizes mergers and antitrust issues. 
 Lawyers describe the hiring of Mr. Baer as a classic move by Mr. Pitofsky, lining up the toughest and brightest for his side of a legal cause. Over a long career in academia and government, the 66-year-old scholar has built a reputation as a low-key but aggressive Washington insider able to get difficult jobs done without ruffling too many feathers.
Under Mr. Pitofsky's predecessor as chairman, Janet Steiger, the F.T.C. had begun shaking off the slumber that critics said characterized the agency during the Reagan era. But Mr. Pitofsky appears to be building an agency that is both more litigious and more eager to push antitrust regulation in new directions as mergers reshape the corporate scene.
No one has suggested that Mr. Pitofsky is going to take the same high-flying approach as Anne K. Bingaman, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, who has brought a number of ambitious cases like the G.E. action only to see them fail. Nonetheless, there is little doubt among antitrust experts that Mr. Pitofsky has begun putting his own stamp on the F.T.C.
"He is interested in bringing cases that set policies and precedent rather than garden-variety cases that the staff says we can win," said Kevin Arquit, a former general counsel and director of the agency's bureau of competition and now a partner at the law firm of Rogers & Wells.
Just yesterday, the Rite Aid Corporation said it would drop its proposed $1.8 billion purchase of Revco D.S. Inc. after the F.T.C. repeatedly threatened legal action, arguing that a merger of the nation's two largest drugstore chains would sharply increase prices. For the first time, the agency rejected a merger on the ground that it would not only raise prices for individual consumers but also for large buyers of prescription drugs, like the discount plans offered to employees by companies.
A little more than a year into Mr. Pitofsky's seven-year term as chairman, legal experts said they expected his tenure to be judged as a time of evolutionary, rather than revolutionary, change. Beyond the traditional focus on maintaining competition, he is prodding the commission to analyze whether deals impede innovation or whether the efficiencies gained in mergers can offset any losses in competition.
"When two companies join, one question is whether you are bulking up to become a power buyer or you are trying to change to become more efficient," he said.
Even those who differ with Mr. Pitofsky on antitrust issues acknowledge that he brings a wealth of experience to his position. He headed the F.T.C.'s consumer-protection arm from 1970 to 1973, and served as an F.T.C. commissioner in the Carter Administration. For most the 1980's, he was dean of the Georgetown University Law Center, and he has written extensively on antitrust issues and frequently testified before Congress.
"It is not invariably true that when someone gets a Government job they know what they are doing," said Joe Sims, an antitrust lawyer in Washington. "But over the past 20 years, Bob Pitofsky has been one of the premier Democratic antitrust experts."
Mr. Pitofsky's arrival at the F.T.C. coincides with changes sweeping the merger arena. The number of mergers filed with the agency has increased 77 percent over its last three fiscal years, according to Government statistics.
But perhaps more importantly, the nature of those mergers has also changed. While the merger boom of the 1980's was stimulated by Wall Street financiers aiming to increase returns through tougher management, the current crop of big mergers involves business consolidations that are revamping industries from health care to communications to military contractors.
"I know people are aware of mergers, but I don't think they have any idea of the magnitude of what is going on," Mr. Pitofsky said. "There are industries that are reinventing themselves."
Historically, oversight of mergers and antitrust issues has been split between the F.T.C. and the Justice Department, with each agency citing its experience with one industry or another to claim jurisdiction over cases. But under the aggressive leadership of Ms. Bingaman, the Justice Department snared most of the headline-grabbing cases in the last three years.
Now, however, the F.T.C. is regaining some balance, a result that antitrust experts attribute to a longstanding friendship between Mr. Pitofsky and Ms. Bingaman. Several lawyers said Mr. Pitofsky and Ms. Bingaman had reduced interagency bickering over cases, with the result that cases are now being assigned more quickly. Currently, for example, the F.T.C. is reviewing the proposed acquisition by Time Warner Inc. of the Turner Broadcasting System.
Some consumer advocates have said that the decision in that case may be watershed event in Mr. Pitofsky's tenure. "The decision will set the tone for the type of consolidation that is consistent with competition and not which will consolidate power in a few hands," said Gene Kimmelman, a co-director of Consumers Union in Washington.
Among other themes, Mr. Pitofsky has signaled that the agency will now take into account the increasingly global nature of competition as it develops antitrust policy.
The agency held hearings last year, taking testimony from corporate officials and legal experts. A report on the F.T.C.'s findings is expected this summer, and while Mr. Pitofsky, characteristically, said he did not expect wholesale changes, he did anticipate some revisions of agency policy.
Under Mr. Pitofsky's leadership, the five-member commission has been testing some of the boundaries of antitrust enforcement.
Last year, it voted to bar a merger of two natural gas companies not because it would limit competition immediately, but on the rarely used theory that it might prove a bar to future competition. In that case, the Questar Corporation, which supplies natural gas to customers in Salt Lake City, sought to acquire a 50 percent interest in the Kern River Gas Transmission Company, which has a pipeline that passes through the same area but does not serve it. As the agency went to court to block the transaction, the companies abandoned the deal.
The F.T.C. is also starting to crack down on companies that it says fail to fully divulge data about the value of acquired assets, thereby masking the effects on market concentration. In February, the Sara Lee Corporation agreed to pay a record $3.1 million fine to settle charges filed by the F.T.C. and the Justice Department that it deliberately hid the value of various shoe polish brands acquired in 1991 from Reckitt & Colman. In settling the charges, Sara Lee denied any wrongdoing.
"Merger filings are being turned upside down and inside out," said Mary Lou Steptoe, a former acting director of the agency's Bureau of Competition and now a lawyer in Washington. In the 1995 fiscal year, agency officials challenged or threatened to challenge 45 proposed mergers, up from 15 similar actions in the 1992 fiscal year.
It is not as if Mr. Pitofsky has been spared the sort of bumps that have tripped up Ms. Bingaman at the Justice Department. His Senate confirmation as chairman was delayed for several months, apparently because some Republicans were angry over his testimony opposing the nomination of Robert H. Bork as a Supreme Court justice in 1987, according to several lawyers familiar with the situation.
Despite Mr. Pitofsky's years as the chief enforcer of consumer protection laws at the F.T.C., some public interest groups have expressed disappointment at the agency's efforts in that area since he became chairman.
Mary Ponder, a projects director with the Consumer Federation of America in Washington, said she believed that new regulations on telemarketing recently approved by the commission still made it too easy for illegitimate telephone solicitors to bilk unsuspecting victims.
Mr. Pitofsky concedes that he is unlikely ever to prove as aggressive as some consumer groups would like.
"I still think of myself of being in the center," he said, reflecting on his earlier role at the agency. "It's just that the center has moved to the right during the past 20 years."
In antitrust matters, it soon should be more clear what Mr. Pitofsky defines as "the center," particularly in health care, a fast-changing industry of major concern to the commission.
The F.T.C. is expected to issue guidelines shortly on the types of business relationships that doctors can enter into without violating price-fixing statutes as they negotiate fees with large buyers such as health maintenance organizations.
And antitrust regulators are eager to rebound from recent setbacks in their efforts to police hospital mergers. In December, the F.T.C. dropped its bid to block the merger of the second- and third-largest acute care hospitals in Joplin, Mo., after unsuccessfully arguing in court that the deal would raise health care costs. And last October, the Justice Department failed in a bid to stop a hospital merger in Dubuque, Iowa.
Convinced that competition among local hospitals must be maintained, the regulators are pushing ahead, trying to adapt their antitrust strategy. In January, the F.T.C. voted to try to block the merger of the two largest hospitals in Grand Rapids, Mich.
"This is an area where we really need to win a case," Mr. Pitofsky said.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Cradle of Terror

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
From the Bekaa Valley in Syrian-occupied Lebanon, the dictator Hafez al-Assad mounts two separate terrorist wars.
One is familiar: The Hezbollah, financed and supplied by Iran through Syria, fires its rockets into Israel at civilians while its guerrillas ambush soldiers in the buffer zone. As Assad tires of humiliating our envoy and his guest terrorists run low on rockets, that war will subside. 
 Assad's other terrorist campaign is directed against Turkey. With training camps in Lebanon's Bekaa and headquarters in Damascus, the P.K.K. -- Kurds at odds with the non-terrorist Kurds we protect in northern Iraq -- launches its raids and provokes Ankara's bloody reprisals. The Syrian-sponsored P.K.K. urges Turkish Kurds to rebel and secede.
Thus does Assad, at no cost to himself -- indeed, at a profit from Iranian cash and Chinese missiles -- conduct two proxy wars. With Iraq in check and Egypt in hock, he is free to move against his major non-Arab rivals. Assad's aim is to dominate the Middle East by debilitating the Jews and destabilizing the Turks.
Filled with Carter-era hopes of a "comprehensive" agreement, President Clinton has followed Shimon Peres down the road of appeasing Assad. Clinton honored the terrorist state with a premature personal visit; sent his Secretary of State to Damascus 20 times; crowned Peres's offer to abandon the Golan with a promise of U.S. troops.
Assad's answer: insults at funerals, boycotts of summits, absorption of Lebanon into "Greater Syria" and the escalation of terrorist attacks by the P.K.K. against Turkey and the Hezbollah against Israel.
It's hard to fault Clinton for taking his lead from Israel's too-trusting present leader. Certainly the unwavering support shown by the U.S. after Israel was drawn into shelling Hezbollah rocket launchers near a U.N. compound stands in welcome contrast to the condemnation routinely heaped on Israel by Bush Administration Arabists.
But a realistic strategy is aborning in the Middle East, based on Turkish-Israeli cooperation. The good thing that came out of the Sharm el-Sheik summit meeting was the cover it gave President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey to pay an official visit to Israel. Military cooperation is now in the open -- and was promptly denounced by Egypt -- while intelligence-sharing is secretly under way .
"Many Turks feel Turkey should follow Israel's example," writes the Ankara pundit Ilnur Cevik, "and knock out the [P.K.K.] terrorists in their shelters. That is why there seems to be deep sympathy for Israel's latest raids against Hezbollah."
Most Turks believe that support from America would be heavily influenced by friendship with Israel. Many Israelis know that Turkey has a strategic asset that strikes fear into both Assad and Saddam Hussein: the Greater Anatolia Project, a series of dams that control the flow of water into Syria and Iraq.
Assad, now riding high on his strategy of inducing Lebanese, Kurdish and Israeli civilian casualties, has to worry about a military alliance between victims of his terror sponsorship. He is trying to counter the Jerusalem-Ankara entente with an approach to Greece, offering help in any Greek-Turkish conflict.
What should the Turks do? Stop the repression and permit the assertion of cultural identity of Kurdish Turks; let its military cease radicalizing helpless Kurds, and instead plan a joint threat with Israel to Assad's terrorist training camps and headquarters in the region. And publicly fondle that water spigot.
What should Israel do? Stop fretting about Arab reaction and give top priority to a military and economic alliance with Turkey. Urge hawkish supporters of Israel in the U.S. to get Bob Dole to put Turkey on his overseas itinerary this summer, overcoming past antipathies.
What should the feuding Kurds in Iraq do? The Talabani faction should cut ties to Iran and the Barzani faction to Saddam. Give the visiting U.S. special envoy Robert Deutsch ("Deutch the Lesser," the C.I.A. calls him) a bare-bones budget for overt aid and present a united front against Baghdad.
The U.S.? Scrap "comprehensive." Openly subsidize the good Kurds with a few million. Embrace the Turks. Isolate Assad. Let Israelis choose their course next month without White House advice.

HEADLINE: U.N. and Iraq Suspend Talks on Limited Oil Sales

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 24

 BODY:
 Iraq and the United Nations temporarily suspended talks today on a plan that would allow Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil in order to buy food and supplies for civilians.
United States and British diplomats continue to insist that they want an agreement on the issue, but without weakening existing economic sanctions against Iraq or allowing President Saddam Hussein to improve his position in any way. 
 "If the changes we put forward are agreed on, we would approve the deal immediately," the American United Nations representative, Madeleine K. Albright, said in an interview. "Some of my Security Council colleagues say that sanctions are hurting the Iraqi people. We want to help them."
The suspension was agreed upon early today by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz.
After meeting with Mr. Boutros-Ghali this morning, Iraq's chief negotiator, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, struck an upbeat note, insisting the talks "are not back to Square 1," stressing the progress made and saying he hoped that talks resumed next month, they "are more sucessful."
But he also made clear that the principal stumbling block remains the changes the United States and Britain insisted the Secretary General make in the agreement, which would allow Iraq to sell up to $2 billion worth of oil every six months to purchase supplies for civilians. "Some member countries objected to some of the provisions and made amendments," Mr. Anbari said.
In particular, the United States and Britain want funds reserved for Iraq's Kurdish provinces funneled through the existing United Nations assistance program there. They question the fairness of Iraq's existing rationing system, which handles food distribution. They also object to Iraq's choosing the bank into which oil payments are made and from which letters of credit would be issued to pay for essential supplies.

HEADLINE: Clinton-Dole Fight on Health Bill Is Preview of Campaign to Come

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole started scrapping today over health insurance and it was clear that they saw a major Presidential campaign confrontation in the making.
The issue that puts the two contenders in stark campaign relief is a provision of a bill whose central purpose is to make health insurance more accessible and to protect workers who change jobs from losing their policies. 
 Both houses of Congress have passed the bill, but the House version contains a provision that Mr. Dole strongly supports and Mr. Clinton as strongly opposes. It would allow people to set up tax-deductible medical savings accounts, which they would tap to pay basic medical expenses if they also bought insurance policies whose high deductibles would not cover the first few thousand dollars of annual health costs.
Despite Mr. Dole, the Senate rejected medical savings accounts last week. Today he took an indirect approach, relying on arcane Senate procedures. He moved to choose Senate conferees who could be expected to surrender to the House and approve the accounts.
Senate Democrats stalled his effort, at least temporarily, and the White House weighed in with a stern warning that if the conferees included the provision, the entire bill would be vetoed.
George Stephanopoulos, senior adviser to President Clinton, said: "The Senate passed a clean bill unanimously. If Senator Dole makes the bill more partisan with medical savings accounts, the President will veto it."
Republican supporters of the accounts contend they would help reduce inflation in health care costs by giving the insured a reason to keep costs down. Mr. Clinton and other Democrats contend they would help only the healthy and the rich. They say that by taking that segment out of the regularly insured population, the accounts would drive up costs for the sick and the poor.
Some Senate Republicans said they did not believe Mr. Clinton would kill the bill because of that single provision. Others argue that if he does, he will take the blame for losing the basic portable-insurance bill.
But Democrats contended that Mr. Dole would take the blame for a veto and would eventually realize that the savings-account proposal was a political liability because it is intensely supported by officers of Golden Rule Insurance, who have contributed heavily to Republican causes.
Republican supporters of medical savings accounts, which were included in the balanced budget proposals vetoed by Mr. Clinton this winter, contend the accounts would stem inflation in medical costs at relatively modest cost to the taxpayers.
Both the Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office estimate that the House plan would cost the Treasury $1.8 billion over seven years.
Supporters of the accounts argue that people would watch costs more carefully if they were spending their own money, rather than an insurance company's money. It would be their own money because whatever went unspent one year could be added to the amount set aside the next year -- and under some versions of the medical savings accounts proposal, withdrawals without penalties could be made for other purposes. Advocates also say the accounts would foster competition among insurance companies for additional business, which might also help control costs.
Money that individuals put aside in pre-tax dollars could be used for medical purposes that many insurance policies either do not cover or cover in a niggardly fashion, like prescription drugs, cosmetic surgery or mental health problems.
The most serious argument against the accounts is that they appeal most to healthy, well-off people.
If those people enrolled in them and bought only the cheaper, high-deductible insurance policies, critics say, people remaining in traditional insurance plans would face higher rates. This would happen, they say, because the pool of people buying ordinary insurance would be, as a group, less healthy than it was before the buyers of medical savings accounts left it.
The effect could be accentuated if employers sought to save money and stopped providing conventional health insurance policies, offering only the high deductibles and perhaps with some contribution to the medical savings accounts.
Moreover, critics say, individuals cannot do much to reduce their spending on health care, since most decisions are really made by doctors, not patients.
Today's skirmish of this health battle, a rematch of the 1994 fight when Mr. Dole defeated Mr. Clinton's universal health insurance plan, was over whom the Senate would pick to negotiate with the House.
Both sides agree that some conferees would clearly come from the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, which produced the insurance bill, and some would come from the Senate Finance Committee. The Finance Committee is involved because Senator Dole offered some tax-related amendments that were passed, notably a measure that would allow the self-employed to deduct 80 percent of their health insurance costs from their taxable income, instead of the current 30 percent.
But the Republican chairwoman of the Labor Committee, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, opposes medical savings accounts, as does the third-ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island.
If a normal selection of three Republicans and two Democrats was made from those two committees, the four Democrats could join Mrs. Kassebaum and Mr. Chafee to block a Senate capitulation on the accounts.
So Mr. Dole proposed bypassing Mr. Chafee and taking only three conferees from Finance, leaving it divided 2 to 1 in favor of the accounts and balancing the 3-to-2 opposition from the Labor Committee. Then he urged adding three conferees from the Judiciary Committee, whose two Republicans would ultimately give him six votes in favor of the accounts.
Democrats objected to the plan, saying the Judiciary Committee had no jurisdiction over any part of the Senate bill, which conferees are at least theoretically committed to defend. So the senators went off to dinner, expecting to fight out the question on Thursday -- or later.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Consumer Savings Likely From Order to Utilities
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered electric utilities to open their transmission systems to outside energy providers, which could eventually save consumers billions of dollars a year.
The rule applies to wholesale power distribution, not home customers, but electricity prices overall are likely to come under pressure. [Page A1.]
 
A Radio Hookup to Internet
The F.C.C. is expected to propose setting aside part of the airwaves for free high-speed communications over short distances. That would drastically cut the cost of hooking up schools and companies to the Internet. [D6.]
 
Strong Compaq Profit Lifts Stocks
Compaq Computer's shares jumped $5.625, to $49.50, propelling other technology shares higher, after the company reported that its profit rose 8 percent and sales jumped 45 percent. [D4.]
 
Nasdaq technology stocks climbed to a new record for the fifth straight session, which was also the busiest day ever. But the Dow Jones industrials fell 34.69 points, to 5,553.90. [D8.]
 
Finally, a Budget Agreement
After seven months of stopgap spending measures and partial Government shut-downs, negotiators agreed to a permanent budget for the year that began Oct. 1. [A1.]
 
Britain Blocks Utility Mergers
The British Government blocked two big mergers in the electricity industry, sending the collective value of the companies involved down $1.5 billion. [D7.]
 
S.E.C. Seeks Say in Accounting

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
Memo to anybody who thinks of 9 Jones as a pleasant, beige-toned restaurant where the menu ranged from Asia to Europe to North Africa: Forget it.
This restaurant has undergone a radical personality change, offering a new menu, a new chef, a new look and lower prices. The chef is now Alan Harding, and if you recall the stylish but fussy health food that he prepared at his last restaurant, Nosmo King, forget that, too. Mr. Harding is now offering what might be called Old New York food. That means dishes like steak tartare, oyster stew and pork chops. 
 Why the changes? Mr. Harding and Ken Lipsmeyer, the owner, said it boiled down to economics. The former chef, Marcey Bassoff, changed the menu often, ranging from Asian one season to Italian the next, making it difficult for 9 Jones to develop an identity, which Mr. Lipsmeyer said made it hard to attract regular customers. "We weren't making it," he said in a telephone interview.
For his part, Mr. Harding says he is happy not to be saddled with the Nosmo King constraints anymore and has simplified his approach to cooking out of economic necessity. "I see myself trying to make the food sing with only two components, rather than four fiddly little things," he said. "I feel kind of unchained."
The best dishes have been found on the menu of any swank New York restaurant 75 years ago, like steak tartare ($6), offered without the traditional tableside preparation but delicious anyway. The small mound of freshly ground beef from the renowned Florence Meat Market next door, spiked with Worcestershire, Tabasco, onion and bits of egg (hard-cooked rather than raw, another concession to modern times), puts one in mind of Scotch, martinis and good cigars. Oyster stew ($7.25), rich, creamy and full of oyster flavor, is another wonderful retro appetizer. The menu, in fact, traces its lineage to Delmonico's 1898. Black bean soup ($5), edged with onion and Madeira, is a lighter version of the dish made famous at the Coach House, once a leading New York restaurant. Mesclun salad with a balsamic vinaigrette ($5) and endive salad with grapefruit and warm "cambazola," a blend of Camembert and Gorgonzola ($7), have less historical resonance but are good nonetheless.
Appetizers are the highlight, but traditional main courses are also good. An unbelievably thick, richly flavored pork chop ($15), served with mashed sweet potatoes, collard greens and chunky homemade applesauce; moist sauteed chicken with a crisp potato-and-leek pancake ($13), and sauteed trout with mashed potatoes and spinach all show a deft hand at insuring that main courses are cooked just to the proper point of doneness. Hidden on the menu among some side dishes is a big excellent hamburger ($10), served with sharp blue cheese, that dwarfs its English muffin.
Without a doubt the best dessert is banana pancakes ($6.50), rolled and served with caramelized bananas and whipped cream, big enough for two.
The narrow dining room has been made more masculine to match the new menu. A brick wall that used to be painted white has been repainted -- what else? -- brick red, matching the floor of ruddy Tuscan tiles, while lights have been dimmed to augment the moody black-and-white photos and drawings.
Early in the evening, the dining room is a quiet, pleasant place, but around 9 P.M., the restaurant undergoes another personality transformation, and blaring disco music (vintage 1975 to 1985) pulses through the dining room. Maybe the people in the bar up front appreciate it, but the beat does not go at all well with oyster stew. Perhaps 9 Jones should consult Delmonico's again.
 
9 Jones
 
 9 Jones Street, near West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 989-1220.
Best dishes: Steak tartare, oyster stew, black bean soup, mesclun salad, endive salad, pork chop, sauteed chicken, sauteed trout, hamburger, banana pancakes.
Price range: $20 to $30.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: 5:30 to 11 P.M. M'ndays through Thursdays, until midnight Fridays and Saturdays; 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sundays.
Wheelchair access: Everything is on one level; restrooms are narrow.

HEADLINE: Boeing Foresees Hiring This Year

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 25

 BODY:
For the first time in five years, the Boeing Company plans to expand its work force.
Boeing, the nation's largest aerospace company, said on Tuesday that its employment would grow this year by nearly 8,200, mainly because of a rebound in commercial jet orders. 
 The forecast is for Boeing's job rolls to reach 113,350 worldwide by the end of the year, compared with 105,185 on Jan. 1 and 107,940 as of Thursday. That leaves more than 5,000 to be hired.
About 6,700 workers are being added in Washington, chiefly in the Seattle area; 1,900 in Wichita, Kan., and about 400 at other sites.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Dutchess County Revives After I.B.M. Downsizing

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
After being hit hard by job cuts at I.B.M., the residential construction market in Dutchess County, N.Y., is showing signs of a rebound.
Several single-family home developments under construction are attracting first-time home buyers and commuters from outside the county, said Steven Domber, president of Prudential Serls Prime Properties of LaGrangeville. "A couple of years ago, sales were fairly stagnant," he said, but now "the market is recovering from what happened with I.B.M. and demand is back." 
 Dutchess was probably the county hardest hit by I.B.M's downsizing. In 1985, the company employed 31,042 people at its plants in Poughkeepsie, East Fishkill and Kingston, just across the Hudson in Ulster County. By 1995, that number plummeted to 10,100, according to the Marist College Bureau of Economic Research in Poughkeepsie.
In the mid-1980's, Dutchess was virtually a company county, with I.B.M. providing 60 percent of its manufacturing jobs and 20 percent of its jobs over all. "It's a situation that just had to explode eventually," said David Stenger, president of Creekview Homes, a developer in Beacon. "You can't rely on one company that way."
But Mr. Stenger has been seeing signs of new life. "Smaller companies are now moving into the empty offices," he said. "It's getting a little better every year."
His company is set to open sales on 75 new single-family homes in four different developments. On average, the homes of three to four bedrooms are expected to sell from $175,000 to $319,000.
"We're marketing to the first-time home buyer, as well as the executive who's moving up to a better house," Mr. Stenger said.
Dutchess developments are attracting buyers from as far south as the Bronx, Mr. Domber of Prudential Serls Prime Properties said. "We no longer depend on buyers from in-county," he said. "I'd say more are now coming from the southern counties."
Some projects, in the northern part of the county, appeal to the move-up buyer who works in Dutchess. One called Coachlight Estates, in Poughkeepsie, offers houses with three and four bedrooms priced from $249,000 to $260,000. "They're for the doctor or attorney who already lives in Dutchess," Mr. Stenger said, "because Poughkeepsie is a bit out of commuting range." Creekview Homes recently bought the remaining 20 lots and has a model under construction.
Creekview Homes builds about 30 homes a year. "That's a lot less than we used to do," Mr. Stenger said. "But we've downsized, too." And he's concentrating exclusively on single-family homes.
"You're not seeing the explosion of condominiums that happened seven or eight years ago," Mr. Stenger said. At that time, apartment buildings were converting to condominiums and many town house developments were being built.
"That reached a saturation level," he said, "and then when the recession hit people were stuck with condos they couldn't sell. The market is still suffering from that."
Some developers with projects that had been approved as condominiums "are going back to the town and changing them to single-family," Mr. Stenger said. "It's usually a matter of killing half the density and the towns are usually agreeable to that."
Another reason for the lack of condominium construction is the scarcity of land. "Condos generally are higher-density developments requiring more land, and it's just not available anymore," said Anthony F. Di Lorenzo, director of sales for Baker Residential, a developer based in Pleasantville. "It's also harder to get approvals for those projects today."
That does not mean that condominium construction has disappeared entirely. "There are still some condos being built," Mr. Domber said. "It's a life-style choice. There will always be people who are interested in a development with amenities like a pool and who don't want to look after lawns."
About a year and a half ago, Mr. Domber said, Dutchess developers began to pursue new land opportunities aggressively and take advantage of more attractive prices.
Creekview Homes has received preliminary approval for a 28-lot development, called Harvest Meadows, in East Fishkill. The homes of three and four bedrooms, mosly split-levels and a few colonials, are expected to sell for $175,000 to $200,000. "We hope to break ground at the end of May," Mr. Stenger said, "and I'm sure we'll sell out within the year."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Picasso Again, Still Surprising

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
FIRST came the mammoth Picasso retrospective in 1980. Then seven years ago was the memorably exhaustive and exhausting "Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism." It might seem that by now William Rubin, the Museum of Modern Art's longtime head of painting and sculpture, who organized both shows, would have had enough of Picasso marathons. But Mr. Rubin is back, out of retirement for yet another Picasso swan song. To him, more is always more, with Picasso at least.
This new exhibition, "Picasso and Portraiture," opening Sunday, is again big, too big, overcrowded and uneven. But it is also immensely accessible, often thrilling and highly revealing. From start to finish, the show's fascination has to do with the sheer sweeping humanity of its subject. Portraitupe, it turns out, is a new way to shuffle the Picasso deck, and room after room has unfamiliar pictures that are ferociously, shockingly inventive and often stirring. 
 This includes works from the last contested decades of Picasso's long life, when his creative powers were thought to have waned. They did, which doesn't mean that occasionally, in a few of these late portraits, he didn't rise to a heady degree of physical freedom. The exhibition begins with his prodigious, melancholic pictures of his father and his Aunt Pepa in the 1890's, images steeped in the tenebrous sobriety of Ribera and the other Spanish Old Masters whose works the young Picasso revered. It ends with one of his most unforgettable s'lf-portraits, from 1972, just before he died at 91: the portrait is a fevered crayon drawing of a near-death mask, staring terrified and goggle-eyed into the abyss.
The show explodes some familiar assumptions. One is that Picaspo changed styles whenever he changed lovers, and that those styles corresponded to the characters of the women. His turn from Cubism to Neo-Classicism in the 1910's, for example, was supposedly on account of his marriage to Olga Kokhlova, whose tastes were conservative.
This is simplistic, and the inclusion of the Neo-Classical "Artist and His Model," from 1914, before Picasso met Kokhlova, proves it. His personal life did of course affect his art, but whether he changed artistic idioms because he met new women (or vice versa) is the wrong question. Picasso's turn from Cubism, such as it was, just as easily might have been his way of keeping ahead of the pack, meaning the Paris artists who had jumped on the Cubist bandwagon and made it a salon style. A decade later, his exploration of Surrealism, likewise, might have been a reaction against the new rage for Neo-Classicism.
In any case, Picasso never really did throw over one style for another. While he was making Neo-Classical portraits, like his concise and loopy drawings of Stravinsky and Diaghilev, he kept making Cubist portraits, too, often painting the same subject both ways.
This remained true throughout the pears. His best-known renditions of Dora Maar, the gifted Surrealist photographer and painter who was his lover during the late 1930's and early 40's, are weeping women: spiky, convulsive, demented figures. But these are just a skewed handful of the Maar portraits Picasso painted. With pictures of her as an electrified coil, a kind of live wire, and others as a smart fashion plate or a poignant, lonely siren, the exhibition restores a sense of Picasso's restless, almost serial approach to portraiture and brings back something of Maar's complex character as well.
Sometimes Picasso's subjects were just armatures, excuses for formal extrapolations. Does it matter whether the audacious, beastly seated hulks you occasionally see in the show represent Maar, Kokhlova, Francoise Gilot, another lover, or Jacqueline Roque, Picasso's second wife? No, because he depicted them in these cases the same way, more or less. And what does it tell us if, as Mr. Ru'in contends, a few of the tender, maternal Neo-Classical paintings, including "Woman in White," are secret portraits of Sara Murphy, an American socialite? It may say something about Picasso's infatuations, but about the pictures, it says little.
Over the years, Picasso used whatever formal depice served his expressive end. So are these portraits, then, really more about him or his subjects? Or put another way, what was portraiture in Picasso's odd case?
Historically, portraits were about likeness, about simulating a sitter's appearance, though all artists, to some degree, revealed their own character in their portraits of others, which is why Velazquez's "Pope Innocent X" is so different from Bernini's, and his paintings of Philip AV unlike Rubens's. Portraits, moreover, were how artists traditionally courted subjects and manipulated them: they were tokens of power long before Picasso used them that way.
But Picasso did conceive a new and radically elastic approach to the genre. With him, portraits became metaphorical: a voluptuous still life could be a stand-in for Marie-Therese Walter, a lover; or an exuberant pointillist melange of jockeying abstract patterns could evoke yet another sweetheart, Eva Gouel. If there is a major drawback to the Modern's show, it is its meekness in this respect: instead of unexceptional portraits, of which there are too many, there could have been more still lifes, landscapes, word pictures and other boundary-stretching allegories that were Picasso's most provocative and venturesome reinterpretations of portraiture.
The show has about 220 paintings and drawings. It is accompanied by a voluminous catalogue with particularly interesting essayp by, among others, Robert Rosenblum on the Walter period, Kirk Varnedoe on self-portraits and Michael FitzGerald on Neo-Classicism and Gilot. Mostly the exhibition focuses on people Picasso portrayed often. Amo'g the exceptions is a single, adept portrait of his sister, Lola, which borrows from Toulouse-Lautrec to turn her into a fin-de-siecle femme fatale. Picasso, of course, borrowed from Velazquez, Delacroix, Redon, African art, medieval art, ev'rywhere. In an early room of the exhibition are his portraits of his lover Fernande Olivier. He turns her into a kind of Greek kore, then into a rocky pyramid of faceted, angular planes, a kind of human analog of Cezanne's mountainous landscapes.
Wherever there was an expressive possibility in any kind of earlier art, Picasso found it and exploited it. Interestingly, his own invention and Braque's, Cubism, initially posed a problem in this respect. Faces were swallowed up in puzzle-like compositions, their features emerging only obliquely, incidentally, encoded. The face of the dealer Wilhelm Uhde in the Cubist portrait here is reduced to a few pinched lines, while the one of Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler is nearly impossible to decipher. It took time before Picasso realized that Cubism could actually be deeply expressive: that the disconnection and rearrangement of parts of a person's appearance opened up vast new emotional possibilities for portraiture.
And you see the results in "Seated Bather," from around 1930, the horrific image that transforms Kokhlova, his then estranged and embittered wife, into a bony, mantislike creature, a painted gorgon closely akin to Giacometti's "Woman With Her Throat Cut." Or, equally, you see the results in "Bather With Beach Ball," Picasso's sardonic remake of his young mistress, Walter, as a pneumatic plaything, a floating zeppelin with a blow-up tube for her head.
The portraits of Walter are often said to be Picasso's best. Some of them are remarkable: heraldic paeans to sex, composed of ripe, somersaulting shapes of unmodulated violets, reds, yellows and blues, bounded bp thick black contours. They are voyeuristic, erotic.
But the Walter portraits here, several rooms of them, are not always his finest. The more memorable works, it turns out, tend to be unexpected. For instance, there's one of Sara Murphy (or whoever) painted with sand. Braque painted with sand, so this portrait is partly a response to him, but what makes it special is the tender effect: a kind of low relief of soft forms fading into shadow that creates an evanescent image, a face seen in the half-light or as if through a scrim.
Then there's a 1938 portrait of Maya, one of Picasso's daughters, in a pinafore, a virtuoso turn made to look childlike, remarkable for its freely scribbled lines against a bare surface and its acutely drawn, sober face. Picasso's contribution to the history of art of children was substantial: he observed not just how they looked and moved but also how they made art, then he copied them savvily. You see him do this also in his portraits from the late 1940's and early 50's of Paloma, another daughter, and Claude, a son. There's one of both of them with their mother Gilot, rendered as if by a child, yet concise and, once you look closely, unbelievably informative, like heiroglyphics: with a few wry, shorthand strokes, Picasso manages to depict Gilot with her legs crossed, reclining, her head resting on upraised arms.
His most frequent portrait subject was Jacqueline Roque. Several densely hung rooms are devoted to these works, and among them is "Seated Woman" from 1971, a big painting so freely brushed and boldly drawn that it can even bring to mind de Kooning. The background, milky white, overlaps and actually defines the darkly painted head, its features illuminated as if by a yellow up-light, so it appears ghostly and unreal. This is an impassioned picture and also doleful.
Picasso was 89 when he painted it. Painstakingly, he had developed from the beginning a pithy economy that allowed him to make not just caricatures of people (it's too bad that, the size of the show aside, none of the early character studies he drew for the Quatre Gats tavern in Barcelona are here) but encapsulating images. With his self-portraits, the encapsulating image became a cocksure gaze, a stare that was his metaphor for the power of vision, Picasso's vision. You see it in "Yo, Picasso," where he's a haughty young man in a flaming scarf and blinding white shirt, and in the self-portrait from 1907, its rough strokes laid down like the crude carvings of a primitive sculpture.
And in the last self-portraits, the stare is still there, but now hollow, not blazing. Picasso often represented himself metaphorically, and most of his self-portraits come early in his career, when he was finding his way. The late self-portraits, in the final gallery, are vivid exceptions, testimonies from the edge of the grave. Picasso clearly used portraiture to exorcise his deepest thoughts and fears, so that by the end of Mr. Rubin's vast exhibition, you feel wrung out but moved.
 
"Picasso and Portraiture: Representation and Transformation" opens Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, and remains on view through Sept. 17. It is sponsored by Phillip Morris and ITT Sheraton. A smaller version of the show will open in Paris in October.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Clinton Wrought

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In just one secret move, President Clinton did the following things:
Made a decision, critical militarily and politically, over the head of Congress and behind the back of the United Nations. Double-crossed America's closest allies on a matter of the lives of their own troops. Strengthened the terrorist power of Iran, the country Washington and foreign offices around the world believe is the principal sponsor of international terrorism. Cut straight across America's own policy of trying to contain Iran -- absolutely contrary to it. Damaged, perhaps beyond repair, U.S. efforts to get friendly nations to help the containment at economic cost to themselves. 
 These results came from Mr. Clinton's secret decision in 1994 -- surreptitious is more accurate -- to give a silent nod that encouraged Croatia to become an open highway for shipments of Iranian arms and military trainers to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government then at war with the Bosnian Serbs.
Now that the war is at least temporarily over, the longer-term and even more important results of the decision are becoming clear. But the major result has not sunk into the consciousness of Congress, press or public.
Mr. Clinton opened the way for Teheran to achieve the one thing it wanted most from the Bosnian war, the same thing that Europeans feared most: a militant-Islamic Iranian base in Europe. Iran quickly established a terrorist center and dispatch point -- and a political haven in Europe, in the most unstable area on the Continent.
Now Iran and the Bosnian Government are using in peacetime the Iranian power and presence that came with the weapons and the specialists accompanying them.
Iran is the major foreign political presence in Bosnia. Iranian soldiers barely disguised as volunteer guerrillas run training centers and carry out terrorist missions. Iranians have trained Bosnians in an Iranian speciality -- death squads created to operate on foreign soil.
One target is Fikret Abdic, a Muslim now in exile in Croatia. He is an opponent of Islamic militancy, and in 1990 outpolled Alija Izetbegovic for the presidency but was squeezed out of the post. When the war started, Mr. Abdic led Bosnian Muslims who were in armed opposition to Mr. Izetbegovic. The Western press consistently and erroneously uses the Bosnian Government's propaganda epithet for Muslims who opposed Mr. Izetbegovic -- renegade.
The specific Clinton decision was to tell Croatia that Washington had no policy about Iran's request to send large shipments of weapons through Croatia to Bosnia. That is diplomatic code for "go ahead and do the dirty work." Ever since The Los Angeles Times broke the story, Mr. Clinton has refused to disclose documents and told his aides to keep their mouths shut, tight.
We can assume what made the Clinton Administration carry out this colossal deception of its own public, the U.N. and its allies. He not only broke the U.N. embargo, which he had said the U.S. must never do, but did it without getting the agreement of Britain, France and other countries. They had said they would pull their troops out of Bosnia if arms from anywhere, let alone terrorist Iran, flowed to the Muslims.
Mr. Clinton wanted to help the Bosnian Muslims in their war against the Bosnian Serbs, without committing American troops or openly sending arms. There was an honorable way to act -- inform our allies and break the embargo publicly, over their objections. The Administration's choice was to do it with cowardice aforethought -- go ahead, but keep us out of it. (A side result: He put his secret, and honor, in the hands of Iran and Croatia, which grow in mutual cooperation.)
Presidents have taken secret military actions before. But when Mr. Reagan, for instance, approved the arming of the Nicaraguan contras, and Mr. Nixon the bombing of Cambodia, at least they thought they were helping causes they were fighting for. I cannot think of another case where a President made a secret deal that would so predictably damage his own cause as Mr. Clinton did to the containment of Iran.
Maybe the Clinton people thought they would never be found out. Maybe they thought that would make it all right. Many people talk themselves into that. Most of them are children, one way or another.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
