HEADLINE: GRAIN PRICES SOAR ON POOR WEATHER AND LOW SUPPLIES

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 25

 BODY:
As the nation's farmers head into their fields for spring planting, economists are paying more attention than usual to how the work is going.
Bad weather, dwindling stocks of grain and strong demand at home and abroad have sent corn and wheat to record high prices this month. And while the ultimate impact of the spike -- on consumers and the broader economy -- depends on such unknowns as the coming season's weather, the price instability has spawned anxious talk of inflation from the Farm Belt to Wall Street. 
 Already, many economists are saying it is likely that food inflation rates, which have hovered between 2 and 3 percent in recent years, will double by next year as the impact of today's prices filters through the food pipeline. Should that happen, the average family with children, which by Government estimates spends approximately $6,500 a year on food, could end up spending $400 more next year.
Economists say that a repeat of last year's experience -- when planting was delayed, summer heat disrupted corn pollination and an early frost crimped yields -- could drive those costs still higher, sending food inflation over 10 percent, a level last seen in the 1970's.
For now, the real impact is on agriculture itself. Many farmers are scrambling to cash in on the price increases by planting more acreage, while cattle producers are starting to kill off cows they can no longer afford to feed with expensive grain.
But what has economists and the financial markets edgy as they look ahead is that food prices are not the only ones going up this spring. Heavy demand has also driven energy prices upward, to their highest level since the Persian Gulf war.
Many bond traders, in particular, have already decided that broader inflation and higher interest rates are on the way, judging from how bond prices tumbled in recent weeks.
"Commodity prices are clearly spooking the bond market," said David Wyss, director of research at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic forecasting service in Lexington, Mass.
Most economists say that Wall Street has been overly anxious about inflation's return. Price shocks to the agricultural sector are certainly nothing new, and energy prices move in a volatile manner, both up and down.
"It is a temporary distortion as things stand now," said Diane Swonk, deputy chief economist at the First Chicago NBD Corporation.
Indeed, futures prices indicate the market is expecting some balance to be restored. While corn prices for delivery next month hit a high today of $4.99 a bushel, traders are willing to bid only $3.35 a bushel for corn from next fall's harvest.
One reason for optimism: Farmers are projected to plant 79.9 million acres of corn this year by the Agriculture Department and as much as 84 million acres by some private forecasters, up from 71 million acres last year.
But analysts say the risk is real that inflation could be uncorked, as much by market psychology as by supply and demand.
David Hale, chief economist for Zurich Kemper Investments Inc., warned in his most recent economic survey that the commodity price increases posed a serious challenge to the economic policy makers of the Federal Reserve Board. The Federal Reserve, he said, must "pursue a policy which prevents higher food prices from encouraging a general acceleration of inflation expectations, which influences wage bargaining." Mr. Hale said that a combination of low grain reserves and depressed output could cause food prices to rise by 8 to 10 percent during 1997.
Normally, grain demand falls relatively quickly as prices climb. This time around, though, all of the world's major grain purchasers kept buying long after economists expected them to curb spending.
In part, that reflects the rise in agriculture of deep-pocketed enterprises that have the means to ride out increases in feed prices. And unlike the situation in the 1970's, when the Soviet Union bought huge amounts of grain on credit, China and other importers are flush with dollars to pay for American grain and meat.
"What's different is that this is a demand-driven market," said Terry Francl, chief economist for the American Farm Bureau Federation, a trade group in Chicago representing more than four million farmers.
Consumers are likely to get mixed signals for many months about what the low stocks and high grain prices mean to them.
The single biggest user of grain is the cattle business. Once it starts killing large numbers of cows, the price of hamburger and other lower-grade meats could fall for many months if retailers pass through the savings. Savings may also show up in the form of larger portions for the same price, as McDonald's is reported to be considering.
Low beef prices will force pork and poultry producers to keep their prices low to compete. The savings at the meat counter may well offset the nickel-to-dime price increases for pasta, bread and other grain products already making their way into some markets.
Eventually, though, there will be less meat around than consumers want, and prices for meat products could rise sharply, economists say.
"We are headed for a shock to consumers," said Paul Prentice, president of Farm Sector Economics Inc., a Colorado Springs consulting firm.
For the time being, it is the agribusiness sector that is reacting to the shocks of corn's near doubling from $2.50 a year ago, wheat's climb from an average of $4.35 last year to about $7, the climb in soybeans from an average of $6.80 to more than $8.20 and the upward pull of those crops on most others.
Farmers stand to profit, but face many tough decisions: Should they rip out winter wheat decimated by drought and disease to free up more land for spring planting or harvest what's left of the wheat in June? How much of this year's corn and soybean crops should they sell in advance? (The biggest winners in this year's price surge were the few gamblers and procrastinators who held on to most of their 1995 crop long after others sold.)
One wild card is the new farm bill, which allows farmers to get Government payments without placing any restriction on what they grow. It gives farmers more flexibility but not necessarily easier choices.
"I've changed my plans about what I'll plant several times since the beginning of the month and I'm not done yet," said Noel Kjesboe, a Wendell, Minn., farmer who usually grows wheat, corn, soybeans and barley.
The giants of agribusiness are also among those feeling pinched. Profits are plunging at grain processors like Cargill and Archer-Daniels-Midland, which recently shut down some of its ethanol production. Tyson Foods and other chicken producers have cut back broiler production for the first time since the 1970's to reduce their need for corn. Interstate Bakeries and its rivals are scrambling to minimize the production losses from dealing with poorer- quality wheat they would normally not buy if supplies were more plentiful.
As in the past, the brunt of the grain squeeze is destined to fall on animal producers, especially the cattle industry. Normally, cattle producers can avoid high corn prices by switching to more use of wheat, hay or grass in pastures. But wheat is expensive and in short supply, dragging up prices for other forage crops. And the pastures of the Southwest and Great Plains have withered under some of the driest conditions in a century.
To make matters worse, the grain prices are rising when the beef cattle herd of 35.3 million animals is too large for the market. That holds down prices packers are willing to pay at feedlots, which are losing an average of nearly $1 a day on every cow they fatten at today's grain prices.
"A feedlot can't afford to tell a packer, 'I don't like your price so I'll wait until next week,' " said Mike Fitzgerald, a spokesman for the Nebraska Cattlemen's Association.
The feedlots have responded by driving down the prices they pay for young animals to around 55 cents a pound. At that price, only 20 percent of ranchers that raise calves can eke out even a slim profit, according to Charles Lambert, economist at the National Cattlemen's Beef Association. Many have begun to sell breeding cows to raise cash.
By some estimates, the nation's cattle herd could drop by two million this year. The selloff is expected to be especially sharp if this summer's weather is not wet enough to restore pasture land and produce bumper grain crops.
"There's no room for another bad grain crop," said Paul McAuliffe, senior commodity analyst here for the North American Grain division of the Continental Grain Company, a leading feed and livestock producer.
Old-timers note that today's prices look modest when inflation is taken into account. Corn soared to $18 a bushel in 1947 and was at $12 a bushel in 1974 if prices are adjusted to today's dollars. Farmers are so much more productive today, though, that economists say such peaks are hard to imagine without a worldwide weather disaster.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Real Welfare Cheats

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The unconscionable assault on welfare recipients by officials at all levels of government is taking place in an atmosphere of extraordinary dishonesty.
Even politicians who traditionally have tried (however modestly) to look out for the interests of the poor are in retreat on the welfare issue. They will tell you that politically they have no choice. The polls show that voters are overwhelmingly hostile to welfare. 
 What the politicians tend not to talk about is the extent to which the public has been misled (often deliberately) about who is on welfare and what benefits they are receiving, and about the potential for catastrophe if benefits are ended for large numbers of welfare recipients for whom jobs are not available.
There is little doubt the public hates welfare, but most Americans are not cruel. "The public is tough-minded but not unsympathetic," according to an in-depth analysis of attitudes toward welfare that was released this week by Public Agenda, a research organization founded by the public opinion analyst Daniel Yankelovich and former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance.
The study found that Americans "resent much of what they see" about welfare, "but few are callous or smugly superior. They vent their anger at what they consider a dismal, almost insane, policy failure, but, within the space of an hour's discussion, show a remarkable willingness to wrestle intellectually with the myriad complexities involved. In many ways, the public is more open-minded and pragmatic than leaders who see themselves as far more 'informed' on the issue."
The problem with welfare for most Americans has to do with values, not money. Working people resent welfare, the study found, primarily because it "represents a repudiation of their own efforts to support themselves and their families and to be self-reliant even during hard times."
But the public is interested in real reform, which means genuine efforts to keep children housed and fed while moving adults into the world of work. Most politicians, with one eye on the latest poll and the other on the next election, have scrapped all thought of reform and are moving willy-nilly to cut benefits.
The public, in this area, is far ahead, both practically and ethically, of the politicians. According to the Public Agenda study, "Of nine possible reforms presented to respondents -- ranging from requiring job training to paying surprise visits to make sure recipients deserve benefits -- reducing benefits ranked last in popularity."
Politicians are moving in the exact opposite direction. Gov. George Pataki of New York -- in lockstep with national trends -- is calling for a 26 percent reduction in monthly benefits, and Democrats who control the State Assembly have caved in to his demand to establish time limits for receiving cash benefits.
In New York City, a deputy commissioner of the Human Resources Administration issued a memo a few weeks ago emphasizing the priorities to be followed in the handling of welfare cases. The top priority was case closings. The lowest (fifth in a list of five) was case acceptances. In other words, getting benefits to poverty-stricken mothers and their children was the least important consideration.
The memo was leaked to the press (it was in the New York Observer Wednesday) and suddenly city officials offered a "clarification." The priorities, according to the clarification, "should be understood as equal."
"They are really doing bad things to poor people," said Liz Krueger, associate director of the Community Food Resource Center in New York. Ms. Krueger is fighting the "Draconian" welfare proposals now being considered in Albany. She asks a simple question. "Where are the jobs?"
A study released last summer by the office of Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger found that at any given time about 50,000 jobs, of all types (not just entry-level), are available in New York City. If they were all filled by welfare recipients, 300,000 more jobs would be needed for the remaining adults on welfare, and an additional 200,000 jobs would be needed for other unemployed New Yorkers. The ratio of out-of-work New Yorkers to available jobs is 10 to 1.
These are problems that need to be looked at seriously and honestly. Instead, politicians are cutting welfare with their eyes closed.

HEADLINE: Lower Rates Raise Resales Of Single-Family Homes

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes jumped 6.9 percent in March to the highest level in more than two years as buyers responded to low mortgage rates.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.21 million, up from 3.94 million in February. 
 The rate was the highest since December 1993, when it was 4.35 million.
"Many consumers, especially first-time buyers, were able to get into the market," said Art Godi, the association president. "They took advantage of extremely favorable rates in the first quarter."
However, rates have been rising recently and many analysts fear higher financing costs will price many buyers out of the market.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.62 percent in March, up from 7.08 percent in February, but down from 8.46 percent last year.
Rates had shot up to 8.05 percent during the week ended on April 11, but slipped to 7.95 percent last week.
Analysts say that for every percentage-point increase in interest rates, 250,000 to 300,000 families are priced out of the market.
John A. Tuccillo, an economist, said the March resale pace is not likely to be sustainable into the summer. "The spring home-buying season started off well, because many first-time buyers closed sales using low interest rates secured in January," he said. "What we are seeing is the result of buyers, including trade-up buyers, who moved quickly before interest rates rose."
The median price of a previously owned home in March was $115,300, up 6.8 percent from March 1995, when it was $108,000. The median is the midpoint -- half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
The median price was $96,000 in the Midwest, $150,000 in the West, $99,500 in the South and $141,100 in the Northeast.
Sales rose in each of the four regions, including a 12.5 percent jump in the Midwest, to an annual rate of 1.1 million. They increased 6.6 percent in the West, to a rate of 970,000.
"California has experienced a surge in home-buying activity over the last several months and has boosted activity in the West," Mr. Godi said.
Sales advanced 5.4 percent in the South, to a rate of 1.57 million, and 5.3 percent in the Northeast, to 600,000.
In a separate report from the Labor Department, the number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits rose by 13,000 last week to the highest level in three weeks.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 372,000. The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims fell by 15,250, to 371,750, during the period ended last week. Many analysts prefer to track the four-week average, which is less volatile.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies on New Evidence Of German Economic Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied broadly yesterday on new evidence of economic weakness in Germany and an influential German banker's suggestion that the mark was overvalued against the dollar.
The dollar's greatest advance came against the European currencies but was less pronounced against the yen. That was also the indirect result of the mark's retreat in foreign exchange dealings. 
 Many traders were selling marks to buy yen, pushing the Japanese currency to the highest level against the mark since early December 1995.
"The story today was more mark weakness than anything," said Win Thin, an international economist at HSBC Midland in New York.
The dollar hit its highest level against the mark since early February -- 1.5350 marks -- before dropping back slightly to 1.5340 marks in late trading in New York, up from 1.5203 marks on Wednesday.
The dollar rose to 106.70 yen from 106.53 yen. The pound fell to $1.5075 from $1.5150.
The mark weakened after Germany's Federal Statistics Office reported a benign April inflation rate, suggesting that the Bundesbank now has more leeway to lower interest rates further.
The central bank lowered rates a half percentage point a week ago but expectations have grown since then that another reduction will be required to stimulate Germany's economy.
Reports of a rise in Germany's insolvency rate and more weakness in the country's construction industry added to the picture of malaise in Germany, further diminishing demand for marks.
"I guess people are still concerned that the German economy is weak," said Seth Cohen, a director of foreign exchange trading at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "People are still looking for further cuts in German interest rates."
The dollar received a further lift on remarks by Franz-Christoph Zeitler, president of the Regional Central Bank in Bavaria and a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council. He said the value of the mark against other European currencies was appropriate but suggested it had further room to weaken against the dollar.

HEADLINE: Senate Bars Plans to Cut Immigration

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Raising serious doubt that Congress will make any meaningful changes in legal immigration this year, the Senate today resoundingly rejected two measures to reduce the number of foreigners entering this country legally.
After six hours of debate, senators rejected, 80 to 20, a proposal to reduce immigration by legal residents' family members by at least 10 percent over the next five years. 
 The proposal would also have effectively shut the door on American citizens' efforts to bring their adult children or siblings into this country. Those visas would instead have gone to the spouses and young children of permanent legal residents; many of those people are already living in the United States but without proper papers.
Though the proposal was offered by Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Wyoming Republican who is the Senate's authority on immigration, 40 Republicans voted against it. Among them was Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader.
Those Republicans' position reflected their strong agreement with the Senate Judiciary Committee's decision last month to deal with legal and illegal immigration in separate bills. Mr. Simpson's proposal was an amendment to a bill intended to curb illegal immigration.
The bipartisan vote against the Simpson proposal also reflected strong support for the position that immigrants who enter the country legally serve as a wellspring of economic growth and innovation.
A second amendment to the immigration bill, offered by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, closely resembled Mr. Simpson's but would have allowed some visas for adult and minor children of legal residents. It was defeated 74 to 26.
Both amendments would have limited family sponsored immigration to the current level of 480,000 people a year. The Immigration and Naturalization Service projects a 41 percent increase in legal immigration this year, including family categories. The number declined 10 percent last year, to 593,000.
Last month the House, by a vote of 238 to 183, removed from its illegal-immigration bill most provisions on legal immigration and then passed the bill. The Senate appears likely to pass its bill on illegal immigration next week.
With the legislative calendar running short and senators now on record against reducing legal immigration and certain family categories, many experts in immigration said that the likelihood of the Senate considering the separate bill on legal immigration might be dimming.
Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, a research group in Washington that favors reducing legal immigration, said that the legal-immigration bill "technically is still alive," but that its fate rested with Mr. Dole's clearing time on the Senate floor for debate.
Today's debate over the two amendments, particularly Mr. Simpson's, was as lopsided as the eventual vote on them.
Even with his amendment, Mr. Simpson argued, "we will continue to have the most open door of any country in the world."
But senator after senator rose to defend the nation's history of accepting legal immigrants.
"We've got room for people who want to come and work," said one of them, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "We don't have room for people who are looking for a handout."
Many lawmakers, including Republicans, also objected to Mr. Simpson's tactics. "Tacking this on to the illegal immigration bill is the worst conceivable way to deal with legal immigration," said Senator Spencer Abraham, Republican of Michigan.

HEADLINE: Penney's Wandering Eye Puts Wall St. on Watch

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the country's fourth-largest retailer, was courted for a takeover by the J. C. Penney Company but swiftly refused the offer, both companies said yesterday.
The offer, which was made in February, has left Wall Street suspicious that Dayton Hudson, which has a mixed bag of both good and troubled retailers, is in play. It also raised questions about whether J. C. Penney, the nation's fifth-largest retailer, had designs on other retailers. 
 Dayton Hudson's stock had a strong run while the offer was kept secret, gaining nearly 22 percent, or about three times the advance shown by the average retail stock. That performance raises the possibility of a leak, although there is no proof.
"The gain in the share price reflects investors' anticipation that the composition of this company will change," said John M. Eade, a retail analyst at Argus Research in New York.
The offer was first reported yesterday in The Star Tribune in Minneapolis, which wrote that J. C. Penney offered a 50-50 cash and stock transaction that valued Dayton Hudson's stock between $90 and $95 a share, putting the deal at roughly $6.8 billion. At the time of the offer, Dayton Hudson's shares were trading around $76. Its shares were unchanged yesterday, at $92.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Yesterday, as both companies refused to comment, the whole offering took on the look of a regrettable cocktail party flirtation.
J. C. Penney released a statement saying that it had proposed a "friendly business combination" that offered "an attractive opportunity" for shareholders, and that Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson had spurned the advance.
Dayton Hudson's press release was equally brief, calling the overture an "unsolicited" proposal that was promptly rejected by the Dayton Hudson board.
"It was a surprise because you just don't imagine J. C. Penney making the bid," said Josephine Kwok, an analyst at Jurika & Voyles, an institutional investor in Oakland, Calif., and a large holder of Dayton Hudson shares. "But as long as the price goes up, I wouldn't mind it."
Retail analysts were left pondering the probability of a new suitor for Dayton Hudson, which has enjoyed healthy profits from its Target discount store division, but has been hurt by its sagging Mervyn's discount department stores and its upscale department store division.
For some time, Wall Street has put pressure on Dayton Hudson to remove its 64-store Midwestern department store division, which like many regional chains, has faltered. Investors have also pressed the company to unload its 297 Mervyn's clothing stores, which compete with the J. C. Penney stores. Both have been a drain on profits.
Analysts have suggested that the company ought to keep the Target stores, which sell everything from eye drops to show shovels. The most frequently mentioned possible suitor for the department store division has been May Department Stores. But Dayton Hudson has chosen instead to upgrade its department stores.
"Wall Street always thought that if you have an ingrown toenail, you should cut off your toe," said Edward A. Weller, an analyst at Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco. "But I think management believes that the payoff of running its department stores more effectively could bring a much bigger payoff than what they would earn on cash."
J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., does not have the reputation of a hungry giant on the make, but it is becoming clearer that it is eager for an acquisition. Last August, it was one of the winners in a bidding contest for some Woodward & Lothrop and John Wanamaker stores held in Federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan.
While its cash reserves have been strong -- it has recently repurchased its own stock -- J. C. Penney has taken a beating in same-store sales, under pressure from Sears, Roebuck & Company. And it seems to be tapped out in domestic growth. A Dayton Hudson acquisition would have permitted new economies of scale, a marriage with the similar Mervyn's business and the benefits of Target.
"I think what this indicates is that J. C. Penney is very profitable and generates a ton of cash," Mr. Weller said. "It sees its expansion opportunities as very limited, and it recognizes the potential for Dayton Hudson's operating companies to have significant improvement in sales and profits."
On the surface, Dayton Hudson's stock movement since the secret proposal seems oddly rapid, given that the company reported disappointing earnings for the fiscal year that ended in January. While its same-store sales were healthy in February and March, some analysts suggested that even performance surprises on the upside would not justify the run-up.
"Earnings were down last year, $3.89 versus $5.52 a year before, and the forecast for this year is $5.25," Mr. Eade of Argus Research said. "That's a nice move off, but it is coming off a depressed number. So it looks like there must have been a little takeover speculation."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET TRUCE: MINIMUM WAGE;
House Republicans Again Avert Vote on Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
House Republicans narrowly fought off a Democratic effort today to vote on an increase in the minimum wage, even though 13 of them deserted their leaders and voted with the Democrats.
After the 220-to-200 vote, Democrats said they would try again next week and expected to do better then, and in any case to win sometime in May. 
 "We plan to use every opportunity that's available to us strategically to bring this up," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the second-ranking House Democrat.
On Wednesday, House Republican leaders said they did not plan to bring the issue of raising the hourly minimum wage to $5.15 from $4.25 to the floor for a vote this year. They said they would propose other changes to help low-wage workers.
Democrats responded today with a surprise effort to amend a procedural rule that was on the floor to provide for a vote on the minimum wage.
Representative Scott McInnis, the Colorado Republican who was managing the procedural rule, denounced the effort as a "sneak attack" and a "diversionary argument" based on election year politics. His Republican colleagues left Mr. McInnis almost alone on the floor to oppose the Democrats in debate.
Democrats argued that since the Republican leaders refused to schedule a vote any other way, this was their only recourse.
"Stop playing games and schedule a vote," demanded Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri.
Representative Gene Green, Democrat of Texas, said, "What we need to do is put the jam on the bottom shelf for the little people."
The Republican victory was made possible only by the votes of 15 Republicans who have sponsored legislation to raise the minimum wage by $1 an hour but who voted against considering the issue today.
They are Representatives Spencer Bachus of Alabama; Steve Horn and Frank Riggs of California; Nancy L. Johnson and Christopher Shays of Connecticut; Ileana Ros-Lehtinen of Florida; Bob Franks and Bill Martini of New Jersey; Benjamin A. Gilman, Amo Houghton and Rick A. Lazio of New York; Frank A. Cremeans and Steven C. LaTourette of Ohio, Phil English of Pennsylvania and Jack Metcalf of Washington.
There does appear to be momentum working for the House Democrats. The last time they staged a procedural vote over the minimum wage, on March 28, they lost 228 to 192, with only 7 Republicans supporting them.
There was no action on the wage issue in the Senate today, but Democrats insisted that they would keep trying to bring it forward. It was clear that while the 47 Democrats were solidly in favor of the increase, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and the other 52 Republicans had nothing approaching a common position.
At a Democratic news conference, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich offered some unsolicited advice to Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, urging him just to let the issue come to a vote. "When you are in a hole," Mr. Reich said, "don't dig."
In the brief House debate, Democrats said they were looking after what Representative Lloyd Doggett of Texas called "the people that mop the floors, that take out the trash, that wash the dishes."
Mr. McInnis answered by attacking Democrats for raising gasoline taxes three years ago. "If you want to help the working poor of this country," he said, "do something about taxes."
Two Georgia Republicans came to his aid. One, Representative John Linder, said: "This is not policy. It is politics and crass politics."
The other, Representative Jack Kingston, accused the Democrats -- "the comrades on the other side," he called them -- of failing to recognize that an increase in the minimum wage would cost jobs. "The folks over there are simply economically ignorant," Mr Kingston said. "I don't believe they are malicious."

HEADLINE: For Japan's Women, a Lesser Work Role

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 25

 BODY:
It would be safe to assume that there is little sexual harassment on the assembly lines of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in Japan. That is because there are virtually no women on the assembly lines of Mitsubishi and other automobile manufacturers.
In the Japanese workplace, many women are confined to subservient roles like pouring tea for their male colleagues, with many of them called office "flowers." Most women have no hope for promotion and no guarantee of lifetime employment; they are expected to quit when they marry. 
 Some industry analysts have said that such differences might have led to a tolerance of sexual harassment at a factory of a Mitsubishi subsidiary in Normal, Ill..
Tsuneo Ohinouye, the top executive at the Illinois plant, denied that cultural differences played a role in the way women were treated. He said the company did not tolerate sexual harassment.
There is evidence that women face sexual discrimination in Japan. In help-wanted advertisements, companies often specify the sex of employees they want and set an age limit for female applicants. It is said that some companies will not hire single women that live alone.
There are very few women in the upper or even the middle ranks of management. Some young women are leaving the country for better employment opportunities.
There are only 5 to 10 sexual-harassment lawsuits filed each year, said Mizuho Fukushima, a lawyer who handles such cases. She said many women accept such mistreatment, however reluctantly, and filing lawsuits is not a common practice in Japan.
A woman brought the first such lawsuit in Japan in 1989 under general civil law for injurious behavior. A court ruled that a company and one of its male employees had violated the woman's rights because of crude remarks that drove her to quit her job.
As for the lack of women on automobile assembly lines, executives attribute that to a Japanese law prohibiting women from working late at night. Most automobile plants have workers alternate day shift and night shifts.
Some progress is being made. Spurred by the passage of an equal opportunity law in 1986, companies began hiring more women for career-track positions in the economic boom of the late 1980's, though many of those gains were lost in the recent recession. More women are also working after marriage.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET TRUCE: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE AND SENATE VOTE TO APPROVE '96 SPENDING BILL

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Congress passed a $160 billion spending bill today, assuring that vast swaths of Government that had closed, reopened, closed again and reopened again during the long budget wars will stay open the remainder of fiscal 1996, now a bare five months.
The House vote was 399 to 25. The Senate approved the bill 88 to 11. 
 President Clinton, who held out during bargaining over the bill for more spending on his priorities like health, education, the environment and jobs programs, said he would sign the bill Friday morning. He hailed the action as a triumph of bipartisanship, and called for new talks on a plan to balance the budget in seven years.
"We have an opportunity," he said. "We can't let it slip from our grasp."
Republicans, who maintained that the legislation locked in place the largest single-year spending cuts since World War II, suggested that Mr. Clinton had to be dragged to the reductions.
"The President was forced to sit down and achieve a result," said Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee.
The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana, lifted a line from Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message to make the same point.
"He said the era of big Government is now over," Mr. Livingston said. "We're taking him at his word. The world has changed, and were heading in the right direction."
But today's vote did nothing to break the broader political impasse over the biggest and fastest-growing part of Government: the benefit programs, like Medicare, Medicaid and welfare, that consume fully two-thirds of the $1.6 trillion budget. Dealing with these entitlement programs will be crucial to bringing the Federal budget into balance.
Nor did the passage of the spending bill settle the root argument between Republicans and Democrats over what and how much Government should do, and how much to spend doing it.
But today's votes did end the longest and most bitter struggle over fiscal policy in memory, one that closed much of Government for a record 27 days last winter. Scores of Federal agencies, including 9 of 14 Cabinet departments, stayed open the rest of the fiscal year only after the combatants agreed to allot them temporary stipends 13 times in a row -- another record.
Seldom before, if ever, had the two branches of Government argued more than a few days into a new fiscal year without arranging some sort of year-long financing for the agencies in dispute.
The Republicans did indeed cut spending: With the new legislation, the Government is authorized to spend a total of $488 billion on domestic agencies, from the military to highway building to environmental protection, for all of fiscal 1996. According to the Congressional Budget Office, that is $20 billion less than was approved in 1995.
Actual spending for 1996 will total $532 billion, compared to $539.2 billion the previous year. Actual spending is greater because it includes money that was authorized, but not spent, in past years.
Judging by today's remarks in the House, negotiations over the budget were every bit as acrid as in December, when most comity between the two sides collapsed.
"If Republicans had worked with the Democrats, we could have kept the Government open," said Representative Joe Moakley, a Massachusetts Democrat. "If Republicans had worked with the Democrats, we could have settled this six months ago and come a lot closer to giving the American people the kind of government they deserve. What took you so long?"
Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, called the vote "the end of a very dark period" and added: "Finally we can say that that nonsense, for the rest of this fiscal year, is over."
Republicans were no less caustic. Mr. Livingston detailed what he said was a long list of instances in which the Congress acceded to the White House -- on environmental spending, on education, on job-training programs -- and then added drily, "Most of these issues will be revisited in the next few weeks." He was referring to the Republican budget for fiscal 1997, which will probably be sketched out in public next week.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich was equally dismissive of Mr. Clinton's plea for a new round of budget talks, saying Congress wants genuine reductions in spending and not "a proposal that's just been written by press secretaries."
"The President would have to indicate a willingness to have real reform this year," he said. "Not some phony proposal that has all the savings in the seventh year or the sixth year, but real reform this year."
Both the Republicans' 1996 budget and Mr. Clinton's budget for fiscal 1997 project fiscal balance in 2002, but postpone the bulk of politically difficult spending cuts until the final years. By most measures, Mr. Clinton's plan "backloads" more spending cuts than does the Republican one.
Mr. Clinton has made his share of attacks on the Republicans' budget. But he elected to stay above the fray today, casting himself as the virtually apolitical leader of all Americans who oppose deficit spending.
"The most important thing to happen today is simply this," he said. "We have shown that we can work together, and when we do, we can get results that are good for the American people, today and for our future. But when the leadership of Congress insists on going it alone, one party alone, we get gridlock, stalemate, vetoes, Government shutdowns. Today was a real victory for progress over partisanship."
The legislation enacted today, the product of five weeks of bargaining, cobbles together a compromise from four spending bills that Mr. Clinton had previously vetoed or that stalled in Congress. It lays out spending plans for the Departments of Commerce, State, Interior, Justice, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, as well as dozens of major agencies like NASA and the Environmental Protection Agency.
In gravity-defying fashion, it satisfies two opposing demands: that domestic spending be cut every penny as much as Republicans want, and that spending on Mr. Clinton's domestic priorities be increased.
Mr. Clinton won about $5 billion in additional spending, though not all he sought, for the environment, education, job-training programs, his national service initiative and his proposal to place more police on the streets, among others.
He also won battles to weaken or strip several amendments from the spending bill. Among them were clauses that would have rolled back Environmental Protection Agency regulation of wetlands, restricted the Endangered Species Act and capped the amount of direct Federal loans to college students.
Mr. Clinton's spending increases were offset by cuts in other parts of the domestic budget, mostly from funds reserved for natural disasters but also in Congress's spending on certain social programs.
In some cases, such as a cut in payments to the states for adoption assistance, the agreement merely reduced the size of a proposed increase in spending.
On the House floor today, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, the Republican Rules Committee chairman from New York, boasted that the spending compromises represented genuine cuts in spending, not "smoke and mirrors." That is essentially true.
On the other hand, both sides did employ some fiscal gymnastics to reach agreement. The compromise finances part of other additional spending, for example, by proposing to collect $500 million more in bad debts owed the Government. And it finances other permanent Government activities with onetime gains in revenue from the sale of Government assets such as oil reserves.
That means the bargainers may have to find still more money in the next budget, when some of the same Federal programs could well be on the chopping block again.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Surging Grain Prices Raise Fears of Inflation
Corn and wheat prices have climbed to records this month, because of bad weather, dwindling supply and strong demand at home and abroad.
While it is too early to gauge the ultimate impact of the spike on either consumers or the broader economy, the price instability has brought anxious talk of inflation from the Farm Belt to Wall Street. [Page A1.]
 
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, before leaving to inspect the parched wheat crops, said the markets should calm down. [D15.]
 
Ford Announces Huge Recall
Ford, responding to consumer pressure and facing lawsuits, announced the largest recall ever by a single auto maker. It asked owners of 8.7 million 1988 through 1993 cars and trucks to bring them to dealers for replacement of ignition switches that might cause fires. [A1.]
 
Congress Passes Budget Bill
Congress passed a $160 billion spending bill, assuring that vast swaths of Government that had closed repeatedly would stay open during the remainder of fiscal 1996. President Clinton hailed the action as a triumph of bipartisanship. [A1.]
 
Harassment at the Factory
Some women working at the Mitsubishi car plant in Illinois say the company has been unfairly accused of tolerating sexual harassment. But others recount a long series of offensive incidents. In Japan, virtually no women work on auto assembly lines. [A20.]
 
Stock Market in Late Rebound
Wall Street staged a late rebound, sending the Nasdaq composite index to a sixth consecutive high, 1,184.17, up 7.34, and the Dow industrials up 13.01, to 5566.91. Computer and paper stocks fueled the advance. [D8.]
 
Strong Gain for Home Sales
Sales of previously owned homes jumped 6.9 percent in March to the highest level in more than two years. Buyers responded to low mortgage rates, but rates have been rising recently, which could deter buyers. [D2.]
 
Sonat Seeks Norwegian Company
Sonat Offshore Drilling of Houston offered to buy Transocean A.S. of Norway in a $1.5 billion deal that would form the world's second-largest operator of offshore rigs. Transocean said its board would consider the offer. [D2.]
 
Guilty Plea in Insider Case
A Las Vegas insurance salesman, Edward Warren Eizman, 35, pleaded guilty to conspiracy in connection with insider trading based on tips provided by a former lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm, which had clients in merger talks. [D3.]
 
Teachers to Cut Tobacco Shares
The New York Teachers' Retirement System voted to cut the tobacco holdings in one of its index funds, saying it was concerned that the uncertainty surrounding tobacco stocks had undermined their investment value. [B7.]
 
Malone Tries To Outfox MCI

HEADLINE: Bosnians See A California In Balkans

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: SANSKI MOST, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
As the people in this valley emerge, battered by war and winter, two men are waiting for them. They intend to grab everyone -- widows, refugees and demobilized soldiers alike -- by their collars, shake them soundly, then point them toward a vision.
"We're going to make this place into California," proclaimed Gen. Mehmed Alagic, without even a blush over a plan that might be mistaken for a fantasy. "Why not?" 
 That vision seems less fanciful when you survey the wide plain surrounding this town. A ring of forested mountains frames the grasslands and acres of cornfields that are cut by the Sana and eight other rivers. If you squint just a little, this could resemble a smaller San Jose in the era when it was a farm town.
Mr. Alagic, who recently retired as general, is one of the most esteemed heroes of the Bosnian Army. His partner in this dream, Mirzet Karabeg, 52, who just stepped aside as mayor so Mr. Alagic could fill that office, is the area's most powerful politician. The men, both Muslims, may carry the weight to pull off the transformation, but their style is more like a small-time dictatorship rather than Golden State modern.
"The first step," explained Mr. Karabeg, "is to start cutting back on all this free food those humanitarian aid agencies are sending in here. As long as people can eat for nothing, they won't work."
If that is not enough, the leaders begin evicting from Government-controlled housing anyone who doesn't put in 180 hours a month at a job or a reconstruction project.
"Socialism taught us to be lazy," he said.
This is a rather surprising analysis for a man who, until the Bosnian war, was a bureaucrat in Yugoslavia's state-owned factories and then a senior functionary in a town administration that sought to protect citizens from life's sharp corners.
But with this valley in ruins, hundreds of its people killed and the survivors scattered and traumatized, the two men see this as a time for change.
For their part, Mr. Karabeg and Mr. Alagic, who before the war was an officer in the Yugoslav Army, have found that everything they once believed in has vanished. Yugoslav Communism evaporated. Even Yugoslavia collapsed in war.
Four years ago, the men's Serbian colleagues and neighbors took control of this area, killing and expelling Muslims and Croats.
Since Bosnian Government troops under General Alagic helped retake the town in October and Mr. Karabeg was returned to city hall, the former mayor has often talked of one of his new sources of inspiration: old American Westerns.
"I won't talk about what happened to the Indians," Mr. Karabeg said. "That was ethnic cleansing too." But then he talks about the lessons he draws from characters played by Glenn Ford and John Wayne. "If you work hard, and you are just, you will be rewarded. Your future is in your own hands."
For the last six months or so, the two men have been working on how to apply those maxims.
"We have thought about it, and we have to change everything," Mr. Karabeg said. "For one thing, the whole agricultural system is wrong."
He was referring to the limit of about 35 acres allowed per farmer, a remnant of old Yugoslav laws that were intended to protect small subsistence farmers, but also effectively kept them out of local economy.
"We will have large ranches, like in California, not small farms where families just produce for themselves." he said. "There will be dairy and cattle ranches, and very large fruit orchards so we can sell on the free market."
The people here say there was a sedate quality to life in this valley before the war. It was caught half-way between farming and industry, with most workers employed in factories as well as tending their small holdings.
"But that's not efficient," said Mr. Karabeg. "The people were not good at either job." Now, he said, he will make people choose: either produce crops for market, or be a factory worker.
When it was pointed out that in California there are tens of thousands of homeless and unemployed at the bottom of the economic order, people who have not found a place in the system he envisions here, he scoffed. "They must just be lazy," he said. "Because in America if you want to work you will succeed."
If the two men see the rural area becoming a replica of California's Central Valley, they see the rest of this region becoming a haven for industry.
Farmers who give up the land could find that the benign conditions on the production line have changed, however. "There were far too many workers, and not nearly enough production," Mr. Alagic said. "We can't afford that anymore." Wages, at least initially, are to be about one-tenth of what they were before the war.
Local government -- in other words, the mayor -- now controls all local industry formerly run by the state. Eventually, the two men say, the enterprises will be privatized. But for now, apart from the 184 small grocery stores and cafes and a couple of barber shops, Mr. Alagic, with the former mayor at his side, has used his influence as a war hero to gain control over almost everything that can generate income or provide a job, from the wood-products factory to the coal mine.
During the three and a half years that Bosnian Serb forces had control here and Bosnian Serbs occupied the houses, there was rampant looting and destruction. And Bosnian Government troops looted homes and farms when they returned.
So almost all the 1,856 tractors that were licensed before the war are now gone. Of the 11,300 factory jobs listed in town records, only a few hundred remain because most factories are damaged and few have equipment in working order. Nearly all the houses are damaged and many of them are uninhabitable.
A study by the United States Army found that there is not enough clean water or medical care available to safely sustain the 20,000 people who now live here, about one-third of the pre-war population.
But these facts do not stand in the way of Mr. Karabeg and Mr. Alagic. The men are encouraging any Bosnian refugee with a strong back and the capacity to believe in El Dorado to make a new life here.
"By this summer there will be thousands more," Mr. Alagic predicted. "But they'd better want to work."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET TRUCE: THE DETAILS;
Both Congress and Clinton Find Cause for Cheer in the Final Budget Deal

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Both Congressional Republicans and the White House can find something to crow about in the $159.4 billion budget agreement that Congress passed today, and each side has eagerly trumpeted its gains.
Republicans met their goal of cutting $23 billion in discretionary spending from the budget over last year's levels. 
 Even though they were forced into some political horsetrading with the White House and shifted millions of dollars to some programs that they have targeted for outright elimination or deep cuts, they were able to force the Administration to accept offsetting cuts from other programs.
Though the agreement approved today does not address the larger, more important steps needed to balance the Federal budget -- particularly changes in entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicaid or Medicare -- the $23 billion in cuts kept the Republicans on track in their plan to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic minority leader, conceded that much today when he was asked what his party's biggest concession had been: "Money," he replied. "Big time."
On the other hand, though the provisions of the new agreement leave this year's budget $30 billion below President Clinton's request for 1996, the White House can clearly claim the advantage on policy issues.
The Administration was able to wrangle $5 billion in additional spending for the jobs, education and health programs it felt strongest about. And it rescued from the Republican trash heap the President's police-on-the-streets program, his Goals 2000 education program and his national service program, AmeriCorps.
And after months of bruising fights between intransigent and outspoken adversaries, the Administration won almost across-the-board success on major environmental disputes in the new budget agreement.
To the very end, a senior White House aide said, the talks on environmental issues were "an extremely high-energy, high-emotion, high-intensity series of discussions." The agreement gives President Clinton special waiver authority to overturn provisions in the bill on several environmental issues, some of which had been debated for nearly a year, his aide said.
Here is a rundown of specific features of the agreement:
 
Endangered Species
 The Administration will soon be able to resume listings of new species for protection under the Endangered Species Act, a procedure that has been halted since last summer, when Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, added an amendment on a spending bill that imposed a moratorium.
 
Wetlands
 The Environmental Protection Agency will retain the authority in existing law to veto permits issued by the Army Corps of Engineers for draining and filling wetlands, a power that Senator Kit Bond, Republican of Missouri, had tried to limit.
 
Tongass National Forest
 President Clinton won in his fight with the three-man Alaskan delegation, Republicans all, over expanded logging in the Tongass National Forest. Though the White House agreed to pay about $100 million in economic aid to local governments in compensation, logging there will not be expanded.
 
Mojave Desert
 The bill would allow increased land use there, both recreational and for commercial purposes like mining. The President is expected to exercise a waiver that would nullify that provision.
 
E.P.A. Spending
 The Environmental Protection Agency, which throughout the budget struggle has been targeted for exceptionally deep cuts in its spending, is to be made almost whole, although its budget will not actually increase, as the President originally had sought, administration officials said.
The agency will be allowed to spend about $6.6 billion in the fiscal year 1996, which is already half over and ends in October. That is a shade less than it spent in the previous fiscal year, and is nearly $1 billion more than the amount allocated by the spending bill that Congress initially passed but that the President vetoed.
Agency officials said the financing would allow it to resume a normal pace of enforcement actions and inspections, one area that has been severely crimped during the long budget impasse, although it would take a long time to catch up on the backlog of unfinished work.
 
Toxic Wastes and Clean Water
 Similarly, work will resume at dozens of Superfund sites all over the country where the task of cleaning up toxic wastes has been halted, the officials said.
Hundreds of millions of dollars are being restored to revolving funds that help the states pay for sewage and drinking water treatment plants, they said.
 
Energy and Emissions
 There were some areas of policy in which Congress prevailed and the President decided not to fight any longer. For example, energy efficiency measures, steps to avoid the emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that are implicated in global climate change and programs to encourage the development of new environmental technologies have all been cut.
 
AmeriCorps
 Republicans had targeted Mr. Clinton's national service program for elimination. Under the new agreement, it survived, though with only $400 million, $69.5 million below the 1995 budget and $417 million below the President's request.
 
Goals 2000
 The Administration's program to improve the quality of education was also on the Republicans' kill list. But it will continue through at least this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, with $350 million, nearly $22 million less than last year.
 
C.O.P.S.
 The Republicans retreated on a plan to turn the President's cops-on-the-beat program a block grant to states and they also provided $1.4 billion, a slight increase over last year's budget of $1.3 billion. Administration officials said it was enough money to keep on track with its plans to put 100,000 new police officers on the streets in the next few years.
Advanced Technology Program
 The Commerce Department-run program was an early Republican target for elimination. But in the end, the Republicans relented and appropriated $221 million for one of Mr. Clinton's pet projects, which last year received $341 million.
 
Abortion Language
 Stripped from the bill is language that would have allowed states to deny payments for abortions for Medicaid recipients who become pregnant through rape or incest. But Republicans preserved a provision that forbids Federal, state or local Governments to deny accreditation, licenses or financial assistance to medical schools or hospitals that refuse to teach abortion procedures. The White House had opposed that language.
 
H.I.V. Policy
 The conference bill overturns a recent law that requires the mandatory discharge of members of the military who test positive for the virus that causes AIDS. That provision was part of a $265 billion defense authorization bill that Mr. Clinton signed on Feb. 10 but only after pledging that he would fight to have the law reversed.
 
Student Loans
 The Republicans dropped a plan to limit the Federal Direct Student Loan Program to 40 percent of new Federal loans. Intead, the bill limited administrative costs of the program to $436 million. The student loan issue was one of the first that the Clinton Administration seized upon as political ammunition against the Republicans.
 
Disasters and Security
 The bill authorizes $1.3 billion in supplemental appropriations for natural disaster relief for flooding in the Pacific Northwest and from last winter's blizzards in the Northeast. There is also $860 million for peacekeeping operations in Bosnia-Herzegovina, $70 million for transferring F-16's to Jordan and $50 million to Israel for anti-terrorism measures.
 
Program Eliminations
 The budget kills 200 Federal programs, half of them in the Departments of Labor, and Health and Human Services. The Administration had suggested or supported many of the eliminations.
 
Public Broadcasting
 The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which came under a pointed and sustained attack from conservative Republicans for having a purported liberal bent, received $250 million.
 
Utility Assistance
 Nearly the entire budget for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance program was restored -- $1 billion. Republicans ran into a maelstrom of protest and negative publicity when they proposed killing the program, which helps pay utility bills for the poor and some elderly people. House and Senate budget negotiators wound up cutting $100 million from the program.
 
Debt Collection
 The budget would give a new set of teeth to the Federal Government's debt collectors. Under the legislation, delinquent debtors would be barred from obtaining Federal credit and Federal employees who owe the Government could see their salaries garnished.
Private collection companies would be used to collect some nontax debts and the bill would put the Treasury Department in charge of a new, centralized effort to collect deliquent nontax debts, which are estimated to exceed $55 billion.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Stocks Rise Again, To 7th Consecutive High

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Nasdaq stocks rose to their seventh consecutive high yesterday, capping the market's busiest week in history.
As investors snapped up shares of technology and smaller companies betting that such issues might provide stronger earnings growth than blue-chip stocks, the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.72 points, to 1,186.89. For the week, the Nasdaq index gained 48.19 points, or 4.2 percent. 
 "Nasdaq is still acting very well, although it looks extended," said Harry Laubscher, an analyst with Tucker Anthony. "More and more secondary stocks are attracting buyers."
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 1.08 points, to 5,567.99, its fourth gain in five days. For the week, it was up 32.51 points. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.59 point, to 653.46.
But the story in the market yesterday continued to be Nasdaq trading, which topped 642 million shares, the fourth most active in history. Thursday's volume of 723 million was the second busiest while Wednesday's 728 million was the busiest ever, Tuesday's 650 million was the third biggest. On the New York Stock Exchange, 404.5 million shares traded hands yesterday.
Still, the pace of trading slowed ahead of the weekend and next week's battery of economic data, analysts said. Among the reports next week, the Government will report on gross domestic product for the first quarter on Thursday and employment in April on Friday.
The stock market is expected to approach the jobs data defensively, given the selloff on Wall Street after the February and March jobs reports were much stronger than expected.
"Things have quieted down after an extremely active week," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "Players and stocks are tired."
For a second day, shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours held back the Dow's gains. Du Pont, which fell 3 on Thursday after reporting weaker earnings, fell another 1 1/2 yesterday, to 79 1/4.
Philip Morris led the Dow's gainers, rising 1 7/8, to 89 1/4. At the company's annual meeting on Thursday in Richmond, the chief executive, Geoffrey C. Bible, pledged that the company would fight health-related liabilty suits and would increase spending on its United States tobacco operations.
Phelps Dodge rose 4 1/2, to 77. Business Week magazine reported that the company might be a takeover target for RTZ of Britain. Both companies declined to comment.
Estee Lauder rose 4 1/4, to 37 5/8, in anticipation of a strong quarterly earnings report next week, analysts said.
Several initial public offerings drew avid interest. Heartport Inc., a developer of procedures for performing minimally invasive heart surgery, skyrocketed 14, to 35, in its first session.
i2 Technologies, a software maker, jumped 19 3/4, to 39 3/4, in its first trading day.
Shares of Affinity Technology also made a strong Wall Street debut, rising 7 1/2, to 20 1/2. The company is a maker of electronic products aimed at speeding up bank consumer loans and other financial services.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,387 to 959 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Earlier in Tokyo, stocks ended slightly higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 4.93 points, at 22,235.03. Japanese financial markets will be closed Monday in observance of Greenery Day.

HEADLINE: Gambling in the Sunlight

 BODY:
Just a few weeks ago, Representative Frank Wolf's proposal to create a commission on the social and economic impact of the nation's gambling explosion seemed just the sort of virtuous idea that everyone in this partisan Congress could support. In early March the House approved the nine-member study panel without dissent. But the Virginia Republican's proposal is in trouble in the Senate and may die there unless the majority leader, Bob Dole, exerts leadership to rescue it.
A special interest group known for its generous campaign contributions -- the Nevada-based gaming industry -- has teamed up with prominent and well-compensated Republican lobbyists to try to stop the bill. With help from Nevada's Democratic Senator, Richard Bryan, and Alaska's Ted Stevens, the Republican chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, the effort seems to be succeeding. 
Mr. Bryan blocked Senate action. Mr. Stevens, meanwhile, has produced a weak revision that would deny the commission the powers it needs to subpoena documents, convene investigative hearings and make recommendations that go beyond such obvious issues as native-American casinos and gambling on the Internet. Angered by criticism, Mr. Stevens last week decided, for now, against reporting any bill out of his committee. The delay increases the chance that the commission will die in the usual close-of-session legislative logjam.
The social and economic consequences of the rapid proliferation of casinos and state-run lotteries have received too little attention. There is room for a comprehensive look at the true costs and benefits for local economies and at the relationship between gambling and crime. There is also a need to look at the industry's role in creating gambling addicts and the extent to which earnings derive from problem gamblers. Even staunch supporters of legalized gambling cannot object to a fair effort to give localities the information they need to make informed decisions before turning to gambling as a source of new or increased revenue.
Although Mr. Dole has received hefty campaign contributions from the gambling industry, he has indicated his support for a national gambling study. To make it happen, though, he needs to move quickly to make room for the bill on the Senate calendar and to insure its passage with the commission's full investigative powers intact. Among other things the commission would study the gambling industry's ability to influence public policy. The Senate's timidity is a case in point.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Cheap Gas vs. Stiff Upper Lips;
So Far, Deregulation Is Leaving Most Britons Cold

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: PLYMOUTH, England

 BODY:
You might think that American and other foreign energy companies would have an easy time stealing British Gas's residential customers, now that the Government is ending the giant utility's monopoly on home deliveries of natural gas.
After all, British Gas charges more for the fuel than just about any other supplier, and it is widely reviled for its shoddy service and, recently, for the huge compensation package it paid its chief executive. 
But if that's what you think, you probably haven't met the likes of Mark King, the director of a community center in this southwestern coastal town. "The way I understand it, it's the same pipeline, and gas is gas," said Mr. King, expressing the same kind of consumer befuddlement that greeted competition in the long-distance telephone business in the United States a decade ago. "So how is it I get a bill from any one of 9 or 10 different companies?"
Partly because of the confusion, the Government is proceeding cautiously with its free-market experiment, which officially begins April 29 in just three southwestern counties -- Devon, Cornwall and Somerset -- with 500,000 consumers. Deregulation will be expanded to the densely populated southeast in 1997 and to all of Britain in 1998.
But the American companies -- Amerada Hess, Texaco and the Southern Company -- are moving aggressively, hoping to glean experience they can apply back home when competition sweeps the utility business there.
Already, the barriers to competition for industrial and some commercial customers have come down in the United States, but homeowners are still locked into buying their gas from local utilities, with the price set by state regulators.
Scattered experiments are beginning, however, that allow residential customers a choice. Soon, residential customers in Wyoming will be asked to choose a gas company, for example, and last month, the public utility that delivers electricity to portions of Orange and Rockland Counties in New York and Passaic and Bergen Counties in New Jersey proposed a plan to allow 1,500 residents to choose their electricity supplier.
One thing American companies have learned the hard way in this country is that the English do not take kindly to door-to-door sales pitches. Sweb Gas, which is owned by the Southern Company of Atlanta, had to dismiss one of the companies it hired to ring doorbells after consumers complained its sales tactics were deceitful. "We decided not to try selling in person after doing some market research that showed it wouldn't be welcome," said Caroline Harper, Amerada Hess's managing director.
The American companies have also discovered that although the Government has published a booklet that thoroughly explains the competition and how it works, most consumers look to the gas marketers themselves for explanation. And making comparisons to competitive telephone services isn't enough, because consumers in some areas don't have a choice of telephone companies yet.
Finally, they are finding that hype falls flat in a country renowned for its stiff-upper-lip stolidness. Almost everyone is complaining about the flood of direct mail related to the competition. And none of the other marketing ploys -- not the sales representatives wearing brightly colored jackets who pitch their line in shopping center parking lots; not the ads plastered on billboards exhorting the public to call a toll-free number for information on how to save on gas bills; not even incentives like vouchers for savings at the Marks & Spencer department store chain -- are having much effect.
Many residents feel overwhelmed by the torrent of glossy pamphlets promising savings of up to 20 percent. Many have greeted the competition with a big yawn. "When we first started getting brochures in the mail, I just threw them away," said Anne Littlewood, a homemaker here. "Then my husband started looking into it. If it was up to me, I suppose we'd just do nothing."
Other reactions ranged from the suspicion that lower prices would lead to poor service to the hope that holding out would help push prices even lower. Then there is the undercurrent of jingoism that sets up an additional hurdle for the Americans.
Tom Birdwell, a taxi driver here, for example, views allegiance to British Gas as something of a patriotic duty. Buying from the Americans isn't an option for him. "They let us fight through the worst of the war and didn't come in themselves until the end," he says, referring to America's entry into World War II in 1941. "I'll buy British, thank you, and support British Gas."
Not all consumers are so dogmatic. But enough are either ignoring the blandishments of the nine gas marketers competing against British Gas, or putting off a decision to switch, that early projections about the impact of the new policy are being thrown into doubt.
While the campaign was expected to lure some 100,000 accounts away from British Gas fairly quickly, the participating companies say they don't expect to reach that level for several months or perhaps not even until next year.
Gas marketers like those participating in the pilot program here are undaunted. Many note that it took several years for consumers in the United States to accept competition for long-distance telephone service and that the AT&T Corporation still dominates that business.
"The light will eventually switch on with residential customers, just as it has with commercial users," said John W. Barr, a principal in Barr Devlin Associates, an investment banking boutique in New York that advises utility companies.
Indeed, some Britons are taking the plunge. John and Pamela Foster opted for a three-year contract with Total Gas, a joint venture between London Electricity P.L.C. and Total S.A., a French oil and gas company, after much thought. "If I save 10 percent, I'll be happy," Mr. Foster said. He figured that would knock his monthly bill down by $50 a year or so, roughly in line with the projected average savings for British households.
British Gas, for its part, expects its new rivals to make headway after their slow start. "We're like a cat with a rather long tail in a room full of rocking chairs," sighed Robert Dangerfield, a company spokesman.
Many of the same companies now vying for residential customers have been competing for commercial and industrial customers since 1986 with a fair amount of success, which they expected to repeat in the $20 billion residential market after Ofgas, the quasi-governmental agency that regulates the gas industry here, opened it to competition.
Many of the companies competing to supply gas to homes blame the Gas Consumers Council for the lack of interest among residents. "They've been most unhelpful," said Caroline Harper, managing director of Amerada Hess Gas. "They've implied that British Gas would be reducing its prices and advised people to wait and see how things went."
She and executives from other gas companies also said the regulators' decision to start competition in the spring, when gas consumption is tailing off, had hampered efforts to focus consumers' attention. "We haven't quite got the numbers signing up that we anticipated," said Graeme S. Boyd, sales and marketing manager for Total.
Linda Gilroy, the regional manager of the Southwest office of the Gas Consumers Council, had a different take. Ms. Gilroy said she was surprised by the apathy she encountered when she spoke about the issue recently to a group of Rotarians, a club for business people, in Exmouth. She had taken along a stack of booklets published by Ofgas that explain the competition and how it works, she said, but only one of her listeners opted to pick up a copy.
Consumers themselves say they find it difficult to understand how the competitive system will work. And it is a bit of an abstraction: British Gas will continue to operate and maintain the pipelines into residential homes, and the other gas companies will pay it a fee based on the volume of gas they pump through the lines. The newcomers are able to offer significant savings because British Gas is saddled with contracts made years ago that force it to pay well over current market rates.
Customers in low-income neighborhoods worry that the new companies will not be as understanding as British Gas about late payments or the lack of a family bank account -- even though they will have to abide by the same laws curbing cutoffs.
Mr. King, the community-service director here, prepays for gas using tokens that he feeds into his meter. He said the new companies had not made much effort to solicit accounts in his neighborhood, where unemployment runs high. But even if they had done so, he added, he would stay with British Gas.
"These new companies are unproven," he said. "Maybe in a few years, if they're even still around, I'd consider switching. But not for now.
"British Gas should have never been privatized, anyway," he added, giving voice to a commonly held philosophical reservation about the Government's new policy.
One might think British Gas would welcome the public's lukewarm support for the new foreign rivals, but instead, the company is desperately hoping that competition will take hold. That's because it is concerned that Ofgas will not allow it to compete head-on with the other gas marketers if they have not attracted enough customers, even though a spokesman for Ofgas said British Gas could lower its prices right away.
But if British Gas does begin competing here on price, it will risk the outrage of its 18 million other customers elsewhere in the country who will still be paying at the old rate.
"We're not in a very nice position at the moment," Mr. Dangerfield said, expressing a sentiment that may well be shared by some of British Gas's competitors.
