HEADLINE: Yankee Who Captured Savannah Is Its Hero

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga., April 26

 BODY:
Not since William Tecumseh Sherman spared Savannah from the torch has this city been so indebted to a Yankee.
And so today, the town showed its appreciation for John Berendt, the New York author whose fabulously successful best seller, "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil," exposed Savannah's eccentricities to the world and spawned a cottage industry in the process. Tourism is booming here, and by everyone's account the main explanation is "The Book," as locals refer to it. 
 This morning, book fans and Berendt friends gathered in moss-draped Monterrey Square to hear the town crier, Harry Jennings, declare it "John Berendt Day" by official proclamation of the Mayor. The square, which is the setting for the book's central action, the murder of a young gigolo by a prominent dealer in antiques, was renamed for Mr. Berendt for the day.
Mr. Berendt said he was flattered. "I'm very pleased," he said, "although I'm a carpetbagger, to be, I guess, the favorite carpetbagger of Savannah.".
The event was concocted with the help of press agents at Random House, Mr. Berendt's publisher, to mark the completion of the book's second year on The New York Times Book Review's nonfiction best-sellers list. The book, with 900,000 copies in print and translations in 11 languages, has fallen off the list from time to time since being published in January 1994. But its appearance on Sunday (at No. 6) will mark its 104th week on the list. Warner Brothers expects to begin filming a movie version in Savannah early next year, with Clint Eastwood directing.
Some Savannahians, of course, would have preferred that their city not become known as home to the gay murderers, black drag queens, voodoo priestesses and piano-playing con men that populate the book.
"I don't think he played up the good parts of Savannah or the history of Savannah as I grew up with it," said Patricia B. McCuen, who was born here 68 years ago. "It's not just the little Southern back-stabbing town he talked about."
But for tourists, those characters and their world have proved an irresistible charm. Everybody, it seems, wants to tour a city that a local historian, John D. Duncan, likens to "a house of secrets."
In 1995, Savannah's hotel and motel room-tax revenues soared by 15 percent, triple the average growth in each of the previous four years. Registrations at the visitors' center increased by 6 percent after two consecutive years of declines.
"Everyone agrees that the book was responsible for the abnormal growth," said Ray Wood, an economic analyst with Savannah Electric who compiled the tourism statistics.
These days, it is common to see visitors walking the streets of the historic district, book in hand, searching for the Mercer House, where Jim Williams murdered Danny Hansford, or Clary's Cafe, where Mr. Berendt first encountered Luther Driggers, who was rumored to be interested in poisoning Savannah's water supply. So many tourists have traipsed through Bonaventure Cemetery, another setting, that the Trosdal family has removed the statue of Bird Girl, pictured on the cover jacket, and stored it in a garage.
Half a dozen companies now offer "Midnight" bus tours of the historic district, featuring personal reminiscences about key characters and stops at all the important scenes. "I have two buses that are full every day," said Pat C. Tuttle, owner of Hospitality Tours. "We turn people away. They're part of this cult."
Nancy Hillis, the model for the character Mandy, sells "Midnight" walking tour maps for $5 and a 45-minute videotape for $15. When tour buses stop by the Hamilton-Turner House, where she lives, Ms. Hillis summons visitors into the parlor to hear her life story and a brief anti-drug lecture. Finishing up her speech this morning, she looked at her watch and gasped. "I have to go talk to 500 Shriners," she said.
Mr. Duncan, who owns a Monterrey Square shop of antique maps and prints, charges at least $100 for his two-carousel slide lecture about the book's characters. He and his wife, Virginia, have sold so many copies of the book in their store that they now earn more from book sales than from his $42,000-a-year salary at Armstrong State College.
Next month, Deborah D. Sullivan plans to open "The Book" gift shop. "Our main feature will be the book, the map of the book, the tape of the book, the large print book, and, of course, the Christmas ornament series, starting with the Bird Girl," Ms. Sullivan said.
Property values in the historic district have been driven up by book-obsessed buyers, said Cora Bett Thomas, a longtime real estate agent. And after a Maine biotechnology company decided to move its headquarters here, its president told local officials that he first became interested in Savannah because of the book.
"I was hoping he would say it was our great marketing," said Richard A. Estus, chairman of the Savannah Economic Development Authority. "But he said, 'Well, I was reading the book and was fascinated and thought Savannah must have great character.' "
But perhaps no one, with the exception of Mr. Berendt, has profited from the book as much as The Lady Chablis, the sassy drag queen Mr. Berendt made famous. Chablis said in an interview -- on a cellular telephone -- that he had received a $100,000 advance from Pocket Books to write an autobiography, which will be published this summer. The title: "Hiding My Candy."
This week, Chablis modeled along with Marla Maples at a New York fashion benefit. When Ms. Maples's husband, Donald Trump, complimented his appearance, Chablis responded, "Well, see now, darling, you married the wrong woman."
Chablis is booked to perform this weekend at a society wedding in a Savannah park for more than $7,000. "That's very good money for 30 minutes work," he said. "I have to thank John Berendt. That book has changed my life."

HEADLINE: Mitsubishi Motors Plans Rescue of Embattled U.S. Unit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 26

 BODY:
The American manufacturing subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, already the target of a potentially huge Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, is also facing serious financial problems that will force a reorganization and a huge capital infusion, the parent company announced today.
Mitsubishi said it would take a one-time charge against earnings to reflect the lower value of the American subsidiary, Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, which has lost money almost every year of its existence and is mired in debt. The charge, for the year that ended on March 31, is 32.6 billion yen, or about $300 million. 
 Mitsubishi Motors also announced a sudden change of presidents. Takemune Kimura, a manufacturing expert who is credited with revitalizing one of the company's main factories, will replace Nobuhisa Tsukahara, who has held the post for less than one year. It is the third prominent change at the top this month among Japanese automobile makers, following those at the troubled Nissan Motor Company and at Mazda Motor Corporation.
Mitsubishi said Mr. Tsukahara, who is ill and has been in and out of the hospital, had stepped down for health reasons. But the move also seems to reflect the decision of Hirokazu Nakamura, the company's powerful chairman, that a change was needed at a time when Mitsubishi was facing growing problems at home and abroad.
"The environment surrounding Mitsubishi Motors has drastically changed," Dr. Nakamura said at a news conference today. Mitsubishi has weathered Japan's long recession better than most of its competitors because it is the leader in the fast-growing sport utility market in Japan. But Honda, Toyota and others have introduced models that are now eating into Mitsubishi's market share. Mitsubishi is the No. 3 auto maker in Japan and is strong in other parts of Asia. But in the United States, it has a weak product lineup and a small, underperforming dealer network.
Mitsubishi officials said the naming of the new president, the planned reorganization of the American plant and the sexual harassment case were unrelated. They said the company decided to write down the value of its American subsidiary now, because results for the fiscal year that ended last month were strong. Even with the charge against earnings, and a 4.9 percent decline in sales, Mitsubishi Motors still expects to report a 9 percent increase in net income, to 20.5 billion yen. (But using the exchange rates in place at the end of the fiscal year, earnings will decline in dollar terms, to about $191 million.)
In his first public comments on the sexual harassment controversy at the factory in Normal, Ill., Dr. Nakamura said the incident had brought "shame" to the company. And he confirmed the company's desire to resolve the situation.
"Some say the press reports do not stick to the facts, but at the same time we have to admit that parts of the reports are true," Dr. Nakamura said. "It's a shame on us and extremely regrettable."
"I really hope that the case can be settled in a friendly manner as early as possible," he continued. "And I believe that the case will be settled in the near future."
Dr. Nakamura said he was worried that harassment charges could give consumers the impression that Mitsubishi lacked the discipline to produce quality products. He said other companies with the Mitsubishi name, which are only loosely linked to the auto company, had also expressed concerns about the impact on their sales and images.
Employees at the Illinois factory have also expressed some concern that the harassment suit will hurt sales, putting their jobs in jeopardy. But it became clear today that the real danger to their jobs is the plant's failure to reach its annual capacity of 240,000 vehicles since it began production in 1988.
The plant has made a profit in only one or two years, said Minoru Wada, a Mitsubishi managing director in Tokyo. The accumulated loss at Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing is $800 million and it has debts of $700 million.
So Mitsubishi Motors, perhaps with help from some other Mitsubishi companies, will inject what Mr. Wada suggested would be about $500 million in new capital into the American subsidiary to retire some debt.
The Illinois factory will undergo cost-cutting and the product line will be revamped. Tsuneo Ohinouye, chairman and chief executive of the American subsidiary, said the company, which has 4,000 employees, will "make a full effort not to have layoffs."
Mr. Wada said the aim was to cut costs so that the factory could be profitable even if it produced only 130,000 or 140,000 vehicles a year. In 1995, the plant produced 218,500 cars, its best year ever, but still lost an undisclosed amount of money, in part because the yen's rise made parts imported from Japan more expensive.
The factory in Illinois, which makes Mitsubishi's Galant and Eclipse models, was owned jointly with the Chrysler Corporation until Chrysler sold its share in 1991. But the output is still sold by both companies. Chrysler sold 80,000 of the cars last year, including the Dodge Avenger and Chrysler Sebring.
But Mitsubishi faces new challenges because Chrysler is expected to stop buying cars from Mitsubishi in the next few years because the stronger yen has made the prices of the models noncompetitive.
"The fact that the Chrysler relationship is weakening is awful for Mitsubishi because they will have to sell the cars themselves and their network is so weak," said Saul Rubin, an analyst at SBC Warburg in Tokyo.
Mr. Kimura, the new president, completed engineering graduate school at Kyoto University. He is given credit for turning the Mizushima Works in the Osaka region into one of the most efficient factories in the company. He became executive vice president in 1993.
Still, the choice was a surprise because Mr. Kimura left the board of Mitsubishi last June to become president of a subsidiary, apparently because Mr. Tsukahara was named president of Mitsubishi Motors instead of Mr. Kimura.
Mr. Kimura has no international experience. And at 65, he might be a stopgap president.
At the news conference today, Mr. Kimura disclosed little about his plans other than to say that his biggest worry was maintaining sales volume and that he hoped to create a company "where all employees can work cheerfully."
He displayed a self-deprecating sense of humor. When someone asked about his health, he replied, "Only my head is bad."

HEADLINE: Bank Lobbying Blocks a Bill On S.& L.'s

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
After months of maneuvering, the nation's big commercial banks succeeded this week in blocking legislation -- supported by both the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership -- that would have forced them to pay a big share of the cleanup bill from the savings and loan crisis.
In a display of raw lobbying power, the American Bankers Association and individual banks from around the country won support from a handful of key Democratic and Republican House members who defied their parties to derail the measure, which would have cost banks $12 billion over two decades. 
 The banking legislation was supported not just by both party leaderships but also by regulators, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and so it may come up again this year. But industry executives, Administration officials and members of Congress said it was unclear how the measure could be pushed through without concessions to the banks.
The lack of legislative action increased the risk of default on $8.2 billion in bonds issued in the late 1980's to help pay for the savings and loan crisis. And it left unresolved a situation in which savings institutions pay vastly more for deposit insurance than commercial banks.
A savings institution with $100 million in deposits -- small by industry standards -- pays $230,000 a year in premiums to the savings insurance fund, because the premiums must go in part to paying interest on the bailout bonds. Healthy commercial banks, even the biggest, pay only a token $2,000 each to the bank insurance fund.
Because of the disparity, savings institutions are rushing to acquire or start commercial bank affiliates and shift deposits into them. That allows a savings institution to pay the much lower bank rate for insurance, but slashes the amount of money available to pay interest on the bonds.
Under Secretary of the Treasury John D. Hawke Jr. said that the bonds, which were authorized by Congress but do not carry an explicit Government guarantee, could be at risk of default as early as next year.
Under the legislation, banks would have had to pay $600 million a year for more than 20 years, in the form of increased deposit-insurance premiums, toward the bond interest payments. The much-smaller savings industry would have paid $180 million a year, plus a one-time assessment of $5 billion to strengthen its deposit-insurance fund.
Similar legislation was passed by the House and Senate last year, but was attached to the Republican-sponsored balanced budget bill that was vetoed for unrelated reasons by President Clinton last fall.
Given another shot at stopping the bill, big banks undertook a lobbying blitz in recent months, generating letters from thousands of bankers and leaning on legislators to whose campaigns they have contributed. They argued that the increase was an unjustified tax and that talk of a bond default was hyperbole.
Under an agreement by Speaker Newt Gingrich and the White House, the measure was to be attached to a temporary spending bill that Congress was about to vote on.
With both Democrats and Republicans on the House Banking Committee supporting the legislation, and with the bill having strong bipartisan support in the Senate, trade groups and such banks as Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, a strong opponent of the measure, focused their lobbying on a legislative bottleneck: the House Rules Committee, through which the measure had to pass.
Among those leading the opposition at a Rules Committee meeting on Tuesday night, participants said, was Representative Deborah Pryce of Ohio, a Republican who represents the district that is home to Banc One's headquarters.
On Monday night Ms. Pryce attended a long-scheduled fund-raiser held in Cleveland by the Ohio Bankers Association at which she received around $10,000 in campaign contributions. During 1993 and 1994 Ms. Pryce received $50,798 in campaign contributions from commercial banks and their lobbying groups, including $10,000 from Banc One, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research organization. During the same period, she received $4,000 from savings and loan institutions.
Among the others leading the opposition was Representative Martin Frost of Texas, who as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee helps raise money for Congressional candidates.
Earlier this week Mr. Frost undertook the maneuver that brought the issue before the Rules Committee. He had been lobbied heavily by the Texas Bankers Association. He received $42,450 in contributions from commercial banks in 1993 and 1994, the analysis said, and $2,000 from savings and loans.
Democratic and Republican House aides said that when Mr. Frost voiced opposition to moving the measure through the Rules Committee, the bipartisan support collapsed.
One reason, they said, was that Republicans feared allowing Mr. Frost to portray himself as a hero to the banks in an election year.
Mr. Frost said his opposition to the measure was based on a belief that controversial legislation should have a chance to be fully debated and not be rammed through on the back of broader legislation.
Ms. Pryce said her opposition "was prompted by the surprise nature of its appearance" before the Rules Committee and said the bill was 'too controversial to be added" to the temporary spending bill.
After being blocked in the Rules Committee, the Administration and the House leadership had the option of trying again on Thursday by attaching the savings and loan legislation to the omnibus spending bill for the current fiscal year.
But a group of 24 House members led by Representative Sam Johnson of Texas, a Republican, had sent a letter to Mr. Gingrich last week saying they might have to withhold support for any budget agreement if the savings bill was attached to it. The 24 Representatives acted after heavy lobbying from banking groups, House staff members said.
Not wanting to risk the budget agreement, the Administration and House leadership moved the budget bill to the floor without the savings measure.

HEADLINE: Bond Market Idles Before Economic Reports

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended nearly unchanged yesterday, in a quiet trading session.
Bond prices traded in narrow ranges, as market participants waited for a number of important economic reports due next week that could provide a clearer indication of the strength of the economy and the outlook for inflation. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management plans to issue its survey on Wednesday, while the Government is scheduled to report on the gross domestic product for the first quarter on Thursday and April employment on Friday.
"The market is going to get a one-two-three punch next week with those three reports," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston.
 The bond market was also taking a breather yesterday after absorbing nearly $74 million in new Treasury notes and bills that were sold at auction this week. Supply, however, continued to be a concern: the Treasury plans to announce next week the terms of the quarterly re-funding.
The price of the 30-year bond edged up 2/32 , to 90, leaving its yield unchanged from Thursday at 6.79 percent.
Bond prices received a boost early in the session from a downturn in commodity prices. Rising grain, oil and other commodity prices have sent minor shock waves through the bond market. Experts were split over whether inflation could heat up long term. Bond investors fear inflation because it erodes the value of their securities, which carry a fixed rate of return.
 In addition, market watchers said bond prices were bolstered by purchases of two- and five-year notes by the Federal Reserve on behalf of foreign central banks.
 These so-called under-the-table transactions are commonplace on a small scale. A spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declined to comment; the Fed almost never comments on such activity.
 "The market basically ended unchanged, but on the positive side, there was some buying by the Fed on behalf of foreign central banks," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at IDEA Inc. a consulting firm in New York.
While the purchase by the Fed supported the market in general, Mr. Stiles said, the positive effect was tempered by dealers seeking to unload the new two- and five-year notes and one-year bills they had bought at auction this week.
 Dealers were trying to distribute recently sold securities ahead of the three critical economic reports set for release next week, he said.
The most important report next week will be on employment, said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The two previous monthly reports showed surprising strength in the job market, roiling the bond market both times.
The economy is expected to have created 129,000 jobs in April, and the unemployment rate is expected to be 5.6 percent, unchanged from March.
 Yesterday, the University of Michigan's released its final consumer sentiment index for April, which was higher than expected but was discounted by the market, traders said.
The index, released only to subscribers, stood at 92.7 compared with 93.7 in the final March index, traders said. Economists had expected a reading of 91.9.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Joins The Latin Trend To Free Markets

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 26

 BODY:
After reversing several years of stalwart resistance to free-market changes, Venezuela is under heavy pressure at home and abroad to produce results.
This week, the Government ended two years of currency exchange controls that had crippled the economy and had plunged the country into high unemployment and double-digit inflation. The Government has also removed some price controls and subsidies, reflected most drastically in a 470 percent increase in the cost of gasoline. It also set a timetable for privatizing some of the vast Government-owned assets this year. With these moves, Venezuela embraced changes that had swept through other Latin American countries years ago. 
 The plan was capped by a preliminary agreement for a standby loan with the International Monetary Fund -- the demon against which President Rafael Caldera campaigned when he won the election two years ago.
"After two years of the wrong policy, I think the President is taking the right steps," said Alejandro Salcedo, president of the Venezuelan stock market.
The I.M.F. board is expected to approve the $1.4 billion standby loan to fortify the country's international reserves and ease the federal deficit, said Fernando Egana, the presidential spokesman. The preliminary agreement by the I.M.F. opened the way for companion loans from the World Bank and the Bank for Inter-American Development. The banks are pledging $1.9 billion to bolster the Government system of employee severance payments, which is collapsing from mismanagement and corruption. Part of the $1.9 billion will go toward offsetting the economic hardships among the poorest Venezuelans that free-market changes are expected to cause.
"The Venezuelan agenda was not undertaken because the Government thought it had no other alternative, but because it thinks it was a good thing to do," Mr. Egana said. "I think people know the adjustment will be painful in the short run and better in the medium and long term."
While Venezuela is not expected to need the foreign cash immediately, the I.M.F. accord provides a measure of credibility to the economic revisions that, analysts said, are the last resort of a country whose economy has been spiraling downward under two years of tight Government control. Inflation ran at 70 percent over the last year, and was projected to reach 100 percent this year, with virtually no growth in the sectors of the economy unrelated to oil.
A bloated bureaucracy and a collection of state-owned enterprises in industries as varied as petroleum, mining, hotels, telecommunications, transportation, banking and electricity have left Venezuela with a deficit that would have reached 6 percent of the country's total output if the emergency measures had not been taken. The Government expects its changes to cut the projected deficit by two-thirds, Mr. Egana said.
While loans from international institutions have in effect thrown the Venezuelan economy a rope of credibility, the reprieve is a limited one. The I.M.F.'s $1.4 billion standby loan runs for one year and falls short of the complete backing that a three-year loan would have signified, analysts said.
With the lifting of the Government-set exchange rate, the value of the national currency, the bolivar, dropped from 270 to around 500 to the dollar, before essentially stabilizing at 465. An expected run on banks from industries starved for dollars did not materialize, in part because banks increased interest rates.
Domestic airlines doubled their fares overnight, and costs of everything from buses to groceries to newspapers have skyrocketed within the last week. The sales tax, which had been 12.5 percent, paid at the wholesale level, will rise to 16.5 percent, and will now be passed on directly to the consumer.
Olga Escalante, a 42-year-old mother of three who sat in a park near the gilded cupola of Congress, said that shopping had become an exercise in patchwork economics. The earnings of her 54-year-old husband, who lost his job in the mail room of a Caracas newspaper, shrank from $705 to $86 a month after he took a job in a perfume factory. "It's horrible," she said, "Today things are one price, tomorrow they're higher, and there's no increase in salaries."
Mrs. Escalante sells lottery tickets and cleans houses, while her high-school-age daughter has started cutting hair to help with the expenses. "Today, black beans that were 300 bolivars are 400, onions went from 100 to 190, floor wax to 900 from 600, sanitary napkins from 200 to 1,000."
The I.M.F. plan is not without its critics. Hugo Faria, an economist and financial analyst at the Institute for the Study of Advanced Administration, a private research organization, said Venezuela already paid 42 percent of its $14 billion annual budget toward servicing its foreign debt. And with some $100 billion in Government properties, he said, the country would do better "selling off its crown jewels" than increasing foreign debt.
The cornerstones of the economic program, he noted, were an increase in taxes and gasoline prices, and a surge in debt. "When you look at it from the financial side, it looks like a bailout of the Government at the expense of people," Mr. Faria said.
Venezuelans, who in 1989 rioted over price increases, appear resigned to austerity measures this time around. In a recent survey, some 86 percent said the changes should have been undertaken earlier. They said they would withhold judgment in the hope of seeing some improvement over the next year.
But some expect slow progress. "Of course, I have hope, at least that this will be a benefit for my children" Mrs. Escalante said. "I don't know whether it will be one for me as well."

HEADLINE: It Was Zoning That Allowed SoHo to Be SoHo;
Tax Inhibits Growth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You correctly state in your April 21 news article that only because so many people ignored the provisions of the Zoning Resolution was New York City able to regain some of its economic strength. 
 I hope that the City Planning Commission, in its revision to come out next month, will build in incentives to promote the new live-work concept from which so much of the new economic vitality derives.
The planning commission should eliminate the tax on the conversion of business buildings into living-and-work quarters, which to a large degree inhibits the growth of infant industries.
 
I. DONALD WESTON
Brooklyn, April 22, 1996
 
The writer is an architect.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Germany Cuts Welfare; Lean Times for Europe?
With Europeans voicing widespread anxiety about whether they can remain competitive in the global economy, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced long-heralded cuts in Germany's well-padded welfare state that are intended to reduce Bonn's budget deficit by $33 billion. 
 The measures, which threaten social benefits that Germans regard as virtually sacrosanct and follow by only two days France's sweeping changes in its national health care system, underscore the worries among European Governments and businesses that leaner times lie ahead. High welfare spending and cosseted labor appear to be at risk as nations, led by Germany, work toward a single European currency. [Page 1.]
 
U.S. Budget Cuts, Wide and Deep
The budget bill signed by President Clinton, combined with other actions taken by Congress in the last year, will cut domestic spending by $24 billion, or 10 percent. Although Democrats rescued a few favorite programs, like the national service program known as Americorps, the Republicans cut spending for a wide range of domestic programs including housing, labor, education and Commerce Department programs. Many of the cuts, like those for the arts, were substantial. [D10.]
 
Stocks Advance;
Busiest Week Ever
Nasdaq stocks rose to their seventh consecutive high, up 2.72 points, to 1,186.89, capping the market's busiest week in history, as investors rushed to buy shares of technology and smaller companies. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 1.08 points, at 5,567.99, its fourth gain in five days. For the week, it was up 32.51 points. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.59 point, to 653.46. [41.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in quiet trading, as market participants waited for a number of important economic reports due next week. [47.]
 
For U.S. Business, Gains in Mexico
American companies operating in Mexico stand to gain from two important regulatory decisions. Although the fees that American-led telecommunications joint ventures will have to pay Telmex, the current phone monopoly, are higher than the seven new competitors wanted, they are lower than the target set by Telmex. Secondly, the Mexican Chamber of Senators voted to approve the creation of privately run pension funds. [38.]
 
Fuji Bank President Quits
The president of Fuji Bank, one of Japan's largest financial institutions, announced his resignation, but denied his decision was a result of Fuji's huge loan losses. Still, the resignation was seen as a way of assuming responsibility for the bad-debt problems, and puts pressure on the heads of other Japanese banks to step down as well. [39.]
 
Japan Leads Asian Currency Pact
Japan has concluded a currency pact with seven neighboring countries in an effort to expand its role in guarding against turmoil in the currency markets in Asia. In New York trading, the dollar fell to 105.55 yen. [40.]
 
Gasoline Futures Prices Surge
Gasoline prices surged for the sixth consecutive session on the New York Mercantile Exchange with unleaded gasoline for May delivery settling 1.20 cents higher at 76.81 cents a gallon. Wheat and corn futures prices again rose sharply. [40.]
 
Herman's Files
For Chapter 11
Herman's Sporting Goods, which operates 117 stores in the Northeast, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, saying it had $127.8 million in assets and $160.5 million in liabilities. The retailer, based in Carteret, N.J., said all its stores would remain open. [39.]
 
In Hoover's Town, Enduring Trust
The trust that "Boss" Hoover built with the 15,000 residents of North Canton, Ohio, home of America's leading vacuum cleaner maker, has endured -- happily for Maytag, which bought the Hoover Company. [9.]
 
Onassis Items Fetch $34.4 Million
The Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate auction ended, after chalking up sales of $34.4 million. The last item that Sotheby's sold was Mrs. Onassis' last car, a 1992 BMW 325i four-door sedan. It went for $79,500. [27.]

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: IN ISRAEL;
Peres's View: Modest Boon

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 26

 BODY:
Prime Minister Shimon Peres, evidently relieved at being extracted by the American-brokered deal from a military operation that had gone awry, declared today that "Israel comes out of this with more quiet and more strength."
The announcement that attacks and counterattacks on civilians in Israel and Lebanon would cease early Saturday cleared the way for Mr. Peres to leave later that day on an official visit to Washington, a trip that was in question as long as the fighting continued. 
 Mr. Peres listed four elements of the agreement that he described as advantages over the unwritten 1993 accord that had similar aims: this one was in writing; it brought Syria, Lebanon, the United States and France into the picture as monitors; it explicitly forbade rocket attacks on northern Israel, and it did not ban Israel from retaliating when attacked.
But the agreement, brokered by Secretary of State Warren Christopher after a week of intensive shuttling, also left the Hezbollah guerrillas free to continue attacks inside the nine-mile-wide zone of southern Lebanon occupied by Israel as a buffer. That made the agreement a big target for the conservative opposition, and Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Peres's challenger in the May 29 national election, opened fire promptly.
"This is not what we waited for," he said. "This reinstates the previous situation, which created the crisis in the first place. This is an explicit Israeli license, in writing, for Hezbollah to act against Israeli Defense Forces in Lebanon, and furthermore it creates safe havens for Hezbollah in the villages."
Mr. Peres and Mr. Christopher announced the agreement at 6 P.M., a scant half hour before the start of the Jewish Sabbath, thus effectively cutting off debate for a day. But Mr. Netanyahu's onslaught and intenal deates that anticipated the pact made clear that the Lebanese operation would not be the political and military success that Mr. Peres evidently had hoped for.
On balance, most commentators said, it will benefit Mr. Peres's campaign by portraying him as a leader ready to take firm action to protect Israel's security -- but only if the pact held. If Katyusha rockets begin falling again, everybody agreed, Mr. Peres will suffer a serious political blow.
That effectively left Hezbollah with the potential to undermine Mr. Peres's election chances. But Mr. Peres seemed to place considerable significance in the fact that Syria had agreed to a written arrangement that involved it as a monitor.
Asked in a television interview what would prevent Hezbollah from attacking, he said: "Their hands are tied not to attack because if they do, it will cause a conflict, and if there's a conflict, it becomes an issue for Syria and Lebanon.
"The Syrians had an agreement with us in 1974, and there has been no infringement in the Golan Heights. I attribute great importance to the fact that Syria and Lebanon have agreed to be partners."
From the outset, Israeli officials said privately that the goal was not to disarm or destroy Hezbollah militarily, but to persuade Syria and Lebanon to curb the guerrillas.
In Israel's view, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria was not necessarily behind the Hezbollah offensive, but he alone is capable of reining in the guerrillas. The Israeli Government also holds that Mr. Assad has adhered to agreements he made, like the Golan Heights cease-fire.
The military operation was intended to increase pressure steadily by sending 400,000 refugees fleeing the south and by selectively shelling the Lebanese civil infrastructure. But the plan abruptly went awry on April 18, when Israeli gunners hit a United Nations camp full of refugees, killing more than 100.
That put Israel on the diplomatic defensive and prompted Mr. Christopher to seek a way out.
The question was whether it was Israel or Syria that got the best of the deal in the end. Though Mr. Peres never spelled out Israel's objectives, officials had indicated that they hoped Syria would agree in writing to rein in the guerrillas completely and to agree to revive peace talks.
In the end, Syria, which was effectively sidelined from the antiterrorism campaign opened by the United States after a spate of suicide bombings in Israel, found itself back at center stage in the search for a regional peace. Israel emerged with its image tarnished by the terrible carnage at the United Nations camp and the impression that it waged a deliberate campaign against civilians and economic targets.
The final toll was 160 dead in Lebanon and no fatalities in Israel. A Hezbollah leader said 13 guerrillas had been killed.
The "understanding" read out by Mr. Christopher was unsigned and obligated Syria only to sit on a monitoring panel whose actual powers and organization remained to be sorted out. Nothing condemned Hezbollah, and leaders of the organization declared their satisfaction with the arrangement.
Israel was also known to be unhappy about bringing France into the monitoring group. France generally sided closer to Lebanon and Syria than to Israel during the operation.
For Mr. Peres, the advantage was primarily the hope that rocket attacks against northern Israel would stop and that more Israelis would come to agree that only a comprehensive peace with Syria would really bring peace to the region.
Inside Israel, the fine points of the agreement were less important than the question of whether it could bring security to the north.
"It should be kept in mind that nuances in the formulas that Christopher has worked so arduously to bring about are of little concern to the Israeli public," wrote Hemi Shalev in Maariv. "As far as it is concerned, the test of the pudding is in the eating, and its judgment of the Grapes of Wrath," as the Israeli operation in Lebanon was called, "like its view of Yasir Arafat and the Palestinian Authority, will be reached exclusively in terms of results on the ground."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Under the Agreement"
 
Groups in Lebanon will not fire rockets or other weapons into Israel.
 
Israel and its allied militia will not fire at civilian targets in Lebanon.
 
Nothing precludes anti-Israeli guerrillas from attacking soldiers in the Israeli-occupied zone of southern Lebanon.
 
Populated areas and industrial facilities will not be used as launching grounds for attacks on Israeli soldiers.
 
Each side retains the right to self-defense.
 
The United States, France, Israel, Lebanon and Syria form a Monitoring Group to follow compliance with the agreement.

HEADLINE: Model Corporate Citizen Finds Its Trust in Doubt Over a Zoning Issue

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Tale of Town and Company

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: NORTH CANTON, Ohio, April 26

 BODY:
It came down to whether they could still trust Hoover, their local corporation. Was Hoover still Hoover? Or had the 1990's turned the Hoover Company, America's leading vacuum cleaner manufacturer, into just another subsidiary controlled by a faraway corporation? That is what North Canton's 15,000 residents have struggled to figure out these last two years.
A mundane suburban zoning matter set off the soul-searching. In 1994 the company announced plans to sell 241 acres here that had been owned by the Hoover family since the early 1800's. Would Hoover follow its past and make sure that the development was a tasteful addition to North Canton? Or would Hoover, purchased by the Maytag Corporation seven years ago, behave like the subsidiary of a bottom-line corporation and squeeze what it could onto the land? 
 Which Hoover? people asked.
From the turn of the century until the mid-1980's, what Hoover was, was as plain as day: an exemplary corporate citizen of North Canton, Ohio, founded by W. H. (Boss) Hoover and guided into the 1950's by his eldest son, H. W. Hoover Sr. At one time Hoover vacuum cleaner salesmen were treated like heroes here, gathering from around the nation every summer and parading along Main Street -- "It beats as it sweeps as it cleans," they'd sing -- before bedding down at the Hoover Camp for the annual retreat.
Hoover has been the family and the company whose generous donations made everything major in North Canton possible -- the City Hall, the library, the Y.M.C.A., Hoover High School, the ball parks, the hook and ladder fire engine, the community Christmas tree on the Hoover factory lawn, $970,000 worth of computers for the public schools.
Stark County is a political bellwether that swings between Republicans and Democrats in Presidential elections, and it is no accident that North Canton is a Republican stronghold. It is Hoover. People here grew up trusting Hoover and voting Republican. If that trust was broken now, it would be bad news for the Republican vision of America.
It is a commentary on the edginess that people feel in these days of restructuring and downsizing that even the president of a company with Hoover's track record must constantly reassure his work force. The president, Brian A. Girdlestone, says: "With employees, at every opportunity I remind them this is still Hoover, the same values. I say it directly and I say it often."
 
Trusting Hoover? Yes, but Maytag?
Hoover went through big changes starting in the 1980's. It has downsized its unionized work force in Stark County to 2,000 from 3,300, while opening factories in Mexico and Texas. It has reduced its famed sales force and other salaried positions by 47 percent since 1988. It was bought by a holding company, Chicago Pacific, in 1986, and by Maytag three years later.
Suddenly, trusting Hoover meant trusting Maytag. Maytag! If ever North Canton residents needed a cautionary tale for modern corporate behavior, it was Maytag. Maytag had gone from a widely respected, highly profitable manufacturer of appliances, with its headquarters in small-town Newton, Iowa, in the mid-1980's, to an overextended fumbler in the international market. In recent years Maytag has closed factories and sold off Hoover's European and Australian operations to generate cash.
Last year, Maytag paid a $16.5 million settlement to 800 West Virginia workers in its Dixie-Narco division. The workers said contended that Maytag had breached its trust by closing a factory that it promised to keep open.
In 1994, when Hoover announced plans to sell the 241 acres, residents here asked themselves: Was this Hoover or was it Maytag, pushing a button in its vacuum cleaner division to suck up cash?
At public meetings Lynne S. Dragomier, a Hoover vice president, promised that the company would be a "steward" of the land in the tradition of Boss Hoover: 70 of the 241 acres would be donated to the city for Little League ball parks, and another 50 acres would be donated to a local university.
But the plan also called for 52 acres of retail and office development in a county that many feel is overrun with drugstore chains, fast-food restaurants, malls and shopping centers. As Dick Stahl, an opponent, said, "Per capita, we probably have more drugstores in North Canton -- I don't think we have that many sick people."
Residents of this middle- to upper-middle-class suburb proceeded cautiously before challenging their biggest employer. A private poll commissioned by Hoover last summer indicated that a large number of people were undecided.
Some, like Ruth Basner, a local historian, proclaimed their trust at public meetings. "Trust has made North Canton what it is," she said. "I trust the Hoover Company."
More debated it privately. "Trust, yes, it's a matter of trust," said Gary Wechter, a 15-year member of the City Council who didn't say much publicly. "I was torn."
Families were torn. Judy Douglass put up a sign in her front yard supporting the opponents, Residents Against the Maytag Mall, or RAMM. When her husband mowed the grass, he yanked it down. "My husband said, 'You don't know who else could buy up that land and do anything they want with it. At least we know Hoover.' "
Mrs. Douglass wasn't so sure.
Mr. Girdlestone, Hoover's president, has mailed four letters to every North Canton home over the last six months. Last month's letter urged residents not to sign a petition to put the rezoning on the November ballot.
Stark County's major corporations -- the Timken Company, Hoover, Republic Engineered Steels and Diebold -- have played an important role in keeping the Republican Party strong here. When Charles Brown, the party's county chairman, is asked why the Canton area is not as heavily Democratic as other Ohio cities like Akron or Cleveland, he gives a one-word answer: "Timken."
It is a complex answer. It is not just that the Timken Company, the county's biggest employer, has a chairman, W. R. (Tim) Timken Jr., who is active in Republican politics. It is that Timken, the steel and roller bearing manufacturer, has been owned by the same family for a century and has stuck by the community through the Depression and the Rust Belt years, richly endowing schools, hospitals and cultural institutions here.
Right alongside Timken was Hoover. The most striking symbol of the kind of citizen Hoover has been is the vacuum cleaner factory itself, which sits in the center of town. In many Midwestern cities, the factory is at the end of a dead-end street, bordered by slums. Hoover's factory is a handsome brick building with lots of windows and a quaint smokestack straight out of a Norman Rockwell print.
When Hoover announced in 1994 its plan to sell the 241 acres, the first thing many thought was, "Maytag's moving Hoover out!" Hoover's vice president called city officials to assure them. "I wanted them to know there were no further symbols here," Ms. Dragomier says. "The real estate market was good, and it was a good time to divest in land we didn't need."
Hoover signed a contract with Robert DeHoff, a local developer. Mr. DeHoff assumed that Hoover's reputation would make the rezoning easy. He learned differently at the first public meeting in the summer of 1994. As Mr. DeHoff entered, he held the door for an elderly man with a cane, then introduced himself. "He says to me" -- it was a profanity. "That's when I knew," Mr. DeHoff said.
Approval is a two-step process. First the 241 acres had to be annexed by North Canton from a neighboring township. Then the land, which was zoned primarily for residential use, had to be rezoned to permit 42 acres of stores and restaurants.
To North Canton officials, annexation seemed logical, giving the city oversight of development and the benefit of increased tax revenue. On Nov. 14, 1994, the City Council voted unanimously to annex.
Yet, even the pro-Hoover comments that night reflected a jitteriness. Councilman Daryl Revoldt argued that the development would bring new jobs and help diversify the economy. People understood what went unsaid: Diversification was necessary because Hoover might not always be here.
Norman Kutz, of Walsh University, which was to receive a 50-acre donation, urged action while Hoover was still Hoover. "That leadership that's there now," he said, "may not be there 5 or 10 years from now as we know them -- or have the feelings toward this community."
The opposition, mainly homeowners who had grown accustomed to living near Hoover's empty fields and woods, fought back. The next month they collected more than 1,000 signatures opposing the Hoover plan and annexation, forcing a citywide referendum. "It wasn't hard getting people," said Kathy Magel, an opposition leader. "We did it in eight days." She told neighbors she did not blame the company; she blamed the City Council for not standing up to the company. "You can't trust a corporation," she said.
Opponents knew where the fear lay. Their speeches and yard signs always called it the Maytag plan, never the Hoover plan.
 
A Revised Plan, With Lots of Green
Hoover's president had assumed that donating the two parcels of land would be enough to show good faith, and was caught off guard. "You hear the things being said," Mr. Girdlestone recalled, "you get a little hurt. You're giving all this land away and you think, my goodness."
Residents Against the Maytag Mall got their yard signs out first last summer. "The day those 500 signs went up," Ms. Magel said, "they knew how serious we were."
Hoover officials felt they had to start a campaign, even if the company appeared heavy-handed. "We had to undertake it to defend not only the plan, but our honor," Ms. Dragomier said.
They also considered changing the land plan. While Hoover kept saying that the 52 acres of commercial and office space would not be a mall, opponents effectively countered that the two local malls, Canton Centre (55 acres) and Belden Village (65 acres) were a similar size.
So Mr. Girdlestone decided to ask Maytag for permission to reduce the commercial tract from 42 to 22 acres, which would also reduce the price Hoover would get for the land, according to Mr. DeHoff.
Mr. Girdlestone has considerable influence within Maytag, in large part because of Hoover's profitablity. Susan Gallagher, a NatWest Securities analyst, says of all the corporation's product lines -- including Jenn-Air, Magic Chef, Admiral, Dixie-Narco -- Hoover ranks second in earnings.
When Leonard A. Hadley, Maytag's chairman, visited last summer, the two met in Hoover's board room. "He realized the importance of Hoover being Hoover," said Mr. Girdlestone. "Part of Hoover's continued success is our relationship with the employees and community."
Mr. Hadley approved the change. "He said if it's the right thing to do, do it," Mr. Girdlestone recalled.
In September, as part of its $75,000 advertising campaign, Hoover mailed all residents a glossy revised land plan that was strikingly green. The next phone survey Hoover did showed "significant movement in the polls for the Hoover plan," Mr. Girdlestone said.
Suzanne Burnett, a retired Hoover High School teacher, said she had been on the fence but felt that reducing the commercial area was a signal this was still Hoover. "I studied the opposition's mailings," she said, "I didn't see anything that gave me reason not to trust Hoover."
People can be cynical, but it is striking how many good deeds done long ago gave Boss Hoover's company the benefit of the doubt now. Ms. Burnett recalled, "When the schools didn't have money to meet the payroll in the Depression, Boss Hoover supposedly brought money into the schools."
Many retired Hoover workers still live here and spoke of Hoover loyalty. The company's second chairman, H. W. Hoover Sr., had the same secretary, Esta Stoner, for 46 years.
People mulled it over and found evidence that Hoover was still Hoover. The last chairman to run Hoover when it was locally controlled, Merle R. Rawson, a widely admired figure, had handpicked Mr. Girdlestone as his successor.
Jim Repace, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers' local at Hoover, saw it as a good sign that Mr. Girdlestone has invested in the plants here, and last year signed a five-year union contract. "We have our problems," he said, "but people have it nice here, they really do."
 
A Windy Omen For Annexation
To get out the vote, the pro-Hoover forces assembled a phone bank of everyone from Little League coaches to retired teachers. "One man I called said this would be a project Boss Hoover would approve of," Ms. Burnett said.
Mr. Revoldt, the Councilman, said he could see things turn Hoover's way in October. "We had a particularly windy set of days, a real Ohio fall," he recalled, "Yard signs were blown down, and afterward I noticed a lot of the opposition signs didn't go back up."
After Judy Douglass's husband took down her RAMM sign, she did not put it back. "I felt Hoover had listened," she said. "I studied that map they sent out -- it was awfully green." She voted for Hoover. "Now I just hope we will be able to trust them."
The annexation passed with 77 percent of the vote. Last month the City Council unanimously approved the rezoning. Opponents have until today to file petitions to put it on the November ballot.
Asked how he thought it would go, Mr. Girdlestone said last week: "They'll get it on the ballot. You can always get people to sign a petition. But we'll win."
Actually, Mr. Girdlestone didn't know it, but Hoover had won. The opposition leader, Ms. Magel, confided to a reporter last week that she would not circulate petitions again. "I could get the signatures in three days," she said. But fighting the commercial area, she added, would also mean fighting the good parts of the plan, like the Little League fields, the university land and new homes.
"It was hard standing up to the establishment in a small town," she said. Hoover outspent her group by 6 to 1.
Ms. Magel says she will monitor the project. She takes pride in having pressured Hoover to alter its plan. "We're not interested in ripping the town apart again," she said. "What's the point? They'd have all those Little League people out there working the phone banks again."
 
Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S.-Backed Pact Puts Japan In New Role in Asian Finance

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 26

 BODY:
Japan has concluded a currency pact with seven neighboring countries in an effort to expand its role in guarding against turmoil in the currency markets in Asia.
Under the arrangements, announced on Thursday, Japan would effectively lend money to the seven central banks against United States Treasury securities and then reverse those deals in what are called repurchase agreements. 
 Such agreements would allow the central banks -- those of Australia, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- to stabilize their currencies against the United States dollar in times of volatility. In February, Japan reached agreements with Hong Kong and Singapore to cooperate in interventions in the currency markets. But today's pact is more extensive.
As the largest economy in the region, Japan appears to be stepping up to a leadership role as a lender of last resort in Asia. Moreover, some economists say this is a step in a broader effort to play a greater role in managing exchange rates in Asia -- and to increase the influence of the yen, which remains a distant second to the United States dollar in Asian dealings.
"It's a manifest attempt to take leadership," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd.
With the collective foreign exchange reserves of Asian countries now surpassing the total of the Group of Seven countries -- which include Japan -- the Asian central banks appeared poised to take a larger role in currency markets.
But some currency traders said the arrangement would have little impact. "What the market really wants to see is for these countries to use their own money" to stabilize exchange rates, a Japanese trader said.

HEADLINE: Dollar Off on Rates Talk

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday after a Japanese newspaper said the Bank of Japan could raise interest rates as early as May, setting off a yen rally that held up even after the report was denied by the central bank.
The approach of two holidays in Japan also helped weaken the dollar, as many traders speculated that the Bank of Japan would not intervene to help the dollar next week. 
 "This is not a market you want to be involved in over a very long Japanese weekend," said Elena Shperling, chief trader at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia. Financial markets in Japan will be closed on Monday and Friday.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 105.55 yen from 106.70 yen Thursday. The dollar fell to 1.5284 German marks from 1.5340 marks.

LENGTH: 1756 words

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Daniel A. Lehner;
Making Sure You Have Something to Read While In-Flight

BYLINE: By DEBRA M. KATZ 

 BODY:
DANIEL A. LEHNER is president of three corporations: Inflight Newspapers, a multimillion dollar business that distributes newspapers and magazines to airlines and hotels; Inflight Advertising, which manages the advertising and manufacturing of the plastic binders that hold the magazines distributed by Inflight Newspapers, and Lehner International, which oversees Mr. Lehner's various business investments, like the Great American Cafe, a Valley Stream restaurant.
Mr. Lehner built his businesses, which employ 150 people in all, out of a small candy store in Queens that his grandfather began in 1936. As late as the early 1970's, Mr. Lehner says, he himself was driving the truck that delivered the newspapers. 
 He is the president of the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce and the Valley Stream Chamber of Commerce. He serves as director or trustes at Dowling College in Oakdale, Mercy Medical Center in Rockville Centre, the Long Island Philharmonic in West Islip, the Association for a Better Long Island in Hauppauge, WLIW-TV in Garden City, and the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting in Garden City.
He grew up in Massapequa Park and now lives in Cedarhurst with his wife, Remy, and her son from a former marriage. He has a 24-year-old daughter from his first marriage. Together he and his wife do much work for charity. On Dec. 12, to mark their second wedding anniversary, they raised $1.2 million for various charities by buying all the seats for a performance of "Phantom of the Opera," the Broadway show close to their hearts because it is where they met.
Both he and his wife are avid private pilots and Mr. Lehner belongs to many aviation groups, including the Long Island Air Guard, of which he is the chairman.
Q. How did you build a multimillion dollar distribution company from a small candy store in Queens?
A. After the war, my father and grandfather couldn't get two salaries out of the store. About 1951 a secretary from T.W.A. came in looking for a special kind of Cuban cigar. They didn't carry that because it was very expensive, like $5 for a box of 50. Nowadays that'd be very cheap, you buy one cigar for $5.
So she said she wanted XYZ cigars and either my grandfather or my father said, "Hang on one second. I know exactly where to get it." So one of them jumped out of the store and ran down and got it where they knew they could find it from a wholesaler. They came back with a bill, you know like a chit you get from a luncheonette, that said on it $4.95 or $6.95 and they handed the bill to the lady to pay for the cigars. There was no thinking about their time involved or their expertise in knowing where to get the product and so on. She just paid the wholesale price.
She was so impressed with this that she said: "We need newspapers. And what happens is every time we send someone down with $5 in petty cash they buy 2 packs of cigarettes for themselves, 4 candy bars for the rest of the crew and maybe 10 newspapers." At the time newspapers were a nickel a copy, very inexpensive. So what we did, and we didn't know this at the time, we brought a control factor to the purchase of newspapers. And that's probably the best thing we do here is control where the product goes.
Q. So this major company began with a secretary from T.W.A. who said, "We need newspapers"?
A. Right. They brought over a bundle of newspapers no bigger than this pile here (Mr. Lehner points to a stack of several papers) and they would do this constantly. Then they went off and acquired other airlines and built the newspaper business to the point that by 1960 they were selling 8,000 to 10,000 newspapers.
Q. And you went into the business in 1965?
A. Right. In 1968 I developed something called the inflight system and that provided for the distribution of magazines all over the world.
Q. So at some point you began adding magazines to the newspapers?
A. Right. The real secret to the magazine distribution is the fact that we get it to where the airplanes are. Say American Airlines has 600 airplanes. The airplane mix doesn't really change, but where the airplanes are on the ground changes. For instance, if they open up the Raleigh-Durham hub, all of a sudden all the planes are in Raleigh-Durham. If they make the New York to Florida trip, the planes are in Fort Lauderdale. We keep track of all the scheduling.
Q. You bring the newspapers and magazines to the airplanes themselves?
A. We get them to the catering facilities in most cases. Catering is one of the last things to go on board an aircraft. And the same thing with the magazines. We need the planes on the ground long enough to change the magazines, too. That's part of the criteria for the calculations; in La Guardia you have a 30-minute turnaround. They come in, get another group of people and take off.
If you want to go to Chicago, you wouldn't think about where that plane goes afterward. That plane goes from here to Chicago, down to Kansas City, over to Alberquerque, up to L.A. and maybe ends up in Seattle that day before the trip ends. So what I need to know is, where is that plane overnight? If it's going to overnight in Seattle, that's where I need to have the magazines.
Q. So you go to airports all over the country?
A. All over the world. We do it for 900 airlines. If you want to say, what is the real essence of what we do here, we are a distribution company.
ip,1mQ. And everything comes out of this building?
A. Right.
Q. Why did you choose Valley Stream?
A. This was the first town out of New York City.
Q. As you got more and more successful, did you ever consider moving to one of the fancy industrial complexes being built all over the Island?
A. They're actually too far away for my purposes.
Q. Because you need the airports? How quickly do you get to Kennedy Airport from here?
A. Probably 10, 15 minutes.
Q. With so many businesses leaving Long Island and folding, you're still happy being on Long Island?
A. I could do this operation probably either on the West Coast, going out to L.A. or San Francisco, or go to Chicago and still reach most of what I want to reach. But we have made a conscious decision to be in Valley Stream. The people on Long Island are great people. You give them opportunities and they grow with them. Most of my people here are homegrown. My personnel director started as a secretary. The assistant marketing director started as a secretary.
Q. You've made a small business into a very large, successful one on Long Island. What advice do you have for someone who wants to start a small business on Long Island?
A. In retail, do not compete with any of the big boxes, the Home Depots, the Incredible Universes.
Create a niche. My business is very, very much a niche. And every time I look at a business -- or even the expansion plans we have, we have several things on the drawing board -- I reject it when they don't have a major niche. Something we can do especially, we know how to do because of our expertise.
Q. So is the time for the small mom and pop store ended forever?
A. It's not going to be the same as it was before. Main Street is changing.
Q. Well, let's look at Cedarhurst's "Main Street," for instance. Cedarhurst used to have the most bustling, thriving, fashionable "Main Street" on Central Avenue. Now there are vacant stores everywhere. What advice would you give to Cedarhurst?
A: Most downtown Main Streets need to be reconstructed. A good example is what they did at Stony Brook. There were some old stores and they reconstructed it all, starting with the post office. They brought in several catalogue stores. These are the highly specialized stores you want to try to get.
Q. Victoria's Secret?
A: That would work. If you can attract them -- and it's not easy to attract them because you have to come up with tax incentives and rent incentives -- the community enjoys going to new products, to a new big box.
Why are there so many strip malls? Because they're new stores. When I did the restaurant, the restaurant was totally rebuilt. The facade's new, the inside's new, everything was gutted. We need to do that to the downtown areas.
Q. Do our winters hurt businesses?
A. Take advantage of it. If you've got snow, sell snow shovels. It's like when we were designing our product, we said, what do we have to do to stay one step ahead? Recycle paper. That's what's going on now.
I just heard of a brand new store that opened up that only sells the late night TV products. So if you want to go buy a thingamajig that makes your stomach get smaller, or something like that, and it was advertised on TV, this guy's got it. That was a clever idea.
Q. What are the disadavantages of owning a business on Long Island?
A. High taxes and high electric bills.
Q. You're the president of the Valley Stream Chamber of Commerce and the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce. Tell me what a successful chamber of commerce does for businesses in its town.
A. No. 1 is to provide the information that's necessary to the smaller business people who cannot get out and find out what's going on. You have to bring it to them. You can't expect them to show up at every meeting and every seminar. If that means somebody is out pounding the pavement, that's what you have to do.
Q. What do you do as the president of the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce?
A. We get together with about 25 Chamber of Commerce presidents once a month and we exchange ideas. For instance, in Valley Stream, we put up banners at Christmastime and the streets are lit. We've done this by taking it in small pieces and allowing each store owner to do a piece of the decorations instead of one person trying to decorate with thousands of dollars worth of stuff. They rent the banners for $50 a year and the lights on each tree costs $100 a year. It's like adopting that tree.
So we've shared this information now with Great Neck who might have tree-lined streets so they can go out and do it. We need an awful lot more of the interaction of information.
Q. You have a nice balance in your life: You have a multimillion dollar worldwide business yet you're very involved in the details of small-town life, like putting Christmas lights on Main Street.
A. I think it's a throwback to when my grandfather had this ice-cream store, which wasn't any bigger than the local flea market vendor. Our community is only what we make it. Too many people say, "Oh, somebody else'll do it," but that somebody else might not be around.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel Lehner, head of Inflight Newpapers, which distributes newpapers to airports, in his office in Valley Stream. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Putting the Focus on the Family Business

BYLINE: By LEONARD FELSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Peter M. Deane, the founder of a kitchen design firm in Stamford, died five years ago at the age of 50, his wife, Ingrid Deane, hired an outsider to run the company until their children, then in their early 20's, could develop experience and grow into the family business.
"It was a wise thing to do. In a small business you can disintegrate quickly if you're leaderless," said Robert Ker Jr., the man hired as chief executive officer of Kitchens by Deane, and a mentor to Carrie, 29, and Peter, 26, since. 
 Going outside -- wise as it may have been -- also may be the exception to the rule when in managing family businesses. That is an issue that the year-old Family Business Program at the University of Connecticut is exploring these days.
"Our mission is simple: to foster growth and development of family businesses," the director of the program, Richard N. Dino, said.
Family businesses face the same business problems as all businesses, but add to that the problems of family, and, Dr. Dino said, "that creates a pool of challenges that are different than what you might have if you're part of a business that is not family-owned and operated."
For UConn, the new venture underscores the changing economic times as big business, long the emphasis at the university's business school, downsizes.
The dean of UConn's School of Business Administration, Thomas G. Gutteridge, said "We're really reaching out to unique niches -- entrepeneurial companies, family businesses, nonprofit organizations, in both directions, trying to provide services and get them involved in what we're doing."
In addition to helping family businesses with practical advice, the new program also is engaged in academic research on the subject. Mr. Dino, an economist, recently co-authored a study with William S. Schulze, also from UConn's business school, on the relationship between organizational governance, or how a business is run, and chances for survival.
The program is also part of a growing movement among business schools to focus on family businesses, which account for 80 percent to 96 percent of the 15 million businesses in the United States, according to Mr. Dino. In Connecticut, with more than 76,000 businesses operating, an estimated 69,000 have been defined as family businesses.
"Historically, family businesses have always been thought of as Mom and Pop operations, and while a huge chunk are three-, four-, five-person operations, there's a significant mid-market size of companies in the $5 million to $100 million range," Mr. Dino said.
Since Mr. Dino was hired to run the Family Business Program, he has been traveling around the state trying to recruit owners and partners in family business to join the program, which conducts seminars, workshops and various other networking events.
Among issues likely to be dealt with are resolving conflict, estate planning, forming a board of advisors, what it's like to be a successor, planning for the worst and preparing a transition.
To date, the program has 20 family business members, who pay a $2,500 annual fee -- which Mr. Dino reminds prospective members is an amount they could spend in one or two days with their lawyer.
"I tell them to look at that money as an investment in their company's future," he said. "You make an investment in your plant and equipment and you make investments in human resources. I tell them, 'This is an investment in your family business capital.' "
At the program's first event, which featured UConn women's basketball coach Geno Auriemma after the team won the national title, only 30 people showed up. But the second event drew 60 and the third, 95.
Mr. Ker, of Kitchens by Deane, said he is one of the program's most enthusiastic supporters. "I jumped aboard fast because I felt it would be very helpful to the children," he said. "It's been helpful to them and to me, and I've been around businesses a lot of years." What Mr. Ker finds most helpful is the program's practical emphasis. "It isn't theoretical," he said, "it focuses on very basic issues like how do you keep a family business running past the first generation."
Another convert to the program is Michael D. Hobbs, president and second-generation owner of Hobbs Inc., a New Canaan residential general contracting business. So far the Hobbses have avoided many of the sensitive issues that can entangle family businesses, in large part because his father retained a team of advisors (a lawyer, accountant, an estate planner and insurance representative) to help set up a detailed succession plan. Also, Mr. Hobbs, one of two children, was the only one interested in the business, and among his three children, all grown now, only one, Scott, has followed in his father's footsteps.
Mr. Hobbs, who was involved in early focus groups when the family business program was being launched and now serves on its advisory board, said it wasn't until he began listening to other family business stories that he realized how sheltered he had been.
"Inside of any given family, the perception of who should be given what kind of authority can be extraordinarily difficult," he said. "If you have good communication, you're 50 percent of the way along, but if a father says to his child, who may now be 50 and is treated the same when he was when he was 15, 'I'll tell you what to do,' it can be catastrophic, and things don't get less complex, they get more complex as time goes on."
Added Mr. Hobbs: "If we're going to be a nation of small businesses, and I don't see any reason why that isn't likely, given technology, the level of sophistication among family business owners simply has got to increase or we're going to have one- generation businesses" that will either fail or be sold to outsiders in the next generation.
While professional advisors certainly can help family businesses, Mr. Dino said his program can help when sensitive issues go beyond the realm of lawyers' or accountants' expertise. "If I have to fire my son or daughter because they're doing a lousy job," he explained, "or as a son if I have to tell Dad, 'You're in the way, you have to step aside,' who do I go for to ask for help?"
Such issues, Mr. Dino said, will need to be addressed increasingly as the bulk of family businesses, which were started after World War II, begin to be passed to the next generation as the owners and founders reach retirement age.
"There's trillions of dollars of assets that are going to be transferred to the next generation," Mr. Dino said, "but the success rate of ownership transfer from the first to second generation is only 30 percent." Most of those businesses get sold to nonfamily owners, often because of poor estate planning.
The changing-of-the-guard phenomenon has been a major push behind family business programs like UConn's. An estimated 55 programs have been established across the nation in the last five years, Mr. Dino said.
UConn's received money from various sources, including grants, seed money from Henry W. Nozko Sr., founder and head of the Acmat Corporation of New Britain, and $15,000 each from program sponsors including Acmat, Arthur Andersen & Company, Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, People's Bank, Reid & Riege and U.S. Trust Company.
Mr. Dino, a former economic and marketing forecaster for Kodak and Xerox, has owned his own business -- a restaurant in Stamford -- and sat on the board of directors of family businesses, said what he has found most amazing is once program members sit down to talk, it doesn't matter that one heads a $5 million company or a $100 million company.
"It's as if," he said, "they speak the same language."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scott Hobbs, left, and his father, Michael, center, work with Richard N. Dino, head of UConn's Family Business Program. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
 BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE MUSEUM, by Kate Atkinson. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) This impressive first novel, a multigenerational tale of a spectacularly dysfunctional Yorkshire family, transmutes the native gloom to guilty merriment.
 
 BLAKE, by Peter Ackroyd. (Knopf, $35.) The life of England's incorruptible, irrepressible visionary poet, artist and cosmic revolutionary, with fearless explications of Blake's works.
 
 CROSS CHANNEL, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $21.) Short stories, crowded with understated or invisible meanings; the characters, wry, witty and often helpless, are English or Irish, living in France; the geographical Channel is a metaphor for separations of a far more intimate kind.
 
 THE DEBT TO PLEASURE, by John Lanchester. (Holt, $20.) A delicious first novel by a British editor and food critic; his hero and narrator, the self-confident, loquacious Tarquin Winot, travels through France, measuring out his life by menus.
 
 JOURNEY TO THE LAND OF THE FLIES: And Other Travels, by Aldo Buzzi. (Random House, $23.) Four delightful essays in stream-of-consciousness tourism; every good thing reminds the author, a Milanese polymath, of some other good thing elsewhere in time or space.
 
 THE MANIKIN, by Joanna Scott. (Holt, $22.50.) A ripe Gothic novel, set in a gloomy mansion stuffed full of brooding characters and ominous appurtenances; a success because the author, not the genre, is always in perfect control.
 
 SEEING CALVIN COOLIDGE IN A DREAM, by John Derbyshire. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Strange, bouncy and amiable, this first novel is narrated by a Chinese immigrant banker who lives on Long Island and turns to Coolidge for enlightenment.
 
 THE SIZE OF THOUGHTS: Essays and Other Lumber, by Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $25.) Excursions in nomenclature, syntax, information retrieval and fractal thinking, performed by a mind on a tightrope.
 
 THE SONG OF THE DODO: Island Biogeography in an Age of Extinctions, by David Quammen. (Scribner, $32.50.) Fundamental evolutionary principles applied to the bitty, fragmented man-made environment: geographical isolation makes for strange creatures and rapid extinction.
 
 THE TEMPLE BOMBING, by Melissa Fay Greene. (Addison-Wesley, $25.) A voyage through a neglected swamp of the civil rights movement: the bombing of Atlanta's oldest and richest synagogue by a handful of yahoos in 1958.
 
 THE VERACRUZ BLUES, by Mark Winegardner. (Viking, $22.95.) A remarkable first novel, set in Mexico and concerned with two major mythologies: American baseball (seen from outside) and the Great American Novel.
