SECTION: Section 7; Page 39; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Jane Jacobs: Still a Pioneer

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger is the chief cultural correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:
There is something strangely pleasing about the fact that Jane Jacobs, who has spent her life writing books about cities and the virtues of urban disorder, has now, at 80, written one about a single woman who lived a life of extreme order in that most rural of places, Alaska. This book -- "A Schoolteacher in Old Alaska" -- is much more important than its self-consciously quaint title lets on. It is nothing like any of Jane Jacobs's other books, and in fact was written only partly by her; the body of it is the memoir of her great-aunt, Hannah Breece, who spent 14 years at the beginning of this century teaching children of Alaska natives. Breece died in 1940, leaving her great-niece a manuscript she hoped would be put into publishable form.
The pleasure in this book comes not from any sense that Ms. Jacobs has reversed course; quite the contrary. She has not elevated Fort Yukon over Greenwich Village, and neither has she put aside her profound belief in the value of serendipity. What she has done is make the point that a sense of independence and of control over one's life is essential to satisfaction and productivity. This is hardly inconsistent with what Jane Jacobs has been telling us for more than 30 years; it is just that until now she has been fairly constant in wanting us to believe that the wide range of choice the city offers makes it a more likely source of fulfillment and independence than the country. The truth is that these are virtues that transcend geography, and can occur in all kinds of places and all kinds of situations; perhaps the most important aspect of her new book is that it contains Jane Jacobs's implicit recognition that this is so. 
 Jane Jacobs let her great-aunt's manuscript languish while she pursued her own career, which included the writing of five books -- among them "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," her powerful testament against modernist urban renewal and in favor of the casual, pedestrian and street-oriented life of traditional densely built cities. One of those rare books that have changed the world, it was to urban planning what Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" was to the environmental movement, and it is arguably the most important book written about cities in the 20th century. Now, more than half a century after her great-aunt's death, Jane Jacobs has finally taken up the challenge and brought her memoir to publication. She began in 1994 by retracing her great-aunt's passage through Alaska, and upon her return to her home in Toronto proceeded to edit and annotate the old manuscript; then she added introductory and closing essays. She presents her great-aunt's story as something of an early work of feminism and cross-cultural inquiry. It all adds up to something that is not nearly as parenthetical to Jane Jacobs's own career as one might at first think.
For if there is any shortcoming to much of Jane Jacobs's thinking -- certainly to her thinking as expressed in "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" -- it is that she has always tended to fall prey to the fallacy of physical determinism, nearly as much as the modernists and urban renewal czars she has so roundly, and deservedly, criticized. They believed that high-rise towers in open space would solve urban and social ills; Jane Jacobs believes that small-scale buildings and lively streetscapes will perform that same miracle. Given the choice, I'll take her view any day, but that's not the point. Her vision is closer to reality, but the physical form of cities doesn't always determine what will happen in them, and sometimes big, ugly high-rise buildings work just fine.
To those whose admiration for Jane Jacobs borders on passion -- and I certainly put myself in that group -- there has always been a certain frustration to the limits of her thinking. She doesn't like to admit that the automobile-oriented suburb works for some people, problematic as we urbanists may find it. She isn't comfortable admitting that Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan, a complex of banal red-brick towers built by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company after World War II, is successful as a place to live and as a community despite what we might call the political incorrectness of its dreary physical form. Nor does she seem terribly eager to acknowledge that the facile architecture of Lincoln Center, however disconnected it may be from the streetscape, has had a profound, and generally positive, impact on the surrounding city, encouraging the very liveliness and mix of uses that Jane Jacobs has claimed such places suppress. The problem is that the physical form of places like Stuyvesant Town and Lincoln Center is too much at odds with her orthodoxy. And an orthodoxy it is, however much it may be correct most of the time.
What has all of this to do with Hannah Breece, a prohibitionist and devout Christian whose life was firmly grounded in 19th-century pieties? Only that Jane Jacobs's long years of pondering her great-aunt's life seem to have brought her to a kind of implicit concession that factors other than the physical form of a community can affect the well-being -- and, more important, the sense of self-determination -- of its people. This may be an odd reason to cheer this new book, but so be it. I have always wanted Jane Jacobs, iconoclastic, wide-ranging thinker that she is, to see the world in still broader terms, and with this book she truly has. I suspect that Hannah Breece would not have been very comfortable in the urban places that Jane Jacobs -- and I -- like best, and Ms. Jacobs's willingness to see her as hero in spite of this both deepens and softens our view of Ms. Jacobs herself.
For Jane Jacobs, in the end, has always been a defender of individuality, and Hannah Breece was as individual as they come, full of courage and self-assurance when such traits were rarely visible, let alone admired, in women. Maybe it isn't really Jane Jacobs's fault that her passion for individuality has been caricatured over the years into a kind of left-wing, Greenwich Village liberal conformity; if you read her words carefully it is clear that she believes in more than that, even though it is that world that has made her a prophet and has molded itself around her views.
Hannah Breece was an activist. She did not man the barricades of protest, but she took charge of her life and ran it with determination and fortitude. How else could you describe a woman who spent her 40's and 50's (she was 45 when she began her 14-year sojourn) climbing mountains, fording streams and pursuing the mission of "civilizing" native children in the wilderness? Jane Jacobs, determined multiculturalist that she is, admits to problems with her great-aunt's Eurocentric attitudes, but eventually comes to terms with the reality that, much as Thomas Jefferson tolerated slavery, even remarkable people sometimes fail to transcend the limits of their times. And to give Hannah Breece her due, at one point she states that her goal is not "whitizing" her students but "civilizing" them, a distinction more subtle than most of her contemporaries would have made.
How similar, in the end, are Hannah Breece and Jane Jacobs! Both were pioneers: Breece in the wilderness, Jane Jacobs in an urban frontier that she could see in a way that others had not. Both looked at the world as full of surprise and wonder, but did so without innocence; they knew that it required constant negotiation, and the satisfaction they found in it did not come from believing that life could go on autopilot. Both put much stock in the joy that comes from ordinary things, and believed that there can be profundity in the minutiae of daily life, and richness in the mixing of different kinds of people into a complex social fabric.
Hannah Breece dealing with recalcitrant tribal chiefs resistant to a school in their community, Jane Jacobs taking on Robert Moses to fight the Lower Manhattan Expressway and save SoHo and Greenwich Village. Here in her great-aunt's life, then, we see Jane Jacobs's true toughness and, even more, her roots, the beginnings of all she has stood for and all she has helped us value. One is tempted to say that Jane Jacobs probably has known all the while how close her own life has been to that of her great-aunt, and that she is just letting us in now on the things that have inspired her all along.

HEADLINE: As Time Goes By

BYLINE: By Joseph Adelson; Joseph Adelson is a professor of psychology at the University of Michigan.

 BODY:

Aging and Old Age
By Richard A. Posner.
375 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.
Richard A. Posner is one of the most interesting figures in American social thought. His new work, "Aging and Old Age," follows a recent book on sex, which in turn succeeded treatises on literature and the judiciary. What these writings have in common is a truly remarkable degree of erudition and, beyond that, the single-minded pursuit of an idea -- the application of economic theory to human behavior. He also draws on ideas from evolutionary biology, cognitive psychology and classical philosophy, above all Aristotle. One might imagine that someone with so extraordinary a range of knowledge would reside in an empyrean of pure thought. But Mr. Posner has a worldly vocation as well, and a very demanding one. He is the Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago. 
 The legal and political problems posed by the elderly were in fact the stimulus for much of this book. There are extended discussions here of topics like the Social Security system, age discrimination, mandatory retirement, pensions and pension law, euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide, the punishment of elderly offenders and much else. Yet those are not the only issues Mr. Posner treats, nor the most interesting. He also discusses such matters as the economic power of the aged and whether it is too great or too small; the relations between age and creativity in various domains of art and scholarship; which careers peak early and which peak late, and why; the differing modes of intelligence and their correlation with age; the status of the old in preliterate societies; why the elderly have a high rate of voting yet a low rate of jury service; why they are less likely to be victims of crime; and why they are (or are thought to be) loquacious, stingy and self-absorbed.
A few of these topics are covered in depth, but on the whole Mr. Posner's aim -- clear enough though unspoken -- is to demonstrate the power of the "human capital" approach put forward by Gary S. Becker and other economists. That position is spelled out in the first four chapters and, be warned, they will not be easy going unless you are familiar with both the language and the underlying ideas of economic analysis. Here is a sample sentence: "If because of the age-related increase in the cost of investing in human capital or the age-related decrease in the expected return, or both, the rate of investment in new human capital eventually declines with age below the rate of depreciation of the worker's existing human capital, there will be net depreciation."
That kind of language prevails even when Mr. Posner deals with simpler matters, like the increase of loneliness in old age: "The loss of friends will be increasing rapidly at the same time that the net utility from forming new friendships is declining." Mr. Posner can be an engaging writer when he lets himself be, as in the occasional anecdote about his family history, or in his paragraphs on Yeats's poetry. But such passages do not last long, and we are soon back to discount rates, utility-disutility and disinvestment.
Still, the approach through economics does discourage excessive sentiment. Since death and disease are so frightening to so many of us, we tend not to think too critically about policy in these areas, instead following the most familiar paths or heeding only the most urgent voices. The results are often perverse. One example is the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which Mr. Posner tells us was sold by emotional rhetoric as a means of protecting elderly workers. He argues that it is "at once inefficent, regressive and harmful to the elderly." In a long, dense concluding chapter Mr. Posner shows that the act discourages hiring the elderly because employers fear the greater costs of training them and the legal complications of firing them. It is in the study of such distortions, and their dynamics, that the careful, nearly obsessive, approach of this book shows to special advantage.
There is also a penetrating analysis of sex differences in medical research expenditures on the elderly. Diseases that affect women -- cervical and breast cancer -- currently receive much more research money per death than those affecting men primarily or exclusively -- like heart disease, lung cancer and prostate cancer. Should we shift the balance? Who gains and who loses, and how? Mr. Posner's subtle discussion of this issue is a model of thoroughness and balance.
On the other hand, "rational choice" does not fare so well when it must deal with the irrational or with instinctual drives, and with the displacements and defenses they generate. We see this most clearly in the discussion of suicide. Mr. Posner proposes a utility theory of suicide, wherein "the utility of living, net of disutility due to suffering, bereavement and other losses, declines with age." Hence, "aging reduces the option value of living on."
With his usual consummate honesty Mr. Posner sets forth the many problems in that formulation, but he will not allow himself to consider that depression may play a significant role in suicide, since he believes depression "is difficult to distinguish operationally from rational, clear-eyed evaluation of declining quality and prospects of life." That is simply not so; the irrational component in suicidal depression is evident rather quickly in most cases. (The first suicidal patient I ever saw made a suicide attempt because the microphone did not work when he was introducing a guest speaker in an auditorium, and he assumed that the audience was -- silently -- jeering at him.) There are other problems with this discussion, some of which Mr. Posner points to, confessing puzzlement. Why is the suicide rate so much higher for men than for women? Why does the rate rise only slightly as women age, yet rise steeply for men? And why is the suicide rate for blacks at all ages so much lower than for whites?
These questions and many others like them either go unasked or receive shallow answers. For all his brilliance and erudition elsewhere, Mr. Posner here has imposed unnecessary limits on himself and on his grasp of human behavior.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1528 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/One Broadway;
Tenants That Felt They Were in Not-So-Good Hands

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
NEW YORK has long been a place where landlords and tenants seem to haggle over everything and where a lease's fine print can run to dozens of pages. But even in New York, the legacy of ill will left by lease -- and eventually, sale -- negotiations between tenants of One Broadway, that landmarked building opposite Bowling Green Park, and Allstate Insurance, its former owner, seems extreme.
"Allstate really negotiated in bad faith all along," charged Robert T. Tobin, managing partner of the intellectual-property law firm Kenyon & Kenyon, the building's main tenant and now its co-owner. 
 "Allstate has never negotiated in bad faith with anyone," countered Peter Kierig, an Allstate assistant general counsel. "The tenants were difficult on every lease term."
At the root of the mutual anger lies the siren call that so many downtown landlords, Allstate included, are hearing of late: That of residential converters, lured to downtown office buildings by city tax breaks for anyone who turns them into apartments, and offering prices well above those that office buildings usually command.
"We're seeing a healthy competition between residential and commercial use, and it is a pleasant surprise," said Carl Weisbrod, head of the Alliance for Downtown Manhattan, who expects more than 1,000 apartments to come on stream this year.
But that same competition poses a dilemma for many would-be sellers of downtown buildings. If they want to sell them as office buildings, they will get a much better price if the buildings are leased up. But for residential use, the emptier the better, since few converters want to deal with buying out -- or waiting out -- existing office tenants.
A landlord who wants to keep both options open must almost by force put lease negotiations in limbo, while tenants wrestle with the specter of corporate homelessness.
That was the bind that everyone at One Broadway got caught in.
Back in 1992, when Allstate took the building back from financially strapped owners, the best strategy seemed clear: Get the 100-year-old building, which badly needed a structural overhaul, into physical shape, get its tenants to renew, and sell it.
"Our plan was to sell this as a commercial structure," Mr. Kierig said. "And since we knew a building was more attractive if its leases were already renewed, we instituted the negotiations with the tenants."
Kenyon & Kenyon and the investment counseling firm Brundage, Story & Rose, which together make up about 70 percent of the 12-story building's tenancy, were clearly the important players. Both firms' leases were expiring in a few years, and both wanted to stay.
"We just love the building, we use it on our Christmas cards, we stamp it on our Christmas chocolate bars," Mr. Tobin said.
But both tenants wanted lease provisos keyed to protect them if the building did change hands. For example, they insisted on so-called self-help clauses, which allow a tenant to handle necessary repairs and deduct the costs from the rent bill.
The tenants felt that such extra protection was only fair in light of unknown ownership. Allstate thought it was onerous, and that a new owner might balk at such clauses.
"Institutional landlords with solid credit rarely agree to such clauses, particularly if they want to sell the building," said Howard Nottingham, a senior vice president of LaSalle Partners, which Allstate hired to manage and lease One Broadway.
The negotiations got cantankerous more than once. And they dragged on and on.
Each side blames the other for the stalls. James G. Pepper, a Brundage, Story partner, and Mr. Tobin of Kenyon insist that Allstate sat on the leases; Mr. Nottingham says that often, Allstate would redraft a lease and not hear from the tenants for months. Another person familiar with the negotiations, who spoke on condition of anonymity, says that both tenants tried to take unfair advantage of Allstate's desire to get leases signed in advance of any sale.
"They tried to beat Allstate up on everything, from the economics down to the most inconsequential clause," he said. "Allstate hung in longer than I thought it would."
Ironically, it was a clause in one of the original leases that wound up breaking the impasse: Kenyon had the legal right to match any outside offer to buy the building.
K ENYON would not have been the first downtown tenant to exercise such an option. In 1994, for example, McGraw-Hill invoked a similar clause and bought 65 Broadway, the home of the municipal bond brokerage firm J. J. Kenney, a McGraw-Hill subsidiary. According to Darcy A. Stacom, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director, McGraw-Hill paid about $13.5 million for a building that is worth closer to $16 million today.
But McGraw-Hill knew what outsiders were offering to pay. Allstate and Kenyon got caught in a Catch-22 situation: Allstate, which was not yet thinking about residential conversion, did not want to market the building until the leases were signed; Kenyon did not want to make an offer until it knew how the market valued the building.
The lease negotiations continued. And despite the slow pace, by last fall all parties figured they were in the home stretch.
"By November we had negotiated all the points," said Mr. Tobin, who says he gave in on clauses that would help Allstate sell the building. For example, he says he agreed to show Kenyon's books to potential buyers concerned with the main tenant's credit.
But then Woody Heller, a Jones Lang Wootton broker whom Allstate had retained to help sell the building, threw a wrench into the procedures.
"I suggested that, because of tremendous enthusiasm for residential development, it might make more sense to market the building empty," Mr. Heller said.
One Broadway is a perfect candidate for conversion to apartments. It has harbor and park views, and its floors are small enough so that the apartments would not have too many interior, windowless spaces. It was once the headquarters of United States Lines, and is still saturated with nautical niceties. There's a wave motif in the first-floor frieze and an entranceway that still has First Class Passengers carved above. A huge Citibank branch at ground level, once a ticket-booking hall, sports murals on maritime history.
So Allstate's lawyers, on the brink of signing the leases, put their pens back down. They asked Mr. Pepper to give them another 90 days while they talked to residential converters. Allstate thought it was a reasonable request; Mr. Pepper was furious, and decided to move, no matter what Allstate decided to do with the building.
"I said I don't care what happens, I will not deal with Allstate ever again," he said. "They have the intellectual capacity and responsiveness of a tar baby."
Mr. Tobin was furious, too. He says he had to learn of Allstate's new plans from Mr. Pepper. "We really felt we'd been had," he said. In January, Kenyon sued Allstate to force it to sign the new lease.
Kenyon hired Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson to handle the suit. Soon after, John L. Mechanic, a Fried, Frank real estate partner, introduced Mr. Tobin to Steven C. Witkoff, a principal at the real estate firm Stellar Management. The two men hatched a plan: Kenyon would exercise its option to buy the building and put up some equity; Stellar would put up most of the equity, and would manage the building.
"People have disproportionately written off the downtown office market," Mr. Witkoff said. "They forget you get substantial tax benefits and energy rate cuts for leasing office properties, too."
The East New York Savings Bank quickly agreed to finance the purchase. "You had a major tenant marrying up with guys who had the management skills and financial wherewithal, and that pretty much mitigated the risks," said Sam Giarrusso, the bank's administrative vice president. And, should the bank ever have to take the building back, "there are plenty of residential converters who would pay good money for it," Mr. Giarrusso said.
I N March Kenyon and Stellar bought One Broadway for $9 million. They immediately renewed Brundage, Story, at the terms Mr. Pepper had negotiated with Allstate. The building's other major tenant, the law firm Fox & Horan, has several years left on its lease. Only the second floor is empty, and Kenyon may take that space itself.
Many lawyers and sales brokers say they expect more such stories to surface soon. "The craze right now is certainly for residential conversion, but there are still plenty of people looking for buildings to keep as offices," Ms. Stacom said.
"It's a sensible partnership, a tenant that wants some equity and control over its space, and an investor that knows how to operate a building," said Mr. Mechanic, who says he has been asked by another law firm to explore whether it should go that route.
Over at One Broadway, scar tissue has formed on the wounds from the difficult negotiations. Kenyon has dropped its suit against Allstate, and all of the tenants are on long-term leases.
"We're happy, and I assume Kenyon's happy," Mr. Pepper said. "I don't give a damn whether Allstate is happy or not."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1105 words

HEADLINE: The View From: Bridgeport;
Downtown Bridgeport, Minus Casino, Builds Hopes on the Arts

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
LIKE a long-forgotten Rembrandt discovered in the attic that restores a family's fortunes, a remarkable, but little-seen, art collection is holding out hope for Bridgeport's downtown.
The collection is owned by Housatonic Community-Technical College, which is relocating to the site of a former downtown shopping mall. Known as the Housatonic Museum of Art, its extensive holdings include paintings and sculpture by Picasso, Matisse, Miro, Mary Cassatt -- even Andy Warhol. 
 "It is the largest and best collection of any two-year college in America," boasted Burt Chernow, its director emeritus, who might be said to know because it was he who assembled it, through donations from wealthy patrons and many of the artists themselves over the last 29 years.
Some pieces are displayed in offices and on hallway walls in the college, presently occupying a former sewing machine factory on Bridgeport's East Side. But the majority of its more than 4,200 works are in storage for lack of a place to show them.
Under current plans, that would be solved by converting McLevy Hall, a stately brownstone where Abraham Lincoln made a campaign speech in 1860, into a museum with ample display space. There, the Housatonic collection would become the center of the city's promotion of arts, entertainment and tourism as one of Bridgeport's main development goals for the 21st century.
Constructed in 1853, McLevy Hall originally was the county courthouse and Bridgeport's city hall. It was remodeled solely as city hall in 1903, reverted to use as a courthouse in 1960, and currently holds municipal offices and the Bureau of Vital Statistics.
If all goes well, the museum will be joined by the Polka Dot Playhouse, a theater company marooned on Pleasure Beach Island by a brokendown bridge, and many new shops and attractions at the nearby harbor waterfront.
Also within a one-block walk is the future home of the college as well as the Barnum Museum. The Downtown Cabaret Theater is just a few blocks away, as are the Beardsley Zoo and the Discovery Museum, adding to what planners hope is the basis for a busy tourism industry.
The idea of expanding arts and entertainment actually originated in 1993, but was drowned out by the quest for a casino and Donald Trump's proposals for an amusement park and a motor racetrack, among other noisy ballyhoo.
It represents a change in direction for the city's economic development plans for the downtown business district. That had been for a combination of retail and housing, but was abandoned when the 1990 recession hit. "That idea was to make the downtown a neighborhood," said Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's economic development director. The new plan is designed to give people a reason to visit and make the downtown business people feel good about the place.
City officials are enthusiastic about their prospects for tying a number of relatively small projects together, each multiplying the tourism effect. They expressed dismay at the prevailing attitude that the city's future was dimmed when the casino proposal was defeated.
"People were saying there's nothing else happening in Bridgeport," Mr. Freimuth said. "The casino was a double-edged sword for us."
Mr. Freimuth said a casino would have helped by attracting development funding. Now the plan rests on the availability of state grants: $3.9 million for the McLevy Hall art museum and $2.7 million for the Polka Dot Playhouse. According to Drew Hingson, chairman of the Downtown Special Services District, "Everything works together." People who go to a show are likely to eat at a restaurant next door and take in the exhibit at the museum across the street.
Housing the Housatonic Art Museum collection in McLevy Hall, he said, would move the arts and entertainment potential of Bridgeport's downtown very close to "critical mass," and perhaps beyond it.
It all makes more than enough sense to Mr. Chernow, whose knack for accumulating masterpieces is diminished by the lack of a place to hang them. "We hope to get McLevy Hall because we have more artworks than we have walls," he said.
He began the Housatonic collection in 1967 soon after he joined the art faculty at the school. A resident of Westport, he and his wife, Anne, a painter of note, were acquainted with many artists and wealthy art patrons who responded to his requests with priceless gifts from their private collections. Within a year, the collection had enough pieces for two exhibits at the Discovery Museum (then named the Museum of Art, Science and Industry).
The collection spans a wide range of art, from ancient Greek and Egyptian pottery, Chinese marble carvings and African masks to Ansel Adams photographs and works by many important contemporary artists.
The new home for Housatonic Community-Technical College will include gallery space and a sculpture garden, but thousands of works would still have to be packed away. For those, McLevy Hall is needed.
Mr. Chernow also hopes for a permanent, full-time staff for the Housatonic Museum of Art, which now has only three part-time people. "There are museums that have a lot of staff and no art," he said. "We have a lot of art and almost no staff. Usually, a museum of this size would have 10 full-time staff members."
The city proposes to move the Polka Dot Playhouse into the old Bridgeport Trust Company building across the street from the McLevy Hall green. The green itself is now being refurbished with the help of private donations.
That block of State Street also is the home of Silver Lining, a nonprofit art gallery, and the Regional Center for the Arts, a magnet high school program that provides classes in dance, theater and jazz for 60 high school students from Bridgeport and five neighboring suburban towns. All three stand to gain from an influx of neighbors. The Playhouse and the Regional Center are already working together on theater programs for students, and Silver Lining is planning an exhibition of art by Bridgeport high school students.
Their biggest problem now is that no one stays in downtown Bridgeport after work, or thinks of visiting there during leisure hours.
"It makes a wonderful, viable cultural center for that area downtown for people who work there and want to come back there after work," Rose Lodice, president of the Polka Dot Playhouse, noted.
Larry Halpern, managing director of Silver Lining, said people who call his gallery are interested in two things: "Where to park and what else is there to do." He said a museum across the street and the Polka Dot Playhouse next door would answer the second question.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Addicted to the Hard Life

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; Benedict Nightingale is chief theater critic of The Times of London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
ANYONE WHO HATES Sir Peter Hall should invite him to spend two weeks beside some idyllic swimming pool, doing nothing but sunbathe and sip champagne. Such a regimen, he says with a shudder, would make him miserable.
Conversely, anyone who wishes the 65-year-old director well should insure that he follows a program that would shatter a man half his age. What about bringing a Feydeau farce to the West End, staging Beethoven's "Fidelio" in Rome, organizing a major radio revival of Shaw's "Man and Superman," putting the finishing touches on a two-part television drama about West Indians in Britain, and transferring his production of Oscar Wilde's "Ideal Husband" to New York -- and all in the space of a few weeks? 
 That has been the first third of 1996 as Sir Peter wanted it, planned it and has come very near to achieving. His production of "Fidelio," scheduled to open on April 16, was suddenly aborted after the opera house technicians in Rome refused to handle its British-built set. But that setback only meant that Sir Peter scheduled extra rehearsals of Feydeau's "Mind Millie for Me," which was on an out-of-town tour before starting previews at the Haymarket Theater four days ago. There, it replaced "An Ideal Husband," which opens on Broadway at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Wednesday.
A doctor once told Sir Peter that his body manufactured so much adrenalin that he had become addicted to it. But that's only half the reason he loathes the idea of taking life easy: "I don't work because someone or something is making me, or because of economic compulsion, but because I love it. I need to rehearse every day. No one says to a painter, why don't you stop painting? There might come a time when I want to slow down, but it hasn't happened in the 43 years I've been directing."
Some people assumed Sir Peter would lessen his workload when he gave up the most taxing job in the British theater, director of the Royal National Theater, back in 1988. Instead, he formed the Peter Hall Company, a commercial organization that started life in high style by dispatching Vanessa Redgrave in Tennessee Williams's "Orpheus Descending" and Dustin Hoffman in Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice" from London to New York.
Though "An Ideal Husband" is the first of his productions since then to have made the crossing, plenty of others have kept his name before the British public. At one point, in 1993, five plays directed by him -- four for the Peter Hall Company, one for the Royal Shakespeare Company -- were running simultaneously in London.
Is there a danger, then, of substituting quantity for quality? "That's for other people to answer," he said. "I do think, though, that people accuse me of spreading myself too thin because they get furious at my appetite and energy. It's somehow un-British, isn't it, to try too hard. I don't say I'm Picasso, because I'm not. But nobody said to Picasso, You're painting too much and you're 80, so why don't you stop? And if an actor keeps on acting, nobody accuses him of spreading himself too thin."
Certainly, Sir Peter has the respect of his senior fellow professionals. Richard Eyre, who succeeded him as director of the National Theater, left "An Ideal Husband" thinking it a better play than Wilde's more famous "Importance of Being Earnest." "He made me feel I'd underestimated it," Mr. Eyre said. "And that's typical of his work, which is true to the text, unostentatious, uncluttered, lucid, quite muscular and wonderfully accessible."
Adrian Noble, director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, thought "An Ideal Husband" demonstrated Sir Peter's skill at choosing the right cast and giving it creative freedom. "He takes on more work than anyone should," Mr. Noble said, "yet gets such good performances out of his actors. He cares passionately about the future too -- developing talent and handing on the baton to new directors."
And certainly Sir Peter's recent productions have been well received by the public. A revival of "Hamlet," with the little-known Stephen Dillane as a quirky, unglamorous prince, defied conventional wisdom by succeeding on commercial Shaftesbury Avenue, and "An Ideal Husband" has been playing to an average of 90 percent capacity on what is actually its return visit to the West End.
SIR PETER'S PRODUCtion, first seen in 1992, was restaged in London only because a special deal was negotiated with the actors' unions allowing a Broadway transfer. British Equity agreed to let Sir Peter bring Jessica Lange and a mainly American cast to the West End in Tennessee Williams's "Streetcar Named Desire" next fall, so American Equity allowed Martin Shaw, Penny Downie and most of the other Britons in Wilde's play to go to New York.
If Sir Peter has not lost his appetite for work since leaving the National, he has not lost his enthusiasm for controversy either. He is still recognizably the man who leaped on a coffee table at a press conference in 1985 to denounce the Government's financial cuts to the theater, famously provoking the Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, to ask her arts minister, "When can we stop giving money to awful people like Peter Hall?" Few directors would dare denounce the restrictive practices of both branches of Equity so ferociously.
When Sir Peter formed his new company in 1988, he hoped that almost all of its productions would play on both sides of the Atlantic. And almost every one, he said, has attracted interest from America. But the reason so few have transferred is not only the hesitancy of Broadway producers to restage financially risky work like Aristophanes' "Lysistrata" or the Dillane "Hamlet." It is also because neither Equity permits foreigners to perform in its own country unless they adhere to strict conditions. Usually that means they must be international stars, or arrive with a permanent ensemble, which the Comedie-Francaise is but the Peter Hall Company is not, or they must be part of a swap: "Ideal Husband" for "Streetcar."
Three years ago, Sir Peter refused to take Peter Shaffer's play "Gift of the Gorgon" to New York because American Equity rejected its leading man, Michael Pennington. Last year, London and Toronto saw his revival of Ibsen's "Master Builder" but Broadway missed out. The union accepted Alan Bates as Solness, but not Victoria Hamilton as Hilde, even though she received some of the most stunning reviews that can ever have come a newcomer's way. More recently, British Equity refused to allow Sir Peter to introduce London theatergoers to a young Trinidadian actor he calls "a bit of a genius," Michael Cherry, who stars in "The Final Passage," his two-part film about the influx of West Indians into Britain.
"Both Equities need their heads banging together, because both of them are ignorant protection societies," rages Sir Peter. "I think they're a disgrace to the profession on both sides of the Atlantic. A union ought to be about the nurturing of talent, especially young talent. It should be about an interchange that's productive and creative. But a closed shop is defensive and deadening, and I've never met an actor in either country who doesn't bemoan it. It is simply dreadful, and it makes me terribly angry."
Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of Actors' Equity in New York, responded to Sir Peter's criticisms last week, describing them as "petulant and ill thought out." The director, he said "is living in a dream world" if he believes that American performers would oppose policies preventing an influx of British actors. Such regulations, he said, help to insure that American actors are not denied the opportunity to develop their talents. Though he noted that unemployment among his union's membership is sometimes as high as 90 percent, he said that Equity has become more liberal. Since 1981, it has agreed to a total of 94 exchanges of individual actors between America and Britain, Mr. Eisenberg said.
"An Ideal Husband" will, in any case, give New Yorkers the chance to see why the British critics were so enthusiastic about a play often dismissed as a Victorian melodrama peppered with Wildean jokes. The reason Sir Peter wanted to direct it and even tried several times to mount a production when he was running the National, was that he believed it a deeper, more humane piece than is usually supposed. "Though it's 100 years old, it couldn't be more violently contemporary, both politically and sexually," he said.
IN SIR PETER'S VIEW, THE story of Sir Robert Chiltern, the statesman blackmailed for a financial indiscretion he committed years ago, has obvious resonances for both Britain and America. But the most prominent character in his production is Lord Goring, the Wildean wit and dandy who gives kindly but shrewd advice to both the politician and the politician's judgmental wife. As played by Martin Shaw, Goring is, said Sir Peter, "an extremely tolerant man who really understands himself and other people." He is also an unacknowledged bisexual, likely to prove "a jolly good husband to his wife and a very good father to his children," Sir Peter said.
In other words, he has much in common with Wilde himself. "Yes," the director continued: "The play is obviously autobiographical. It was written when Wilde was being blackmailed by rentboys, and six months after it opened he was in Reading Gaol. It's a play about bisexuality written at a time when you couldn't admit in the theater that homosexuality existed. Even in the 1960's, the feeling was you had to be one thing or the other. Now we are beginning to admit that bisexuality may actually be the norm."
Fop Sir Peter, the jokes are not decorative but a "comic version of the British stiff upper lip, an attempt to keep control at times of great tension and difficulty." Indeed, it's the play's combination of humor and emotional seriousness to which he attributes its success in a London that seems to get more like New York every day: "The political scandal makes audiences laugh, but there is also an enormous tenderness and tolerance in the play that I think we yearn for now. We live in a society that is so competitive and selfish that audiences really respond to ideas of understanding and forgiveness."
What next? There were newspaper reports two months ago that Sir Peter had suffered a serious heart attack. In fact, he fainted after giving a two-hour lecture to the company he formed 36 years ago, the Royal Shakespeare Company, and then driving through heavy traffic to a theater 10 miles south of London. Tests in the cardiac ward of a local hospital revealed he was suffering from tension. The Grim Reaper -- a figure Sir Peter has admitted he fearfully ponders every day -- was not about to pounce. "I feel very well, very energetic," he said. "And my appetite for life is as strong as ever."
Extracurricular life th'se days revolves round Nicki, his fourth wife, and Emma, their 3-year-old daughter and his sixth child. In the autobiography he published in 1993, Sir Peter spoke of bouts of near-suicidal depression that had hit him when he was working too hard or, sometimes, not working hard enough. But the marriage he made in 1990 is, he declares, keeping them at bay.
That doesn't mean any let-up in a regimen that will, he vows, continue until he does indeed drop dead. After completing "Man and Superman" for BBC radio and transferring the "Julius Caesar" he directed last year from Stratford to London, he stages Sophocles' "Oedipus" plays at the National and in Greece, directs Moliere's "School for Wives" and Williams's "Streetcar" for his own company, and starts readying himself to do a six-hour television film based on Barrie Unsworth's slave-trade novel, "The Sacred Hunger."
He would also like to form an ensemble of about 12 actors, take over a West End theater and offer programs of three plays in repertory. It is more a hope than a firm plan, but, with Sir Peter, hopes have a way of happening. "I've always filled my days up as full as possible," he said. "But I'd also like to do one more big thing before I hang up my clogs."
 
The Diary of a Busy Director Whose Work Is Truly His Play

plans not to retire, "In the 1950's I was the youngest director, so maybe one day I'll be the oldest." Here is a typical schedule the

HEADLINE: Habitats/46 West 83d Street;
Lawyers' Apartments of the 1st Part and the 2d Part

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AT the nadir of the real-estate recession of the early 1990's, Barbara Peabody couldn't sell her one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side.
"No more than five people looked at the place," said Ms. Peabody, a lawyer who works in the New York City Corporation Counsel's office. 
 She had bought apartment 8A at 46 West 83d Street 22 years ago, as the building was going co-op; she married, gave birth to one child, then another. "There were Fisher-Price toys everywhere," she said with a laugh.
Like many other parents struggling at the time to sell their too-small apartments, Ms. Peabody and her husband, Michael Cusick, a corporate lawyer with a downtown firm, knew something had to give. So they looked sideways, to the adjacent apartment.
An elderly woman was living next door in 8B, a rent-controlled tenant who had not bought her one-bedroom apartment. Someone told Ms. Peabody that the building's sponsor had contacted the tenant, then in her 80's, and re-offered the apartment -- which the woman supposedly had again declined.
Ms. Peabody leapt at the chance. She called the sponsor and bid $60,000 -- $5,000 above the old insider's price. The sponsor refused. She offered $80,000; he accepted.
The deal was set and then completed. But when the excitement of the closing -- and the dozens of sketches of how the two apartments would look combined -- had passed, the family was left with the central problem: They had bought an occupied apartment.
"Now comes the macabre part," Ms. Peabody said. "We tried not to think of it -- because we really liked her. But we couldn't help thinking of it: How long would she live?"
Ms. Peabody prides herself on being a careful person, and she had done spread sheets on the financial aspects of the deal.
Financially, it made great sense to her. Because of an anomaly when the building became a co-op, her original one-bedroom -- for which she had paid $87,000 -- had a $1,100 monthly maintenance, possibly one reason it had not found a buyer when she tried to sell it.
The one-bedroom next door, virtually the same 1,100 square feet but without some of Ms. Peabody's lovely views of Central Park, had a $700 monthly maintenance. From that standpoint alone, combining the apartments was a way to even up the situation.
But there were also more calculations: The tenant was paying $506 a month in rent -- less than the maintenance the new owners would have to pay.
The couple rented out their old apartment for about $2,300 a month and moved to a rental apartment at 79th and Broadway, a fine apartment with a maid's room and a dining room. The rent on the family's 79th Street apartment started at $2,400 a month. By the time they left -- four and a half years later -- the rent was up to $2,800.
In March 1994, while they were in the rental apartment, their elderly tenant died.
At that point, Ms. Peabody asked the board for permission to sublet the second apartment indefinitely, while she lived in the rental on 79th Street and made renovation plans to link the two apartments on 83d Street. The board balked, but agreed to let her sublet both apartments for a year and a half more.
By subletting the second apartment for $2,000 a month, Ms. Peabody said, she took in "about $20,000" -- money she is using to do the long-planned renovation, which is finally taking place. (Her expenses, including a mortgage on the second co-op apartment, totaled $2,367 a month; her income from the two rents was more than $4,300.)
T O find an architect, Ms. Peabody simply asked around. She heard about Tom Vail from the mother of one of her children's schoolmates. She was impressed, she said, because Mr. Vail returned her call within minutes.
They went over her plans. Because of the board's generosity on subletting, she was able to get her plans approved by the necessary city agencies, and by the building's board, more than a year before she actually decided to start work.
Her tenants moved out Dec. 1. The work started in January. Mr. Vail, she said, recommended excellent contractors.
"You know the nightmare," she said. "I do contract litigation."
In her own case, the first estimate -- for 8A -- may have arrived vaguely worded, but she instructed the contractors what she wanted to see on their bid.
"I don't want to see just 'electrical' and a price; I want to see exactly what's going in," she explained. "I don't want to see 'bathroom work'; I want to see 'three new walls for bathtub enclosure.' "
The architect and his client worked on drawings, figured out in their own minds what the job should cost and went back to the contractors and asked: Can you do 8A's renovation for $40,000?
They could.
Right now, the renovation is very much in progress. Ms. Peabody's old kitchen is being enlarged; the ceiling is open and the electricians are trying to figure out what fixtures will go there.
"Well, I want to have some lights here," Ms. Peabody, a handsome woman with streaky gray hair pulled back in a ponytail, said offhandedly. "We're going to put a table there now, so maybe a hanging fixture, but then we eventually want to build some cabinets across the back, so maybe some track lights?"
The electrician, who appeared to have a good sense of humor, agreed to put in a ceiling box for now -- and the exact fixture could be contemplated later.
The long hall leading from the entrance of 8A into the rest of the new apartment had cracked plaster, and has been laminated with sheetrock, bringing the surface out 5/8 of an inch. The 4- by 8-foot sheets of the drywall don't go all the way up to the 9 1/2-foot ceiling, so the carpenters have applied a picture-frame molding along the top edge of the drywall, creating a small ledge -- which Ms. Peabody is trying to decide if she likes.
(To cut pieces of drywall and laminate it into the space between the new drywall and the ceiling would add considerably to the budget.)
T HERE are still more decisions: Should there be a French door from the long hallway -- which broadens into a central foyer -- into the dining room? Should the bookcases at the end of the living room be retained the way Ms. Peabody designed them years ago, or changed? What color should the walls be?
But these decisions are minor, and Ms. Peabody is one of the first to describe herself as "fairly ecstatic" with her deal.
"The agents say I've got one of the biggest bedrooms on the Upper West Side," she proclaimed. "My kids -- Isabel, 6, and Theo, 9 -- use it to play soccer; they use it as a gymnasium." Her bedroom, created by combining the living room and bedroom from the tenant's apartment, measures about 17 by 24 feet and has a beautifully tiled new master bath off on one side, where the former kitchen used to be.
With the architect's fee, the costs for renovating both apartments came to $75,000. Added to the combined $167,000, the total comes to $242,000 for an elephantine three-bedroom apartment with three-and-a-half bathrooms and a formal dining room -- hundreds of thousands of dollars less than such an apartment would ordinarily cost.
"I knew it was weird," she said, standing in the midst of the renovation, "but the way I worked it out, I really thought it was absolutely foolproof."
What if the elderly tenant had brought in a daughter or granddaughter, who inherited the rent-controlled apartment?
"Yes," Ms. Peabody said. "That was the scary part."

HEADLINE: Medically Uninsured Increasing On Island

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
AN increase in Long Islanders without health insurance is generating concern that many people are not receiving adequate medical care.
The number of uninsured people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has steadily climbed since 1990, according to the State Health Department. In 1990 Long Island had 207,000 people, or 7.5 percent of the population, without health coverage. Last year the total was 314,000, or 10.8 percent of Long Island. 
 The rise reflects a statewide trend, a spokeswoman for the department, Frances Tarlton, said. The uninsured statewide rose, from 22 million, or 12.3 percent in 1990, to 29 million, or 16 percent, in 1995.
The growing number on Long Island is mostly made up of people who have lost their jobs or workers in small companies that have halted insurance programs, experts said.
The chief economist for the Long Island Association, Dr. Pearl Kamer said the economy and the insurance problems were directly related. Many discharged employees have lost their insurance, and people who have gone into business for themselves or who have joined small companies are finding themselves in critical situations, without insurance and unable to afford the high premiums, she said.
"On Long Island," Dr. Kamer added, "we are fundamentally a small-business economy. Today many employers of small businesses are looking to outsource some of their work or to hire part-time employees, so they can avoid the expense of health-insurance coverage.
"This is creating a contingent work force that is much less secure than the work force of a decade ago, when more people had permanent jobs with a full range of benefits. The issue of providing health-insurance coverage is actually stunting the economic recovery on Long Island."
Last week the United States Senate passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job. The bill faces difficulty in the House of Representatives, which passed a different version last month, but election-year concerns are reported to be giving the measure some momentum.
The core of the bill is a provision that would require insurers to cover workers under a new employer's plan if their last job carried insurance. But it would sharply limit any exclusions for pre-existing medical conditions. People who leave their jobs are among those who might not be able to pick up new insurance right away.
Health insurance for a person costs an average of $150 to $200 a month, according to Douglas Jacobs, a broker at Bender Insurance in Massapequa. For a family of four, Mr. Jacobs said, the monthly premium might run from $400 if the family is in a managed-care plan to $650 for a full-service program, with a choice of doctors outside a network.
Many insurers no longer sell policies for individuals, and those that do often impose high deductibles, he said, adding, "Times are tough, and people are doing a lot of drastic things they never thought of before to keep their family budgets going."
In terms of medical care, many uninsured people are not going to doctors' offices for primary or preventive care like checkups and immunizations, Ms. Tarlton said. One result, she added, is that too many people find themselves going to hospitals in the midst of medical crises.
"This is a forgotten population," the Suffolk Health Services Commissioner, Dr. Mary Hibberd, said. "People tend to think that there are only two groups, those who have insurance and those on Medicaid. Too often this huge population in between -- of the working poor -- is forgotten about in state plans, and nobody is taking care of them."
Suffolk County operates eight neighborhood health centers, and they have a total of 250,000 visits a year. The fastest growing group at the health centers is the uninsured, according to Dr. Hibberd. Uninsured patients have increased since 1992 by 15,000 visits a year, and that group makes up 35 percent of those at the centers.
The county has expanded clinic hours to evenings and weekends, Dr. Hibberd said, and those extra hours have filled up quickly with people who work during the day and have no access to other health care.
People without insurance are receiving less frequent care for themselves and their children, she said. Fees for a visit to a pediatrician usually range from $50 to $150, and the uninsured cannot afford that, especially with several children.
"What concerns us is that there are medical conditions like diabetes, hypertension and asthma that should be treated early," Dr. Hibberd said. "If people don't get early treatments they'll get sicker and need more expensive care later. Unfortunately this is a growing problem."
The centers have sliding fees that range from free to $200 a visit, based on the services rendered and patients' earnings.
Nassau runs nine centers, including one at a school and a clinic for sexually transmitted diseases. Their fees range from $10 to $180.
Immunizations and services for tuberculosis and sexually transmitted diseases are free.
Nassau Health Commissioner Kathleen A. Gaffney said that most patients at the centers had always been uninsured, but that the number was growing.
With major employment dislocations, the the centers feel the effects tangibly, Dr. Gaffney said. When Grumman dismissed hundreds of employees, the center in Plainview had a surge of new patients who were former Grumman workers and who had lost their insurance.
Concern is also growing for postcollege young adults, she said. After college, young adults are usually not covered by parents' policies, and if they are not in jobs with health insurance, typically do not seek health care, Dr. Gaffney said.
The lack of insurance is also a significant problem for women who cannot afford mammographies, the Commissioner said. The county has started offering free mammographies at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow and other centers. Last year more than half the women who were given mammogrophies had no insurance, she said.
A major state program, the New York Prospective Hospital Payment Mechanism, expires on June 30. Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed the Health Care Reform Act, which would include changing health insurance, said Ms. Tarlton.
One proposal is to continue surcharges that insurers pay for hospital care, but providing some of those funds earlier, instead of reimbursing the hospitals after they have rendered the services. The state would raise $1.37 billion from the surcharges, of which $702 million would help pay hospitals for charity care and offset the costs of treating the uninsured.
By law, hospitals have to provide emergency care for all patients, whether or not they can pay.
An additional $174 million would be allocated for subsidized health insurance, including expansion of the Child Health Plus Program, which covers children of workers without health insurance. The program now covers 100,000 children up to the age of 14.
Mr. Pataki calls for adding another 100,000 participants over three years, increasing the eligibility to 18 and expanding coverage to include in-patient hospital care.
In addition, the Governor has designated $14 million to a new program, the Small Business Insurance Partnership, an incentive to encourage small businesses with fewer than 50 employees to provide insurance.
Under that program, the state would pay 45 percent of the premium, the employer would pay 45 percent, and the employee would pay the remaining 10 percent.
The reforms would not cover all of the uninsured, but would be a first step, Ms. Tarlton said.
The chairman of the State Senate Health Committee, Kemp Hannon, Republican of Westbury, said the Legislature was digesting the proposals. "As more people are being left out of the system," Mr. Hannon said, "we are seeing more irregular health care that too often ends up with acute situations that must be treated in emergency rooms. There is a critical need to address this problem. Individually, you need insurance to have good health care, and the system needs more people to be insured to have good health care and to be an effective system."

HEADLINE: HOME REPAIR;
With Plastic Laminates, Start Simply Because There's No Turning Back

BYLINE: By EDWARD R. LIPINSKI

 BODY:
PLASTIC laminate is the tough surfacing material widely used as a cover for kitchen countertops. Laminates are made of thin sheets of kraft paper impregnated with phenolic resin. A plastic veneer, melanin, is added to the resin-paper sandwich, followed by a layer of colored or patterned plastic, then topped with another layer of melanin. The multilayered sandwich is fused under heat and pressure. The result is a thin, heat-resistant veneer that makes a durable and decorative work surface. Two copyrighted trade names for this product are Formica and Micarta.
Plastic laminate is available in 4-by-8-foot sheets. (Some home centers may also stock 30- , 36- and 60-inch widths and 6- , 10- and 12-foot lengths.) It costs about $1.50 to $2.50 a square foot. The laminate is available in two thicknesses: 1/16 inch and 1/32inch. The 1/16-inch thickness is a general-purpose laminate. The thinner, 1/32-inch sheets are called vertical-grade laminate and are designed for use as facing for backsplashes, drawer fronts, doors and cabinets. Vertical-grade laminates are too thin for countertops. 
 Laminates are manufactured in a wide assortment of colors (more than 250) and patterns. They also come in a variety of surface textures like matte, glossy, embossed and grained. It's wise, however, to avoid using glossy or textured laminates on countertops because they do not wear well and will lose their brilliance in a few years.
With most laminates, the color is impregnated in the top layer only, so the edge is a dark band. The dark edge may not be noticeable if the surface color is also dark, but it can be incongruous with a light surface. The solution is to use a color-through laminate that has all the layers imprinted with the color. Color-through laminate is more expensive than ordinary plastic; it runs from $3 to $5 a square foot.
Laminate is too thin to be used alone, and it must be bonded to a substrate, or support piece, like a 3/4-inch plywood or particle board. Particle board is economical and suitable as a substrate for a desk or workbench, but it is not water-resistant. For a countertop that will support a sink, moisture-resistant or exterior grade plywood is a better choice as a substrate.
The laminate is bonded to the substrate with contact cement. The cement is brushed onto the top of the substrate and the underside of the laminate, then allowed to dry. Aligning the laminate can be tricky because the cement bonds the two coated pieces together the instant they touch. You cannot move the laminate once the bond is made.
The best method of bonding the laminate is to place two sheets of paper on the cement-coated surface of the substrate. Place the laminate on the paper, and align it with the top. Then slide the paper out. Even with this "slip-sheet" method, alignment can be less than perfect. That's why it's best to cut the laminate a little larger than the top -- allowing about a 1/2-inch overhang on all sides --and trim it to size after it's bonded.
If you've never worked with laminate, it may be well to experiment with it. Start with a simple project, like a card table or a laundry table, to perfect your skills. If you don't have a table, you can make one by attaching four legs (home centers have various styles available) to a sheet of 3/4-inch particle board.
Start by cutting the sheet to approximate size; remember to allow at least 1/2-inch overhang on all four sides. There are a number of ways to cut the laminate. If you have a table saw, you can use it with a carbide blade or an old combination blade. Do not use your best steel blade because the hard plastic laminate will dull it. If you don't have a power saw, you can use a hand saw with fine crosscut teeth.
Still another way to cut the laminate is with a laminate scriber. The scriber looks like a utility knife but is made for hard plastic. To make the cut, place a straight edge down, then score a line across the face of the laminate with the scriber. Bend the laminate back until it breaks. This technique sounds easy, but it can be tedious because you may have to make a number of passes before the score mark is deep enough for a clean break.
Before bonding the laminate to the table top, examine the top for bumps or holes. Sand down the bumps and fill the holes with wood putty. Make sure the surface is clean and dry before brushing on the contact cement.
Contact cement is a petroleum-based adhesive. It is flammable and toxic. Be sure to work in a well-ventilated area away from heat or an open flame. There is a water-based contact cement that is less toxic and non-flammable, but it has less bonding strength than the petroleum-based cement.
Bond the edges first. Adhere one strip, then trim it before doing the next one. The best tool to use to trim the laminate is a router fitted with a carbide trimming bit. (Be sure to wear eye protection.) You can also use a plane, a Surform tool or a special laminate trimmer (available at some rental stores).
Do the top last. It's important to make sure that the bond is secure and that there are no air pockets beneath the plastic. One way to do this is by tapping across the entire surface with a hammer; to avoid marring the finish, place a wood block under the hammer. You can also use a rolling pin to press the laminate in place.

HEADLINE: Group Opposes Managed Care

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

 BODY:
"CODE BLUE" -- in medicine, the words indicate a patient has gone into cardio-pulmonary arrest and must receive immediate emergency resuscitation.
Recently, an advocacy group of doctors, nurses and patients took the name Code Blue to underscore their belief that, in the words of one of the group's founders, "our dying health care system needs to be resuscitated." 
 Dr. Carl P. Weber, a surgeon who practices in White Plains, and Dr. Richard Frimer, an internist who specializes in intensive-care medicine and pulmonology who also practices in White Plains, founded Code Blue to promote awareness of what they say are the pitfalls of managed care. The doctors say that the managed-care system prevalent in America today influences doctors to make medical decisions based on financial considerations, stresses cost cutting over cures, penalizes doctors for recommending certain tests, treatments and consultations with specialists and may actually reward them for withholding care.
To publicize their views, Dr. Weber and Dr. Frimer have placed advertisements in newspapers and magazines, spoken at public meetings, contacted legislators and given interviews for publication or broadcast.
"On top of being sick and frightened, many people now have to fight with their insurers simply to get reimbursement for some procedures," Dr. Weber said. The managed-care trend, he added, is to cover only the basics, only the barest minimum. "This country is developing a system where you can get the gas tank filled, you can have the oil changed, but when the engine falls out you have to fight to get it replaced and paid for."
"We have gone back to the dark ages," Dr. Frimer said. "The science of medicine is getting lost in a lot of jargon about cutting costs."
Managed care, Dr. Weber explained, is a general term for insurance plans that oversee where and how members receive health care. Although specifics vary with each plan, this usually entails determining which, and how many, doctors a patient can see and which tests he or she can get. Under many plans, a patient's freedom of choice is severely restricted, Dr. Weber said, observing that often a patient must see a "gate keeper" doctor who determines whether consultations with specialists are necessary and therefore reimbursable.
Because the majority of employees of large and small companies are now enrolled in some type of managed-care plan, doctors feel pressure to provide services through those plans, Dr. Weber said. He added that those doctors who take part may find themselves financially penalized by the insurance companies for ordering certain tests, referring a patient to specialists or keeping a patient in the hospital beyond a certain number of days.
"The decisions are made by people interested in economics first, and the actual welfare of the patient, a distant second," he said. Furthermore, he said, some studies indicating that managed care saves significant amounts of money are skewed because they were conducted on a group younger and healthier than the average American. "We need to educate the public about what managed care really is doing," he said.
Toward that end, he and Dr. Frimer have raised $48,000 from doctors, nurses and patients to pay for full-page newspaper ads. Code Blue has also joined in a lawsuit, as an advocate, on behalf of a patient who is claiming her treatment was compromised under a managed-care plan. The group has also filed a petition in State Supreme Court, asking that the court require the state's Department of Health to investigate the impact of managed-care plans on patients' welfare. And they are volunteering to speak to any group willing to listen.
"The proponents of managed care fail to consider the devastating situations people often find themselves in," Dr. Weber said. "There was a case, not long ago, in which a child needed a transplant. This particular health maintenance organization approved payment but stipulated that the procedure be done at a particular transplant center, which happened to be 150 miles from the child's home.
"Both parents needed to work, but because of this, the mother had to quit working to be near her child. The father, who had a low-paying job, could not stop working, and rarely got to see his sick child. The other child in the family developed psychological and behavioral problems as a result of all this stress. This HMO's policy virtually destroyed a whole family."

HEADLINE: Hospital Plans Unit for Children

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
COUNTY officials recently announced plans to build a $60 million children's hospital at the County Medical Center in Valhalla within five years. This 150-bed hospital would become the only hospital in the New York City area specializing entirely in providing tertiary care -- the highest level of care -- for seriously ill children.
At a time of economic difficulty for both governmental units and hospitals, the county will provide $9.9 million toward the project from the 1997 capital budget, with the rest coming from the Medical Center's own fund-raising efforts. This will be the first major fund-raising campaign in the Medical Center's history. When completed, it will become the first new medical building on the Valhalla campus since the Medical Center opened in 1977. 
 "We will not be focusing on the child who has pneumonia or asthma but the child who has cancer or heart disease or who needs transplant surgery," Edward A. Stolzenberg, the county's Commissioner of Hospitals, said at a news conference in a pediatric outpatient area. "We treat many of these illnesses now in the main hospital, but we can't provide the amenities that children and their parents need."
Each year, the Medical Center treats 20,000 patients under age 20. This represents a sixth of the center's patient population. The main hospital has 109 pediatric beds on two floors. Services provided there to children include kidney transplants, brain surgery and cancer care. The Medical Center is the only hospital between Westchester and Albany that does pediatric open-heart surgery and has an intensive care unit for children. There are 570,000 children in the seven-county region north of New York City.
"We are letting out the best-kept secret in the Hudson Valley and that is the quality of our child services at the Medical Center," said Dr. Michael H. Gewitz, director of pediatrics. "We're interested in providing a functionally designed hospital for children that matches the care they need."
Dr. Gewitz said that in treating children it is important to provide a non-threatening environment and take family needs into account. The Medical Center is limited in that regard. The new hospital, for example, will have rooms equipped with pullout beds so a parent can stay overnight.
Commissioner Stolzenberg said that pediatric liver transplants will soon be performed at the Medical Center. "But since the children's beds are full on a regular basis, we must expand to provide new services," he said.
The expansion plans come at a time when many hospitals are being forced into intense competition by cutbacks in government aid. County officials said that the new hospital will not compete with local hospitals, because the mission of the new hospital will be to treat the most seriously ill children, those who cannot receive adequate care elsewhere in the county.
There are two other children's hospitals in the New York area: Babies and Infants Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan and Schneider Children's Hospital at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park. Neither of these hospitals is devoted solely to tertiary care.
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said the project will go forward even if there is a change in the county's relationship with the Medical Center, such as the county's turning control of the center over to a public benefit corporation. "There has been a need for this for a long time," Mr. O'Rourke said. "We are building a new hospital that will either be run by the county commissioner or a public benefit corporation."
Mr. O'Rourke defended his decision to ask the county's Board of Legislators to help finance the project. "The county spent $68 million to build a new jail a couple of years ago," he said. "It needed to be done, but it's time we spent money on something of equal importance to the future of this county and state."
Commissioner Stolzenberg said that feasibility studies have identified how private sources can provide most of the money needed to complete the project. Fund-raising efforts will begin in June at the hospital's annual ball. State approval will be necessary before construction begins. Early plans are to build the new hospital behind the main hospital near the Medical Center's heliport.

HEADLINE: Norwich's Deer Now In Hunters' Sights

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
MOST of the deer from the Mohegan Park Zoo in Norwich, remainders of a herd that had served as town pets since 1936, were shipped out of town one night early this month, auctioned off in Ohio, and are now in Texas game farms where they will be hunted and killed for trophies.
An East Lyme-based wildlife rescue organization, which had been trying to prevent the deers' slaughter, only managed to acquire eight of them, which will eventually be returned to Connecticut. 
 The developments apparently ended a struggle between economics-minded town officials who argued that the deer must go, and others seeking to continue the Norwich tradition of a local deer herd especially beloved by children.
Last fall there were 53 deer in the zoo's three-acre fenced-in enclosure. Six died during the winter and five escaped after a hole was cut in the fence in March and the remaining 42 were turned over to Ponte Brothers, of Westport, Mass., after being tested, at Norwich's expense, for potential health problems.
Only 39 survived the trip to Woods and Waters, a western Ohio animal auction house. And three of those animals were so damaged in transit that auction officials said they had to be destroyed.
Before being auctioned on April 20, the remaining 36 animals were examined by potential buyers, and there were some expressions of dismay. "It's very unusual that animals in this poor condition are auctioned here," said Raymond Bailey, an Ohio white-tailed-deer breeder.
Indeed, auction house employees warned potential bidders that the animals had a host of injuries including lameness, abscesses, open sores, a broken jaw and deep infected wounds. But regulars said the animals were auctioned at some of the highest prices in memory for white-tailed deer.
"I've never seen anything like it," said Mr. Bailey. Animals that usually would have sold for less than $100 commanded $400 to $600, he said.
"This is only business," said Bill Engles, a seller of deer to Texas game farms. "I have people who are paying $8,000 for bucks and $1,800 for does. I have an order for 800 animals." It was Mr. Engles and two associates, all wearing big black Stetsons hats and black Western attire, who bought most of the bucks and large does offered at the auction. One of the Mohegan Park bucks sold for $1,000; a doe sold for $850.
Mr. Engles bought 22 of the zoo deer; 6 were bought by deer breeders, and the wildlife rescue organization got the rest.
Ponte Brothers, which was paid $3,600 by the Town of Norwich to have the deer tested for disease, received about $20,000 for the sale of 36 deer. It was as a result of a $5,000 donation from Donald Burr of Norwich that the North American Wildlife Association was able to buy the eight deer, said Robert Salvatore, president of the organization.
Volunteers are trying to stabilize the animals and prepare them for transport to the association's 25-acre wildlife refuge in East Lyme, said Mr. Salvatore.
Two years ago a zoo advisory council recommended the destruction of the herd. The city is converting the zoo into a petting zoo, which will only have barnyard animals.
Following the council's recommendation, a deer contracted rabies, and the city was ordered by the state to erect a second fence around the deer enclosure.
The city then made plans to have the deer shot and butchered for local soup kitchens.
But public school children and other city residents protested the animals' death sentence.
In February, Mr. Salvatore said, he was contacted by City Manager Bill Tallman and told that his wildlife association could take over the care of the animals at the association's refuge.
And volunteers were building an enclosure when, on April 8, in secret and after dark, the zoo animals were turned over to the Ponte Brothers for their apparently rugged trip to Ohio.
The city did consider sending the deer to North American Wildlife Association, said Mr. Tallman. But the city was advised by Dale May, head of the state Department of Environmental Protection's wildlife division that the association did not have sufficient resources to care for the animals. The city also had an agreement with George Ponte, owner of Ponte Brothers, that he would get at least 40 deer, said Mr. Tallman.
Robert Pritchett, a Pennsylvania deer breeder, bought a zoo buck with an infected wound on its left front leg at the auction. Mr. Pritchett said he believed he could heal the buck's wound and use him for breeding until the fall. "He'll be alright until the fall. Then he's going to be eaten," said Mr. Pritchett.
Not so, apparently, for the small group bought by the wildlife association, which is trying to raise an additional $5,000 to transport the animals to Connecticut, build a five-acre enclosure at the refuge and begin a fund for the animals' ongoing care, said Mr. Salvatore.
At the wildlife refuge these animals, the last remnant of a 60-year-old herd that was always the city of Norwich's pets, will be able to live out their natural lives, he said.
"At the very least Norwich's children can be told that the city government did not succeed in having all of the city's pet deer killed," Mr. Salvatore said.
