HEADLINE: Can Towns Control Gaming's Downside?

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
LEDYARD is a rural eastern Connecticut town where the churches easily outnumber the cocktail lounges. But it still worries about bad influences. Town Council member Cynthia S. Brewster is putting the finishing touches on a 15-page ordinance that would restrict adults-only book and video stores, massage parlors and nightclubs.
Ms. Brewster says people in town are worried that with the largest casino in the Western Hemisphere already open in Ledyard, and another planned in the next town over, people are worried that the region could become the next Las Vegas. 
 Nearby Salem and Colchester are preparing similar ordinances, Norwich has one on the books, and other towns in the region are beginning to look at their own laws for controlling pornography. Two prostitution rings have been broken up, rings that were tied to casino customers, advocates of the ordinances point out.
"Our region is changing quickly, and we've lost control of a lot of our land because of Federal mandates regarding Indian reservations," Ms. Brewster said. "This is an attempt to regain some of that control."
Jenny Contois, Colchester's First Selectman, said her town has the third-highest growth rate in the state. "All that activity raised a red flag -- particularly with the casinos so close by," she said. "People have really been concerned about the possibility of adults-only businesses moving into town, and they've asked us to look into an ordinance that could control it."
But many local officials also believe the threat is overblown. They note that there are no adults-only bookstores, video shops or massage parlors at the Foxwoods Resort Casino, which is run by the Mashantucket Pequots on the border of Ledyard and Preston, and there are none planned for the Mohegan Pequot's Sun Resort Casino under construction in Montville.
Ms. Contois, for instance, said she doesn't think the casinos would so heavily influence commercial development in Colchester, which is 15 miles away, that peep shows will be opening along Main Street.
"I'm not a big proponent of gambling," Ms. Contois said. "I think it has its negatives. But it has also generated a lot of jobs, and had this industry not been here as defense companies were downsizing, we would have experienced much higher unemployment."
Kathy B. Warzecha, the city planner in Norwich, said an ordinance banning nude dancing, adult bookstores and other adult-oriented enterprise has been in place there just over a year.
"But it hasn't been a big issue in town," Ms. Warzecha said. "I've never had anyone come in and propose something that would violate the ordinance. In fact, what I'm more concerned about now is the opening of pawn shops."
Ms. Warzecha said if the casino has had any impact in town, it has been positive. With more than 60,000 people going to the casino on a busy day, there is no way the restaurants and shops on the grounds of the gaming complex can accommodate everyone, and the other towns in the region could get the spillover.
"There are such large numbers of people involved, you don't even need to capture that much of it on a percentage basis to make a big difference in the business climate," Ms. Warzecha said. "There's a lot more traffic moving through Norwich now, and once things go a little further you'll see more benefits from the people driving through."
"What it's done is created a new level of enthusiasm," she continued. "We've had five or six new businesses come into the downtown in just the last month. You can't focus on the bad points of the casinos because they're here, so you have to try to focus on the good points."
Other officials say the ordinances make sense even if casinos don't have the impact many people expect.
"This is an effort to think ahead," agreed Cynthia B. Rowin, the Salem Town Clerk. "Salem is a fast-growing town, and when you have an area that's seeing a lot of development, this is one of the areas you look at. We want this ordinance in place before an adult-oriented business decides to locate here."
But lawyers caution that the towns cannot carry their restrictions too far. Joseph S. Grabarz, executive director of the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, said many of the local ordinances are meaningless, legally.
"There are already laws on the books that govern what minors can buy, and that put limits on what can be shown or printed, so I would question what these local ordinances would accomplish," Mr. Grabarz said. "It's a chancy thing for a town to do, and can often lead to a large financial exposure."
Mr. Grabarz said, for instance, that some towns respond to citizen pressure to restrict what an adults-only business can put on a sign outside its doors.
"There's a problem whenever they try to regulate content," Mr. Grabarz said. "The town shouldn't be in the business of telling one business how it can advertise, unless it's the same rule for all businesses."
He said, though, that the Civil Liberties Union rarely steps into the fray when a town attempts to ban the distribution of pornography.
"They can be very lucrative businesses, so as soon as the law is enforced and one of them is shut down, there's enough money at stake that the business obtains a high-powered attorney and gets it overturned," said Mr. Grabarz.
Alan Neigher, a Westport lawyer who specializes in First Amendment cases, said towns have a right to use zoning laws to maintain the essential nature of the town, but it can quickly be undermined.
"The types of regulations that get struck down are generally those that focus on a particular type of activity," Mr. Neigher said.
"If towns around Ledyard have kept their residential character, they probably have a better chance of enforcing an ordinance," Mr. Neigher said. "But once they develop commercial areas, that argument starts to slip away. It won't be long before you have a business that wants to get into entertainment, first with restaurants, then nightclubs, and so on. Before you know it, you have lap dancing."
Most of the towns said they are aware that they have to proceed carefully. Salem's 10 1/2-page ordinance goes into great detail about how signs must identify the business as "adult-oriented," owners must be licensed and the businesses cannot be within 500 feet of a residential area, 2,000 feet of a park or school, or 3,000 feet of another adult-oriented business.
"There was actually very little discussion of First Amendment rights because the ordinance is so carefully worded it won't infringe on anyone's rights," Ms. Rowin maintained.
The ordinances must also, by law, go into great detail about what is banned, with specific and graphic detail of genitals, breasts and buttocks. Ms. Brewster said members of the committee drafting Ledyard's 15-page ordinance joke that it will be difficult to find someone who won't be embarrassed reading it into the record.
"There are still a lot of gray areas in terms of what the courts view as constitutional and unconstitutional, but I think this is a good ordinance," Ms. Brewster said.
Not everyone is happy, she acknowledged. One zoning commissioner complained that the ordinance might ban nude dancing for bachelor parties at a local bar, and several people have expressed concerns about how it might affect a couple of existing video stores where videos that might be called triple-X-rated, are stocked in a back room.
But Ms. Brewster said most support the ordinance. "This is not the type of business we want to attract," Ms. Brewster said. "In the long run, how is that kind of business going to improve our quality of life?"

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
Just an Old-Fashioned Town, Filled With Music, Art and Fish This Weekend

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. SMITH 

 BODY:
Fish and people are pouring into Lambertville and its Pennsylvania neighbor New Hope this weekend for the 15th annual Shad Fest, a popular showcase not only for art and music, but also for the town of Lambertville itself.
In its heyday, the town, a ferry crossing that became a manufacturing and transportation hub in the 19th century, saw the construction of picturesque churches, stately commercial buildings, and elegant Second Empire and Victorian houses. As economic development moved south, recessions and Lambertville's physical isolation in the Delaware Valley had the beneficial effect of causing the village to enter the mid-20th century largely undeveloped and unchanged. 
 A new generation of young professionals now calls Lambertville home, but a sense of community remains. Images of the area from the 1850's to the 1920's fill a new book of photographs, "Lambertville and New Hope" (Arcadia Publishing), by three members of the Lambertville Historical Society, James Mastrich, Yvonne Warren and George Kline.
Subjects of the photographs include Billy McCartney, the World War I-era New Hope postman who crossed the bridge every working day to pick up mail at the Lambertville railroad station ("You could set your watch by him," Mr. Mastrich said); Boy Willie Smith, a fisherman, mending curtainlike shad nets called seines, which have been used since the days of the Lenni Lenape Indians; a very quaint A&P store offering modern prepackaged convenience; the garage of George C. Green, a legendary mechanical genius who could diagnose machines' malfunctions without even taking them apart; a bell destined for the St. Andrew's Episcopal Church being removed from a temporary location, and the Lambertville House, the town's premiere hotel, whose long-awaited renovation is under way.
When word of the project spread, area residents came forward with useful information, suggestions and pictures. Dr. Mastrich, a psychologist practicing in Kingston, said he treasured this sense of community as well as Lambertville's ambiance, so charming as to seem hardly real.
"When I was a kid, I had a wonderful train set with a downtown, a little church, little buildings," said Dr. Mastrich, who grew up in Stamford, Conn. "And now I live in it."

Green, a legendary mechanic; right, the scene at an early A&P market.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Big Refinancing at a Middle-Income Co-op

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
"WE came looking for a better way of life," said Philip Leblang, explaining what brought him and his family to the Amalgamated Warbasse Houses middle-income co-op in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn 32 years ago, when it was newly built. He and his wife, Hilda, are still in the two-bedroom apartment on the third floor that they bought then for $2,600.
He is 77 now, and their two sons have grown up and moved out. For Warbasse, which has 2,585 apartments in five 23-story buildings and plenty of outdoor parking, he has nothing but praise. But if pressed, he will admit that age has caught up with the elevators. 
 "They cut out, they stall, they're always being fixed," he said. "If the odd one is out, we're in trouble, and it's often out, believe me." If the odd one is out, he must walk up or down a flight to catch the elevator that stops on the even floors.
The elevator problem and some of the other infirmities of advanced building age are on the threshold of treatment and cure at Warbasse, however.
After obtaining a Federal mortgage-insurance commitment, the development closed in March on a new $33.36 million 35-year first mortgage at a fixed 8 1/8 percent interest rate from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Pension Trust.
With $14.2 million of the loan, the co-op paid off the balance remaining on the state moral-obligation bonds that financed the project. About $11 million has gone into a reserve fund for future building needs, including a complete window replacement.
But millions more are already committed to a roof replacement program ($1.7 million) and an upgrading of the elevator system ($4.5 million). The elevator work will be done over the next two years by the Republic Elevator Company, of Long Island City, Queens. When it is complete, two elevators will serve every floor.
What is unusual in all this is that a middle-income co-op, whose residents have only a modest equity stake in their housing, has decided to buy out two state-backed bonds running to 2006 -- one carrying a 3.6 percent interest rate and the other a 3.8 percent rate -- and accept significantly higher long-term monthly carrying costs in order to make a substantial rehabilitation program possible.
Moreover, Warbasse has done it without opting out of the middle-income housing program itself, which developments may do after they have been in it for 20 years. Staying within the program means that vacancies will continue to be sold at prices well below their true market value.
With the new financing, the shareholders' monthly maintenance costs have gone up by 8.7 percent, or 3 percentage points more than was required for normal increases in operating expenses.
T HE owners now pay $123.21 a room per month, or $579 for a typical two-bedroom apartment without a terrace on a middle floor, including utilities.
Current purchase prices for vacant apartments range from $8,595 for a small one-bedroom to $20,055 for a three-bedroom penthouse unit with seven rooms. The typical midlevel two-bedroom with no terrace would sell for $12,892.
So far this year, vacancies have occurred in 10 two-bedroom apartments. Eight of them have gone to families already living at Warbasse who needed larger units. The two others went to outsiders who had been on the waiting list for four years.
The New York State middle-income, or Mitchell-Lama, housing program was established in 1955 under a law sponsored by Assemblyman Alfred Lama of Brooklyn and Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan. Over 400 developments with more than 150,000 housing units, both rentals and co-ops, were built under the program, using long-term state bonds and getting the benefit of low property taxes. New arrivals may earn no more than seven times the annual rent or maintenance charge in smaller apartments, and as much as eight times in larger apartments.
Under this eligibility rule a family of four earning as much as $65,420 would be eligible for a two-bedroom apartment at Warbasse. Thousands of families apply to get on the waiting list when, periodically, the development advertises for applicants, but only 400 names are drawn. Then it takes a few years till the list is used up. Warbasse plans to establish a new waiting list for one-bedroom apartments next year.
According to Michael J. Martino, senior vice president for housing in the New York State Housing Finance Agency, the ownerships of 17 developments with 11,000 apartments that were built under the agency's auspices have chosen to prepay their mortgages, leave the program and thereby charge market rents for vacancies. Almost all have been rentals, normally owned by the investor-builders who chose to participate in the development program.
"Warbasse wanted to maintain its middle-income status while enhancing its physical environment," Mr. Martino said.
The agency, which has originated the financing for 90 developments with 53,000 housing units across the state, with about $1.1 billion in loans outstanding, is hoping to come forward with a program that will allow this type of refinancing to occur under state auspices.
But with no such program available, Warbasse found itself frustrated for several years until it was led by mortgage bankers -- Bert M. King of King Mortgage Corporation, of Bethesda, Md., and Irwin Shapiro, of New York Urban Servicing Company -- to the Federal Government for an insurance commitment under the Section 223f program.
This multifamily insurance program was used in the 70's to assist newly built middle-income developments that encountered fiscal difficulties.
In recent years it has been used by private rental owners to refinance their mortgages, with about 20 projects coming through the New York office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development since 1992. But it had not previously been used to provide financing for major capital improvement programs at successful older Mitchell-Lama co-ops.
"Warbasse had about $2 million in its reserve funds," said Theodore B. Liban, a lawyer for Warbasse. "That was clearly not enough to make repairs that were urgent."
Managers of other major Mitchell-Lama developments are taking notice.
"Any development that needs a major capital improvement and hasn't got the money available needs to see if it should refinance its first mortgage so that it can spread out the cost to its residents over time," said Jeffrey C. Gold, vice president of Marvin Gold Management in Brooklyn, which manages 14 Mitchell-Lama developments with 6,360 apartments.
These developments may feel compelled to leave the state program if proper financing mechanisms are not available.
Amalgamated Warbasse Houses, on 29 acres off Neptune Avenue, was sponsored by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.
Its name honors James P. Warbasse, a physician who lived from 1866 to 1957 and founded the Cooperative League of the U.S.A. Near it are other large middle-income developments of the era -- Trump Village, Brightwater Towers and Luna Park.
T HE unionist founders of the co-op movement so successfully achieved their dream of replacing squalid housing with affordable modern housing in the Coney Island and Brighton Beach area that tenancy turnover has been glacially slow. Warbasse is now considered a "Norc" -- a naturally occurring retirement community. About 40 percent of the households have at least one member over 65, and a large number have one member over 75. There are 8,000 residents in all.
Nowadays many younger families are moving in, including a large contingent of Jews from the former Soviet Union.
"The community is getting younger," said Joseph Tarantola. "There are many small children around, and I enjoy seeing that."
But it is Mr. Tarantola who seems to embody the spirit of the place. He is 72, and a retired officer of the jewelry workers' union.
He arrived at Warbasse in 1965 with his wife, Selma, and two children, 9 and 5, from a rental in Crown Heights. The children are gone and the grandchildren are in Maryland, but he and Selma remain in their three-bedroom apartment with a terrace.
Move? "We've thought of that," he said. "But we love the city. We can walk to the beach. We're not anxious to move out."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Below-Market Rental for Village Employees

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
THIS small, affluent village, known for its riverfront mansions and quaint downtown, has agreed to sell a vacant waterfront building to an affordable-housing organization that plans to build 24 rental units on the top two floors and a new library for the village on the first floor.
The first below-market-rate housing ever built in Irvington, it will be targeted to village employees, many of whom are now forced to live outside of the village because of its high cost of housing, according to Steve McCabe, the village administrator. 
 "We'll develop a point system," Mr. McCabe said, "giving priority to village employees, volunteer firefighters, workers with the ambulance corps, teachers and seniors."
After holding several public hearings, the village encountered very little opposition to the proposal, according to Mayor Dennis Flood.
"I think people are always afraid these developments will somehow adversely affect their property values," the Mayor said. "I think we've done a good job in alleviating those concerns. Also the county's planning department has been very helpful in pointing to projects that have worked out very well in other communities."
One of the immediate advantages to this proposal is that it makes use of an 115-year-old white elephant, which has sat vacant at the foot of Main Street for over 10 years. "It will bring an infusion of people downtown, hopefully helping to revitalize the downtown shops," said Mr. McCabe.
Like other Hudson River communities, Irvington at one time had a bustling industrial section on the waterfront. Lord & Burnham Company, which manufactured greenhouses, operated in Irvington from 1870 until 1986. It built several low-rise brick buildings by the water. A smokestack with the company's name on it rising over the buildings still serves as a primary identifying feature of Irvington from the water.
In recent years, some of the old industrial structures, especially those on the west side of the railroad tracks, have been finding a new life as office buildings, offering loft-style spaces with river views and big windows, and attracting graphic-art and other creative companies from Manhattan.
The 30,000-square-foot Burnham Building, which is on the east side of the tracks, was not part of the waterfront renaissance. After being on the market for several years, Lord & Burnham eventually sold it to the village in 1993 for $750,000.
"When we acquired it, we always hoped it would be the site for our new library, but the right proposal never materialized," Mr. McCabe said.
Then the nonprofit Affordable Housing Construction Company, of Katonah, offered to develop it jointly with the Greyston Foundation, another nonprofit developer, in Yonkers. "They liked the idea of the library," Mr. McCabe said. "Other developers were reluctant to give up that space."
O N April 4, at a public hearing, the project's architects -- Stephen Tilly, Architect, of Dobbs Ferry, and Galliher, Baier & Best of Simsbury, Conn., an associate in the library's design -- and presented their plans for the renovation, which includes gutting the interior and creating 24 apartments, including studios and one- and two-bedroom units.
The building is actually comprised of several structures that have been pieced together over the years, according to Stephen Tilly, the lead architect.
"The challenge is to make the interior space seem seamless," he said. One part of the building is an 1880's Queen Anne carriage house with a skylight. "The top of that could be turned into an amazing studio," Mr. Tilly said.
He also plans to create an outdoor terrace at the back of the building, which would be used communally. "It's just an interesting space," Mr. Tilly said. "We could wind up with a multitude of floor plans. The apartments will certainly not look alike." They are expected to rent for between $575 and $875 a month, according to Mr. McCabe.
When Jonathon F. P. Rose, president of Affordable Housing Construction, first saw the building, "I immediately fell in love with it," he said.
"It fit the mission of our company completely," he added.
His firm looks for projects within walking distance to mass transportation, Mr. Rose said.
"It's also important," he went on, "that a project bring people and diversity to a downtown. We would never build a big box outside of town that would sap a downtown."
The library component will occupy 10,000 square feet on the first floor, which is triple the size of the existing library in the Village Hall.
"I think it's the perfect mixed use," Mr. Rose said. "More and more, libraries are becoming meeting places. It will serve to anchor Main Street."
The entire project is expected to cost $5 million, Mr. McCabe said. A local group is raising funds for the library construction. "They hope to raise $900,000," he added. "They're off to a good start."
T HE developers will be looking to state and county grants and Federal tax credits for most of the financing. They have already applied for a $720,000 county loan and a $192,000 Federal loan, and they are seeking a total of $672,731 in state and county grants and will apply for $2 million in Federal tax credits.
"The county has really been pushing for villages to develop affordable housing," Mr. Rose said. "The money is there. It's a matter of finding the right sources."
Four years ago, the county set a target of building 5,000 new units of affordable housing over a period of 10 years. "We now have 800 units that have been completed, are under construction or are ready to go," said Lynn Oliva, the County Planning Commissioner.
She added that the Irvington proposal "seems to be a wonderful mixed-use project" that "makes use of a landmarked building and brings a residential component to the downtown."
"It's got a lot going for it," she said.
The affordable-housing goal for Irvington was 35 units, according to Mr. McCabe, "and we stand a very good chance of exceeding it."
Last month, Jim Dinan, a local resident, gave the village a one-acre parcel off Broadway, with the stipulation that it be used for affordable housing.
The land is the site of the Irvington Presbyterian Church, a 1853 Gothic Revival building, which was practically destroyed by fire in 1972. Only remnants of the stone walls remain. They will be replaced by three town houses to be built by the Future Homes Company of Westchester, based in Valhalla.
"There will be a total of 14 homes with two and three bedrooms," Mr. McCabe said. And they will be for-sale units.
"We're excited that we could be one of the few communities to meet the county's goals for the number of affordable housing units," Mr. McCabe said. "We could set an example to other villages. If little old Irvington could do it, they could, too."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 23-Story Building to Go Up Near United Nations;
$30 Million Office Tower For German Government

 BODY:
Construction is to begin within days on a 23-story office building near the United Nations that will be entirely occupied by the Federal Republic of Germany.
The building, on a 50- by-100 foot site at 871 United Nations Plaza, between 48th and 49th Streets, will allow Germany to consolidate three of its New York offices. 
 The property was bought from the Albanese Development Corporation of Garden City, L.I., which also assisted the German government in designing the building and arranging for the Turner Corporation to serve as general contractor. The architect was Schuman Lichtenstein Clamon & Efron of Manhattan.
The project will cost about $30 million, said Karl-Heinz Schoer, first secretary of the German Mission to the United Nations.
Mr. Schoer said Germany's U.N. Mission at 600 Third Avenue, its Consulate General at 460 Park Avenue, and its Information Center at 950 Third Avenue will be housed in the new building when it is completed in two years.
"It's much more economical to do that," Mr. Schoer said of what he called "a trend here in New York" for foreign governments. The three agencies, he said, "will still be independent, but with one joint management office."
And because foreign governments are tax exempt, Germany will not have to pay real estate taxes, as it now indirectly does as a renter, Mr. Schoer pointed out.
The president of the development company, Vincent M. Albanese, said a Swedish company had been interested in building a hotel on the site several years ago, but ran into financial difficulty.
"We abandoned the idea of a hotel and determined that this site was uniquely suited for a foreign government, because of its proximity to the U.N.," Mr. Albanese said. Originally, the plan had been to sell floors to several foreign governments.
The 100,000-square-foot building, with a two-story high lobby and a slim plaza in front, will have a glass and light-brown granite facade.
The Albanese company also owns a building on 49th Street that abuts the site of the proposed office tower, and the German Government has purchased the first floor of that building for use as a passport and visa office.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Fade Out a Flea Market, Fade In a Multiplex Theater

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
FOR 20 years, a 20-acre tract off Route 1 here was home to the U.S. 1 Flea Market, where some 100 merchants sold their wares at bargain prices in a 175,000-square-foot building that now is vacant and forlorn.
But over the next month the building will be demolished and a 16-screen, 79,000-square-foot Sony movie theater with 4,200 to 4,400 seats, a 70,000-square-foot retail complex and up to three free-standing restaurants will rise on the site and on an adjacent 15 acres. There will also be parking for more than 1,600 cars. 
 Sony Theaters, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment Company, based in Manhattan, will build the theater and lease the ground under it from the Sheldon Elizabeth Company, a Roseland developer that owns the entire site. Sheldon Elizabeth, using its own equity and traditional bank financing, will build the retail and restaurant space.
The theater, which marks the return of a nonpornographic moviehouse to the city after a more than a 20-year absence, is expected to open by November. Construction on the rest of the $20 million project will begin once a sizable portion of the retail space has been preleased, said Barry Yeskel, a partner at the development company. Completion is expected sometime in 1997.
Mr. Yeskel said the decision to move ahead with the project was based on economics. "The concept of an entertainment center and quality retail made sense," he said, adding that it was a "higher and better use" than the flea market for the site.
For Sony the site offered an opportunity to enter an underserved market. Kenneth B. Benjamin, Sony's vice president of real estate, said the site was chosen because of its access to and visibility from a highway and, adding a twist to the old developer mantra, "demographics, demographics, demographics."
He said that more than 400,000 people, with an average household income of $63,000, lived within a seven-mile radius of the site. And that, he said, does not include the student population at Rutgers University, which now numbers around 35,000.
New Brunswick officials welcome the project. Along with providing jobs it will generate less traffic and more tax revenue than the flea market, said Glenn S. Patterson, director of the city's Department of Policy, Planning and Economic Development. "And" he added, "it will also burnish the city's image as an entertainment and cultural hub."
Over the last decade, Livingston Avenue at the southern end of New Brunswick's reviving central business district has been reshaped into something of a cultural center. Three theaters now stand there -- the State Theater, a performance center, and two legitimate theaters, the George Street Playhouse and Crossroads Theater, which houses the state's largest professional acting company. .
A ND just last year the corner of Livingston Avenue at New Street became home to a five-story, 160,000-square-foot structure for Rutgers University's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, the Center for Urban Policy Research and the Mason Gross School of the Arts, where exhibitions are held.
Restaurants and other food outlets have also sprung up -- 35 is the latest count. That count also includes recent arrivals like coffee bars, including Butterfield's Beanery on Albany Street, and a microbrewery, Harvest Moon, that opened last month on George Street.
Mr. Patterson said the Sony theater complex would give people another reason to come to New Brunswick. Though it is outside the downtown "there will be some spinoff," he said.
Claudine I. Gillooly, executive director of the eight-year-old New Brunswick City Market, added that the theater "would bring more people who will see what else the city has to offer, try our stores and spend money." She said some downtown merchants saw the flea market "as unfair weekend-only competition."
City Market is the 16-block downtown special-improvement district, in which property owners tax themselves to finance physical improvements and services, including marketing to inject new life downtown.
The project is moving ahead at a time when the retail climate in New Jersey is soft and, industry analysts say, is expected to remain so at least for the balance of this year. But movie theaters are among the few users still shopping for space, helping to pick up some of the slack left behind by the store closings and bankruptcies of national discount chains, said Jonathan S. Meisel, a broker who deals with the theater industry at the East Rutherford office of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage.
They are being driven today through competition to "provide a higher level of technical sophistication and comfort that simply cannot be done at old theaters," Mr. Meisel added. As a result they are expanding at their current locations or looking for new sites all around the state, which remains popular because of its density, he said.
Mr. Meisel said there were at least a half dozen other movie theater projects under way or planned in northern New Jersey alone.
Mr. Benjamin of Sony said his company planned to add 50 screens in New Jersey this year by expanding existing theaters or building new ones, like the one in New Brunswick.
Others include a 10-screen theater under way in Mountainside and the expansion of an 8-screen theater in Wayne to 14 screens.
But Ted Kraus, who runs a retail consulting firm in Mercerville, said the aggressive posture of some movie operators may lead to overbuilding.
Sony disagrees, at least for the new screens they are adding. "We are aggressive, not foolish," said Mr. Benjamin, noting that in the case of the New Brunswick project the nearest significant competitor was the theater at the Menlo Park Mall, some eight miles to the north. He said the project would also be within a concentrated retail setting, which is preferred because of the interaction that can occur with other retailers.
F ROM a retail perspective the multiplex movie theater is "one of the uses that can be counted on as a destination," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a forecasting firm in Scotch Plains. "But while they tend to bring in more traffic, the people going to the movies may or may not go to the stores and buy."
The key, added Mr. Kraus, the Mercerville consultant, is siting the three uses so all are visible from the highway, providing sufficient parking and having a retail mix that complements the theater.
Mr. Yeskel, of Sheldon Elizabeth, the development company, said the project's retail component would incorporate all those factors. Though the leasing will be "driven by the market," he said the project as now envisioned would have three to four large national tenants like a bookstore or an electronics store "that would be consistent with an entertainment theme."
That concept sits well with Ms. Gillooly of City Market. "But if it winds up having 15 to 20 smaller retailers," she said, "that would hurt the downtown."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Old U.S. 1 Flea Market in New Brunswick will be razed for a 16-screen Sony Theater complex. (Photographs by Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
What Budget Squeeze? There's Money to Borrow

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
The state government is facing lean times, and the Legislature, the Whitman administration and dozens of interest groups are furiously debating what expenses to cut to bring the $16 billion budget into balance. But lawmakers are still feeling generous when it comes to borrowing money to pay for future programs.
So far, nine bond issues have been proposed for the November ballot, for a total of $1.6 billion in new spending -- nearly half as much as the state's entire existing bonded debt. 
 This does not mean that all nine will actually be on the ballot. Each year, lawmakers propose as many as 15 bond issues, of which only a handful (and often none) are approved by the full Legislature and the Governor for submission to the voters. Still, all are awaiting hearings in various legislative committees; approval requires a three-fifths vote in both houses, or a simple majority two years in a row. The deadline for inclusion on this November's ballot is Aug. 27.
Voters have traditionally looked kindly on environmental bond issues, and the largest proposal so far would allow the state to borrow $450 million for the Environmental Cleanup and Containment Bond Act of 1996. The money would be used to match Federal funds to dredge the Kill Van Kull, to build containment areas for dredged material, to upgrade underground storage tanks and to safeguard drinking water supplies.
No one testified against the bond act at a hearing of the Assembly's Environment, Science and Technology Committee last week, while the State Department of Environmental Protection, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and business and labor groups all said the money was needed to keep ships moving in the port.
Here are the other proposals:
HOUSING $290 million to build affordable houses and apartments, to help low-income families make down payments and pay closing costs for home purchases, and to provide loans and grants for small businesses. Two bills are proposed, with one in the Assembly Housing Committee and one in the Senate Urban Policy Committee.
 
PRISONS $275 million to pay for building and renovating state prisons and county jails. As an alternative, voters would be asked for $150 million to build new jail space, with at least $40 million to be used for county adult jails and juvenile detention centers. Both proposals are in the Assembly Law and Public Safety Committee.
 
PINELANDS PROTECTION $70 million, mostly for grants and loans to local governments in the Pine Barrens for sewage treatment and water supply projects. The bill is in the Assembly Environment, Science and Technology Committee.
 
DEMOLITION $35 million, most of it to be used for loans and grants for local governments to demolish unsafe buildings. Two bills are proposed, with one in the Assembly Local Government Committee and one in the Senate Urban Policy Committee.
 
SCHOOLS $250 million for construction and renovation of schools, with $60 million to be set aside for grants to build kindergarten and pre-kindergarten classrooms in poorer districts. The bill is in the Assembly Education Committee.
 
LIBRARIES $50 million to build and renovate libraries, with grants of up to 20 percent of any one project's costs. The bill is in the Assembly Education Committee.
 
MENTAL HOSPITALS Trying to stave off the Whitman administration's plan to close Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital, supporters have proposed this $50 million bond issue to improve the hospital or build a new one on its grounds. The bill is in the Assembly Health Committee, but even its supporters concede that its prospects are dim.

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
The Price of Pinstripes

 BODY:
George Steinbrenner is unhappy in the Bronx. What should New Jersey offer him -- if anything -- to move the Yankees here?
 
Low Bid
Nothing.
 
WALTER KENT
Glen Rock
 
Raising the Stakes
I am a lifetime Yankee fan who has often taken his family to the stadium in the Bronx. We have never had a problem. All the talk about a new stadium is only about money. That is why if Steinbrenner ever comes to New Jersey, the only money we taxpayers should offer him is the toll for the George Washington Bridge. He can carpool by taking with him any New Jersey politician who would dare spend any of our money to feed his greed.
 
GREGORY ADAMO
Metuchen
 
If I Were Steinbrenner
Simple facts of economics: 1. The Yankees work as hard as any other major-league team. 2. They are the No. 2 draw on the road, yet they are a lowly 12th in attendance at home. If I were Steinbrenner, I'd be mad too! The Yankees are not getting fair market value for their efforts, and it is not any of their own fault. The area, parking, etc., are a hindrance.
 
MAX CARRATURA
Westwood
 
Naming a Price
To attract the Yankees to New Jersey and not cost the taxpayers a dime, why not continue the practice of selling names?
Rest stops are renamed as political favors. Continental Airlines paid tens of millions of dollars to place its name on an arena. Take the logical next step.
Since attracting the Yankees would take a little more, let's start the bidding at naming a roadway. Make the Garden State Parkway "Steinbrenner's Way." If that doesn't work, offer a city. Will anyone really miss Ho-Ho-Kus with the Yankees in the state?
As a last resort, offer to change the name of the state. The only question would be whether to call ex-New Jerseyans Steinbrennerians or Steinbrennerites.
 
JOHN BURY
Kenilworth
 
Who Deserves What?
Being an old-time Brooklyn Dodger fan, I don't worry much about the Yankees, but even they don't deserve George Steinbrenner. I think we ought to let him stay in New York. Why do we want any more pathological personalities in New Jersey?
 
MICHAEL P. SHEEHAN
Monmouth Beach
 
A Voice From New York
The Yankees are New York's team the same way Dallas is "America's Team." They can't and shouldn't be allowed to move!
 
SANDER ABRAMSON 3d
Corfu, N.Y.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Trolley Urged for a Limping Old Freight Line

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: FLORENCE TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
Once, the railroad connected the blue-collar towns along the Delaware River from Camden to Trenton. As many as 50 passenger trains a day shuttled students, commuters and shoppers. Freight cars hauled raw materials to dozens of factories, including the Roebling Steel plant here, which built the cables for the Brooklyn and Golden Gate bridges.
But by the 1950's, highways and suburban shopping malls had pulled people off the trains and into their cars. In 1963, passenger service ended, and as factories moved to the outer-ring suburbs or closed (Roebling in 1974), freight service decreased to only a few times a day. 
 Now, there is talk of reviving passenger rail service for the 30-mile trip between Camden and Trenton.
For supporters, the idea is more than nostalgia. The service could be part of a proposed South Jersey rail network extending from Glassboro to Trenton, with connections to Philadelphia, New York City and beyond. But perhaps just as important, the service could give the riverfront area a much-needed second wind.
"We are in an area that is somewhat depressed economically; we have a lot of empty buildings that used to be for manufacturing; we have a lot of people who are either unemployed or underemployed," said Assemblywoman Diane Allen, Republican of Edgewater Park. "This would be an economic shot in the arm. This area would come alive again in ways it hasn't seen in a long, long time."
And Herman T. Costello, Mayor of Burlington City, said: "This train thing could be very helpful. Industries might come here now if they know that people can commute 20 miles via rail."
A week ago, New Jersey Transit hired consultants to study whether light-rail trains, or modern trolleys, are feasible on such a line; the results should be announced within three months. The project is certain to be expensive, since other light-rail lines have cost up to $40 million a mile -- which works out to $1 billion for the link from Camden to Trenton. Then there is the likely opposition from people who live near the tracks.
But the project does have advantages. Freight service still runs on the tracks, so little property, if any, would need to be acquired. And the tracks, now owned by Conrail, are for sale, so the timing could be just right for state officials to jump in.
"Technically, it's not a complex project; it's simple," said Frank M. Russo, senior director of new rail construction for New Jersey Transit. "It's just a matter of, is the ridership there? Are the economic development requirements there? Do we have the money that we want to commit to it?"
The project would be quite a comeback for a storied line. Built in early 1830's, the Camden-to-Trenton route (officially the Bordentown Secondary) was part of the Camden & Amboy railroad, one of the nation's first passenger lines. With three tracks available, affluent Philadelphia families took day trips to picnic along the New Jersey side of the Delaware; adventurous Burlington County couples went the other way for an excursion to the big city.
But when rail was eclipsed by the automobile, the route lost its relevance. (It may have been a sign of things to come that Thornton Wilder's 1931 play "The Happy Journey to Trenton and Camden" centered around the automobile, not the train.)
Even now, the railroad is an afterthought. Freight cars chug on a single remaining track past shuttered storefronts, inert downtowns and empty, rusted factories that once made pipes and steel. And while freight service is still profitable, it isn't as profitable as other lines, and Conrail would like to sell the tracks, as well as several other South Jersey lines, by early next year, said Bob Libkind, a Conrail spokesman.
Neighbors of the line say that would not be a bad thing, citing worries about noise from increased freight service. A recent proposal to build a light-rail system from Camden to Mount Holly was shelved indefinitely because of residents' fears about safety, noise and crime.
Still, many are crossing their fingers that something will be done soon along the riverfront.
"We've got to get people back in the mind-set of using the train to get to work," said Carol Ann Thomas, principal transportation planner in Burlington County's office of the engineer. "The potential here is pretty amazing. Whether or not its time has come yet, we will see."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carol Ann Thomas, a Burlington planner, says trolleys have "amazing" potential. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)
 
Map of New Jersey and Pennsylania shows the freight rail line from Trenton to Camden that may be restored for trolley service.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
State Knows a Thing or Two About the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By Brett Pulley; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
For $5.50 an hour, Sal Risalvato will put a willing and able person to work -- pumping gasoline, cleaning windshields and mopping the restroom floors at his service station in Riverdale, Morris County.
For such dirty work, the pay may not sound like much, but it is 45 cents above the current minimum wage in New Jersey. And that margin, according to Mr. Risalvato, is what enables him to compete for entry-level job seekers. So when he recently heard that the Federal Government was considering increasing the nationwide minimum to $5.15, from its current level of $4.25, he started to worry about what it might mean for his business and the 11 workers he employs. 
 "If they raise it, it will raise the threshold on what I pay," said Mr. Risalvato, who has owned the gas station for eight years. "The government shouldn't be mandating this. The marketplace is really what should prevail."
If Mr. Risalvato's words sound familiar, they should. It's been four years now since New Jersey raised its own minimum wage by 80 cents above the federal level to $5.05. Passed in 1991 by the State Legislature, then controlled by Democrats, the increase went into effect a year later. At that time, business lobbyists appealed to state legislators, warning that an increase would lead to layoffs and also make New Jersey businesses less competitive than their counterparts in other states.
But since then, there seems to be little evidence that business has gone to other states or that the higher minimum wage has led to job loss. According to state labor statistics, 134,000, or about 3.7 percent of New Jersey's total work force, earned the minimum wage in 1993, the latest year figures were compiled. For the most part, businesses that employ minimum wage workers have absorbed the higher costs in wages, and passed them on to the consumer through higher prices -- as they do with all other increased costs.
Alan Krueger, co-author of a 1995 book called "Myth and Measurement: The New Economics of the Minimum Wage," said his own study of the impact of New Jersey's increase found that it did not result in layoffs, nor did it cause customers to react to higher prices by going to other states with lower price structures.
"Minimum wage jobs provide services like retail sales and fast food," he explained. "These are services the consumer can't go elsewhere to get. You're not going to drive into Pennsylvania just to pay less for a hamburger."
Republican politicians and business owners like Mr. Risalvato usually oppose increases, while Democrats and labor groups approve. But now New Jersey Republicans are apparently betting that their friends in the business community can indeed swallow a modest increase. Addressing a conservative group of independent business owners, Representative Richard A. Zimmer of Hunterdon County, who hopes to succeed Bill Bradley in the Senate, took a big gulp recently and suggested that he might support a minimum wage increase as long as it does not "reach a point were it hurts the people its intended to help."
And two other New Jersey Republicans, Representatives Bill Martini of Clifton and Robert D. Franks of New Providence in Union County, went one step further recently and joined a group of breakaway Republicans who co-sponsored the legislation to raise the minimum wage. "I really thought it was a fairness issue," Mr. Martini said. "We're asking people to get off welfare. So this is one way to make that option more attractive."
Opponents of an increase argue that the only people who really benefit in the long run are politicians looking to collect votes. They contend that the higher wages too often go to wealthy or middle-class kids who are just earning a little fun money. "The whole concern about the minimum wage is a sham issue to cover up our failure to prepare people," said Donald Scarry, principal economist of New Jersey Economics, a policy consulting firm. "They come out of school poorly trained and then we shift the burden to the business community to pay them a decent wage."
Mr. Risalvato says he is bracing himself for a likely increase and the ripple effect that it will have on the wages he pays. "I've got to compete for employees," he said. "What else can I do?"
At least he hasn't started lobbying the Legislature to change the law to allow him to use those automated gasoline pumps that are operated by credit cards -- not yet, anyway.

PUB-DATE: April 28, 1996

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2868 words

HEADLINE: A Million Here, a Million There

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
GOVERNOR WHITMAN has finally had to take the budget ax out of the closet.
Until now, the Governor has been able to keep her campaign promise to reduce income tax rates without making huge cuts in state spending. She relied in part on creative money management -- lowering state contributions to employee pension funds and stretching out debt payments, for example, moves that she insists were fiscally prudent though critics deride them as gimmicks. 
 This year, the Governor has bigger holes to patch. She is planning to take $250 million from the fund that distributes benefits for up to 26 weeks to people who are temporarily disabled. But that's nowhere near enough to cover the $1.2 billion lost in this coming year through the income tax cut alone. And many of the Governor's efforts to make government "smarter and smaller" by turning over state programs to private contractors either have not come to pass or have not yielded huge savings.
So for the fiscal year that starts July 1, with her full 30 percent tax cut in place, Mrs. Whitman is telling New Jersey for the first time that it must make ends meet the old-fashioned way: by deep spending cuts. To balance her $16 billion budget, the Governor has recommended more than half a billion dollars in program cuts. Almost 1,220 state jobs would be eliminated, 814 through layoffs and 406 through attrition.
The Departments of Environmental Protection and Human Services face the biggest cuts. But few state agencies and programs are spared, except perhaps for the Department of Law and Public Safety, where money was added to help enforce "Megan's Law" and pay for new juvenile justice programs.
Many of the proposed cuts can certainly be defended in tough fiscal times. Since there is no longer a shortage of nurses, Mrs. Whitman is seeking to eliminate the state's $534,000 nursing scholarship program, along with $316,000 in subsidies to nursing schools. The administration is also seeking private backers for the Garden State Games, to replace $150,000 in tax money for the statewide amateur athletic competitions.
But other cuts could cost money in the long run. The Governor has proposed eliminating money for a 44-year-old program that rewards state employees for money-saving suggestions. Right now, it costs $100,000 a year to run the program out of the State Department of Personnel, which pays for one staff member and bonuses ranging from $25 to $10,000. Last year, the program generated 79 ideas; carrying out just 16 of them saved the taxpayers $15.8 million.
While the Governor's agenda has dominated the debate since she introduced her budget proposal in January, others get a chance to put in their two cents' worth, so to speak. The Legislature began hearings late last month, scheduling session after session to hear the concerns of the public, lobbyists, and Cabinet officials.
Mrs. Whitman has told legislators that they can restore whatever cuts they want, as long as the budget balances in the end.
BUT assuming -- just assuming -- the Governor got everything she wanted, here's a look at how the budget would affect you:
* If you're 65 or over, a $26 million cut in the state's prescription subsidy plan could mean higher copayments and possibly the removal of 30,000 participants who have assets totaling $50,000, excluding their residence and automobiles.
* If you're a student enrolled in the state's colleges or universities, you are likely to face a tuition increase. Although Mrs. Whitman recommends keeping state contributions flat at $773 million for colleges and universities, she is proposing that colleges pay for salary increases negotiated this year, so some administrators are looking at raising tuition to make up the difference. At the same time, the Governor recommends $23.1 million more in scholarship grants, which will allow the state to increase the number of awards from 52,500 this year to 55,160 next year.
* If you own a business, the Whitman administration wants to cut some of your taxes. The decline in the corporation tax from 9 percent to 7.5 percent would make New Jersey more competitive with neighboring states. New spending was also included for two new programs at the Department of Commerce to create and retain jobs and to provide financing to small businesses in urban areas.
* If you farm, you might be concerned about the $100,000 cut to the Agriculture Department's "Jersey Fresh" promotion budget and a $2.9 million reduction in state grants to help farmers buy equipment and improve marketing or production methods.
* If you qualify for welfare, the administration is seeking to impose a five-year limit on benefits and end most long-term training and educational programs. But to encourage welfare recipients to find work, the Governor would allow them to keep more of their income. The administration is also considering changes in state-subsidized day care that could disqualify working parents who earn more more than $22,000 a year.
* f you're among the 13 million people who visited one of the state's 28 parks, 57 historical sites or 42 natural areas last year, you may want to call ahead before your next trip. A proposed $800,000 budget cut is expected to reduce hours throughout the park system and close many historical sites all but two or three days a week.
* If you're a commuter, you might find fewer potholes now that Mrs. Whitman has agreed to distribute $25 million to fix roads damaged by the harsh winter. The number of miles maintained on state highways will increase by 38 from 10,609 to 10,647, but the number of county bridge inspections will decline from 1,550 to 850. The number of buses operated by New Jersey Transit is expected to remain the same, while the number of railroad passenger cars will increase from 692 to 787.
* If you're worried about the environment, you may not be reassured by the administration's contention that the elimination of 305 jobs and a budget cut of $17.6 million will not affect its ability to monitor the environment. This includes a $3 million cut in the budget of the commission that is overseeing the cleanup of 6,000 known hazardous waste sites in the state.
* If you're a state employee, chances are you will be paying more for health benefits. Unionized employees will see their wages frozen next year as part of a new contract negotiated by the administration (they will get a $250 bonus in the next few weeks). All this assumes, of course, that you are not one of the 814 people whose jobs will be eliminated. If you are, you'll find that the state is no longer offering placement services for laid-off workers.
* If you're a parent with a child in public school, the school may get a new computer because of a $10 million technology grant tobe distributed statewide. But the school subsidy program at the Liberty Science Center has been eliminated, and a $3.2 million cut is proposed for the Goodstarts program designed to improve the school performance of low-income children from pre-kindergarten to the early primary years.
Almost half of the state's more than 600 school districts would see declines in overall aid, forcing 293 districts to propose tax increases or program cuts.
* If you're a mayor, you probably have dreams (nightmares?) about property taxes. Mrs. Whitman has proposed that municipal aid remain flat this year, but she did not make up the difference to cover a drop in the gross receipts tax that will cost municipalities $40 million this year. There are also several proposed cuts in state agencies that would affect property taxes. For example, the administration is seeking a cut of $2.8 million that would end toxicology testing and forensic services, forcing some county medical examiner offices to pick up the tab.
However, the administration says counties could be passing on some savings to taxpayers because the state has assumed much of the cost of running the court system. Mrs. Whitman also points out that municipalities have some new cost-control tools, like binding arbitration, that give them more leverage when negotiating police and firefighter contracts.
"We have not seen an increase in property taxes because of a decrease in the income tax," said Harriet E. Derman, the Commissioner for Community Affairs, who is about to become the Governor's chief counsel. "The numbers just don't support that. The increase last year was 4 percent, which is the second-lowest increase in 20 years. So far, all indications are good that the municipalities are coming in fairly low again this year. The mayors and council members are doing a good job."
But Democrats contend that the full impact of the tax cut will ultimately force such big cuts in the state budget that property taxpayers will be forced to make up the difference.
State Senator James E. McGreevey, a Democrat who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge in Middlesex County, said state aid for his township would decline by 6 percent under the Governor's proposed budget, from $30.2 million last year to a proposed $28.4 million this year.
"Mayors are last on the food chain, and this year the Whitman administration has put us even farther down the line than usual," Mr. McGreevey said. "The Governor's aid reductions to local government will again result in a cost shift to municipalities property tax burdens."
Lawmakers have already made noises that some proposed cuts would be restored before a final budget is approved before the new fiscal year begins on July 1.
Within hours after learning of the proposed restrictions in the the prescription program for the elderly, legislators hinted that they would never go along with the idea. The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Robert E. Littell, a Republican from Sussex, told parents and students at the A. Harry Moore School, a school for the handicapped in Jersey City, not to worry about a $750,000 cut proposed in Mrs. Whitman's budget. Legislative leaders have also said that $265,000 cut the state Agricultural Museum is likely to be restored.
"I can tell you that every dollar in the budget has a constituency and we always make changes," Mr. Littell said. "It is not easy. There will be some cuts that will be restored. But we will more than likely have to make some cuts in other areas in order to make up what we want to add back."
THE Legislature relies heavily on the Office of Legislative Services, a nonpartisan research staff, to offer analysis. The office issues budget reports on each state agency, along with revenue estimates. This year, the Office of Legislative Services has said Mrs. Whitman may be relying on overly optimistic revenue projections that could lead to a $249 budget gap for the new fiscal year.
But State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer, who had already revised the state's revenue collections downward in January for this fiscal year, described the state's revenue targets as "prudent, responsible and achievable."
Mrs. Whitman's fellow Republicans, in control of both the Assembly and the Senate, didn't raise too many questions about the difference. They have also been relatively easy on members of the Whitman Cabinet who began appearing this month before budget committees to explain budget cuts.
And even the Democrats, who pounced on the discrepancy in the revenue estimates at the budget hearing, have not had much success poking holes in the administration plan, even with the help of advocates worried about the fate of the programs closest to their hearts.
State Senator Bernard F. Kenny, Democrat of Hoboken, whose questions have been among the most pointed, says Mrs. Whitman, for the first time since taking office, is being forced to defend her policies rather than talk about tax cuts alone.
"The political gain from the tax cuts has been exhausted," Mr. Kenny said. "The pain is starting to be reflected in this budget. The Governor is cutting government, which is something I don't think that she was anxious to do. I think that she was trying to say that you can have it both ways. but you can't significantly cut a broad-based tax the way that she did and not expect that there are not going to be consequences on the social side, the governmental side and on the policy side.."
Outside Trenton, the budget debate is being closely watched by the major bond rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, whose analyses determine how much interest New Jersey pays when it goes to Wall Street to borrow money, mostly for capital projects.
Although Mr. Clymer, the State Treasurer, has built a healthy surplus into the budget, outside analysts have raised concerns about several potential problems that could knock the budget out of balance.
There is the state's charity care program, which distributed $400 million to hospitals last year. The state's authority to continue diverting money from the state unemployment fund to pay for charity care expired on Dec. 31, and the Whitman administration and the Legislature have not yet come up with a new financing plan.
Then there's the New Jersey Supreme Court decision requiring the state to come up with $450 million to close the gap between the wealthiest and poorest school districts. The state contends that it has already made a "good faith" payment of $186 million, but lawyers for the poorer districts say that is not enough. Mrs. Whitman has tried to shift the debate away from giving more money to the poorer districts to coming up with new statewide curriculum standards that have not yet been adopted and that have not yet had a price tag placed on them.
Another problem was the the seven-month impasse between Congress and President Clinton on a new Federal budget. Late last week, the Whitman administration was just beginning to sort out how much aid it would be getting from Washington.
Whatever happens to the New Jersey budget, it will almost certainly be not be seven months late. In fact, seven months from now Mrs. Whitman will be preparing to present a budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, 1997.
 
Potholes and Detours on the Road to a Budget
Figuring out a budget is hard. Just ask President Clinton and Congress. Or ask the New York legislature, which has failed to pass a budget on time for the last 12 years.
New Jersey tends to make its deadline -- which is the start of the new fiscal year on July 1. But it's rarely easy. Here's are examples of some of the obstacles on the road to approval of the $15.98 billion spending plan that Mrs. Whitman outlined in January.:
NO. 1
Both major bond rating agencies, St'ndard and Poor's and Moody's Investment Service, raise several questions about the Whitman plan, including a proposal to help balance the budget by using $250 million in surplus money from a fund that aids temporarily disabled workers.
NO. 2
The Senate President persuades the Governor to restore the property tax deduction on state income tax forms. This will cost the state $176 million that is not included in the Governor's budget.
NO. 3
Older voters start letting legislators know they are upset about the Governor's proposal to cut a prescription plan for the elderly. If legislators listen, this could punch a $26 million hole in the budget.
 NO. 4
The Governor releases her 400-page budget book, providing enough nitty-gritty details to send an army of advocates marching toward Trenton. There's no money for group homes for the developmentally disabled. A state lab that tested water in Toms River must be closed. Hours will be sharply cut at Grover Cleveland's birthplace in West Caldwell. And what happened to the money for the Monmouth Boys and Girls Club?
NO. 5
State and federal data show a loss of 26,500 jobs in January. Is this a sign of an long-term economic downtown that will hurt tax receipts? Or is just a blip, something else to blame on the bad winter weather?
NO. 6
Who is going to pay for 'ospital care for the uninsured? There's no money in the budget. Business and labor balk at continuing to divert money -- $1.6 billion last year -- from an unemployment insurance fund. The hospitals are getting ready to sue. Whatever happened to that idea to increase the cigarette tax? Did somebody mention Jim Florio's name?
NO. 7
A newspaper article says budget cuts mean that 200 blind children won't be able to go to camp this summer. A Republic senator who prides himself on cutting state spending vows to help restore the money.
NO. 8
Congress and President Clinton are still arguing about the federal budget. Last year New Jersey got $4.5 billion; some Washington watchers say tha state will be lucky to get $3.5 billion this year.
NO. 9
The Supreme Court says the state has to find the money to insure parity among poor and wealthy school districts. The Whitman administration insists it's just a matter of moving money around. Nobody else in Trenton seems to want to talk about it.
In June, the real wrangling, and late-night negotiating sessions begin. Some of the programs will survive the chopping block, others will not.
The bottom line is that the state must have a new -- and balanced -- budget when the next fiscal year begins July 1.
